editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The EpiÅ¿tle Dedicatory. TO THE ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors & PractiÅ¿ers OF THE COMMON LAW OF ENGLAND.
div.p:
THis Tract in French was bequeathed to me by an alliance, William GliÅ¿Å¿on EÅ¿quire deceaÅ¿ed, which I have tranÅ¿lated into our own Language for the Common benefit of all. I am not Å¿ingular in it, for daily experience manifests the contrary: neither is it a Novelty for Law-books to appear in this dreÅ¿s. Antiquity may be pleaded, Sr.
Germin Perkins, Stanford, Crompton, Lambert, Sir Henry Finch, Dalton, and divers others have in former days troden this path. My deÅ¿ires are that it may not be peruÅ¿ed by thoÅ¿e who read only to fault, what they cannot mend, but by thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e judicious Pen will correct the errors as Cognizances of humane frailty. I wiÅ¿h it Å¿ucceÅ¿sful to all, be he Pleader or PractiÅ¿er; and that the Common Law of England may Å¿hine forth in theÅ¿e Cloudy, and EclipÅ¿ed days, is the Prayer of him who is

closer.signed: A Well-wiÅ¿her to the Laws HEN. APPLEGARTH.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: THeÅ¿e enÅ¿uing Lines were not fixed to this TreatiÅ¿e to commend its worth unto thee; for, if I can judge rightly, it needs them not, as I doubt not but thou wilt confeÅ¿s upon the peruÅ¿al of it. And this made me Å¿ome years paÅ¿t take Å¿ome pains in correcting many Errataes of the PreÅ¿s, and explaining many obÅ¿curities I met with; and in Å¿hewing the reaÅ¿on of the Law in many places, without any other aim than my own private Å¿atisfaction. But Å¿ince that underÅ¿tanding an intent of Re-printing of the Copy, I thought it not amiÅ¿s to impart what I had done to the Undertakers thereof; not only for their benefit, but for the Readers clearer information, and eaÅ¿ier underÅ¿tanding of the greater variety of the matters therein contained, and in the former Edition very briefly, and in many places obÅ¿curely Å¿et forth. If my pains herein may prove profitable to any, I Å¿hall think it well beÅ¿towed; however I Å¿hall reÅ¿t Å¿atisfied with this perÅ¿waÅ¿ion, That neither the Printers nor Readers can be prejudiced by theÅ¿e my well intended endeavours.

div.head: Account againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage.
In what Court Account lieth againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage.
div.p: IT lies in the County Court or Common Bank. Nat. br. 117. b.
It lies not before the Sheriff, 43 Edw. 3. fol. 21. pl. 11. Thorpe: For Brook, Account 14. Å¿aith, the Sheriff cannot aÅ¿Å¿ign Auditors, and therefore it is in vain to bring the Action before him.
A good plea to Å¿ay the Land is ancient demeÅ¿n, becauÅ¿e the reality may come in queÅ¿tion, Coke 5. part, fol. 105. A. Aldens caÅ¿e.
It lies not in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey: Coke 10. part, 74. b. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have a Writ againÅ¿t Guardian in Soccage.
div.p: The Heir in ward Å¿hall maintain an Action againÅ¿t him after the age of 14 years, or at his full age at his election. Littleton S. 123.

But Nat. br. 118. b. he Å¿hall not have it till the age of 21 years. Crook fol. 131. pl. 106. by reaÅ¿on of the words of the Statute of Marlebridge, cap. 17. Å¿cil. (cum ad aetatem pervenerit) 3 & 4 Mariae, Dyer 137. pl. 25. New tenures 3. b. 18 Edw. 3.55. pl. 76. 29 Edw. 3. fol. 5. pl. 13. Vide RegiÅ¿t. origin. 136. Lib. Intra. 21. D. 8 R. 2. Gard. 166. 10 Rich. 2. Account 132. Doct. Stud. fol. 14. b. Old Nat. br. 91. A.
If the Heir in Å¿uch caÅ¿e die before his full age, his Executor Å¿hall maintain an Action of Account, Crook 131. pl. 106. becauÅ¿e it concerns a Chattel.

Yet note, the Heir in Gavel-kind at 15 years brought an Account againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage, and Å¿hews, by the CuÅ¿tome he may alien at Å¿uch age; and for this cauÅ¿e he was awarded to Account, per Welby. 29 Edw. 3. fol. 5. pl. 13. For if he may do the greater, he may do the leÅ¿s; to fell is more than to take an Account.

The Executor of an Heir Å¿hall have an Account,
per WeÅ¿t. 2. cap. 23. Littleton 27. A. Crook 131. pl. 106.
Executor of an Executor Å¿hall have an Account by 25 Edw. 3. cap. 23. Com. 290.
Filius & Haeres Domini defuncti non habebit breve de computo, quia pertinet ad executionem adminiÅ¿trationis bonorum defuncti. RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 135. b
A RecuÅ¿ant Å¿hall not have an action for any thing that is Å¿eized into the hands of the King, 3 Jac. cap. 5. for the King is accountablle to no body.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t what perÅ¿on an Account lieth as Guardian in Soccage.
div.p: Account lieth againÅ¿t any that taketh the profits before the Ward be of the age of 14 years, Littleton Nat. br. 118. D. 4. Hen. 7.6. 10 Hen. 6.7. 13 Edw. 3. Account 77. 29 Ed. 3.5. pl. 13.

But if one occupy, and after Guardian in Soccage recover in right of the Ward, the party Å¿hall not render an Account to the Heir, for the Guardian ought to account for this, 27 Edw. 3.79. Gard. 22. and therefore the Account Å¿hall be made to the Guardian.
The reaÅ¿on is (as it Å¿eems) that the Writ doth not make mention of the blood. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 136. b. neither the Count, Lib. Intra.

Account lieth not againÅ¿t an Executor of a Guardian, Littleton. Nam non jacet verÅ¿us Executores, quia merÃ¨ pertinet ad Curam ChriÅ¿tianam, cognoÅ¿cere de computo reddendo verÅ¿us Executores. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 23. pl. 145.
But if Executors account, an Action of Debt lieth for the Arrearages, 2 Hen. 4.13. pl. 2.
And if the TeÅ¿tator covenants to account to the Heir and doth not, Covenant lieth againÅ¿t his Executor, RegiÅ¿t. origin. 165. b. Nat. br. 145. H.

div.head: The Account againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage.
div.p: The Heir counts, that it was ordained by the Common Council of the Land, that the Guardian in Soccage Å¿hould Account, &c. and Å¿hews the tenure Å¿pecially, and that the Defendant had the cuÅ¿tody of the Lands, &c. from Å¿uch a day for 12 years enÅ¿uing, and hath not accounted for the iÅ¿Å¿ues and profits, &c. and that at Å¿uch a day the Heir was at full age. Lib. Intra. 21. b. Sect. 1, 2.29 Ed. 3.4. pl. 13. No. Lib. Intra. 47 E. Sect. 3.

div.head: The Writ againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage.
div.p: Rex, &c. Å¿i A. fecerit, &c. tunc Å¿ummon. &c. B. quod Å¿it coram JuÅ¿tic. noÅ¿tris, &c. oÅ¿tenÅ¿um quare cum de Comm. Concilio Regni noÅ¿tri proviÅ¿um Å¿it, quod cuÅ¿todes terrarum & tenementorum quae tenentur in Soccagio haeredibus terrarum & tenementorum. cum ad aetatem pervenerint, reddant rationabilem computum Å¿uum de exitibus, terris, & tenementis illis provenient: de tempore quo cuÅ¿todes illi habuerunt, ratione minoris aetatis haeredis praedictae, idem B. praefato A. rationabilem computum Å¿uum de exitibus provenient. de terris & tenementis Å¿uis in N. quae tenentur in Soccagio, & quorum cuÅ¿todiam idem B. habuit, dum praedictus A. infra aetatem fuit, reddere contradicit, ut dicitur. Et ideo, &c. This Writ is founded per le Stat. de Marlebr. cap. 17. Nat. br. 118. A. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 136.

Note, this Writ lies againÅ¿t any one that occupies the Land during the nonage of the Ward, whether it be the parents of the Heir or not, RegiÅ¿t. origin. 136. b. for it makes no mention of the blood, but only of taking the profits.

The Writ was Receptor denariorum: A good plea to the Writ, becauÅ¿e he was Guardian in Soccage, for otherwiÅ¿e he would be twice charged, 18 Edw. 4.3. pl. 17. viz. as a Receiver of his rents or profits of the Lands, and alÅ¿o as a Guardian in Soccage by the Statute.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage: 1. Before appearance. 2. After appearance.
div.p: The ProceÅ¿s at Common Law before appearance was but a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Herberts CaÅ¿e.

But per Marlebridge cap. 23. a Capias was given againÅ¿t a Baily, and per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. exigend. given againÅ¿t a Servant, Baily, Chamberlain, or any other Receiver, Coke 3. part 12. A. Herberts CaÅ¿e.
And in Account againÅ¿t a Guardian there Å¿hall be a Capias, 29 Edw. 3.5. pl. 13.
But no exigend. becauÅ¿e this was given againÅ¿t a Receiver only, 17 Edw. 2. ProceÅ¿s 203. 17 Edw. 3.59. pl. 55. Shard.
2. After appearance.If he comes in by Capias or diÅ¿treÅ¿s, he Å¿hall be committed to the Fleet, 29 Edw. 3.35 pl. 63.

If the Account be adjudged to lie, &c. and he be not preÅ¿ent in Court, a Capias ad computandum Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue forth, 1 Edw. 3.2. pl. 10. 1 Hen. 7.1.
pl. per TownÅ¿hend. Lib. Intra. 18. c. Sect. 1, 2, 3.

In Judgment quod computet: the Plaintiff dies, his Executors Å¿hall have a Scire facias upon the Judgment, and if the Defendant come not in upon the garniÅ¿hment or warning, an exigend. Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue forth, 14 Hen. 4.1.

div.head: The Barr by a Guardian in Soccage: 1. To the Action of Account. 2. Before Auditors in diÅ¿charge.
div.p: That he had the CuÅ¿tody till Å¿uch a day from Å¿uch a day, and accounted till the full age of the Plaintiff without that, that he was Guardian before or after, Lib. Intr. 21. cap. Sect. 2.
It is a good Barr in diÅ¿charge of the Account, that he expended Å¿o much for neceÅ¿Å¿aries for the Plaintiff, ultraque, &c. Littleton.

No Barr to Å¿ay he was not next of Kin, for the occupation is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and not the Kindred, Littleton 29 Edw. 3.5. pl. 13. 22 Edw. 3.11. pl. 8. 4 Hen. 7.6. b. 10 H. 6.7. pl. 21. 13 Edw. 3. Account 77.
That he was never Guardian in Soccage a good Barr, Lib. Intra. 21. b. Sect. 1.

div.head: The Judgment againÅ¿t a Guardian in Soccage, 1. Of Account. 2. To recover the thing.
div.p: 1. To Account.The Judgment is, quod computet, & ideo in miÅ¿ericord i, quia prius non computavit, Coke 11. par. 38. A. Metcalfs CaÅ¿e. Lib. Intr. 19. D. Sect. 1.

The Judgment is, Ideo conÅ¿ideratum eÅ¿t, quod
praedictus W. recuperet verÅ¿us praefatum M. to recover as much as he is found in Arrearages, & dampna occaÅ¿ione implacitationis: Coke 11 part 40. A.

div.head: Execution againÅ¿t Guardian in Soccage: 1. per Common Law, 2. per Statute Law.
div.p: By the Common Law it was but a Levari facias or Fieri facias: Coke 3. part 12. A. Herberts CaÅ¿e.
And this only within the year; for if the year paÅ¿Å¿ed, he was put to his Action of debt.
If the ProceÅ¿s were not continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33.
Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 45. Scire facias is given after the year.
Per WeÅ¿tm. cap. 2.18. Elegit is given, Coke 3. part 12. a.
Per Marlebridge cap. 23. & WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. Capias was given in ProceÅ¿s and by conÅ¿equence, Capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum: Coke 3. part 12. a.

Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. If an Accountant before Auditors be found in Arrearages, he Å¿hall be by them committed to the next Goal in execution; but then they ought to commit him forthwith, Coke 8. part 119 b. Bonhams CaÅ¿e. 27 Hen. 6.8. Com. 17.
But if an Account be before the Plaintiff, he ought not to commit him to priÅ¿on; becauÅ¿e the Statute Å¿aith, before Auditors, 45 Edw. 3.14 pl. 13.

div.head: Ex parte talis.
div.p:
WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. If Auditors are aÅ¿Å¿igned by the party, which will not allow to the Guardian
his reaÅ¿onable allowances, and they charge him with the thing he never received, and him commit to priÅ¿on, he Å¿hall have an Ex parte talis. Nat. br. 129. F. 4. Hen. 6.18. A. pl. 3. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. b.

The Writ is returnable before the TreaÅ¿urer and Barons of the Exchequer at a certain day, and a Scire facias is in the Writ, to warn the Plaintiff and alÅ¿o the Defendant to be there, Nat. br. 129. G, H. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137.

div.head: Account againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of a Court or Hundred. 2. of a Mannor-houÅ¿e, &c.
In what Court it lies againÅ¿t a Baily.
div.p: IN the County Court: RegiÅ¿t. origin. 135. A. Nat. br. 117. b.
In London before the Sheriffs, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A & B.
In the five Ports, RigiÅ¿t. origin. 135. A.
In Communi Banco, Nat. br. 117. b. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. B.
But Ancient demeÅ¿n is a good plea to the juriÅ¿diction, Coke 5. part 105. A. Aldens CaÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the Account is of the iÅ¿Å¿ues and profits of the Mannor, 8 H. 6.34. pl 36. 2 Ed. 4.3. pl. 3.
And the reality by preÅ¿umption may come in debate, Hobart Chief JuÅ¿tice, Hill. 11 Jac. Com. Ban. Rot. 254. Cox & BarneÅ¿ley.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of a Court, 2. of a Mannor.
div.p:
If A. make B. his Baily of his Court or of a
Hundred, he Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him. Nat. br. 118. E.
Æ²nder-Baily. A. having a Bailywick makes B. his Under-Baily, he Å¿hall have Account againÅ¿t B. 3 Edw. 3.54. pl. 24.
A. makes B. his Baily,Dep â¢ ty. which makes G. his Deputy, A. Å¿hall have Account againÅ¿t B. but not againÅ¿t C. becauÅ¿e C. receives this to the uÅ¿e of B. Nat. br. 119. B. 14 Edw. 3. 100. pl. 8.
An Infant purchaÅ¿es Lands, he Å¿hall have an Account, if any take the profits. Nat. br. 117. B.

For the profits that the Guardian in Soccage takes after the Heirs age of 14 years, the Heir Å¿hall have an Account during his nonage againÅ¿t him as his Baily: but for the profits taken before Å¿uch age, he Å¿hall have Account as Guardian in Soccage; but not before his full age. Nat. br. 118. B. becauÅ¿e he cannot be Guardian after the age of 14 years.

Account for the Major and Aldermen of London.
Major and Aldermen of London grant the WardÅ¿hip of an Orphan to A. they Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t A. at the full age of the Orphan. 8 Rich. 2. guard. 166.
A. deviÅ¿es to his Executors that they Å¿hall Å¿ell his Land, and that his daughter Å¿hall have part of the money, Å¿he Å¿hall have an Account at the Common Law. 4 & 5 Mariae Dyer 151. pl. 5.

A Lunatick Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t the Committee,Lunatick. when he comes to his Å¿ound memory; for the Committee is but in the nature of a a Baily. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 26. pl. 164. Coke 4. part 127. b. Beverley's CaÅ¿e.

An Executor Å¿hall have an Account.Executor. Nat. br.
117. C. 3 Edw. 3.66. 7 Edw. 3.269. 5 Edw. 3.141. pl. 7.
But this was by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 23.
And if one hath Judgment againÅ¿t a Baily upon an Account, and dieth, his Executors Å¿hall have a Scire facias, 14 Hen. 4.1. upon the Judgment.
Executor of an Executor Å¿hall not have an Account, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 23. 7 Edw. 3.270. pl. 54.
But this was given per 25 Edw. 3. cap. 5. pl. Com. 290.
Filius & haeres domini dofuncti non habebit Breve de Computo Å¿uper Ballivum, quia pertinet ad executionem adminiÅ¿trationis bonorum defuncti. RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 135. bâª
Husband receives the profits of the Lands of his wife and dies, the wife Å¿hall not have an Account for the profits during the Coverture againÅ¿t the Executors of the husband. Nat. br. 119. A.
Joynt-tenant makes his Companion his Baily, he Å¿hall have Account againÅ¿t him, 21 E. 3.60. pl. 5. Q.
Two Joynt-tenants of a ward; one takes all the profits, the other Å¿hall have an Account. Nat. br. 118. J. 39 Edw. 3.28. pl. 25. 45 Edw. 3.1. Q.
Two Joynt-occupiers of a houÅ¿e and MerchandiÅ¿e, one Å¿hall have Account againÅ¿t the other as Baily of the houÅ¿e and MerchandiÅ¿e. Lib. Intra. 18. Sect. 6.

Terre-tenant Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t Tenant by Elegit, but this is only by Scire facias,
Old Nat. br. 24. 21 Edw. 3.26. pl. 21. & fol. 10. pl. 13. 21 Edw. 3.2. pl. 60. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 20. ConuÅ¿or Å¿hall have it in the Å¿ame manner againÅ¿t the ConuÅ¿ee, Coke 4. part 67. b. 47 Edw. 3.11. pl 9. & 25. pl. 63.

Prior, Abbot, or MaÅ¿ter of an HoÅ¿pital Å¿hall have an Account for the time of their PredeceÅ¿Å¿or, Nat. br. 117. F. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b. 4 Edw. 3.100. pl. 8. 25 Edw. 3.545. pl. 19. 28 Edw. 3.90. 30 Edw. 3.1.
If one make another Baily of his Mannor, &c. he Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him as Baily, Nat. br. 116. D.
Breve fuit quod reddat, &c. M. & Å¿ociis Å¿uis mercatoribus de Å¿ocietate de D. in Flandria rationabilem computum; this is naught, 5 Edw. 3.138. pl. 39. for the generality of it.
The King may make a Bayliff of a Mannor, and Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him, 33 Hen. 6.2. pl. 10. and fol. 29. b. pl. 2.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom an Account lieth as Baily, 1. of a Court or Hundred. 2. of a Mannor &c.
div.p: A.having a Bailywick makes B. his Under-Baily to gather the Amercements, he Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him, 3 Edw. 3.54. pl. 24.
If one enter into my land to my uÅ¿e, 2. Baily in Law. and take the profits, I Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him as Baily in Law, Nat. br. 117. A.
An Infant purchaÅ¿es Lands, his parents occupy this, he Å¿hall have Account againÅ¿t them as Bailies in Law, Nat. br. 117. b.

Non jacet verÅ¿us Executores, quia mere pertinet ad curam ChriÅ¿tianam cognoÅ¿cere de Computo reddendo, verÅ¿us Executores, RegiÅ¿t. origin. 135. b. Nat. br.
â¢â¢ 7. C. Littleton, 48 Edw. 3.2. 4 Edw. 4.25.
But if an Executor will account, though not compellable, debt lieth for the Arrearages due upon the Account, 2 Hen. 4.13. P. 2.
And if a Baily be found in Arrearages before Auditors, his Executors Å¿hall be charged, if they have AÅ¿Å¿ets, 11 Hen. 4.84. & fol. 19. pl. 48.
It lieth not againÅ¿t a Deputy-Baily, Nat. br. 119. B. 4 Edw. 3.100. pl. 8. becauÅ¿e the Head-Baily is chargeable.

It lieth not againÅ¿t an Infant, 118. D. Nat. br. becauÅ¿e he hath not diÅ¿cretion to Account, 21 Edw. 3.8. pl. 21. RegiÅ¿t. origin. 135. A. AlÅ¿o he cannot wage his Law, 26 Edw. 3.63. b. for he cannot take an Oath.
It lies againÅ¿t a Woman, Nat. br. 118. D. 19 Hen. 6 4 pl. 10.
Two Joynt-tenants of wood, one Å¿ells all and takes the money, the other Å¿hall not have an Account againÅ¿t him, Doct. & Stud. 32. b.
It lies not againÅ¿t a Surveyor or Controller, Nat. br. 119. C.

The King Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t any perÅ¿on that takes the profits, though he claim them to his own uÅ¿e per Prerogativam, Coke part 11.90. DevouÅ¿hers CaÅ¿e. 35 Hen. 6.27. b. Nottingh. 8 Eliz Dyer 249. pl. 83.
The King Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t an Executor, Littleton, Coke 11. part 89. B. DevouÅ¿hers CaÅ¿e, per Prerogativum.

div.head: For what things Account lieth againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of a Court, &c. 2. of a Mannor, &c.
div.p: Crook 21 Hen. 7.75. pl. 23. Account againÅ¿t one as Baily Burgi Å¿ui de B: and good.
Account againÅ¿t one as Baily of a Mannor, Nat. br. 116. P.
Account againÅ¿t a Steward of an HouÅ¿e, and of Goods in it, 14 Hen. 4.20. 9 Edw. 3.356. pl. 40.
Account for the delivery of three Tuns of Wine Å¿old, 43 Edw. 3.2. pl. 11. 46 Edw. 3.3.3. pl. 6.13 Rich. 2. Account 50.
For Herrings delivered and Å¿old, 46 Edw. 3.9. pl. 4.
For four Å¿acks of Wool delivered and Å¿old, 9 Edw. 3.359. pl. 38.
Tenant per Elegit accounts for the overplus, Old Nat. br. 34. 21 Edw. 3.26. pl. 21.
A man accounts for the profits de, &c. Nat. br. 118. B.
A Baily of Woods accounts for Herons and Hawks, 14 Edw. 3. Account 131. Moubrey.
Arrearages of Rent upon a LeaÅ¿e for years or at will lies not in Account, for nothing certain lies in an Account, 19 H. 6.20. pl. 67. 20 H. 6.16. pl. 2. as the Rent is; but an Action of Debt.
So of Goods leaÅ¿ed with a HouÅ¿e, although they are waÅ¿ted, 20 H. 6.16. pl. 2.
So for a CuÅ¿tome, that one Å¿hall gather Rents, and take the toll and pety CuÅ¿tomes payable to the Lord 22 l. annuatim, becauÅ¿e he pays a certain Å¿um, 11 Hen. 6.14. pl. 4.

div.head: The Count againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of a Court or Hundred. 2. of a Mannor, &c.
div.p: Counts that from Å¿uch a day to Å¿uch a day he had the adminiÅ¿tration de bladis, foenis, equis, bobus, vaccis, porcis, bidentibus, carucis, ac de omnibus aliis rebus, &c. & de, &c. ad merchandizandum & proficuum faciendum, &c. & ad rationabilem Computum, &c. Lib. Intra. 17. A. Sect. 1. vide more Lib. Intra. 17. a, & b. Å¿ect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. fol. 17. b, &c. Å¿ect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

The Plaintiff ought to Count that the Defendant was Baily of the Mannor-houÅ¿e and Lands, &c. and yet it is not material whether he had the Mannor-houÅ¿e, &c. for the Receipt charges him, 9 Edw. 3.356. pl. 38. Stoner. 27 Edw. 3.29. pl. 25.
He need not count the things particularly, becauÅ¿e it may be Å¿hewed before the Auditors, Crook 1 Hen. 8.153. pl. 2. where he is to charge him particularly.
But the Book of 49 Edw. 3.13. 14 Hen. 4.14. Å¿ays, that it is material. Q. inde.
If Account be brought againÅ¿t one that by CuÅ¿tome ought to gather the Rents, the Count muÅ¿t be Å¿pecial, 21 Hen. 7.76. pl. 23. becauÅ¿e the CuÅ¿tome makes the caÅ¿e to be Å¿pecial.
The Count was againÅ¿t one as Baily of a houÅ¿e and merchandiÅ¿e occupied by Joynt-tenants, ex quacunque cauÅ¿a Å¿eu contractu. Lib. Intra. 18. A. Å¿ect. 6.

The Count was, that he was Baily at the FeaÅ¿t of St. Michael, and good, becauÅ¿e it Å¿hall be
intended th'Archangel, Coke 11. part 39. A. Metcalfes CaÅ¿e, 20 Hen. 6.23.
The Count was againÅ¿t a Tenant per Elegit, that he had made waÅ¿te to the value, &c. Old. Nat. br. 34.
ConuÅ¿or counts that the ConuÅ¿ee had levied the Å¿um, or that he had levied part, and tendred the remnant, 47 Edw. 3.11. pl. 9. and fol. 25. pl. 63.
And Å¿o of the AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a ConuÅ¿or, 25. Ed. 3.53. pl. 17.

The King is not held to Count againÅ¿t one as Baily, but may alledge generally in his information, quod ille ad computand. Domino Regi tenetur; and if it be againÅ¿t Executors, quod is tempore mortis Å¿uae tenebatur. Coke 11. part 90. DevouÅ¿hers CaÅ¿e.

div.head: The Writs againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of a Court or Hundred, 2. of a Mannor, &c.
div.p: Rex, In ComitaÅ¿u. &c. Praecipimus tibi quod JuÅ¿ticies I. B. quod juÅ¿tÃ¨, & Å¿ine dilatione reddat B. rationabilem computum Å¿uum de tempore quo fuit Ballivus Å¿uus in M. Å¿icut rationabiliter monÅ¿trare poterit, quod Å¿ibi reddere debeat, ne amplius inde clamorem audiamus pro defectu juÅ¿titiae, TeÅ¿te, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135 A.
In London, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A.
For Executors, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A.
For Merchants, RegiÅ¿t. orig. ibid.

Rex, &c. Praecipe A. quod juÅ¿tÃ¨, In Banco. &c. reddat B. rationabilem Computum Å¿uum de tempore quo fuit Ballivus Å¿uus in N. & niÅ¿i fecerit, & praedictus B.
fecerit te Å¿ecurum de clamore Å¿uo proÅ¿equendo; tune Å¿umm. per bonos Å¿ummonitores praedictum A. quod Å¿it coram JuÅ¿tie. noÅ¿tris apud WeÅ¿tm. Ã die PaÅ¿chae in quindecim dies oÅ¿tenÅ¿ur. quare non fecerit: & habeas ibi Å¿umm. & hoc breve TeÅ¿te, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b. Nat. br. 117. E.
It lies for a man and his WiÅ¿e. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b.
For a MaÅ¿ter of a houÅ¿e. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b.
For a Prior in the time of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b.
For an Executor and an Abbot Co-executor. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. b.
But there is another form of a Writ founded upon the Statute of Marlebridge, cap. 23. Nat. 117. H. orig. RegiÅ¿t. 135. b.
Account againÅ¿t B. as Baily and Receiver in K. a good bar to the Writ, that he was not Baily nor Receiver in K. 21 Hen. 6.21. pl. 42. Vide 44 Edw. 3.1. pl. 2.
The Writ ought to comprehend the County. 10 Edw. 3.365. pl. 19. Shard.
If it be brought againÅ¿t one as Receiver, where he was Baily, it Å¿hall abate. 3 Edw. 3.70. pl. 28. 18 Edw. 4. pl. 17. For the Law takes notice of them as diÅ¿tinct and different employments.

But one Writ may comprehend Baily and Receiver. 9 Edw. 3.356. pl. 38. Nat. br. 116. P. 21 Hen. 6.21. pl. 42. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135 b. For a man may be charged in a double capacity, and if he rightly charged either way it is gone.

div.head: The proceÅ¿s againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. before appearance; 2. after appearance.
div.p: At the Common Law the ProceÅ¿s was but a diÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e.
But by Marlebridge, cap. 23. a Capias was given, Coke 3. part. 12. A.
And per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. proceÅ¿s of Outlawry is given, Coke 3. part. 12. A. 17 Ed. 2 proceÅ¿s 203. 17 Edw. 3.59. pl. 55. Shard. 29 Ed. 3.5. pl. 13.
But againÅ¿t Tenant by Elegit, is but a Scire facias, 21 Edw. 3.2. pl. 6. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 20. RegiÅ¿t. judicial. 73. b. Old Nat. br. 34.
And if they appear not being Å¿ummoned, judgment Å¿hall be given againÅ¿t them, 5 Edw. 3.159. 21 Edw. 3.1.
ConuÅ¿or Å¿hall have a Scire facias againÅ¿t the ConuÅ¿ee, Coke 4. part. 67. b. 47 Edw. 3.11. pl. 9. & fol. 25. pl. 63.
So the AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a ConuÅ¿or, 25 Edw. 3.53. pl. 17.
If a Baily come in by Capias or Exigend. he Å¿hall be forthwith committed to the Fleet, 29 Edw. 3.35. pl. 63. for his contempt in not appearing before.
So if he come in by DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and the Account be adjudged, 29 Edw. 3.35. pl. 63.

But if the Account be adjudged, and he be not preÅ¿ent in Court, a Capias ad Computandum Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue out againÅ¿t him, 1 Edw. 3.2. pl. 10. 1 Hen. 7.1. pl. 1. TownÅ¿end, Lib. Intra 18. c. Sect. 1, 2, 3.

div.head: The Bar for a Baily, 1. to an action of Account; 2. before Auditors.
div.p: A good Bar,Account before Auditors. that he did account before Auditors, 25 Edw. 3.39. pl. 1. 2 Edw. 3.45. pl. 13. Lib. Intra. 17. A. Sect. 1. he Å¿hall Å¿hew the time and the Auditors.
But in pleading he ought to Å¿ay, that the Auditors were aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Plaintiff only, and not by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, 29 Edw. 3.40. pl. 21.
A good Bar, that he did account with the Plaintiff himÅ¿elf. Lib. Intr. 18. A, & B. Sect. 6.11 Rich. 2. Stath. Account 46. 45 Edw. 3.14. pl. 13.
But it is no Bar to Å¿ay,No bar. he did account with the Plaintiff after that he had impriÅ¿oned him, 22 Edw. 3.13. pl. 32.
Account per Executors a good Plea, that he did account to the TeÅ¿tator, and Å¿hews an Acquittance of the TeÅ¿tator. 1 Edw. 3.2. pl. 10.
Heir Frank-tenant a good bar, 28 Edw. 3.90.

An Abbot brought an account againÅ¿t B. as Baily of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or, and the Defendant pleads,Property. that he had a LeaÅ¿e of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or for 3 years, and entered after the end, and found certain things there; this is a good Bar, 16 Edw. 3.368. pl. 30.

The Defendant Å¿aid, that it was debated between the Plaintiff and his Wife, and it was agreed, that the Wife Å¿hould have the Land for her maintenance, and Å¿he leaÅ¿ed to the Defendant rendring Rent; this is a good bar, 47 Edw. 3.18. pl. 34.

An account for the delivery of three Tuns of Wine; a good bar for the Defendants to Å¿ayâª
that the Wife was a common Taverner, and that they were Bailies for the Å¿ale thereof, without the aÅ¿Å¿ent of him, and that Å¿he fold and paid the Plaintiff, without that, that they were his Bailies in any other manner, 13 Rich. 2. Account 50.
Defendant pleads a LeaÅ¿e to him of the Mannor, a good bar, 49 Edw. 3.7. pl. 11.
Account of a HouÅ¿e and Goods: it is no Plea to Å¿ay, he bought the goods of the Plaintiff; but muÅ¿t Å¿ay without that, that he was his Baily for Account-render, 49 Edw. 3.7. pl. 11.
Payment by command of the Plaintiff,Payment. a good bar in diÅ¿charge, Coke 11. part. 38. B. Metcalfs caÅ¿e. 1 Edw. 5. 42 Edw. 3.6. pl. 21. But this is before Auditors, and not in bar of the Action.

The Defendant Å¿aid,Servant. that he was Servant to the Plaintiff, and he did chaÅ¿e the Cattel out of the field, without that, that he was Baily in any other manner; for if the Cattel are hurt he Å¿hall have an action of the CaÅ¿e, 7 Hen. 4.14. pl. 18.
He was his Surveyor, without that, that he was his Baily, 4 Edw. 3. Account 34.

The Defendant Å¿aid,Statute-Merchant. that the Plaintiff granted by Deed, and Å¿hews, that when he came to C. he was to acknowledge a Statute Merchant, that the Account Å¿hould not be, and Å¿hews likewiÅ¿e, that he did it; this is nothing without Å¿aying, he delivered it to the Plaintiff, 20 Edw. 3. Account 79. Q.

Account for the delivering of Tyn,Vendee. &c. the Defendant Å¿aid, that he delivered this, and took an obligation in the name of the Plaintiff; this is no bar, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 29. pl. 193. for he had no authority to take the Bond.
Baily of Woods to Å¿ell; it is no Plea to Å¿ay, he had not Å¿old them, becauÅ¿e this comes in debate before Auditors, 14 Edw. 3. Account 131.
The plt. after judgment for him quod Comput. dies, his Executors Å¿hall have a Scire facias; the which being Å¿erved, if he appear not, an Exigend. Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue out againÅ¿t him, 14 Hen. 4.1.

div.head: The Judgment againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. of Account; 2. to Recover the things.
div.p: The Judgment is, Quod Computet & ideo in miÅ¿cricordia, quia prius inde non Computavit. Coke 11. part. 38. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e. Lib. Intra. 19. b. Å¿ect. 1. & 20. D. Å¿ect. 1.
Quod computet for parcel, and Bar for the remnant. Lib. Intra. 22. A. Å¿ect. 12.

The Judgment is, Ideo conÅ¿ideratum eÅ¿t quod praedictus W. recuperet verÅ¿us praefat. M. as much as he Å¿hall be found in Arrearages, & dampna occaÅ¿ione implacitationis, &c. Coke 11. part. 40. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e.

Scire facias againÅ¿t Tenant per Elegit to Account, and not appearing upon garniÅ¿hment; the Judgment was, that the Plaintiff Å¿hall recover his Lands without any more proceÅ¿s upon the cauÅ¿e of the Account, &c. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 20.

div.head: Execution againÅ¿t a Baily, 1. per Common Law; 2. per Statute Law.
div.p:
By the Common Law he Å¿hall have but a Levari facias, or Fieri facias. Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e. And this within the year only, for
if the year paÅ¿s, he was put to his Action of debt, if the proceÅ¿s were not continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33.
Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 45. a Scire facias is given after the year.
And per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 18. Elegit is given. Coke 3. part. 12. A.
And per Marlebridge, cap. 23. and WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. Capias is given in proceÅ¿s.
And per conÅ¿equence a Capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum after Judgment, Coke 3. part. A. 12.
And by the Statute of WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. if an Accountant be found in arrearages before Auditors, he Å¿hall be Committed by the Auditors to the next Goal in execution.
But then the Auditors ought to Commit him to priÅ¿on forthwith. Coke 8. part. 119. b. Bonhams caÅ¿e, 27 Hen. 6.8. Com. 1.7.
But if he Account before the plt. he cannot Commit him to priÅ¿on, 45 Edw. 3.14. becauÅ¿e he Å¿hall not be Judge in his own cauÅ¿e.

div.head: Ex parte Talis by a Baily.
div.p: Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. if Auditors be aÅ¿Å¿igned by the party which will not allow to the Accountant reaÅ¿onable allowances, or charge him with a thing he never received, and Commit him to priÅ¿on, he Å¿hall have a Writ ex parte talis. Nat. br. 129. F. 4. Hen. 6.18. A. pl. 3. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. b.

But if Auditors be aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Court, and they do not allow reaÅ¿onable allowances, he Å¿hall not have this Writ, but Å¿hall Å¿hew it to the Court, and they Å¿hall make allowances, Nat. br. 129. F. 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30.
If it be Å¿ued in London, and Auditors be aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Court which will not allow, &c. there this Writ lieth, Nat. br. 129. F.
But note in RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. b. is againÅ¿t it. go: Q.
But if the Plaintiff aÅ¿Å¿ign Auditors there, then Å¿uch Writ lieth, Nat. br. 129. I. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. b.

The Writ Å¿hall be returnable before the TreaÅ¿urer and Barons of the Chequer at a day certain, and a Scire facias in the Writ to warn the Plaintiff and Defendant to be there, Nat. br. 129. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137.

div.head: Account againÅ¿t a Receiver, 1. in Law; 2. in Deed.
The Court where it is to be brought,
div.p: IN the County Court, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A.
In London, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A.
In the 5 Ports, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A.
Before JuÅ¿tice of Peace, per 2. Marlebridge, cap. 8.
Before Auditors, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11.
In the Com. Ban. RegiÅ¿t. 135. Nat. br. 117. E.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t a Receiver.
div.p: Husband and WiÅ¿e Å¿hall have an Account upon a Receipt dum Å¿ola fuit, 22 Hen. 6.39. pl. 10.
Executor Å¿hall have an Account, but this is per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 23. Nat. br. 117. C. 3 Ed. 3.66.7 Edw. 3.209.5 Edw. 3.141. pl. 7.11 Hen. 4.479.

But one Executor Å¿hall not have an Account againÅ¿t his Companion. 11 Hen. 4.79. pl. 20. for there is no privity betwixt them, and they have intereÅ¿t in the goods of TeÅ¿tator, in his right, and not their own.
If one have Judgment againÅ¿t a Receiver, and dies, his Executors Å¿hall have a Scire facias. 14 H. 4.1.
If two Merchants occupy in Common and one die, his Executors Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t the other. Nat. br. 117. D. for the two Merchants had Å¿everal IntereÅ¿ts.
An Executor of an Executor Å¿hall not have an Account, but only by the Statute of 25 Edw. 3. cap. 5. Com. 190.17 Edw. 3.270. pl. 5.
Filius & haeres non habebit breve de Computo verÅ¿us Receptorem, quia pertinet ad executionem AdminiÅ¿trationis bonorum defuncti. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. B. and therefore it belongs to the Excecutor.
Guardians of a Church againÅ¿t their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, 8 Edw. 4.6. P. 5. Å¿hall have an account in right of the PariÅ¿h.
And per 2. Marlebridge cap. 8. they Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t a Baily or head ConÅ¿table of an Hundred, &c. for amerciaments, or not repairing High-ways.

Guardians and PariÅ¿hioners Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t ConÅ¿tables and Churchwardens for Forfeitures of AlehouÅ¿e-keepers, in the Å¿ame manner as for other things by the Common Law, 1 Jac. cap. 9.

Two Joynt-tenants of goods, one of them delivers the goods to the other to render Account, one Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t the other. 43
Edw. 3.21.12 Hen. 4.18. Nat. br. 118. H. for here is a privity betwixt their Å¿everal IntereÅ¿ts.

The Sheriff levies Money upon a fieri facias, and does not deliver it to the plt. neither brings it into Court, the plt. Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t him, 11 H. 4.58. pl. 8.20 Hen. 6.24. A. 21 Hen. 6.5. A. Or the party may move the Court againÅ¿t him.
If one teÅ¿tifie by his deed, that he received 20 l. to beÅ¿tow for me, I Å¿hall have an Account, Hen. 8. Dyer. 20. pl. 118.11. Hen. 6.39. pl. 31. for the privity appears by the deed.
So if one receive Money to my uÅ¿e, Nat. br. 117. Q. 6 Hen. 4.7. pl. 33. But here I muÅ¿t prove the Receipt, though I need not in the former caÅ¿e.

So if A. deliver Money to B. to deliver to me. Nat. br. 117. Q. 13 Hen. 4. pl. 1. Hankeford, Nat. br. 138. A. I Å¿hall have an Account upon the privity in Law, and A. may have an Account upon the privity in Fact, Q.

A. indebted to B. in 200 l. prays C. to receive this for him. A. prays C. to borrow this to pay B. C. borrows it of D. to pay to B. but pays it not at the day. A. was bound to D. for re-payment. B. Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t C. for this Money belongs to B. inÅ¿omuch that C. had his warrant to receive it, Hill. 12 Jac. Com. Bon. Harringdon verÅ¿us Dean: and Å¿o there is a truÅ¿t and privity betwixt them.
A. delivers Money to B. to deliver to C. and he pays it not, A. Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him. Crooke 21 Hen. 7.69. pl. 2. per Frowicke. Q. if C. may not have an Account.

The King Å¿hall have an Account,King. if goods be
deviÅ¿ed to him, againÅ¿t the PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿our in whoÅ¿e hands Å¿oever they be, Coke 11. part. 90. A. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e. 40 AÅ¿Å¿i. pl. 35. per Praerogativam Å¿uam. For whereÅ¿oever the King hath equity, the Law will not be deficient to him.

If one takes goods which appertain to the King, claiming them to his own uÅ¿e; yet the King Å¿hall have an account, Coke 11. part. 90. A. 33 Hen. 6.2. 35 Hen. 6.27. B. Nottingham. 8. Eliz. Dyer 249. pl. 83. For the right being diÅ¿putable, the Law will judge the Kings claim to be true rather than the others; for the King can do no wrong in the eye of the Law.

Two offer to be bound for A, that he Å¿hall Å¿erve the King truly in Å¿uch an Office, and they preÅ¿ent him to the King, and he doth not perform his Office, they Å¿hall account to the King, though they are not bound, Coke 11. part. 92. B. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e. 30 Edw. 3. Rott. 6. For the King repoÅ¿ed truÅ¿t in them, and he Å¿hall not be prejudiced by them.
If one be entituled to an action of Account, and be outlawed, the King Å¿hall have an Account for it, 28 Edw. 3.92. pl. 10. for he comes in the Å¿tead of the party outlawed.
If one be indebted to the King and dies, the King Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t his Executors or Tertenant, 5 Eliz. Dyer 225. pl. 33. At his Election Q. whether againÅ¿t both.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Account lieth as Receiver.
div.p:
It lies not againÅ¿t a Prentice, Nat. br. 119. D. 7 Hen. 4.14. 8 Edw. 3.310. pl. 26. for there is no Writ in the RegiÅ¿ter againÅ¿t a Prentice, Coke
11. part. 89. B. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e; for a Prentice is not Å¿ui juris.
Per a. Marlebridge, cap. 8. Churchwardens Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t a Baily or head ConÅ¿table, for amerciaments for Highways not repaired.
It lies againÅ¿t the Husband for the receipt of the Wife, Nat. br. 118. F. for her Receipt is his Receipt. Q. If the Receipt was dum Å¿ola fuit it Å¿eems it doth.
It lies againÅ¿t a Deputy of a Receiver, for he receives this to the uÅ¿e of his MaÅ¿ter, Nat. br. 119. B. 4 Edw. 3.100. pl. 8. therefore the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have account.

It lies not againÅ¿t an Executor,Executor. Nat. br. 117. C. Littleton, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. B. quia mere pertinet ad curam ChriÅ¿tianam cognoÅ¿cere de computo reddendo verÅ¿us executores, 48 Edw. 3.2. 4. Edw. 4.25. Q.
But if an Executor will account, he Å¿hall be charged afterward, 2 Hen. 4.13. pl. 2.19. Hen. 6.5. A. ForteÅ¿cue; for he hath waved the Spiritual Court.
Note in the caÅ¿e of the King he Å¿hall have account againÅ¿t Executors, Littleton. For he may recover his right by what Law he pleaÅ¿eth.

It lieth not againÅ¿t an Infant, Nat. br. 118. D. becauÅ¿e he hath not diÅ¿cretion to account, and Å¿o may wrong himÅ¿elf in his Account; and per. 21 Edw. 3.8. pl. 21. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. A. 26 Edw. 3.63. he cannot wage his Law, becauÅ¿e he muÅ¿t perform his Law by taking his Oath.
It lies againÅ¿t a Woman or Chaplin, Nat. br. 118. D. viz. a Feme Å¿ole.
Churchwardens Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, 8 Edw. 4.6. pl. 5. for they are perÅ¿ons intruÅ¿ted by the PariÅ¿h.
Two being bound, both of them to Account, and each of them of the whole; quaere if Account lies againÅ¿t one only, 5 Edw. 3.141. pl. 8.

It lies not againÅ¿t a PariÅ¿h-PrieÅ¿t that hath the Offerings, for the Clark holds the veÅ¿Å¿el in which they are put, Nat. br. 119. E. 25 Edw. 3.46. pl. 32. vide 11 Rich. 2. JuriÅ¿diction 18. and he is not tied to be reÅ¿ponÅ¿able for his Clark.

The King grants the Toll of a Village to the Inhabitants, and in the Å¿aid Village there were certain Collectors to receive it, the Village Å¿hall have a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion out of the Chancery againÅ¿t him that receives this Toll, to hear and determine it, and to hear their Accounts, &c. Nat. br. 119. F.

If any takes the goods of the Kings Debtors which dies, the King Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him, Coke 11. part. 93. A. For the Law creates a privity in caÅ¿e of the King, for the preÅ¿ervation of his Revenue.
It lies for the King againÅ¿t a Debtor, or his Executors or Tertenents, 5 Eliz. Dyer 225. pl. 33. Com. 321. Mynes.

But if one purchaÅ¿e to him and his Wife, and he become indebted to the King, and die, his WiÅ¿e Å¿hall not be charged, 5 Eliz. Dyer 215. pl. 33. Contra, if he be firÅ¿t in debt, and purchaÅ¿e but a Chattel, 5 AÅ¿Å¿iz. pl. 5. For the Feme had an intereÅ¿t in the Land made by the Husband, and Å¿he Å¿hall not be charged with her Husbands debt; but the Executor of the Husband.

If one be an Accountant to the King, and become indebted to the King, and afterward Å¿ell a LeaÅ¿e for years, the Vendee Å¿hall not be charged, becauÅ¿e it is but a Chattel, Coke 8. par. 171. A. and
it was lawful for him to buy it, and might not know the Vendor to be an Accountant.

One in debt to the King purchaÅ¿es Lands with the Kings money, to the uÅ¿e of Å¿ome Friends in Fee per covin, and yet takes the profits, the King Å¿hall have the Lands in execution, 5 Mariae, Dyer 160. pl. 41.24 Edw. 3. Rot. 4. Coke 11. part. 92. B. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e. For the Law abhors Fraud in all parties, but eÅ¿pecially where the King is concerned.

div.head: For what things Account lieth againÅ¿t a Receiver.
div.p: A. delivers three tuns of Wine to B. to Å¿ell, he Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t him for them; but then he ought to count of the receipt of every Å¿um received of every Å¿everal man, 43 Edw. 3.21. pl. 11. 46 Edw. 3.3. pl. 6. 46 Edw. 3.9. pl. 4. Hill. 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. Rot. 1707. TreÅ¿ham againÅ¿t Ford. A indebted to B, and C indebted to B. A Å¿ends money to B by his Servant, which accepts of it for the debt of C, and not for the debt of A; yet A Å¿hall have an Account againÅ¿t B, becauÅ¿e he cannot accept of this in any other manner than the other tendered it, which was, to Å¿atisfie his own debt.
If one receive money to my uÅ¿e he Å¿hall account for it, Nat. br. 117. q. 6 Hen. 4.7. pl. 33. Q. if he receive it againÅ¿t my will or conÅ¿ent.
So if A deliver money to B, to deliver to me, Nat. 117. g. 13 H. 4. pl. 1. Hankeford, Nat. 138. A. I Å¿hall have an account, for it was delivered for my benefit: Q. if A Å¿hall not have an account.

He which ought to pay me an Annuity, pays this to another to pay me, or if my Tenant pay it
to another to pay me, I Å¿hall have an account againÅ¿t him that received it, or I may charge my Tenant notwithÅ¿tanding the delivery of it, Å¿o not a double remedy, 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 33.

A delivers Money to B beyond the Sea to be paid in England, he Å¿hall account for it to A, becauÅ¿e the payment was to be made in England, and that was the ground of the delivery of it. Nat. br. 118. G. 41 Edw. 3.3.

Money delivered to one upon the performing of a Condition, if the condition be not performed the money to be re-delivered, he Å¿hall account, Nat. br. 118. G. 41 Edw. 3.10. 18 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 135. 11 Hen. 6.39. pl. 31. for the Condition implies an Account, if not performed.

A leaÅ¿es Tithes to B rendring Rent: A being indebted to C, aÅ¿Å¿igns B to pay this. No account lieth for this, 5 Edw. 4.140, 141. for if it be not paid A may have his Action for the Rent, and B is not a Receiver in this caÅ¿e.

If goods be deviÅ¿ed to the King, account lieth for them, Coke 11. part 9. A. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e. For the King may uÅ¿e what Action he will to recover his right, and no injuÅ¿tice is done to any by this Prerogative.

If one take goods of the Crown, and claim them as his own proper goods, yet he Å¿hall account for them, Coke 11. part. 90. A. 33 Hen. 8.2. 35 Hen. 6.27. B. 18 Eliz. Dyer. 249. pl. 83. For Å¿uch taking doth not deveÅ¿t them out of the Crown; for though he may have right, yet Å¿uch taking is not the proper way to recover them.

div.head: The Account againÅ¿t a Receiver, 1. by other hands; 2. by his own hands.
div.p: The Account was, that he was a Receiver till Å¿uch a time, until, &c. within which time he received of the moneys of the Plaintiff 10 l. by the hands of B, and 10 l. by the hands of C; for B and C here Å¿hall be accounted but as Servants to A, except the contrary be Å¿hewn, Lib. Intra. 19. C, & D. 1, 2, 3. fol. 20. A. Sect. 4.

Account of the Receipt of Moneys by the hands of the Wife and a Stranger not good, becauÅ¿e they ought to have been Å¿everal IÅ¿Å¿ues, 43 Edw. 3.33. pl. 34. For the Receipt of the Wife is the Receipt of the Husband, and therefore as to her the account ought not to be per autre maine.

Note the difference between the ballment of the Wife, and the Receipt of the Wife.But if the Account be of the delivery by the hands of the Wife of the Plaintiff, it had been good, 5 Edw. 3.146. pl. 6. Count of Bailment by the hands of a Servant of the Plaintiff, Hill. 4 Eliz. Com. Ban. Rott. 1707. TreÅ¿ham verÅ¿us Forde.
And Å¿o it is of the delivery of a Stranger, and the Wife of the Plaintiff, 43 Edw. 3.33. pl. 34.

Account that the Defendant Å¿old a thing to A, and received 20 l. for it, and another thing to another, and received of him 10 l. this is nought, for the 10 l. and good for the remainder, 46 Edw. 3.3. pl. 6. BecauÅ¿e it is not Å¿aid to whom the other thing was Å¿old; and Å¿o there can be no iÅ¿Å¿ue joyned.

Viz. an Executrix,Baron and Feme count, that the Defedant fuit Receiver to the TeÅ¿tator from Å¿uch a time to Å¿uch a time, and received by the hands of B, &c. and did not account to the TeÅ¿tator neither to the
Executrix dum Å¿ola fuit, neither to them after the coverture. Lib. Intra. 20. A. Sect. 4.

Account againÅ¿t a Husband upon the receipt of his Wife Å¿hall be by the Husbands own hands, Nat. br. 118. F. viz. the count Å¿hall be that the Husband receive it, for the receipt of the Feme is the receipt of the Baron.
Bar in detinue is a bar in account, per Brian. 2 Rich. 3.14. pl. 19,Bar. for the one and the other affirm property, and Å¿uppoÅ¿e a detainer.

The Defendant Å¿aid,Coverture. that the Plaintiff at the time, &c. was under covert Baron, and this was good, 6 Edw. 3.184. pl. 5. Vide 18 Hen. 6.3. pl. 3. 2 Hen. 7.15. for then Å¿he had no power to Å¿ue.

Delivery to another by the command of the Plaintiff Male, Delivery. for it is too general; but to Å¿ay, that he was Baily to the Plaintiff to deliver to B. of the which he had a deed, this is good; becauÅ¿e he had not confeÅ¿Å¿ed it by the account render, this being Å¿pecial matter of juÅ¿tification. 19 Hen. 6.5. pl. 10. 26 Hen. 49. pl. 7. 30 Hen. 6 5. pl. 4. 41 Edw. 3.31. pl. 37. Lib. Intra. 20. A. Sect. 5.

Account againÅ¿t a Carrier, who Å¿aid, that goods were delivered to him to deliver to B. which he had done without that he was Receiver in any other manner; this is a good bar, per cuÅ¿tome d' Angleterre. Mich. 40, 41 Eliz. Com. Ban. Burrel verÅ¿us Callice.

So if the plt. deliver to one 20 l. to carry to the Lombard to be exchanged, and he brings a Bill of exchange for the money and traverÅ¿eth, without that, that he was a Receiver for account render, for by this he doth not confeÅ¿s the receipt for Account-render, 5 Hen. 5.4. pl. 10. 28 Hen. 6.9. pl. 1.
3 Hen. 6.4. pl. 4. but juÅ¿tifies by a Å¿pecial Receipt.

So if the Plaintiff deliver to one 20 l. to obtain a diÅ¿charge under the great Seal of the CuÅ¿tomes for 10 HogÅ¿heads of Wine, the which he hath done; this is good, 30 Hen. 6.5. pl. 4. for the former reaÅ¿on.
Re-delivery to the plt. without acquittance not good,Redelivery. 39 Edw. 3.19. pl. 21. for he confeÅ¿Å¿es thereby the Receipt, and therefore it is reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould account.
So if it be with an Acquittance, 3 Edw. 3.52. pl. 13. becauÅ¿e by this he hath confeÅ¿Å¿ed the receipt for Account-render, and he may plead the Acquittance before the Auditors.
But this is good before Auditors, 29 Edw. 3.35. pl. 1. in diÅ¿charge of the Account, though it was not good in bar of the Action.

The Defendant pleads, that he, as MeÅ¿Å¿enger of the Plaintiff, received of C Å¿uch a Å¿um, being ProvoÅ¿t to the Plaintiff, and this he paid and delivered to the Plaintiff, this is no bar to the Action, becauÅ¿e by the Receipt he is liable to the Account, 6 Edw. 3.185. pl. 7. 29 Edw. 3.20. pl. 11. but it may be in diÅ¿charge of the account.

An account of a Receipt by the hands of B. 1. of May till the firÅ¿t of July; Mort. it is no plea that B was dead the third of May, becauÅ¿e he may receive this the Å¿econd of May. 8 Hen. 6.32. pl. 28. and Å¿o accountable by his own Å¿hewing.

A delivers 20 l. to B to redeliver;Obligation. B binds himÅ¿elf to pay this; no bar in account, 4 Edw. 3.125. pl. 45. for the obligation is but additional Å¿ecurity, and alters not the nature of the bailment.

Defendant pleads,Payment. the Plaintiff being in his debt, commands him to receive of B Å¿o much to his own uÅ¿e as will Å¿atisfie his debt; which he doth without that, that he was his Receiver for Account-render, and good, Lib. Intra. 20. A, & B. Å¿ect. 6. 5 Edw. 4.29. B. Brian. For there is difference betwixt a receiving by way of Å¿atisfaction, which is to the Receivers uÅ¿e; and a Receipt per Account-render, which is for anothers uÅ¿e.
But if he confeÅ¿s the Receipt upon account, and he commands him afterwards to retain the debt, this is no bar of the Account by reaÅ¿on of his confeÅ¿Å¿ion; 28 Hen. 6, 7. pl. 9.

No plea,Robbery. that he was Factor and was Robbed, in bar of the Action; but a good plea before Auditors, Coke 4. part. 84. A. 41 Edw. 2.2. pl. 9. in diÅ¿charge of the Account; yet quaere, if he was robbed by the Kings Subjects.
Vendee and takes an obligation no bar, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer. 29. pl. 193.Vendee. for that is for his own Å¿ecurity that made the Å¿ale, and not the Owner of the goods.

Upon Receipt by others hands,UniÅ¿on Receiver. a good plea that he was never Receiver by their hands, 10 Edw. 4.8. A. 7 Edw. 3.259. pl. 13. 8 Edw. 3.285. pl. 34. 7 Edw. 3.242. pl. 1. 24 Edw. 3.66. pl. 74. 25 Edw. 3.39. pl. 24. for this deÅ¿troys the very gift of the action.
But 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 22. this is not good; but Å¿hall Å¿ay generally, that he never was his Receiver. Q. Car moy Å¿emble c'eÅ¿t n'eÅ¿t ley, Å¿i il Å¿oit charger come Receiver per autre maine.

If one teÅ¿tifie his Receipt by deed, he cannot plead, that he never was his Receiver, 10 Edw. 3.383.
pl. 18. for he is eÅ¿topped by his own deed to plead Å¿o, the Law will believe a mans deed rather than his bare averment.

Defendant pleads, that he is Executor of B, and that he received the money as a debt of B; this is not good, becauÅ¿e the Plaintiff Å¿uppoÅ¿eth him his Receiver; but he ought to Å¿ay without that, that he received it as the money of the Plaintiff, 11 Hen. 4.79. pl. 20. 13 Hen. 4. pl. 1. for Å¿uch a traverÅ¿e doth deÅ¿troy the Plaintiffs Å¿uppoÅ¿al.

Note, if the Receipt be by the hands of the Plaintiff, the Defendant may wage his law, 7 Edw. 3.269. pl. 52. viz. that he oweth him nothing, becauÅ¿e it may be a thing acted in private betwixt them, where the Nay of the Defendant is as much to be credited as the Yea of the Plaintiff.
So upon the delivery of the Wife of the Plaintiff, 13 Hen. 4.8. 43 Edw. 3.33. pl. 31. for HuÅ¿band and Wife are one perÅ¿on in Law.

But upon a Receipt by other hands he cannot, 9 Eliz. Dyer 265. pl. 2. 22 Hen. 6.39. pl. 10. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 22. 33 Hen. 6.8. B. Moyle, becauÅ¿e the Receipt lies in notice of the Countrey, upon which an iÅ¿Å¿ue may be joyned, and a trial had.
An Executor brought an Account upon the delivery of the TeÅ¿tator, the Defendant cannot wage his Law, 7 Edw. 3.269. pl. 52. for the delivery and the receipt was not acted betwixt them.

Outlawry of the Plaintiff after the Receipt a good bar,Outlawry. although he had a Charter of Pardon, 28 Edw. 3.92. pl. 10. for the Defendant is not bound to take notice of the Pardon until it be pleaded.

A good plea,Accord. that after the Receipt he married the Daughter of the Plaintiff, and it was then agreed, that he Å¿hould keep the money, 12 Hen. 4.18. A. for by this agreement the former contract in Law is deÅ¿troyed.
So if that he put the money in a bag, and agreed that he Å¿hould keep it in licu of a debt, 28 Hen. 8. pl. 9. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
Delivery and Redelivery.Delivery over by command of the Plaintiff, a good plea, 19 H. 6.5. pl. 10. Lib. Intr. 20. A. Sect. 5. 42. Edw. 6. pl. 21. for by this command the former truÅ¿t is made void.

A Re-delivery is a good plea without an Acquittance,Re-delivery. becauÅ¿e he cannot compel the Plaintiff to make an Acquittance, becauÅ¿e he received but his own goods, 29 Edw. 3.35. pl. 1. 6 Edw. 3.185. pl. 7. 29 Edw. 3.20. pl. 11. but it Å¿eems it may be a good plea before Auditors. Q.
Expences reaÅ¿onable Å¿hall be allowed to a Factor,Expences. 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30. for the labourer is worthy of his hire.
A Factor pleads, that he was robbed, Coke 4. part. 84. A. Southcots caÅ¿e 41 Edw. 3.3. pl. 9. vid. Antea, Q.
So for goods loÅ¿t by TempeÅ¿t, 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30. 41 Edw. 3.3. pl. 9. For here is the hand of God, which could not be avoided, and therefore the party not to be puniÅ¿hed.
So for goods Å¿old under value, by reaÅ¿on of War, 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30. becauÅ¿e of the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of the time.

Receipt in Satisfaction.Defendant Å¿aid, he received money in full Å¿atisfaction of a debt of another, &c. This was held void, becauÅ¿e he did not name that he never was his Receiver, the which was Å¿ound before Hill. 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. Rott. 1707. TreÅ¿hams caÅ¿e; Å¿o that his plea doth not anÅ¿wer the Plaintiffs Declaration.
Vendee of goods takes an obligation in the name of the Plaintiff,Vendee. a good plea, 28 Hen 8. Dyer 29. pl. 193.
But then he ought to Å¿hew that the obligor was Å¿ufficient to pay at that time, 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30.

div.head: The Judgment againÅ¿t a Receiver, 1. to Account; 2. to Recover.
div.p: 2. The Judgment is, quod computet, & ideo in miÅ¿ericordia quia prius inde non computavit, Coke 11. part. 38. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e, Lib. Intra 19. D. Sect. 1.
Quod computet for parcel, and bar for the remainder, Lib. Intr. 22. A. Sect. 2. for if there be juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to account for part, the Action is maintainable.

But if he confeÅ¿s part and traverÅ¿e the other, no Judgment Å¿hall be till the other be tried, 41 Edw. 3. Account 34. for it may be he is to account for all notwithÅ¿tanding his traverÅ¿e, which may be falÅ¿e.

The Judgment is, Ideo conÅ¿ideratum quod praedictus W. recuperet verÅ¿us praefat. M, Å¿o much as he is found in Arcarages, & dampna Å¿ua occaÅ¿ione implacitationis, &c. Coke 11. part. 40. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e.

The King is not held to bring a particular Account againÅ¿t any as Receiver, but to declare generally, quod ille ad computum domino Regi reddend. tenetur: and againÅ¿t Executors, quod tenebantur tempore mortis Å¿uae, Coke 11. part. 90. DevouÅ¿hers caÅ¿e; for the King is not tied to punctualities of Law, where no perÅ¿on is injured by his not obÅ¿ervance of them.

div.head: The Writ againÅ¿t a Receiver.
div.p: In Comitatu. Rex, &c. pr. A, quod juÅ¿te, &c. reddat B rationabilem computum Å¿uum de tempore quo fuit Receptor denariorum ipÅ¿ius B,In Com. Ban. &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. & ibidem B. vide diverÅ¿a brevia de computo verÅ¿us Receptorem. Writat the Com. Law, by the Stat. of Marleb. cap. 29.
But there is another form of a Writ founded upon the Statute of Marlebridge, cap. 23. Nat. br. 117. H. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 136. B.

A good plea to the Writ, that he was Baily and not Receiver, for otherwiÅ¿e he Å¿hall be twice charged, viz. as Baily and Receiver, 3 Edw. 3.70. pl. 28. 18 Edw. 4.3. pl. 17. which the Law judges unreaÅ¿onable, and will prevent by making the Writ certain.
A good plea to the Writ, that he was Guardian in Soccage, 18 Edw. 4.3. pl. 17. and Å¿o not properly a Receiver, as the Writ Å¿uppoÅ¿eth.
The Writ Å¿hall be always general, and if the cauÅ¿e be Å¿pecial, it Å¿hall be Å¿et forth in the Count, Nat. br. 118.Q. F.

The Defendant pleads the Receipt by deed, and demands judgment of the Writ without Å¿hewing it, this is no plea to the Writ; becauÅ¿e the Receipt and not the Deed is the cauÅ¿e of Action, and he
hath confeÅ¿Å¿ed the Receipt, and the Deed appears not to the Court, 1 Hen. 6.8. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 20. pl. 121. But 9 Edw. 4.50. B. per Choke contra 2. Hen. 6.9. quaere.
No plea to the Writ, if it do not agree with the Plaintiff concerning the manner of the Receipt, 4 Hen. 6.12. pl. 4.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s againÅ¿t a Receiver, 1. before Appearance; 2. after.
div.p: At the Common Law the ProceÅ¿s was but a diÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e.
But per Sat. de Marlebridge, cap 23. a Capias is given, Coke 3. part. 12. A. for more expedition; for Liberty is more precious than ones EÅ¿tate in the eye of the Law.

And by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. ProceÅ¿s of Outlawry is given, Coke 3. part. 12. A. 17 Edw. 3. ProceÅ¿s 203. 17 Edw. 3.59. pl. 55. Shard, 26 Edw. 3.5. pl. 13. which is a more violent proÅ¿ecution to bring the Defendant to do right.

A Scire facias Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue againÅ¿t Tenant per Elegit to account, 21 Edw. 3.2. pl 6. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 20. RegiÅ¿t. Judicial, 73. B. Old Nat. br. 34. what profits he hath received out of the lands extended, and how far his debt is Å¿atisfied.
And if he come not upon Summons returned, Judgment Å¿hall be given againÅ¿t him, 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 20. 21 Edw. 3.1. Quod computet.
ConuÅ¿or of a Statute Å¿hall have a Scire facias againÅ¿t a ConuÅ¿ee to Account, Coke 4. part. 67. B 47 Edw. 3.11. pl. 9. & fol. 25. pl. 63.
So the AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a ConuÅ¿or, 25 Edw. 3.53. pl. 17. both for the former reaÅ¿on upon the Elegit.

But then he cannot Å¿urmize, that it was appraiÅ¿ed and found of baÅ¿e value, 17 Edw. 3.36. pl. 6. For by the bringing of the Action he admits of a certain value to account upon, and Å¿uch a Å¿urmize is a matter dehors.

If a Receiver come in by a Capias or Exigend. he Å¿hall be forthwith committed to the Fleet, 29 Edw. 35. pl. 63. for his contempt in not coming in till compelled by force, which is a diÅ¿turbance of the publick Peace,
So if he come in by diÅ¿treÅ¿s, and the account be adjudged againÅ¿t him, 29 Edw. 3.35. pl. 63. for then it doth appear he was a Fort feaÅ¿or.

But if the account be adjudged againÅ¿t him, and he be not preÅ¿ent in Court, a Capias ad computandum Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue out, 1 Edw. 3.2. pl. 10. 1 Hen. 7.1. pl. 1. TownÅ¿end, Lib. Intr. 18. Sect. 1, 2, 3. to make it appear to the Court, whether he was to account or no.

If in Judgment given quod computet, the Plaintiff dies, the Executor Å¿hall have a Scire facias, which being Å¿erved, if the Defendant appear not, an Exigend. Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue forth againÅ¿t him, 14 Hen. 4.1.

But if the Defendant be taken per Capias ad computandum, and dies in priÅ¿on, a Scire facias lies not againÅ¿t his Executors, 10 Edw. 4.7.41. AÅ¿Å¿ize: So that a Scire facias lies for an Executor, but not againÅ¿t an Executor; for the Executor may not be Å¿o privy to the receipts and payments of the TeÅ¿tator, as to know what to plead to the Account.

div.head: Bar by a Receiver, 1. to an Action of Account; 2. before Auditors.
div.p: The Defendant pleads, he bought the goods of the Plaintiff,Bought. before he brought this Action for them, a good bar, 14 Hen. 4.19 pl. 21. for thereby he claims the property in them.

The Defendant pleads,Accord. that it was agreed that he Å¿hould be bound to the Plaintiff for the principal and uÅ¿e, the which he did; this is a good bar to the Action, 22 Hen. 6.55. pl. 32. for this drowns the former contract: otherways he ought to plead this before Auditors. Q. Whether it may be pleaded in bar of the Action, or in diÅ¿charge of the Account before Auditors. It Å¿eems it is no plea before Auditors.

So if the Plaintiff grant, that if the Defendant pay 20 l. he will withdraw his Action; this is a good bar to the Action, becauÅ¿e of this Accord, 7 Edw. 3.325. pl. 11. 18 Edw. 3.39. pl. 35. which hath taken away the ground of the Action.

No plea, that he put it in a bag, and that the Plaintiff agreed that he Å¿hould keep it in lieu of a debt; becauÅ¿e the Receipt for Account-render is confeÅ¿Å¿ed, 28 Hen. 6.7. pl. 9. and Å¿o it appears the Plaintiff hath cauÅ¿e of Action.

The Plea was, that he did account of Å¿uch a Sum Å¿uch a day, and year, and place, before A and B, Auditors aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Plaintiff, a good Bar, Lib. Intra. 19. D. Sect. 3. 25 Edw. 3.39. pl. 1. 2 Edw. 3.45. pl. 13. For they are Judges, and Å¿o Å¿hall not account twice for one Å¿um.

The Plaintiff Counts of divers Å¿ums received between Å¿uch and Å¿uch a day, and the Defendant pleads to parcel of the time, that he hath fully accounted, and to the remainder, that he was not his Receiver; there he ought to Å¿hew of what he had accounted, 30 Edw. 3.1. pl. 4. for otherwiÅ¿e his plea is too general, incertain, and captious, which the Law will not permit.
That he accounted to the Plaintiff from three months to three months, and Å¿o to the time of the action, a good Bar, 39 Edw. 3.5. pl. 22.
A good bar that he did Account 1o April; but then he ought to Å¿ay, without that, that he w â¢â¢ his Receiver after, 21 Edw. 4.66. pl. 47. 7 Hen. 4.14. pl. 17. 45 Edw. 3.14. pl. 13. 34. Hen. 6.44.

Counts that he was Receiver for Å¿even years, i â¢ is no bar that he accounted 1o Maii Anno 5o with out anÅ¿wering for the two other years; becau â¢â¢ he is to anÅ¿wer for the whole time, as well Å¿o â¢ the increaÅ¿e as principal, 7 Hen. 6 5. pl. 8.
As to 20s. received 1o Jun. fully account â¢ for, and to the Receipt afterward, or before th â¢â¢ he never was Receiver, 27 Hen. 6.1. pl. 8. a goo â¢â¢ plea.

A good bar quod 21. Januarii Anno, &c.
ãâã
D, in the County of W, he fully accounted wi â¢â¢ the Plaintiff, Lib. Intra. 20. B. Sect. 8, 9, 10, 11. Before the Writ brought he did account with th â¢ Plaintiff, a good bar, 4 Hen. 6.43. pl. 4.

But he ought to account to the Plaintiff befor â¢ he is impriÅ¿oned, or elÅ¿e no bar; becauÅ¿e it is pe â¢â¢ dente lite, and it appears the Plaintiff had cauÅ¿e ãâã action, elÅ¿e he not not been committed, 22 Edw.
â¢ 3. pl. 32. 7 Hen. 4.14.34 Hen. 6.44. pl. 4.
For the Plaintiff cannot commit him to priÅ¿on, for WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. gives this power only to the Auditors, 45 Edw. 3.14. pl. 13. who are the Judges.
To an Account brought by Executors it is a good bar, that the Defendant did account to the TeÅ¿tator, and Å¿hew his Acquittances, 1 Edw. 3.2. pl. 10. for then the Executors have no colour of action.

The Defendant pleads an award made by Arbitrators, that he Å¿hould re-deliver the goods, this is nought; but if he had been charged only with the Å¿afe cuÅ¿tody of them, then good, 2 Hen. 5.2. pl. 6. For the Defendant is chargeable to Account for the provent of the goods, as well as for the goods themÅ¿elves.
Account upon a Receipt by other hands, Arbitrement is a good bar, 22 H. 6.39. pl. 10. For the Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Arbitrement creates a new Contract.

div.head: Execution againÅ¿t a Receiver, 1. per Common Law; 2. per Statute Law.
div.p: 1. By the Common Law it was but a Levari facias, or Fieri facias, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e; to levy the arrears upon his Lands, or Goods and Chattels. Q.
And this only within the year; for if the year was paÅ¿t, then an Action of debt only lay upon the Judgment.
UnleÅ¿s the ProceÅ¿s be continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33. For the Court will not grant out Executions upon Å¿leeping Judgments, for this may prove dangerous.

2. Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 45. a Scire facias is given
after the year, Coke 3. part. 12. A. upon the Judgment againÅ¿t the Defendant, to Å¿hew why he Å¿hould not pay the Arrears due to the Plaintiff by the Judgment.

Per Marlebridge, cap. 23. & WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. a Capias was given in ProceÅ¿s, and by conÅ¿equence a Capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum in execution, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Lib. Intra. 18. C. Sect. 1, 2, 3. which are both to lay hold on the perÅ¿on of the Defendant.

Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. if the Accountant before Auditors be found in Arrearages, he Å¿hall be committed by them to the next Goal in execution: the Å¿ame law is, if he will not account before the Auditors, 10 Edw. 3.387. pl. 28. when he is adjudged by the Court to do it.
But this Å¿hall be forthwith, Coke 8. part. 119. B. Bonhams caÅ¿e, 27 Hen. 6.8. Com. 17. for the Statute being penal muÅ¿t be Å¿trictly purÅ¿ued.
But if he account before the Plaintiff he cannot commit him to PriÅ¿on; for the Statute Å¿aith before Auditors, 45 Edw. 3.14. pl. and no impriÅ¿onment lay before the Statute.

But an Accountant to the King Å¿hall be impriÅ¿oned, and his goods and lands in execution per the Common Law, Coke 3. part. 12. B. 5 Eliz. Dyer 224. Com. 32. which is tender of the King as well in his Revenue as his PerÅ¿on.

div.head: Ex parte talis.
div.p:
Per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. if Auditors be aÅ¿Å¿igned by the party Plaintiff, who will not allow reaÅ¿onable charges to the Receiver, or charge him with a thing he never received, and then commit him to priÅ¿on, he Å¿hall have this Writ, Nat. br. 129. F. 4
Hen. 6.18. A. pl. 3. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. B. which is in the nature of an Audita querela.

But if Auditors be aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Court which do not make allowance; yet the Defendant Å¿hall not have this Writ, but may complain to the Court, and they Å¿hall order them, Nat. br. 129. E. 3 Edw. 3.56. pl. 30. to do juÅ¿tice; for they are MiniÅ¿ters of the Court, and to be anÅ¿werable for their actions.
If one be Å¿ued in London, and the Court aÅ¿Å¿ign Auditors, who make not allowance, &c. the Defendant Å¿hall have this Writ, Nat. br. 129. F. But note RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. contra, Q.

The Writ Å¿hall be returnable before the TreaÅ¿urers and Barons in the Exchequer at a certain day, and a Scire facias in the Writ to warn the Plaintiff in the Account, and alÅ¿o the Defendant to be there, Nat. br. 129. G, & H. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 137. vid. WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11.

Note, that an account lieth in one Writ againÅ¿t a Baily and Receiver, Nat. br. 116. P. 21 Hen. 6.21. pl. 42. 9 Edw. 3.356. pl. 38, & pl. 40. 14 Hen. 4.20. pl. 25. vide the Writ Nat. 117. C. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 135. For one and the Å¿ame perÅ¿on may be Baily and alÅ¿o Receiver at one time to one and the Å¿ame perÅ¿on.
Vide the Count, Lib. Intra. 17. B. Sect. 1.
And for all the other parts they are in the Å¿ame manner as is deÅ¿cribed before in Baily and Receiver.

div.head: Action upon the CaÅ¿e.1. Quid. 2. Quotuplex.

list.head: Action upon the CaÅ¿e is either by
list.item: 2. Not doing of a thing, ought to be done by
Law, as to perÅ¿ons diÅ¿co â¢ continued,

div.head: In what Court it lieth.
div.p:
It lieth not in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, Coke 10. part. 7 â¢
A. 76. A. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey. For that Court is limited ãâã hold plea but in particular caÅ¿es. But this learni â¢â¢
was now out of doors, in reÅ¿pect that that Court was wholly taken away; but now again revived.

p.hi: For doing of wrong to the dammage of another, touching a thing hereditary, who Å¿hall have it.

div.p: Baron and Feme.Baron and Feme joyn upon an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to the Wife dum Å¿ola fuit, and good, Hill. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wolverton and his Wife againÅ¿t Day. For elÅ¿e the party would be without remedy.

Baron and Feme joyn in Trover and converÅ¿ion for a Deed for an annuity granted to the Wife, and it is good; for if he Å¿urvive, he Å¿hall have the Deed, Trin. 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. RuÅ¿Å¿el & Caresby. Q.
Husband had an Action Å¿ole upon the AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to the Wife, and counted of the aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to him, 27 Hen. 8.24, & 25. for the aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it made to the Wife is made to the Husband.
Commoner Å¿hall have it for feeding his Common,Commoner. though he be but a Copyholder, Coke 9. part. 112. B. Mayes caÅ¿e. For he is thereby damnified, and no other Action lies for him.
But then it Å¿hall be Å¿uch feeding by which he loÅ¿eth his Common, or elÅ¿e cannot have it in that beneficial manner as he ought, Coke 9. part. 231. A. Mayes caÅ¿e. De minimis non Curat Lex.

Executor Å¿hall have it for putting him out of his Term by the LeÅ¿Å¿or,Executor. Nat. br. 92. G. RegiÅ¿t. 97. Coke 4. part. 95. A. Slades caÅ¿e. For a Term belongs to an Executor, except it be otherwiÅ¿e diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of.
For money for Grain fold, Lib. Intra. 4. B. Sect. 2. the Court there. Q. whether debt lies not.

Upon an AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to the TeÅ¿tator, to marry one or pay 20 l. Lib. Intra. 10. B. Sect. 5. For by
the ConÅ¿ideration the TeÅ¿tators eÅ¿tate is prejudiced, if the aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it be not performed.
Upon an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to Å¿ave the TeÅ¿tator harmleÅ¿s of an obligation, Lib. Intra. 12. B. Sect. 2. for the Executor is liable to be Å¿ued upon it.

If a NuÅ¿ance be made,Feoffee. and a Feoffment is made, if this continue as a new NuÅ¿ance, the Feoffee Å¿hall have an action, Coke 5. part. 101. A. Penruddocks caÅ¿e. For the Feoffee is thereby hindred of enjoying the beÅ¿t of his bargain.
The Heir Å¿hall have an action for a NuÅ¿ance made in the time of his Father,Heir. if it be continued, &c. for the Inheritance is prejudiced thereby, Coke 5. part. 101. A. Penruddocks caÅ¿e.
Two cannot joyn for calling them falÅ¿e Knave and Thief,Joynder. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 19. pl. 112. for they are Å¿everal Å¿landers, and perÅ¿onal.
Two cannot Å¿ue in the Admiralty where one of them ought to have an Action at Law, 5 Mariae, Dyer 157. pl. 39. for the Common Law is to be preferred.

LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have it againÅ¿t Tenant at will for voluntary waÅ¿te,LeÅ¿Å¿or. Littleton 15. A. 14 Hen. 8.12. Brown. Coke 5. part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e, 48 Edw. 3.25. Dyer 121. pl. 17. 11 Hen. 6.38. for an Action or waÅ¿te doth not lie.
But not for negligent or permiÅ¿Å¿ive waÅ¿te, Coke 5. part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e he is not bound to repair.
Tenant in Common.Tenant in common Å¿hall have it againÅ¿t the other, for breaking a Gutter between their houÅ¿es, 2 Hen. 5.3. pl. 12. for Å¿ic debes uti tuis ut aliens non noces.

For making a Lime-pit in his Land, which they
have in common, by which the water Å¿urrounds his houÅ¿e, 13 Hen. 7.26. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
Tenants in Common may joyn in an action for a NuÅ¿ance upon their Land committed, becauÅ¿e this concerns all their profit, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Stone againÅ¿t Dromage.
For taking of a Meer-Å¿tone, 1 Hen. 5.1. Lib. Intra. 9. C. Å¿ect. 1. for the Land may thereby be endangered to be loÅ¿t.

div.head: 2. AgainÅ¿t whom this lieth.
div.p: It lies againÅ¿t an AdminiÅ¿trator,AdminiÅ¿trator. upon an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it of the TeÅ¿tator, Lib. Intra. 4. C. Å¿ect. 3. for he received benefit by the conÅ¿ideration, viz. their eÅ¿tate.
Which cuts Trees without cauÅ¿e; 18 Edw. 4.27.
AgainÅ¿t a Baily of a Baily of goods,Baily. 12 Edw. 4.13.
It lies againÅ¿t Baron and Feme,Baron and Feme. for not repairing Seabanks upon the Land of his Wife, 7 Hen. 4.31. for the tort is done by the Husband as well as by the Wife.

Trover and ConverÅ¿ion lies againÅ¿t Baron and Feme for the ConverÅ¿ion of the Feme, for it is a diÅ¿loyal act: which his Wife may do, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. RegiÅ¿t. Drapers caÅ¿e; and Å¿o an Action upon the CaÅ¿e lies not.

Trover and ConverÅ¿ion lieth not againÅ¿t a Carrier for a delivery to his Servant,Carrier. but an Action upon the CaÅ¿e, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Reg. Wornhall and BradÅ¿haw. For the delivery to the Servant is a delivery to the MaÅ¿ter, and for which he is anÅ¿werable.
A CounÅ¿ellor is retained to purchaÅ¿e land,CounÅ¿elor. and diÅ¿cloÅ¿es the Secrets by which the party is damnified, &c. 11 Hen. 6.18.
Upon an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to pay a debt,AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it. No. Lib. Intra. I. B. Å¿ect. 1. Coke 9. part. 86. B. Pinchons caÅ¿e, 1. Coke 9. part. 94. A. Banes caÅ¿e; viz. upon the Å¿pecial agreement.

AgainÅ¿t Churchwardens for not repairing a Gutter of the Church,Churchwardens. which is a NuÅ¿ance to my houÅ¿e. Lib. Intra. 10 D. Å¿ect. 1. For they ought to repair the Church, and are publick Officers of whom the Law takes notice.

Divers do make an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it, Joynder. action lies not againÅ¿t two of them only, but if the Plaintiff Å¿hews that the others are dead, then it is good, and it is Å¿ufficient to Å¿hew, that at the requeÅ¿t of them that are alive and the others the thing was done, and that the others are now dead, Trin. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Brereton and his Wife againÅ¿t King and Milner.
AgainÅ¿t a MaÅ¿ter upon a Å¿ale and warranty of the Servant,MaÅ¿ter. 11 Edw. 4.6. for the act of the Servant being for the MaÅ¿ters advantage is the act of the MaÅ¿ter.
Tenant at will.AgainÅ¿t Tenant at will for voluntary waÅ¿te, Littleton 15. A. 14 Hen. 8.12. Brown, Coke 5. part. 13. Salops caÅ¿e, Dyer 121. pl. 17.
But not for permiÅ¿Å¿ive or negligent waÅ¿te, Coke 5. part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e; for the Law makes a difference betwixt negligent, and wilful and malicious wrongs.

Tenant per Elegit.AgainÅ¿t Tenant per Elegit, which holds over, and cuts the Trees after money tendered to him, 21 Edw. 3.16. to Å¿atisfie the debt; for he is to hold the Land till his debt is Å¿atisfied.

Tenant in common.AgainÅ¿t a Tenant in common of a HouÅ¿e by his Companion for breaking his Gutter between their houÅ¿es, 2 Hen. 5. plea 12. for treÅ¿paÅ¿s vi & armis he cannot have, becauÅ¿e he is Å¿eiÅ¿ed per jug. & per tout.
For making a Lime-pit to burn Lime,Kiln. by which his houÅ¿e is damnified, 13 Hen. 7.26.

Tenant for years. A having an ancient Light, B erects a houÅ¿e which Å¿tops it, and leaÅ¿es it to C; yet an Action lies not againÅ¿t C, becauÅ¿e the LeÅ¿Å¿ee had done no wrong, and he could not pull it down, Trin. 13 Jacobi Ban. Regis, Bolds caÅ¿e. Q. as the Law is now taken, whether it lies againÅ¿t B.
When a man preÅ¿cribes in an Ile in a Church,Vicar. and the Vicar will not Å¿uffer him to make a Sepulchre there, No. Lib. Intra. 8. B. Å¿ect. 7. for he diÅ¿turbs his Inheritance.
AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff upon a falÅ¿e return,Sheriff. Lib. Intra. 11. A. Å¿ect. 1.
Upon returning nichil, where the party had Å¿ufficient, Lib. Intra. 11. C. Å¿ect. 2. for this is a falÅ¿e return.

div.head: For what things this Action lies.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t a Tenant by elegit, Trees. that holds the Lands after his money tendered him, and cuts the Trees, 21 Edw. 3.16. vid. Å¿upra.
So if Tenant at will cuts the Trees, Littleton 15. A. Coke 8. part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e, 48 Edw. 3.25. for that is voluntary waÅ¿te, for which he is puniÅ¿hable.
If a Baily cuts Trees without cauÅ¿e, 18 Edw. 4.27.

Chappel.For diÅ¿turbing of men to come to my Chappel
with offerings, 19 Rich. 2. Action upon the CaÅ¿e, 52. This is now out of doors Å¿ince the Reformation temps Edw. 6.
AgainÅ¿t the Owner of the Land in which I have a Way,Way. 1. EÅ¿treite. and he Å¿traitens it; for I am thereby abridged of my eaÅ¿ement, 33 Hen. 6.26.
For trenching of it,2. Trench. for the former reaÅ¿on, Lib. Intra. 616. C. Sect. 1.
For any manner of diÅ¿turbance in my paÅ¿Å¿age or part of my way,3. DiÅ¿turb. Å¿o that I cannot paÅ¿s Å¿o commodiouÅ¿ly as I did before, 14 Hen. 8.31. 21 Hen. 7.35. 22 Hen. 6.15. 10 Hen. 7.21.

4. Stopping of it.If the whole way be Å¿topped by one that is not owner of the Soil, it lies, 22 Hen. 5. 33 Hen. 6.26. 10 Hen. 7.21. For I am wholly deprived of my eaÅ¿ement, and no other Action lies againÅ¿t him.
So if Tertenant and others Å¿top it, 34 Hen. 6.4. tamen quaere as to the Tertenant.

For againÅ¿t Tertenant that Å¿tops all the way an aÅ¿Å¿ize of NuÅ¿ance doth lie, and not this Action, 22 Hen. 6.14. 3 Eliz. Dyer 250. pl. 88. 19 Hen. 6 29. pl. 49. PaÅ¿ton. 2 Hen. 4.11. pl. 48. No. Lib. Intra. 12.6. Sect. 10. Q. whether two Actions may not be brought in the former caÅ¿e.
But if I have it but for years an Action on the CaÅ¿e lies, 33 Hen. 6.26. Nat. br. 176, & 184. L. eodem. For he can claim no inheritance in the Land where the way lies.

If A Å¿tops my way, and leaÅ¿es the Land to B, it lies againÅ¿t B, if he do not open it, for continuing of the wrong; but if A build a HouÅ¿e and leaÅ¿es it to B, there B cannot pull it down for to lay open my way, for this is waÅ¿te in B. Trin.
13 Jac. Regis, Bolds caÅ¿e, and RutlandÅ¿hiers caÅ¿e; and therefore an Action lies not againÅ¿t B for not pulling down the houÅ¿e, for that were unreaÅ¿onable.

But by 11 Hen. 4. an Action upon the caÅ¿e lies for Å¿topping of a way in groÅ¿s only, and an aÅ¿Å¿ize of NuÅ¿ance for a way appendant. 21 Edw. 3.2.6. 34 Hen. 6.4. pl. 11. Note the difference, one Å¿avours of the realty, the other is but perÅ¿onal.

But for Å¿topping of a way in my own Land TreÅ¿paÅ¿s vi & armis lies, and not this Action, 31 Edw. 3. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 38. 13 Hen. 7.26. For there is a plain breach of the Peace by diÅ¿turbing my poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

But for Å¿topping of a Highway the DeÅ¿endant Å¿hall be puniÅ¿hed in the Leet, and not by this Action, unleÅ¿s the party had a Å¿pecial loÅ¿s; for a Å¿pecial loÅ¿s admits of a Å¿pecial remedy, 27 Hen. 8.26. 5 Edw. 4.2. b. 7 Edw. 4 8. 33 Hen. 6.26. Coke 5. part. 73. A. Williams caÅ¿e. 21 Hen. 7.35. Coke 9. part. 113. Mayrs caÅ¿e. For a Court Leet is to redreÅ¿s Å¿uch publick grievances.

Slander of my Title.If A Å¿ays, that B hath right in my Land for years an Action lies, Coke 1. part. 177. Mildmays caÅ¿e. No. Lib. Intr. 30. A. Å¿ect. 27. but I ought to Å¿hew how I am prejudiced by his Å¿aying Å¿o, or elÅ¿e it lies not, for his lye were it a treÅ¿paÅ¿s only, the Law will not puniÅ¿h it.

A brought an Action upon the CaÅ¿e againÅ¿t B, becauÅ¿e that B publiÅ¿hed and declared falÅ¿ly, that he had the LeaÅ¿e of the Land of A, and that he intended to Å¿ell his Land, and was thereby hindred; B Å¿aid, that he had an Indent. of LeaÅ¿e, as in the Count is mentioned, and traverÅ¿eth that he forged it not,
1. when B claims a right, though he had none; yet the Action lies not, for it appears not whether he had a right or not; 2. the Count is good, becauÅ¿e it is, that it was againÅ¿t the knowledge of B that it was forged; 3. Sciens is not traverÅ¿able, Coke 4. part. 18. A. caÅ¿e 14. See the CaÅ¿e at large.

For Å¿topping a Ditch by which my land is Å¿urrounded with water, Nat. br. 88. E, 89, M, 39 Hen. 6.32. 11 Hen. 4.82. 14 Hen. 8.31. Q. whether it lies for Å¿uffering it to be Å¿topped by negligence,Land. viz. by another.
For not Å¿couring a Ditch, by which my land is overflown, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 100. A. Q. if I be not thereby damnified.
For breaking of a Seabank, by which my land is Å¿urrounded, Nat. br. 86. F. 89. B, & C. Reg. orig. 95. A.
