It lies not for erecting of Coney-burroughs, by which I loÅ¿e part of the profits of my land, becauÅ¿e the party that erected them had no property in the Coneys, for they are ferae naturae, Coke 5. part. 104. BoulÅ¿tons caÅ¿e; and it is lawful for me to kill them if they come upon my ground. Q. tamen in regard of the trouble.
If one hath a BakehouÅ¿e by PreÅ¿cription,Trade. and I Å¿et up another by him to his prejudice; for the Law favours and protects ancient Rights, preÅ¿uming they had lawful commencements.
1. For diÅ¿turbing my Baily to diÅ¿train for an amercement,DiÅ¿treÅ¿s. 18 Hen. 6.9. pl. 20. for the wrong is done to me; for the Baily is my Servant, and acts for my benefit.
2. For diÅ¿turbing me to diÅ¿train or to attach, Nat. br. 102. F. This is Å¿tronger than the former caÅ¿e, and the injury more apparent.
3. For diÅ¿training more Suitors to come to my Leet than ought to be, Nat. br. 94. G. Coke 4.94. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 103. B. for the Law hates needleÅ¿s troubles and vexations.

4. For diÅ¿training ParÅ¿ons or Vicars in their Spiritual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, Nat. br. 94. E. and the Writ is, contra legem & conÅ¿uetudinem regni noÅ¿tri, & contra formam articulorum, & contra pacem noÅ¿tram, ibidem. For the Common Law protects the Clergy, and takes care for their eÅ¿tates to preÅ¿erve them from violence.
Fair and Market.1. AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ets up a new Fair or Market againÅ¿t my Fair or Market, 22 Hen. 6.14. 11 Hen. 4.74. for I am prejudiced thereby in my ancient right.
But 41 Edw. 3.24. per Belknap, Quod permitt at lies, and not this Action. Q. tamen car Å¿emble nemy.

2. For diÅ¿turbing CuÅ¿tomers to come to the Market. 11 Hen. 4.47. 41 Edw. 3.24. 29 Edw. 3.18. 9 Hen. 6.45. Nat. br. 91. G. 2 Edw. 3.32. pl. 9. For it is as well a private injury to them, as it is a prejudice to the Commonwealth.
3. For diÅ¿turbing me to hold a Fair or Market, 16 Edw. 2. Action Å¿ur caÅ¿e 47. for it hinders my profit.
And the Writ was, that it held three days, and the Count two days and two half days, and good, for it is all one in Å¿ubÅ¿tance.
4. For diÅ¿turbing me to take Toll in a Fair or Market, 9 Hen. 6.45. 21 Hen. 7.16. quaere, for it Å¿eems TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies.
5. For Å¿elling in another place out of the Fair, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 107. A, & B. for thereby the Fair and the profit is leÅ¿Å¿ened.
1. When the Tenant for life or years burns the Deed to him delivered of remainder,Deeds. 9 Edw. 4.53. viz. by the remainder in Ann.
2. When a Deed is loÅ¿t, 34 Hen. 6.4. viz. by negligence; for the Law puniÅ¿heth negligence whereby another is damnified.
3. When the Seal is broken off, 39 Hen. 6.46. Lib. Intra. 7. B. Sect. 1, & 3. either wilfully or negligently.
4. For Deeds Å¿old with the Land, and not delivered upon requeÅ¿t, Lib. Intra. 5. A. Sect. 2. for the agreement is not performed, which the Law creat s.
5. For forging a Statute Staple or Merchant, Nat. br. 96. B. 17 Edw. 3.49. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 115. A, & B. to recompence the party wronged, though the party may alÅ¿o be indicted for it.
6. For forging of a ReleaÅ¿e by which I loÅ¿e my Ward, 39 Edw. 3.13.

FalÅ¿e Return.1. For returning me Å¿ummoned, and thereby Judgment is given by default againÅ¿t me, where I never was Å¿ummoned; but this was after the death of the Summoners, 8 Hen. 6.1. 6 Edw. 4.3.8. 26 AÅ¿Å¿ize 48.
2. For returning a Nichil where I had lands, Nat. br. 93. b. 31 Edw. 3. ProceÅ¿s 55. for I am thereby diÅ¿paraged.
1. For Å¿etting up a new Ferry to the NuÅ¿ance of my Ferry,Ferry. 22 Hen. 6.14. and Å¿o my damage.
2. For threatning me or PaÅ¿Å¿engers, by which I loÅ¿e the profits of my Ferry, 22 Hen. 6.17. pl. 32.
For diÅ¿turbing my Foldage,Foldage. No. Lib. Intr. 14. D. Sect. 12. for by the Foldage my land is made better.
For diÅ¿turbing one to have certain walks in the ForreÅ¿t of Selwood, ForreÅ¿t. Coke 5. part. 76. the CounteÅ¿s of Pembrokes caÅ¿e; for his profit is thereby hindred.
For erecting a Warren or Dove-houÅ¿e this Action lies not, although it be to the NuÅ¿ance of another,Warren. Coke 5. part. 104. B. BoulÅ¿tons caÅ¿e; for they are caÅ¿ual and uncertain profits.
For executing ProceÅ¿s in my Liberty,Liberty. Nat. br. 95. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 103, 104. 5 Edw. 3.150. pl. 20. for my priviledge is thereby abridged.

1. For hindring my light by making a Wood pile, Coke 9 part. 57. B. Alreds caÅ¿e, le Count there,HouÅ¿e. and 58. No. Lib. Intra. 19. B. Å¿ect. 16. 7 Edw. 3.261. pl. 15. Q. if I make it upon my own ground, and for my own private uÅ¿e.
2. For infecting the Air of my Parlour with an HogÅ¿-skin, Coke ibidem; for thereby my health is endangered, which is more to be valued than wealth.
3. With a DyehouÅ¿e, Coke ibid. for they uÅ¿e many offenÅ¿ive Drugs.

Michaelis 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Ward verÅ¿us CheÅ¿hire. The Plaintiff counts that he is Å¿eized in fee of a Kitchin, in parochia Å¿ancti DunÅ¿tani in London, and preÅ¿cribes to have Windows into the BackÅ¿ide of the Defendant, and for his Å¿topping up of maximam partem, &c. port. To action, and upon Not guilty pleaded it was found pro quer. and moved in arreÅ¿t of Judgment.

1. He did not Å¿hew that the Kitchin was ancient; but it was reÅ¿olved, that it was implyed in the PreÅ¿cription; but by Williams this was not material: but Crook Ã¨ contra, by the cuÅ¿tome of the City it may be Å¿topped, if not ancient. Q.
2. For that the quantity was not Å¿hewed, but reÅ¿olved it need not be, Coke 4. part. 49. Com. 249.

3. Neither Å¿hews he the PariÅ¿h in which the BackÅ¿ide is, Å¿ed non allocatur; becauÅ¿e the Å¿topping of the light is the material point, and it was Å¿hewed where that was: and the Plaintiff had judgment. Nota & que C. Ley a ceÅ¿t jour.

Hill. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, Hughes & Keme. A had an ancient houÅ¿e in London, B builds a new one which Å¿tops the light of A; per Curiam, 1. That a man cannot by the cuÅ¿tome of London erect a new houÅ¿e, where there was not one before, to Å¿top the Lights of the ancient houÅ¿e. 2. Upon an ancient Foundation a man may erect a new houÅ¿e, and Å¿top the ancient Lights of his Neighbour; for by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on that his Neighbour erected his houÅ¿e more high, may the other at any time erect his, but he cannot enlarge his in breadth or length to Å¿top the Lights of his Neighbour, vide 22 H. 6.15. Q.
For removing a Plaint out of my Mannor without cauÅ¿e,Mannor. 27 Hen. 6.4. for thereby the profits of my Court are leÅ¿Å¿ened.
For taking an eÅ¿tray within my Mannor or Liberty, 13 Edw. 3. breve 674. 31 Edw. 3. breve 333. but ibidem, it lies not before Å¿eiÅ¿ure of the Å¿tray, for before the Lord was not intituled unto it.

For removing a MeerÅ¿tone, though one of them be Tenant in Common,MeerÅ¿tone. 1 Hen. 5.1. Lib. Intra. 9. C. Å¿ect. 1. for thereby part of the Land may be endangered to be loÅ¿t, and Suits may thereby ariÅ¿e touching the extent of the Lands.

1. For diÅ¿turbing my CuÅ¿tomers to come to my Mill,Mill. 11 Hen. 4.47. 41 Edw. 3.24. 29 Edw. 3.18. 9
Hen. 6.45. for thereby my Toll is leÅ¿Å¿ened.
2. For erecting a new Mill, Lib. Intra. 9. B. Sect. 2, D. Å¿ect. 1. Q. if it be not to the hindrance of an ancient Mill.
1. For diÅ¿turbing to take Å¿eiÅ¿ure of an Office,Office. 6 Edw. 3.9. for till Å¿eiÅ¿ure he cannot receive the profits thereof.
2. For diÅ¿turbing the Steward to hold Court, Lib. Intra. 5. B. Sect. 1. Q. whether it may be brought by the Lord and the Steward alÅ¿o? It Å¿eems it may, for both may be damnified.
3. For diÅ¿turbing to take the profits which belong to the office, 9 Rich. 2. Action Å¿ur caÅ¿e, 5. for there is apparent dammage.
4. AgainÅ¿t an EÅ¿cheator that returns contrary to that which was found by office, 9 Hen. 6.60. for by the falÅ¿e return the party concerned may be damnified.

5. If he make a return where no office was found, 21 Edw. 4.23, & 27. for he is not a Judge, but Officer, 9 Hen. 6.60. viz. to return the EnqueÅ¿t found by the Jury, and not to judge of himÅ¿elf how the Lands were held.
6. For procuring a falÅ¿e Office to be found by which my Land is Å¿eiÅ¿ed, 47 Edw. 3.15. Kitcbin 175. A. for my Inheritance is thereby made worÅ¿e by reaÅ¿on of the tenure. This is now otherwiÅ¿e.
For erecting of a DyhouÅ¿e which poyÅ¿ons my water, by reaÅ¿on where of my FiÅ¿h dies,PiÅ¿cary. Coke 9. part. 59. A. Aldreds caÅ¿e; and Å¿o is it for infecting the Air thereby. vid. antea.
Procurement.1. For releaÅ¿ing to me with warranty, and procuring another to Å¿ue me, 34 Edw. 3.20. for this is fraudulent dealing.
1. AgainÅ¿t Tenant in a Precipe,Protection. which hath protection allowed to WeÅ¿tm. for one year, and within the year he Å¿tays at GlouceÅ¿ter, 15 Edw. 4. Q.

If I Å¿ue a SchoolmaÅ¿ter for erecting a School in the Å¿ame Town the Action lies not;School. for it is no NuÅ¿ance, 11 Hen. 4.47. pl. 21. 22 Hen. 6.14. priÅ¿ott. and it is for the good of the weal publick, which is to be preferred before any ones private profit.

S â¢ ander of my Title.If A Å¿ays that B hath right in my Land for years an Action lies, Coke 1. part. 177. Mildmay â¢
caÅ¿e, No. Lib. Intra. 30. A. Sect. 27. but I ought to Å¿hew how I am prejudiced particularly, elÅ¿e there appears no cauÅ¿e of Action.

A brought an Action upon the caÅ¿e againÅ¿t B, becauÅ¿e that he publiÅ¿hed, that he had the leaÅ¿e of the Land of A, and that he intended to Å¿ell it and was hindred; B Å¿aid, that he had an Indenture as in the Count is mentioned, and traverÅ¿eth that he forged it, 1. when B claims a right, though he had none, yet the Action lies not, for it may be he thought he had a right, and Å¿o there cannot be Å¿aid any malice. 2. The Count is good, becauÅ¿e it is that it was againÅ¿t the knowledge of B that it was forged. 3. Sciens is not traverÅ¿able, Coke 4. part. 18. A. caÅ¿e 14.
1. For Å¿topping a Ditch,Land. by which my Land is Å¿urrounded, Nat. br. 88. E, 89. M. 39 Hen. 6.32. 11 Hen. 4.82. 14 Hen. 8.31. for the Land is thereby made worÅ¿e, elÅ¿e it will not lie.
For not Å¿couring a Ditch, by which my Land is overflown, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 100. A. Non-feaÅ¿ance is puniÅ¿hable as well as a MisfeaÅ¿ance.
For breaking of a Seabank, by which my land is Å¿urrounded, Nat. br. 86. F, 89. B, & C. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 95. A. vid. antea.

It lies not for erecting of Coney-burroughs, by which I loÅ¿e the profits of my Land, becauÅ¿e the party had no property in them, Coke 5. part. 104. BoulÅ¿tons caÅ¿e; and I may take them upon my land and juÅ¿tifie it. vid. antea.

1. If one hath the trade of a BakehouÅ¿e by preÅ¿cription for the whole Town,Trade. and another erects another and Å¿ells, and Action lies, Coke 8. part. 125. caÅ¿e of London, 19 Rich. 2. Action Å¿ur CaÅ¿e 52. The Law favours Ancient rights, for it tends much to peace.
2. For uÅ¿ing the trade of a Dyer in R without LicenÅ¿e of the ArchbiÅ¿hop of York, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105, & 106. Coke ibidem; for the priviledge of the BiÅ¿hop is thereby impaired.

3. The King grants to A the Å¿ole faiÅ¿ance of play-cards, yet A Å¿hall not have an Action upon the caÅ¿e againÅ¿t others that uÅ¿e the trade, becauÅ¿e the grant is void, Coke 11. part. 86. A. Monopolies; for it is a Monopoly which is againÅ¿t the publick good, and the liberty of the Subject.

Tenant at will makes voluntary waÅ¿te,WaÅ¿te. an Action of waÅ¿te lies againÅ¿t him, Littleton 15. A. 14. Hen. 8.12. Brown. Coke 15 part. B. Salops caÅ¿e, 48 Edw. 3.25. Dyer 121. pl. 17. 11 Hen. 6.38. and not an Action on the CaÅ¿e.

For diverting of part of the Å¿tream by the owner of the Land, by which the Å¿tream flows over,WatercourÅ¿e. 12 Hen. 4.47. 21 Hen. 7.30. Dyer 248. pl. 80. Coke 4. part. 86. Lutterels caÅ¿e the Count there. 3 Eliz. Dyer 195. pl. 37.
But for diverting majoris partis AÅ¿Å¿ize lies, 8 Eliz. Dyer 248. pl. 80. but this is intended when the Mill cannot go, for that is prejudicial to the Freehold.

For Å¿topping a Pit that one hath for water, although it is not a common watering-place,Watering-places. 21 Hen. 7.35. No. Lib. Intra. 18. D. Å¿ect. 15. for thereby I that digged it loÅ¿t my labour and eaÅ¿ement.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: Ought to be certain as the Count, except in the place and time, 22 Hen. 7.91. which in this actio â¢ are not traverÅ¿able.

It ought to have the Å¿ame certainty as the Count, and to have the effect of all the Count except the year and day, the quantity and certainty of the Land, 38 Hen. 6.9. pl. 20. PriÅ¿ottâª for the Land comes not in queÅ¿tion. Q.
The Writ Å¿hall not be vi & armis, Nat. br. 92. E. for it Å¿uppoÅ¿eth not the breach of the publick Peace, but only a particular dammage.

When there are two cauÅ¿es of Actions, 1. cauÅ¿ â¢ cauÅ¿ans, 2. cauÅ¿a cauÅ¿ata, the former may be alledged vi & armis, Coke 9. part. 50. B. Salopâª caÅ¿e: For that is but as an inducement to the cauÅ¿e of action, upon which the Action is brought.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s, 1. before appearance; 2. after.
div.p: At Common Law a Capias lieth not, 43 Edw. 3.11. Coke 10. part. 72. A. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey; for liberty was preferred before private wrongs, which concerned the eÅ¿tate only.
But 10 Hen. 7. cap. 9. Å¿uch proceÅ¿s is given in an Action Å¿ur le CaÅ¿e in Ban. Regis & Com. Ban. as for TreÅ¿paÅ¿s or debt, Br. exigend. 29. vid. the Statute.

div.head: The Judgment.
div.p: For not repairing of a Bridge per quod, &c. the judgment Å¿hall be to recover dammages to the party damnified, and a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s to the Sheriff to compel the Defendant to repair to prevent further dammage to any.

div.head: For what things it lies.
div.p: ChaÅ¿ing Sheep.1. For chaÅ¿ing Sheep into the water, 2 Hen. 7.11. B. Q. if the Sheep be not hurt by it, if it do not lie? It Å¿eems not.
2. For taking of Sheep delivered to me for a year to dung my Land, Nat. 26. B, & D. Q. for I thereby am damnified.
1. AgainÅ¿t him that I give money to give to my Attorney, and he gives it to my adverÅ¿ary, 20 Hen. 7.9. for here is breach of truÅ¿t by which I am damnified.

For goods lent, and are waÅ¿ted.2. If I lend my Plate or other goods to one, and he waÅ¿tes them, or miÅ¿uÅ¿eth them, or converts them to his own uÅ¿e, 27 Hen. 8.25. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 137. 20 Hen. 7.4. 2 Hen. 7.11. 2 Edw. 4.5. 18 Edw. 4.23. 21 Edw. 4.19. Crook, 2 Hen. 8.160. pl. 2. For here the Law creates a truÅ¿t and Covenant, which is broken.
3. If againÅ¿t a Baily that cuts my Trees, or kills my Cows, 18 Edw. 4.23. Q.
4. If a Baily lend them to B. and he waÅ¿tes them, it lies againÅ¿t B. 12 Edw. 4.13. for the Bally might lend them.
5. AgainÅ¿t my Butler that breaks my Hanaper, 18 Edw. 4.27. Now it is Felony by the Statute, Q.
6. Upon bailment of a Bag, in which was 20 l. and he breaks the Seal, 21 Edw. 4.30 pl. 25.
7. So for an obligation, 39 Hen. 6.46. for I may be damnified thereby.
8. AgainÅ¿t a Baily of BeaÅ¿ts, which kills them, Littleton 15. A. Dyer 121. pl. 17. 14 Hen. 8.12. for he hath no Å¿uch Authority quatenus a Baily.

Goods not delivered.The Executor comes to the Heir 31 days after the death of the TeÅ¿tator, and demands the goods that are in the houÅ¿e, and he refuÅ¿es to deliver them; 1. this is a convenient time, 2. this wrong is puniÅ¿hable. Mich. 7. Jac. Ban. Regis, Steedmans caÅ¿e; for thereby the execution of the will is retarded.

Wood and EÅ¿tovers.1. A Å¿old 20 cords of Wood to B to have by aÅ¿Å¿ignment, and afterward Å¿old 4000 to C to have at his election, and aÅ¿Å¿igns to B, which he Å¿hall cut, and C takes them, B Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t C, for the firÅ¿t bargain was made with him, Coke 5. part 24. Palmers caÅ¿e.
2. Tenant for years Å¿hall have EÅ¿tovers in the Wood of B which Å¿hall be cut, or have an Action, Coke 9. part. 112. B. Mayers caÅ¿e; if he be hindred.
1. AgainÅ¿t a Carrier that breaks Pots and GlaÅ¿Å¿es, 2 Hen. 7.2.Carrier. for this is a misfeaÅ¿ance in the Carriage, which the Law implies ought to be Å¿afely.

2. If the things be delivered to the Servant of the Carrier, yet an Action lies againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wornhall & BradÅ¿haw;
For the MaÅ¿ter muÅ¿t anÅ¿wer for the misfeaÅ¿ance of his Servant.

A HorÅ¿e.1. For delivering a HorÅ¿e to B for Å¿aÅ¿eguard, who delivers him to C, to the uÅ¿e of A, who Å¿poils him, A Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t C. 12 Edw. 4.13. pl 9. Q. for the HorÅ¿e was delivered for the benefit of A.

2. AgainÅ¿t a Smith that pricks my HorÅ¿e, Nat. br. 94. D. vide the Writ there, 17 Edw. 4.43. 11 Edw. 4.6. 46 Edw. 3.19. 3 Hen. 6.36. 14 Hen. 6.18. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 106. A. 48 Edw. 3.6. pl. 11. For misfeaÅ¿ance, for the Law implies he ought to be skilful and careful.
And if the Smith lends the HorÅ¿e to another, who pricks him, Action lies againÅ¿t the Å¿econd, 12 Edw. 4.13. Q. if it lies not alÅ¿o againÅ¿t the Smith.

A Servant brought a HorÅ¿e to the Smith, who pricked him, by which the Å¿ervice of the MaÅ¿ter is neglected, the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have an Action, Hill. Jac. Ban. Regis, for the dammage comes only to the MaÅ¿ter.
For taking my Pigeons with engines,Pigeons. 16 Edw. 4.7. or Å¿hooting of them. Q.
Dice and Cards.For playing with falÅ¿e Dice, Nat. br. 95. D. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 240. No. Lib. Intr. 8. Å¿ect. 8. or for cheating with true.
The Å¿ame law of falÅ¿e Cards, Coke 11. part. 87. B. Monopolies; for the Law puniÅ¿hes fraud in all things.

1. For diÅ¿training of a HorÅ¿e of a Prelate,DiÅ¿treÅ¿s. when he had other things diÅ¿trainable, Nat. br. 93. I. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 100. B. Coke 4. part. 95. A. Slades caÅ¿e; in reÅ¿pect of uÅ¿efulneÅ¿s of him above
other goods, and his damage for want of him. Q. tamen.
2. For diÅ¿training in a High-way, or in any Spiritual Land belonging to a Church, againÅ¿t the Articles of the Clerks, 94 E. RegiÅ¿t. 100. B.
3. For diÅ¿training one to come to my Leet, when he owed no Å¿uit to my Leet, Nat. br. 94. G. for the diÅ¿training was unlawful.
For diÅ¿training Cows, and then impounding them till they caÅ¿t their Calves, Nat. br. 86. E. Q. if the diÅ¿treÅ¿s was not abuÅ¿ed, if it lie.

For diÅ¿training Cattel of the plough, or Lambs, where there was other Å¿ufficient diÅ¿treÅ¿s, Lib. Intra. 226. D. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, the Writ there, Nat. br. 90. B. for a mans lively hood is favoured in Law, and alÅ¿o tillage. Q. if the Lambs be weaned.
The Count Å¿hall not Å¿hew that there was other Å¿ufficient diÅ¿treÅ¿s, but it Å¿hall be contra forman Statuti, which provides againÅ¿t Å¿uch diÅ¿training, 14 Eliz. Dyer 312. pl. 86.
And it lies when the Tenant hath made agreement for the Rent, and yet is diÅ¿trained, 18 Edw. 2. quaere.
For diÅ¿training in a Liberty where the Contract was not made, RegiÅ¿t. orig. A. per le Stat. WeÅ¿tm. 1. cap. 34. which directs where DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es ought to be taken.

EÅ¿cape from a Goaler.By a Goaler againÅ¿t a PriÅ¿oner that eÅ¿capes being committed per Auditors, Nat. br. 95. C. 130. B. the Writ there; for the Goaler is liable, and therefore it is reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould have remedy againÅ¿t the party.
For tearing an Obligation delivered to be kept,Deeds. 30 Hen. 6.44. Lib. Intra. 7. B. Å¿ect. 1. for this is breach of truÅ¿t.
The Defendant pleads, it was delivered in the nature of an Acquittance abÅ¿que hoc, that it was, &c. Lib. Intra. 7. B. Å¿ect. 2.
AgainÅ¿t a Ferry-man that Å¿urcharges his Boat,Ferryman. by which my HorÅ¿e is drowned, 22 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41. for I am damnified by his misfeaÅ¿ance.
Forgery & Counterfeiting.1. For forging of an Obligation that is put in Å¿uit againÅ¿t me, 5 Edw. 4.126. pl. 44. Coke 4. part. 18. B. caÅ¿e 14. 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8. for the private dammage done me thereby.
2. For forging of a ReÅ¿ignation, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 114. B.
3. For forging of a Will, 5 Edw. 4 120. B.

4. For counterfeiting a Letter in the name of his MaÅ¿ter, that the Plaintiff would Å¿end his MaÅ¿ter 20 l. upon which the Plaintiff delivered 20 l. to the Defendant, 33 Hen. 8. cap. 1. PaÅ¿ch. 7. Jac. Ban. Regis, Tracy verÅ¿us Veale alias Smith. In all theÅ¿e caÅ¿es an Indictment doth alÅ¿o lie, becauÅ¿e it is contra pacem.
For taking away a ward,Guard. he Å¿hall have a value of the marriage, 29 AÅ¿Å¿ize 35. and not this Action, by a Writ de valore maritagii.
For putting Å¿omething in my Ditch, whereby my grain is drowned, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 95. B. 97. A. Grain drowned. and thereby made worÅ¿e; elÅ¿e Q. whether it lie or no.
For menacing to take my goods,Menace. if I do not give him 20 l. 7 Edw. 42. Q.
For taking away my Pales,Pales. quaere whether TreÅ¿paÅ¿s vi & armis doth not lie, 15 Edw. 4.4. Choke.
For putting in a common River piles,Piles. by which my Oxen periÅ¿h, Nat. br. 92. F. otherwiÅ¿e it Å¿eems it lies not.
For taking my goods after protection to me granted,Protection. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 12. A. Q. for I may plead my Protection upon a Replevin.
By a Sheriff againÅ¿t one that reÅ¿cued one in Execution,ReÅ¿cous. Dyer 24. 1. pl. 47. for the Sheriff is thereby in hazard to pay the debt.
1. For taking my Servant out of my Å¿ervice,Servants. 19 Rich. 2. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 52. for it is to my prejudice in the intendment of the Law.
Not his Servant is a good plea in bar,Bar. 20 Hen. 7.4. pl. 13. Fineux; of the Action for the Defendant to plead, viz. tempore Captionis.
2. For inticing my Servant to depart,Servant. and him to retain, 11 Hen. 4.23. for this is fraudulent and unconÅ¿cionable.
3. For beating my Servant, though he Å¿erve me but for pleaÅ¿ure, 21 Hen. 6.9. for I receive profit by his Å¿ervice, and do loÅ¿e it by beating of him.

But he ought to count per quod he loÅ¿t his Service, Coke 9 part. 113. A. Mayers caÅ¿e, 18 Edw. 4.27. pl. 24. 2 Hen. 4.12. pl. 49. 28 Hen. 6.14. and there was omitted this word per and yet good, for the Å¿enÅ¿e was good without it.
And if the Plaintiff have a Verdict and doth not count as aforeÅ¿aid, he Å¿hall never have judgment, Crooke 21 Hen. 7.71. pl. 15. becauÅ¿e it doth not appear he had cauÅ¿e to bring his Action.
But he need not count of the retainer, 21 Hen. 6.31. pl. 18. 22 Hen. 6.30. B, & 43. B. 31 Hen. 6.12. pl. 2. for if he was not his Servant the Defendant may traverÅ¿e it.
4. For menacing my Servant, per quod, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 94. B. for the loÅ¿s of the Å¿ervice is the main cauÅ¿e of the Action.
5. For aÅ¿Å¿ault and battery of my Servant, per quod, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. A. Nat. br. 91. vide the count Lib. Intra. 613. B. Å¿ect. 19 674. C. Å¿ect. 1.
6. For aÅ¿Å¿ault and battery, and impriÅ¿onment, till the Plaintiff made fine, per quod damnificatus, &c. 19 Hen. 6.35. pl. 37.
7. For battery, mayheme and impriÅ¿onment, per quod damnificatus, &c. Crooke 7. Hen. 8.180. pl. 4.
8. When his Dog bites my Servant, per quod, &c. RegiÅ¿t. 111. A. Å¿ervitium amiÅ¿i; but then he muÅ¿t count that kept him, knowing him to be accuÅ¿tomed to bite.
A good plea to the Writ, that it was his Wife that was bitten, 7 Rich. 2. traverÅ¿e 206. for then his Count is falÅ¿e.
So, that it was his Farmor, 13 Rich. 2. traverÅ¿e 210.
So, that it was his Prentice; Q. for a Prentice is a Servant, 2 Hen. 6.31. pl. 18.
So, that it was his Companion, 37 Hen. 6.7. pl. 13.
AgainÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or that outs the Executors of the Term left to the TeÅ¿tator,Term. Nat. br. 92. G. Q. whether an ejectment doth not lie.
And the Writ is there by Summons not per pone per vadios, &c. Summons is the ancienter ProceÅ¿s.

div.head: For doing of wrong to the damage of another touching his body.
div.p: Lying in wait.For lying in wait to kill me or take me as his Villain, Å¿o that I dare not go about my buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, 2 Edw. 4.5. 17 Edw. 4.4. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 101, 102.
Crooke 13 Hen. 7.26, 27. 2 Hen. 7.12. pl. 15. Coke 4. part. 18. A. caÅ¿e 14. for the Law highly prizeth life and liberty.

Note, Actio quod metus cauÅ¿a fuit, datur ei qui probabili metu rem Å¿uam tradidit, vendidit vel promiÅ¿it, verÅ¿us cum qui metum intulit, & dicitur metus probabilis qui in virum conÅ¿tantem cadere poÅ¿Å¿it, & non in hominem meticuloÅ¿um, Bracton, lib. 3. cap. 4. fol. 103. B. It muÅ¿t be Å¿ure grounded on a reaÅ¿onable cauÅ¿e of fear.
1. For arreÅ¿ting me in the name of B, ArreÅ¿t. without his conÅ¿ent, 7 Hen. 6 43. pl. 19. for it may be he would not have arreÅ¿ted me, though he had cauÅ¿e.
2. For arreÅ¿ting me without cauÅ¿e, 8 Edw. 4.13.
But this ought to be by colluÅ¿ion to vex me, 43 Edw. 3.20. for if there be probabilis cauÅ¿a it lies not, for one may be deceived in the Law.
3. For arreÅ¿ting me to appear in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, where I was not Å¿ued, 3 Hen. 6. eÅ¿toppel 18. 10 Hen. 6.13. 7 Hen. 6.30. for this is vexatious.
4. For arreÅ¿ting me in London, knowing I was priviledged in Bank, 7 Hen. 6.45. for I am debarr'd of my priviledge, and put to more trouble.
5. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff for returning me nibil where I had lands, by which I was taken per Capias, Nat. br. 93. b. 31 Edw. 3. ProceÅ¿s 55. for his falÅ¿e return to my prejudice.

For arreÅ¿ting me and bringing me before a JuÅ¿tice, where I was indicted and acquitted, and this is good cauÅ¿e of Action although the time of the arreÅ¿t is not Å¿hewed, becauÅ¿e of the vexation, Trin. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Olivers caÅ¿e, which is the
cauÅ¿e of the Action, and the time is not material.

If one exhibit Articles to a JuÅ¿tice of Peace againÅ¿t B, Articles. to have him bound to his good Behaviour, no Action lies for this, becauÅ¿e it is in courÅ¿e of JuÅ¿tice, Coke 4. part. 14. B. But quaere if the Articles be falÅ¿e.

For putting Irons and putting in the Stocks,Goaler. and giving little Å¿uÅ¿tenance to one committed for Debt, or Arrearages in Account, Nat. br. 83 H. for the Law warrants it not, and the Law hates cruelty.
For procuring another to be indicted without cauÅ¿e,Indictment. Nat. br. 114. D. 116. A. viz. probable cauÅ¿e.

For procuring B to be indicted for a common Barector, and he is acquitted Å¿ecundum Leges Angliae, 1. good, although that the Count was not, that he was lawfully acquitted, for it is Å¿o implied; 2. he ought to have Counted quod inde acquietatus fuit, or words that do amount to Å¿o much, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Rott. 407. Bell verÅ¿us Gamble; for elÅ¿e there appears no cauÅ¿e of Action.

For threatning by word or writing to beat me,Menace. if I come out of my houÅ¿e, 17 Edw. 3.4. vide Bracton, lib. 3. cap. 4. fol. 1.13. B. for I am thereby hindered in my occaÅ¿ions, and Å¿o damnified.
For threatning another of life and member, 10 Edw. 4 6. the Writ and Count, Lib. Intra. 661. B. Å¿ect. 1, 2. for he thereby goes in fear, and Å¿o the Peace is diÅ¿turbed.

For putting poyÅ¿on in my meat,Poy â¢â¢â¢
âª
RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. A. wittingly, to the hazard of my life or health.

AgainÅ¿t a Chirurgion that impairs the body by his Medicine, 21 Hen. 6.55. 11 Rich. 2. Action upon the caÅ¿e 37. For it is either a misfeaÅ¿ance of ignorance or of malice, both which are puniÅ¿hable on thoÅ¿e that undertake a truÅ¿t and skill.

div.head: For doing a thing to the damage of another touching his Name, which is Slander; for it turns to his prejudice.
div.p: Dicitur quod Å¿candaloÅ¿um eÅ¿t generale verbum, Slander. and Å¿ignifies that which one does to the overthrow of anothers credit and repute; therefore it is conceived, that if the words are Å¿poken to the wrong of another, an Action lies, Kitchin 173. for the intended injury.

Fit autem injuria non Å¿olum cum quis pugno percuÅ¿Å¿us fuit, verberatus, vulneratus, vel fuÅ¿tibus ceÅ¿us, verum cum ei convitium dictum fuit, vel de eo factum crimen famoÅ¿um, & hujuÅ¿modi. Bracton, lib. 3. fol. 155. A.
There are two kinds of defamations, Spiritual and Temporal, Nat. br. 55.

Note, when words are not Å¿poken adjectively, if they touch one in his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion or Trade they are actionable, otherwiÅ¿e not, Coke 4. part. 19. caÅ¿e 15. Q. Adjective words are incertain, and Å¿ignifie nothing poÅ¿itively or directly affirmative.

AlÅ¿o if they imply or preÅ¿ume an illoyal act, viz. againÅ¿t the publick Peace, then an Action lies although they are Å¿poken adjectively; but if they imply an intention only, then an Action lies not, Coke 4. part. 19. B. caÅ¿e 15. for the Law puniÅ¿heth not Intentions, except it be in caÅ¿es of TreaÅ¿on.

It lies not for calling one Adulterer,Adulterer. becauÅ¿e it belongs to the Spiritual Court, 27 Hen. 8.17. Coke 4. part. 17. caÅ¿e 11. but now it doth, becauÅ¿e Adultery is made death by a late Statute.

1. For calling a man Bankrupt it lies not,Bankrupt. unleÅ¿s a man be a Merchant, or uÅ¿e a Trade, or get his living by buying and Å¿elling, PaÅ¿ch. 40 Eliz. B â¢ ckard & ConÅ¿table; it was there doubted, then one CaÅ¿e was cited in Ban. Regis, that it did not lie.
2. For Å¿aying that B will be a Bankrupt within two days, it lies, 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 72. pl. 6. Coke 4. part. fol. 19. for he is impaired in his credit, for none will truÅ¿t one that is likely to break.

3. A Å¿hews that he was a Shoemaker, and did uÅ¿e to buy and Å¿ell per 10 years; the Defendant Å¿aid that he was a Bankrupt, and this was good although he did not Å¿hew that he was a Shoemaker for 10 years, for it is implied in that he Å¿aid, he uÅ¿ed to buy and Å¿ell per 10 years, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Dayet, Chandler.
4. For calling a Merchant Bankrupt-Knave it lies, becauÅ¿e it toucheth him in his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, Coke 4. part. 19. A, & B. in both the words.
1. For calling one BaÅ¿tard, if he be an Heir,BaÅ¿tard. No. Lib. Intr. 28. Å¿ect. 25. Trin. 25 Eliz. Ban. Regis. Q. if he be not an Heir, and no Å¿pecial damage laid.
2. A intends to preÅ¿ent B to a Church, and C Å¿ays that he is a BaÅ¿tard, by which he is not preÅ¿ented, B Å¿hall have an Action, Coke 4. part. 17. caÅ¿e 11. for here is a particular damage laid.

For calling one Bawd it lies not,Bawd. 27 Hen. 8. Kitchin 173. becauÅ¿e it belongs to the Spiritual Court. âif it be Å¿poken in London it lies;
And me Å¿eems the Å¿ame Law, if it be in the Countrey.

A Å¿aid to B your Attorney is a bribing Knave,Bribery. Action lies becauÅ¿e it toucheth him in his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, Mich. 11 Jac. Com. Ban. Yardly & Ellil. Q. For a bribing Knave is one properly that gives bribes, and not a taker of bribes; but that is not fair practiÅ¿e.
A Å¿aid of an Attorney, you are well known to be a corrupt man, and to deal corruptly, Action lies, Coke 4. part. 16. caÅ¿e 6. for he is Å¿candalized in his profeÅ¿Å¿ion.
For calling a man Common MiÅ¿Å¿eaÅ¿or or Barector,Barector. it lies not, Kitchin 173. A. vide 22 AÅ¿Å¿iz. 43. Q. tamen of the word Barector.
1. For calling a man CouÅ¿ener it lies not,CouÅ¿ener. Coke 4. part. 15. B. Q.

2. Thou art a CouÅ¿ening Knave, and haÅ¿t couÅ¿ened my two kinÅ¿men of Land worth 6000 l. and I will bring thee to Å¿tand upon the Pillory for it, the Action lies not, Kitchin 173. B. Q. tamen, for for calling one Cheater lately adjudged actionable in B. S. in ParkhurÅ¿t and Bramptons caÅ¿e, by Glon. Chief JuÅ¿tice.
3. A is a CouÅ¿ening Knave, and I have proved him a CouÅ¿ening Knave for Å¿elling me a Saphir for a Diamond, it lies not, Kitchin 174. A. Q. if the words were Å¿poken of a GoldÅ¿mith or Jeweller.

4. If Sir John S. might have his will, he would kill all true Subjects and the King, and he is a maintainer of PapiÅ¿ts and Rebellious perÅ¿ons; upon Not guilty the Jury found that he Å¿aid, I think in my ConÅ¿cience ut Å¿upra, &c. 1. the words are actionable, for Å¿candalum dicitur quod parit ruinam
vel occaÅ¿ionem ruinae, 2. the Jury found the Å¿ubÅ¿tance and no variance, Mich. 14 Jac. Regis, Sydenham & May; one muÅ¿t not tell his thoughts to prejudice another.
Thou art an Enemy to the State of this Realm, an Action lies, Hill. 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. Hooknell & Smith. Q. tamen, for the words Å¿eem very dubious.

It lies for writing a Libel in a paper,Slander in writing. and affixing it to the Church-door, by which I am to enter, 17 Edw. 4.3. Lib. Intr. 13 B. Å¿ect. 4. for it is in effect Å¿peaking of Scandalous words.
FalÅ¿e JuÅ¿tice.For calling one falÅ¿e JuÅ¿tice of Peace it lies, 4 Edw. 6.22. if Å¿poken in relation to his Office.
FalÅ¿e Knave.It lies not for calling a man falÅ¿e Knave, Kitchin 173. B. for the word Knave is a general word, and a word of heat.
FalÅ¿e Å¿uit.1. It lies not for Å¿uing a man for Forgery, 11 Eliz. Dyer 245.
BecauÅ¿e for falÅ¿e Action Å¿equitur nulla poena, 2 Rich. 3.9. for if the Action be falÅ¿e the Defendant Å¿hall have his damage pro falÅ¿o clamore.
For this is in courÅ¿e of JuÅ¿tice, Coke 4. part. 14. B. And if it would lie, men would be terrified from puniÅ¿hing Vice.

2. But if one be Å¿ued in the Star-chamber for a thing not examinable, there an Action lies, Coke 4. part. 14. B. caÅ¿e 3. No. Lib. Intr. 23. B. Å¿ect. 21. For Actions are to be brought in the Courts proper to try them, and not in Arbitrary Courts. Ergo Q. whether an Action upon the CaÅ¿e doth not lie for Å¿uing in Chancery, where a plain Action lies at the Common Law.
3. But if one bring an Appeal in Com. Ban. it lies not, becauÅ¿e this is in the nature of a Legal Å¿uit, though brought in a wrong Court.
1. For calling a Judge a Felon,Felon. 30 AÅ¿Å¿ize 19. Kitchin 173. A. for Felony is Capital.
It lies for Å¿aying that one had forged a Deed,Forger. 11 Eliz. Dyer 285. for Forgery is indictable.

1. For calling one Heretick it lies not,Heretick. becauÅ¿e it properly belongs to the Spiritual Court, 27 Hen. 4.17. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 54. Coke 5. part. 57. B. Specotts caÅ¿e. And the Common Law Courts ought not to entrench upon the Spiritual Courts; nec i contra.
2. But if one Å¿aid of a Divine that he is a Heretick, by which he loÅ¿eth his Benefice or PreÅ¿entation, Action lies, Coke 4. part. 17. caÅ¿e 11. for there is a temporal loÅ¿s.
1. For calling one Thief an Action lies, 27 Hen. 8. 14 Eliz. Dyer. 236.Thief. pl. 26. Lib. Intr. 12. D. Å¿ect. 2. Hill. 4 Eliz. Com. Ban. Reques caÅ¿e, Dyer 9. pl. 112.
Common voice and Å¿ame is not Å¿ufficient to call a man Thief, 26 Hen. 8.9. Dyer 236. pl. 26. for it may be falÅ¿e.
But he may juÅ¿tifie that the Plaintiff Å¿tole Å¿heep, Mich. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. CuddinÅ¿ton & Wilkins, or any other thing; the Å¿tealing whereof is Felony, or pety Larceny.
For calling one Thief, and cauÅ¿ing him to be indicted where he was acquitted, 27 Hen. 8.11. Lib. Intr. 12. D. Sect. 2. Q. if the matter was Å¿uÅ¿picious.
For Å¿aying that A had Å¿tole Å¿heep, 27 Hen. 8.22.
For Å¿aying that A Å¿tole Sheep of B, 26 Hen. 8.9. pl. 11.

A is a falÅ¿e Knave, and was at my houÅ¿e on the SeÅ¿Å¿ions day at night, and would have robbed me, and did break my doors, and did put me in jeopardy of my life, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer pl. 171. for the words are very Å¿candalous, though they Å¿eem very general.
A is infected with Å¿uch a Robbery that he doth Å¿mell of it, 14 Eliz. Dyer 317. pl. 8. 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 72. pl. 6. for it implies that he was acceÅ¿Å¿ory to it.
There is a neÅ¿t of Thieves at B, and C is the maintainer of them, and is a Å¿trong Thief, Dyer 75. pl. 2. Q. if the firÅ¿t words alone are actionable.

Men cannot have their Cattel go up and down the Common, but B and his Children will kill them with Barbers Dog, no Action lies, Dyer 118. pl. 79. for the words are not Å¿candalous, and they are general and incertain.

Thou art a Steal-gown, and the firÅ¿t Gown that thou diddeÅ¿t wear thou Å¿tolleÅ¿t, and then diddeÅ¿t walk up and down in thy Å¿tollen Gown, and haddeÅ¿t no Gown until thou diddeÅ¿t Å¿teal one, Action lies, No. Lib. Intr. 22. D. Å¿ect. 20. becauÅ¿e there is a particular act of Theft Å¿et forth.

Thou art a Thief, for thou Å¿tolleÅ¿t my Sons goods, Action lies without averring that he had goods, PaÅ¿ch. 38 Eliz. Com. Ban. Elin. & Moore; for it Å¿hall be intended he had goods without an averment.

My MaÅ¿ter B hath robbed me of all my goods, Action lies without averring that he was his Servant,
for this is AÅ¿Å¿ets certain, Mich. 15 Jac. Bun. Regis, Brown & Low; for MaÅ¿ter and Servant are relata, poÅ¿ito uno ponitur alterum.

B burned my Barn, (innuendo) a Barn of Corn, Action lies not; for it is not Å¿hewed a Barn with Corn, nor that it was parcel of the ManÅ¿ion-houÅ¿e, and the innuendo cannot aid it, Coke 4. part. 20. caÅ¿e 16. No. Lib. Intra. 24. D. Å¿ect. 22. for a Bar â¢ may be without Corn, and not be parcel of ãâã ManÅ¿ion-houÅ¿e.

A hath Å¿tollen my Wood, Action lies, for wool cannot be intended Trees growing, PaÅ¿ch. 38 Elit. Com. Ban. Arbor dum creÅ¿cit, lignum dum creÅ¿ce â¢
neÅ¿cit.
A doth or will prepare to Rob me, Action lie â¢ for this tends to the ruine of A, Mich. 14 Jac. Re â¢ Sydenham & May. Q. tamen, for the words a â¢ very incertain.

A calls B Thief, and juÅ¿tifies that he Å¿tole Å¿heet B pleads the General pardon after the words Å¿poken, the Action lies, for by the Pardon the wo â¢â¢ Thief is taken away, Mich. 13 Jac. Com. B â¢â¢ Cuddingtons caÅ¿e, and Wilkens. Q. for it Å¿ee â¢â¢ hard Law, there being good cauÅ¿e to juÅ¿tifie at the time of the words Å¿poken.

Thou didÅ¿t Å¿ert on me on the High-way, and didÅ¿t take away from me my PurÅ¿e, and I will be Å¿worn to it, Action lies, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Regi â¢ Stoner & Holland; for it implies Felony, que â¢ tamen.
1. For calling one Leper or Leprous Knave Action lies,Leper. Intr. Taylor & Baggs; for thereb men will avoid his company, & homo eÅ¿t anims Å¿ociabile.
For LeproÅ¿us extra communionem poÅ¿itus petere non poteÅ¿t, Bracton, lib. 2. fol. 12. A.
1. For calling one Murtherer, Action lies,Murtherer. 6 Eliz. Dyer 236. pl. 26. Q.
2. Thou haÅ¿t killed my Wife, no Action lies, becauÅ¿e it appears to the Court that Å¿he is alive, Coke 4. part. 16. A. and Å¿o no damage can be by Å¿peaking of the words.

3. Thou didÅ¿t poyÅ¿on thy Husband, Action lies; and yet it was objected, 1. that Å¿he ought to Å¿hew that he was dead, 2. that he died within the year, 3. that it was voluntary, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Gardiners caÅ¿e. Q
4. Thou didÅ¿t poyÅ¿on S, and it Å¿hall coÅ¿t me a 100 l. but I will hang thee for it, Action lies, No. Lib. Intr. 25. C. Å¿ect. 23. The latter words enforce the former.
5. A Å¿aid, that C gave counÅ¿el to B to kill me, it lies not, becauÅ¿e a man is not puniÅ¿hable without an action done in purÅ¿uance of the CounÅ¿el given, Coke 4. part. 16. caÅ¿e 10.
1. For calling one perjured,Perjured. 2 Hen. 8.22. Kitchin 173. yet an Indictment lies for Perjury.
2. But for Å¿aying that he had ForÅ¿worn himÅ¿elf, it lies not; for it might be againÅ¿t his will, or not in a Court of Record, Coke 4. part. 15. A, & B.
UnleÅ¿s he had Å¿aid in Å¿uch a Court of Record, Coke 4. part. 15. B. and then it implies he is perjured, and the words amount to as much.

3. A hath gotten a Mannor by Swearing and ForÅ¿wearing, Action lies not, becauÅ¿e the words are too general, and fix no offence upon the party, Coke 4. part. 15. A, & B. No. Lib. Intr. 21. B. Sect. 18.

4. W is forÅ¿worn and perjured in Swearing at the Common Pleas bar, upon the Deed which he then had in his hand; this Å¿hall not be intended that he Å¿wore upon the Deed, but upon the Book, ergo the Action lies, Hill. 35 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rot. 56. Crowe; for words muÅ¿t have a reaÅ¿onable conÅ¿truction, according to occaÅ¿ion of the Å¿peaking of them.

H is a perjured old Knave in the Court of T, Action lies, for perjury in a Court Baron is puniÅ¿hable per the Statute of 5 Eliz. for the right comes in debate there, & perjurium eÅ¿t jus alie. num pervertere, PaÅ¿ch. 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. Hatchman & Southcotte. But before the Statute quaere whether the words were Actionable or not.

A Å¿ays to B, thou haÅ¿t an old Creeple whore to thy Mother; for which words he Å¿ued him in the Spiritual Court, and produced B for a WitneÅ¿s; A takes exception to him becauÅ¿e he was perjured at the AÅ¿Å¿izes of D in Å¿uch a cauÅ¿e; W for this brought his Action againÅ¿t A, which juÅ¿tifies as aforeÅ¿aid, 1. this was a legal courÅ¿e, viz. to take exception to a WitneÅ¿s; ergo the Action lies not; 2. the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Court may puniÅ¿h perjury, therefore it lies not here, Trin. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, WeÅ¿tover verÅ¿us Dabener.
Thou art perjured, and I will prove it, Action lies, No. Lib. Intr. 26. A. Sect. 24.
For Å¿aying that A was detected of perjury in the Star-chamber, it lies not, becauÅ¿e an honeÅ¿t ma â¢ may be detected, but not convicted, Coke 4. part. 16. caÅ¿e 8. Note the difference.

1. For Å¿aying of an Innholder,Plague. that he had buried divers of the Plague that died in his houÅ¿e in
his Garden, Action lies, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 173. B. for by the Å¿peaking Å¿uch words he is in danger to loÅ¿e his GueÅ¿ts. But quaere if he ought to alledge, that he is damnified thereby.

M is a Whore and hath the Pox,Pox. and they have made Å¿uch holes in her that you may turn your finger in them, and K the Chirurgion hath given her a Diet drink to heal them, take heed how you drink with her, Action lies; 1. for calling her Whore, and this is the cauÅ¿e of the Pox, 2. the cure is publiÅ¿hed, to wit the Chirurgion and the Drink, 3. the contagion, take heed how you drink with her: Ergo it Å¿hall be intended the French Pox, and not the Small Pox, Trin. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis Milner and his Wife againÅ¿t Reeve.

1. A Å¿aid of B, ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion. being a BarreÅ¿ter, that he had no more Law than a Jack-an-Apes, an Action lies, becauÅ¿e it is an unreaÅ¿onable Creature not having any Law, and it Å¿candals him in his profeÅ¿Å¿ion, Mich 36, & 37 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Palmers caÅ¿e, and it is as much as if he had Å¿aid, he hath no Law.
For Å¿aying of a CounÅ¿ellor, he will deceive you,Revealer of a cauÅ¿e. he was of my CounÅ¿el and revealed my CauÅ¿e, No. Lib. Intra. 22. B. Å¿ect. 19. for this may hinder him from Clients.
For calling a man Rogue it lies not,Rogue. Kitchin 173. B. But quaere if he call him branded Rogue.

A Å¿ays of a Preacher,Sedition. thou haÅ¿t made a Å¿editious Sermon to day and moved the people to it, Action lies, becauÅ¿e he is Å¿candalized in his profeÅ¿Å¿ion, Coke 4. part. 19. caÅ¿e 15. and he might then have been puniÅ¿hed for preaching Sedition.

An Action. de Å¿candalis magnatum was brought for Å¿aying, you like of thoÅ¿e that maintain Sedition
againÅ¿t the â¢ Queens proceedings, Coke 4. part. 12. B. Cromwells caÅ¿e. Q. if it lie, for the words are general, and it may be he did not know it.

L Å¿aid E did report,Sorcery. that your wife Å¿acrificed her Child to the Devil to make away my Mother, Action lies, becauÅ¿e Å¿orcery is felony, per 11 Jac. Regis, and there is an evil intention and an act joyned together, PaÅ¿ch. 15 Jac. Locke verÅ¿us Locke.
It lies for calling one Traytor,Traytor. 27 Hen. 8.14.30 AÅ¿Å¿ize 29. Coke 10. part. 130. B. Osburns caÅ¿e.
Thou diddeÅ¿t Å¿peak TreaÅ¿on, Action lies, 9 Jac. Brereford & PreÅ¿ton; for Å¿peaking of TreaÅ¿on is TreaÅ¿on, and puniÅ¿hable.

Walter Å¿aid P did Å¿ay, that Mr. Lewis did Å¿ay there was no Prince in England, an Action lies, for it cannot be intended but that he meant Prince Charles was not Prince; and becauÅ¿e it toucheth the Plaintiff in his Alleageance it Å¿hall be taken in the favourableÅ¿t Å¿enÅ¿e as is, Fama, fides, oculus non patiuntur ludum, Hill. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Lewis & Walter; for it is not lawful for me to Å¿ay what I hear another Å¿ay, if it tends to a third perÅ¿ons prejudice.
For calling one UÅ¿urer it lies not,UÅ¿urer. becauÅ¿e it meerly belongs to the Spiritual Court, 27 Hen. 8.17. and UÅ¿ury is tolerated by the Law. But Q. if one call another Extortioner.
It lies not for calling one Whore,Whore. Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, HudÅ¿ons caÅ¿e, Coke 4. part. 18. A. but it doth by the late Act.

But in London by cuÅ¿tomes it did lie before, but if it be removed to WeÅ¿tm. no Procedendo Å¿hall be granted, for Å¿uch cuÅ¿tomes to maintain actions for
brabling words is againÅ¿t the Law, Coke 4. part. 18. A. caÅ¿e 13. Q. tamen, for Roll Chief JuÅ¿tice held it ought to be granted; but Bacon JuÅ¿tice to the contrary, 23 Car. B. R. Izack againÅ¿t Green, & 24 Car. B. R. Kings caÅ¿e.

For Å¿aying of a Maid that Å¿he had a BaÅ¿tard, an Action lies, 1. becauÅ¿e it is puniÅ¿hable by our Law, viz. the Statute; 2. if Å¿he be to be married it hinders her preferment, Coke 4. part. 16. caÅ¿e 11. Davies & Gardiner.

div.head: For doing of wrong to the damage of another, touching Suits in Law.
div.p: Admiralty.For Å¿uing me in the Admiralty for matter about neque Å¿uper altum mare, neque ultra mare, per 2 Hen. 4. cap. 11.5 Mariae, Dyer 159. pl. 27. and Å¿o not belonging to the JuriÅ¿diction of the Admiralty.

But if one which is only Baily in the Admiralty, and is arreÅ¿ted, when the principal matter is not determinable, there this Action lies, quaere, for it was argued at the Bar, Mich. 11 Jac. Com. Ban. Rot. 1127. Rowe verÅ¿us Alporte.
AgainÅ¿t him that diÅ¿turbs an Officer to make Attachment. Q. whether by the Officer,Attachment. or the Plaintiff, or both.
AgainÅ¿t a Baily of a Franchize, that fraudulently delivers to the owner his goods attached, Nat. br. 93. F. 2 Edw. 3.43. for the Law creates a privity, and here is breach of truÅ¿t.
1. AgainÅ¿t an Attorney that makes default,Attorney. by which my land is loÅ¿t, Lib. Intr. 2. AÅ¿ect. 1. vide the count there, viz. by negligence or collation.
2. For Å¿uing debt in my name without my aÅ¿Å¿ent, 7 Hen. 6.43.45. for it may prove to my prejudice.
3. For Appearing without warrant, and imparling where the party is miÅ¿named, becauÅ¿e his Client loÅ¿eth the advantage of the plea, 15 Hen. 7.14. of MiÅ¿noÅ¿mer.
For taking an Obligation in his own name, where it ought to be taken in his MaÅ¿ters, 20 Hen. 6.25. for this is apparent wrong.
5. It lies for not executing his office, 20 Hen. 7.9. A. King Å¿mell. viz. for NonfeaÅ¿ance as well as for MisfeaÅ¿ance.
6. It lies for Utlawing me in the name of B, that was dead at the time, Coke 7. part. 1. A. Bulwers caÅ¿e; for there was no warrant for Å¿uch Utlawry.
7. It lies for pleading Non Å¿um informatus without warrant, 20 Eliz. Dyer 361. pl. 13. Q. for it Å¿eems he may do it in Å¿ome caÅ¿es.
8. It lies for appearing in default of the Tenant, and confeÅ¿Å¿ing the Action without warrant, 9 Edw. 4.13. 43 Edw. 3.20. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 113. A. for hereby the Defendant is condemned.
9. AgainÅ¿t him that will be my Attorney without my aÅ¿Å¿ent, 42 Edw. 3.14. for my election is thereby taken away, which the Law will not permit.

AgainÅ¿t a CounÅ¿ellor retained for a certain Å¿um,CounÅ¿ellor. and he diÅ¿covers his counÅ¿el, and was of CounÅ¿el with the other party, and good, although he doth not Å¿hew for what Å¿um he was retained, 11 Hen. 6.2.18. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 7. Lib. Intr. 2. B. Å¿ect. 2. for the Retainer is the principal, and the Å¿um for what is not material.

AgainÅ¿t a CounÅ¿ellor that is an Ambodexter, Lib. Intra. 2. B. Å¿ect. 3. or on CounÅ¿el on both Å¿ides,
which is not lawful but in Å¿ome caÅ¿e, by the conÅ¿ent of the parties.
ChriÅ¿tian Court.AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ues me for Tithes in Court ChriÅ¿tian, although I Å¿hew him a CompoÅ¿ition by me time out of memory, 8 Edw. 4.13. for he ought to Å¿ue at the Common Law.

1. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that Å¿uffers one to eÅ¿cape upon a Capias ad Computandum; EÅ¿cape. for he Å¿hall not have an action of debt, becauÅ¿e there is no duty certain, 15 Edw. 4.19. 16 Edw. 4.2.3. eÅ¿cape 37. and Å¿o, if he may not have this Action, he would be without remedy.
2. AgainÅ¿t a Goaler that lets one eÅ¿cape that was committed upon the Statute of Labourers, 14 Hen. 6.8. viz. by the MaÅ¿ter of the Servant committed.
3. AgainÅ¿t a Goaler that Å¿uffers one to eÅ¿cape taken upon a Capias upon a Statute Merchant, viz. by the ConuÅ¿ee of the Statute at whoÅ¿e Å¿uit the proÅ¿ecution is, Nat. br. 93. A.
4. AgainÅ¿t a Goaler that Å¿uffers one to eÅ¿cape upon Execution, Lib. Intra. 8. C. Sect. 1. for thereby the Plaintiff is deprived of his remedy to recover his debt.
5. AgainÅ¿t a PriÅ¿oner that breaks priÅ¿on and eÅ¿capes, Nat. br. 95. C. 130. B. viz. by the Goaler, who is to anÅ¿wer for the eÅ¿cape.
6. AgainÅ¿t an Officer that arreÅ¿ts one at my Å¿uit, and Å¿uffers him to eÅ¿cape, RegiÅ¿t. 111. A, & B. for I am thereby retarded in my Å¿uit.
AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that quaÅ¿hes eÅ¿Å¿oyns in Reply erronice without aÅ¿Å¿ent of the Suitors, 20 AÅ¿Å¿ize 45.EÅ¿Å¿oyn.

1. A having goods of B in his houÅ¿e,Execution. the Sheriff comes and takes the goods in execution, and
A him diÅ¿turbs, 1. if the Sheriff gives notice to A, and after he diÅ¿turbs him, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have this Action againÅ¿t him, otherwiÅ¿e not; 2. A may keep his houÅ¿e faÅ¿t till notice; 3. the Count is not Å¿ufficient, that A. praemiÅ¿Å¿orum non ignarus, &c. but it ought to be alledged preciÅ¿ely that he had notice, Coke 5. part. 93. A. Semaines caÅ¿e, for the other is but by way of argument.
2. By hindering Execution by removing the Record by attaint, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 113. A. viz. where there is no cauÅ¿e.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ues out Execution upon a Statute, as Executor of the ConuÅ¿ee where he is not, or where the ConuÅ¿ee is alive, 2 Rich. 3.8. for this is deceitful.
FalÅ¿e Return, no Return.1. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that returns quarto exactus, where it Å¿hould be quinto exactus, 9 Hen. 6.60.81. for by this falÅ¿e return the Plaintiff is hindred in his proceedings.
2. For returning Cattel eÅ¿trayed, which are dead, 32 Hen. 6.27. which is a falÅ¿e return, and may prejudice the party.
3. For making other return than the Baily made, 36 Hen. 6.1. 30 AÅ¿Å¿ize 5. viz. the Baily of a Liberty.
4. For returning a man of the enqueÅ¿t where he Å¿hews him a Charter to be priviledged to the contrary, 18 Hen. 8.5. for thereby he is wrongfully moleÅ¿ted and put to charge.
5. AgainÅ¿t a ComiÅ¿Å¿ary that returs a Jure patronatus otherways than it is found, 22 Hen. 6.30. to the hindring the due courÅ¿e of the Law.
6. Upon a devaÅ¿tavit returned falÅ¿ly, Lib. Intr. 11. A. Å¿ect. 11 Hen. 6.37. B. viz. where there was none, whereby the Executor is chargeable de bonis propriis.

7. For returning a man Å¿ummoned where he was not, 26 AÅ¿Å¿ize 48. 1 Hen. 6. pl. 4. or where he was not Å¿ummoned by a reaÅ¿onable time, 39 Edw. 3.7. for that is all one in Law as if he were not Å¿ummoned at all.
8. The Å¿ame Law upon GarniÅ¿hment, 2 Edw. 3. cap. 14. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 112. B.

9. For returning non eÅ¿t inventus where the party was Å¿ufficient, and ought to be Å¿ummoned, 31 Edw. 3. ProceÅ¿s 55. Nat. br. 39. B. for Å¿uch return is to his diÅ¿credit, and the Law is tender of mens Reputations.

10. For returning a cepi Corpus, and had not the body at the day, the Plaintiff Å¿hall not have an Action upon the caÅ¿e, but Å¿hall Å¿ue him upon an account, 7 Hen. 4.31. ProceÅ¿s 120. Q. for it Å¿eems it lies.
11. For delivering a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and returns not the Writ, 21 Edw. 3.43. viz. of Replevin, whereby the proceedings are hindred.
AgainÅ¿t a Deputy of a Sheriff, 20 Hen. 6. deceit 11. for the Law takes notice of Å¿uch an Officer.
12. For returning a Nihil where the party had Å¿ufficient, Lib. Intr. 11. C. Å¿ect. 2. Nat. br. 39 B. for this is to his diÅ¿grace.

13. AgainÅ¿t an eÅ¿cheator that certifies an office otherways than it is found, or that certifies one where there is none found, 21 Edw. 23. 9 Hen. 6.60. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 115. B. for though it may be traverÅ¿ed, yet this puts the party to charges and trouble to do it.
14. By the new Sheriff againÅ¿t the old Sheriff for returning one Å¿ufficient, which is not, by which the Plaintiff, viz. the new Sheriff, is charged in iÅ¿Å¿ues, 19 Hen. 6.38. B. PaÅ¿ton.
15. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that makes a precept to one that is not Baily of a Franchize, 38 AÅ¿Å¿ize 13. as if he were Baily of a Franchize.

16. If the Sheriff returns not a cepi Corpus, Å¿ed languidus, when the Defendant was in good health, he, viz. the Defendant, Å¿hall have an Action of falÅ¿e ImpriÅ¿onment, 11 Hen. 6.42. pl. 39. 2 2 Hen. 6.5. A. And the other, viz. the Plaintiff, an Action upon the caÅ¿e, 21 Hen. 6.5. A. for it is falÅ¿e return.
17. In a falÅ¿e Judgment, if the Sheriff returns that there is no Å¿uch things, &c. if it be falÅ¿e Action lies, 10 Edw. 3.389. pl. 35. pro falÅ¿itavit.
18. For the Sheriff Å¿hall not be amerced, 44 Edw. 3.3. pl. 11. for it is no contempt to the Court, and they will take it for a good execution of the ProceÅ¿s till the contrary Appeal.
19. If the Sheriff make a falÅ¿e return upon an enqueÅ¿t, the party hath no remedy, Coke 5. part. 32. B. PettiÅ¿ors caÅ¿e. Q. for me Å¿eems an Action on the CaÅ¿e lies.
20. For not returning a Writ delivered by Bill by the old Sheriff, WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 39. 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 12. But note 8 Edw. 3.3.298. pl. 26. Herle.
21. It lies againÅ¿t a Sheriff for a falÅ¿e Return, Doct. & Stud. 134. B. 19 Hen. 6.29.5.72.
22. For returning Å¿ummoned where he was dead, Action lies. 8 Edw. 3.330. pl. 1. for the Plaintiff is thereby deceived.

23. AgainÅ¿t a Summoner that returns a man Å¿ummoned where he was not, by which he was excommunicated, Mich. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Pole and Godfrey, the Count and pleadings in the Reports; for the Common Law takes notice of Excommunications.
For Å¿uing one upon a forged Obligation,Forgery. Goke 4. part. 18. B. Q.
AgainÅ¿t a CuÅ¿tos brevium for embezeling a Writ to him delivered,Imbezeling. 7 Hen. 4.6.
For inciting another to imbezel a Writ, 19 Hen. 6.29. if the Writ be thereupon imbezeled; for the Law favours not encouragers to do wrong.
If my Attorney or Deputy of the Sheriff imbezel a Record, Deceit lies, 10 Hen. 6.30. in reÅ¿pect of TruÅ¿t deceived, which the Law creates betwixt the parties.

For Å¿uing me before the Steward or MarÅ¿hal,MarÅ¿hal. where I am not of the HouÅ¿hold, 3 Hen. 6. EÅ¿toppel. 18. 10 Hen. 6.13. for every one ought to be Å¿ued in the Courts at the Common Law, and which are proper to try the Action.
1. AgainÅ¿t a Baily of a Franchize that diÅ¿continues his plea, Nat. br. 93. F. the Writ there,Plea. where it ought not to be.
2. AgainÅ¿t a Baily of a Franchize that Å¿ues after the plaint removed, Nat. br. 93. E. 14 Edw. 3. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 39. for then he hath no power to hold plea.
3. AgainÅ¿t a Guardian which pleads a falÅ¿e plea, or vouches one that is not Å¿ufficient, 9 Edw. 4. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 118. by the ward, for it is to his prejudice.
AgainÅ¿t him that procures one to Å¿ay,Procurement. he is A.B. the Plaintiff in the fuit, and confeÅ¿Å¿es the Action, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 113. B. for this is deceit.
AgainÅ¿t him in Court ChriÅ¿tian that proceeds after Prohibition delivered,Prohibition. Nat. br. 92. E. the Writ Å¿hall Å¿ay contra pacem, becauÅ¿e it is in diÅ¿turbance of the Common Law.
AgainÅ¿t him that throws the Prohibition in the dirt, Nat. br. 92. E. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 92. the Writ Å¿hall Å¿ay contra pacem; for this is in contempt of the Common Law.
AgainÅ¿t him who gets a Protection of the King for one,Protection. and gives it to another of the Å¿ame name, 30 Hen. 6.18. viz. by him who is thus deceived in the truÅ¿t repoÅ¿ed in the party.

AgainÅ¿t a Tenant in a Praecipe that hath a Protection to come to WeÅ¿tm. and Å¿tays at GlouceÅ¿ter, 15 Edw. 4.19. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 119. B. 20 Hen. 6.10. for this is an abuÅ¿e to the Law, and prejudice to the party.
AgainÅ¿t him that gets a protection, where he was not in Å¿ervice of the King, Lib. Intr. 49 â¢ . D. the Count 493. Sect. 2, 3. and Å¿o abuÅ¿e the King and the party.
PurchaÅ¿e of a Writ.AgainÅ¿t him that purchaÅ¿es a Writ, whereby I am Å¿ued to pay a fine without my privity, RegiÅ¿t. 112. A.
Quare Impedit, 112. A, & B.

3. AgainÅ¿t an officer in Ban. Regis, which purchaÅ¿es a Å¿uperÅ¿edeas for one that I have a Plaint againÅ¿t in London, upon a falÅ¿e Å¿urmiÅ¿e that the Defendant is his Servant, 21 Edw. 4.23. and Å¿o abuÅ¿eth the Court to the prejudice of the Plaintiff.
But upon Å¿urmiÅ¿e that he hath an Action depending there it lies not, becauÅ¿e the Court cannot have notice, ibidem. Q.

4. AgainÅ¿t an Officer in Chancery, which purchaÅ¿eth a SuperÅ¿edeas for his Servant, where he was not his Servant retained before the time, 11 Hen. 6.8. for this is abuÅ¿ing his priviledge to anothers hurt.
1. By a Goaler againÅ¿t ReÅ¿couÅ¿Å¿ors of one in Execution,ReÅ¿cous. Dyer 241. pl. 47. for he is liable to the debt thereby.

2. A being arreÅ¿ted upon a Latitat at the Å¿uit of B, and ReÅ¿couÅ¿Å¿ed by C, B Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t C, and ought to Å¿hew that he intended to declare againÅ¿t A in debt; for there are no other ProceÅ¿s in this Court, PaÅ¿ch. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Kemps caÅ¿e, viz. the Latitats upon which one may declare in what action he pleaÅ¿eth.
AgainÅ¿t him that acknowledged a Statute in my Name without my privity,Statute. 112. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. for this may be very miÅ¿chievous to the party.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ues me on purpoÅ¿e to vex me,Vexation. 8 Edw. 13.43. 1 Edw. 3.20. for the Law hates vexatious Suits.
But for cauÅ¿eleÅ¿s Suits no Action, 11 Eliz. Dyer 285. for, pro falÅ¿a actionis proÅ¿ecutione nulla Å¿equatur poena, 2 Rich. 3.9. pl. 22. Å¿o that there was probable cauÅ¿e.
2. AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ues me for a thing arbitrated before that the day come to perform the award, RegiÅ¿t. 111. A. for this is unjuÅ¿t vexation.

div.head: For the not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the Law, touching a thing hereditary to the damage of another.
div.p: A Copyholder by CuÅ¿tome that may nominate him which Å¿hall Å¿ucceed him, and names one,AdmiÅ¿Å¿ion. and prays to be admitted, and offers reaÅ¿onable fine to the Lord which reÅ¿uÅ¿eth; the Copyholder Å¿hall not have an Action of the CaÅ¿e againÅ¿t the Lord, becauÅ¿e before admittance he had no right, PaÅ¿ch. 13 Jac. Ban. Regis, Forde and Hoskins.

A Beadle of a Hundred brought his Action o â¢ the CaÅ¿e againÅ¿t many Brewers;Beadle of a Hundred. and preÅ¿cribes to have three gallons of the beÅ¿t Beer of even Brewer for 7 d, and good, for it is not unreaÅ¿onable; 1. He need not Å¿hew what eÅ¿tate he hathâª 2. It is good againÅ¿t many, becauÅ¿e all in common are acceÅ¿Å¿ory, 19 Rich. 2. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 51.
AgainÅ¿t him which ought to encloÅ¿e againÅ¿t me,EncloÅ¿ure. and doth not, by which my graÅ¿s is conÅ¿umed. 11 Rich. 2. Action on the caÅ¿e 36. be it by his own Cattel or a Strangers.

But if it be between two houÅ¿es, a Guria cl â¢â¢
denda lies, ibidem. a Writ to enforce him to encloÅ¿ â¢ his own Yard.
A Å¿old Land to B, FeoÅ¿ment. and he will not enÅ¿eoff him, Action lies, 22 Hen. 6.44. Newton. Q. for he may make him another Conveyance.

AgainÅ¿t an Archdeacon which refuÅ¿eth to â¢â¢
duct,Induction. wh â¢ ch is as much as to give poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a Living,InÅ¿titution. 26 Hen. 8.3. Nat. br. 47. becauÅ¿e here the Archdeacon is in place of the Sheriff, Mich. 12 Jae. Ban. Regis, Poole and Godfrey. But in this caÅ¿t by Doderidge and Coke, it lies not againÅ¿t the Ordinary for not inÅ¿tituting a Clerk, becauÅ¿e this is meerly Spiritual; in the caÅ¿e above Å¿pecified; and the Clerk may be unfit, which they are to judge of.

A hath a nomination,PreÅ¿entation. and B the preÅ¿entation; A names one, B will not preÅ¿ent; yet an Action lies not by the Court, PaÅ¿cb. 13 Jae. Ban. Regis, in the caÅ¿e of Forde and Hoskins; for B hath a greater intereÅ¿t than A, or equal.

AgainÅ¿t one that ought to find a PrieÅ¿t,To find a PrieÅ¿t. and will not, viz. to Å¿ay MaÅ¿s, Å¿ing Dirges, &c. 21 Hen. 7.5.22 Hen. 6.46. Lib. Intra. 2. D. Å¿ect. 5. this was
Law in the time of Popery, but not now.

But if he Å¿hall be found by the Lord, and his Tenants of his Mannor, no Å¿uch Action lies, Coke 4. part. A. Williams; but it Å¿hall be in the Court ChriÅ¿tian, for the incertainty where the fault is that he is not found.
1. AgainÅ¿t a LeÅ¿Å¿or that refuÅ¿es to repair his houÅ¿e,Reparations. Dyer 36. pl. 37. viz. where he promiÅ¿ed to do it. But quaere, if he do not promiÅ¿e.
2. AgainÅ¿t him that ought to repair a Bridge, by which I have a way to my Mannor, 11 Hen. 4.82.45 Edw. 3.17. for I am hindred in my eaÅ¿ement.
3. But if a Highway be not repaired, by which my HorÅ¿e is mired, I Å¿hall have an Action, by Heiden, 5 Edw. 4.3. Q. viz. for my particular miring.
4. AgainÅ¿t him which ought to repair a Mound or Bank, by which my Land is drowned, 29 Edw. 3.32. 12. Hen. 4.7. Nat. br. 93. G. 7 Hen. 4.31. pl. 13.

5. So of the Banks of a River, Nat. br. 93. G. 15 Edw. 4.18. 45 Edw. 3.17. 7 Hen. 4.8.31. 11 Hen. 4.82, 83. 33 Hen. 6.26. 29 Edw. 3.32. pl. 49. for in all theÅ¿e caÅ¿es I am damnified, and am to be repaired by him that is the cauÅ¿e thereof.
But if they be broke by TempeÅ¿t, no Action lies, 29 Edw. 3.32. pl. 49. for this could not be foreÅ¿een nor prevented, and Å¿o there is no fault in any body.
6. For not Å¿couring Ditches, 11 Rich. 2. an Action upon the CaÅ¿e lies, 36. Nat. br. 93. G.
7. For not repairing of a Gutter, Lib. Intra. 10. D. Å¿ect. 1. whereby another is damnified.

For not repairing a houÅ¿e that is ready to fall upon my houÅ¿e, Crooke 22 Hen. 7.98. pl. 4. per Fineux & Brudnel; for I am like to Å¿uffer damage, and an Action may Å¿ometimes be brought to prevent a wrong.
AgainÅ¿t him that is retained to purchaÅ¿e Lands and doth not,Retain. 11 Hen. 6.18. Q. for it may be it i â¢ not to my prejudice, yet here is breach ãâã truÅ¿t.
But if he doth his endeavour it Å¿ufficeth, Å¿o ultra poÅ¿Å¿e non eÅ¿t eÅ¿Å¿e.
But if he be a CounÅ¿el with the other partyr Action lies, 11 Hen. 6.18. pl. 10. Babinton, & 55 pl. 26. for then he is retained againÅ¿t me to my prejudice.
AgainÅ¿t a Lord in Ancient demeÅ¿n which ãâã not hold his Court,To hold Court, 11 Edw. 2. Action upon the â¢â¢ j. 46. lies; for the Tenants may be prejudiced thereby.

Toll. 1. AgainÅ¿t a Millar that refuÅ¿eth to grind To â¢ free for one that is Toll-free, 43 Edw. 4.24. Cr â¢â¢â¢
130. pl. 100 l. per Keble; for this is appare â¢ wrong to take my goods where I am exemp â¢ e â¢ by the Law from being charged.
2. AgainÅ¿t him that bought or Å¿old in ãâã Market or Fair without paying Toll, 7 Hen. 4.4 â¢ . pl. 11. for this is my loÅ¿s, and to the ill example â¢ others.

3. But if one paÅ¿s over my paÅ¿Å¿age or po â¢ where I have Toll, and doth not pay it, qu â¢â¢
what remedy, 21 Hen. 7.16. pl. 25. It Å¿eems ãâã Action on the CaÅ¿e doth lie, if it be demanded.

div.head: For not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the Law, to the damage of another, concerning Chattels.
div.p: A borrowed a HorÅ¿e of B, Borrowed. which died Å¿uddenly without his default, Action lies not, 40 Edw. 3.36. for this is the act of God, and not the faul â¢ of the borrower.
It lies not againÅ¿t an Attorney that will not do his office unleÅ¿s he be retained,Attorney. 20 Hen. 7.9. for he is but in the nature of a Servant, and is not bound to be retained.
AgainÅ¿t a Baily that hath money to bail my Attorney,Bailment. and doth it not, 20 Hen. 6.9. B.
AgainÅ¿t my Servant, becauÅ¿e he pays not money for bailing and Å¿aving harmleÅ¿s, 20 Hen. 6.9. for I may be damnified thereby.

S being a Dutchman,Cocket. his Parents being Å¿ubjects to the King, brought an Action againÅ¿t a CuÅ¿tomer for not putting a Cocket upon his Merchandize, and avers that he tender'd the CuÅ¿tomes. Coke Ch. JuÅ¿t. Å¿aid, that inÅ¿omuch that the Dutchmen here aÅ¿Å¿embling are not of our Nation, nor free of any company of Merchants, that the Action lies not, PaÅ¿ch. 14. Jac. Stephens his caÅ¿e.
Farrier & Smith. 1. AgainÅ¿t a Smith that refuÅ¿eth to Å¿hooe my HorÅ¿e, 14 Hen. 6.18. Crooke. 18 Hen. 7.50. pl. 4. for this is for the publick good as well as private.
2. But then he ought to have all neceÅ¿Å¿aries, and his wages tendered, 2 Hen. 6.55. Q. for the wages are not due till the work is done.

3. AgainÅ¿t a Farrier that applies medicine, and cures not my HorÅ¿e. But if no default be in him, it lies not, 19 Hen. 6.49. 43 Edw. 3.33. 48
Edw. 3.6. for he doth his beÅ¿t according to his skill.
AgainÅ¿t an Innkeeper that will not lodge me,Innkeeper. 39 Hen. 6.18. Crooke. 18 Hen. 7.50. pl. 4.14. Hen. 7.22. B. Higham, for it is againÅ¿t the good of the weal publick.

Pledge. 1. AgainÅ¿t him that will not deliver my Pledge upon tender of the money borrowed, Nat. br. 86. C. RegiÅ¿t. 91. B. Lib. Intra. 8. B. Sect. 1. for the Pledge is judged to be more worth than the Money.
Servant. 2. AgainÅ¿t a Servant that will not do his Å¿ervice, 2 Hen. 7.11. B. Q. for the MaÅ¿ter is damnified thereby.
For his Wages is certain by the Statute, and he hath his Action to recover it, 3 Hen. 6.36. B. So note, it muÅ¿t be a Covenant-Servant hired according to the Statute.
3. AgainÅ¿t one that will not Å¿erve not having Land, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 101. A. & B. for Å¿uch are bound by the Law to Å¿erve.
4. AgainÅ¿t one that will not Å¿erve in Summer, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 101. B. In time of HaryeÅ¿t it Å¿eems more eÅ¿pecially.

div.head: For the not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the Law, to the damage of another touching his Body.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t an Innkeeper that refuÅ¿eth to lodge me,Innkeeper. 39 Hen. 6.18.
A good bar that his houÅ¿e was full,Bar. and had no room, 5 Mariae, Dyer. 158. pl. 32. for he is not bound to provide lodging out of his own houÅ¿e.

AgainÅ¿t a Chirurgion that takes upon him aChiturgion
Cure, and neglects it, 48 Edw. 3.6. whereby the Cure is become impoÅ¿Å¿ible, or is retarded.
AgainÅ¿t a Victualler that refuÅ¿eth to Å¿ell to me,Victualler. 39 Hen. 6.18. for his profeÅ¿Å¿ion is for the publick, and he ought to make no diÅ¿tinction of perÅ¿ons.

div.head: For not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the Law, to the damage of another touching Suits in Law.
div.p: 1. It lies againÅ¿t an Attorney that is retained,Attorney. and makes default; Lib. Intra. 2. A. Å¿ect. 1: RegiÅ¿t. orig. 113. A. if his Client be prejudiced by it.
Clerk of AÅ¿Å¿ize.AgainÅ¿t a Clerk of AÅ¿Å¿ize that takes a Fee, and enters not the Jury, 34 Hen. 6.4. for thereby the CauÅ¿e is delayed by his nonfeaÅ¿ance.
Feoffee to uÅ¿e.AgainÅ¿t a Feoffee to uÅ¿e, which doth not plead according to the directions of the Feoffor, 14. Hen. 8.24, B. pl. 2. Q. for the pleading is for his advantage or diÅ¿advantage.

To hold Court.AgainÅ¿t a Lord of a Mannor that will not hold his Court, 11 Edw. 2. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 46. for the Tenants of the Mannor are thereby prejudiced, and the Lord is as well bound to hold his Courts duly, as the Tenants are to do their Å¿ervices.
1. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that will not execute ProceÅ¿s,Sheriff. 14 Hen. 7.23. the party being Å¿hewed to him, 8 Edw. 4.14.17. for JuÅ¿tice is thereby delayed.
2. For the Plaintiff againÅ¿t a Sheriff that will not return his Writ, 2 Hen. 6.5. 8 Edw. 4.14.7. for he is thereby hindred in his Suit.
3. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff that will not return an Outlawry, 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 12. for though it properly concerns the King, yet the party may receive prejudice by not returning it.
4. For delivering a diÅ¿treÅ¿s upon a Å¿econd deliverance, and not returning the Writ, 2 Edw. 3.43. for thereby the further proceedings of the Avowant are hindred.

div.head: AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it.
For the not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the agreement of the party to the damage of another, touching things hereditary.
div.p: AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it. Quid. Quotuplex. ASÅ¿umpÅ¿it is either by word, or deed Poll.
If it be by Covenant it lies, and needs not any conÅ¿ideration to be averred, 2 Hen. 7.11. 21 Hen. 6.55. for a Covenant Å¿uppoÅ¿eth a conÅ¿ideration, becauÅ¿e it is a Å¿olemn act.
If it be by word, then it ought to be upon a conÅ¿ideration, otherways it is but Nudum pactum unde non oritur actio, for the other hath no wrong, though the promiÅ¿e be not performed.

A ConÅ¿ideration is a cauÅ¿e or occaÅ¿ion meritorious, ConÅ¿ideration. Quid. Quotuplex. requiring mutual recompence in deed or in Law; in Deed expreÅ¿Å¿ed in words; in Law not expreÅ¿Å¿ed, but created by Law, 16 Eliz. Dyer 336. B. pl. 34.
The ConÅ¿ideration is either expreÅ¿Å¿ed in words, or implied by Law; in every Contract there is an AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it or promiÅ¿e implied by Law, Coke 4. part. 94. Slades caÅ¿e.
If it be expreÅ¿Å¿ed it ought to be Å¿hewed in the Count or Declaration, 3 Hen. 6.36. 11 Hen. 4.33.
A ConÅ¿ideration of a thing paÅ¿t is not good, Doct. & Stud. 104. B. except it be a continuing conÅ¿ideration and benefit to the party.

An AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it may be made in the abÅ¿ence of another, if he will agree to it afterward, 27 Hen. 8.24. and it Å¿hall be all one as if it were made to the party. Quaere, whether he that aÅ¿Å¿umed may not refuÅ¿e before the other conÅ¿ent.

div.head: General Bar.
div.p: 1. Concord pleaded, viz. after the AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it made, Lib. Intr. 6. C. Å¿ect. 6.

2. Non aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it, and this a man may plead although there is no conÅ¿ideration, PaÅ¿ch. 26 Eliz. Ban. Regis; for if there was no conÅ¿ideration for the promiÅ¿e, it is all one as if there had been no Å¿uch promiÅ¿e made.
But if the former were upon an entire Å¿um upon two AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿its, then no bar, Trin. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Paine and Selley.
A good Bar that he promiÅ¿ed upon Condition, which is not performed, Lib. Intr. 5. D. Å¿ect. 1. and Å¿o he is not bound to perform his promiÅ¿e, for the Condition is to be precedent.
Non emiÅ¿Å¿es the Land of him, a good bar, Lib. Intra. 6. B. Å¿ect. 5. viz. an Action brought for moneys promiÅ¿ed to be paid upon a purchaÅ¿e of lives.
That the Plaintiff diÅ¿charged him of the bargain, a good bar, Lib. Intr. 685. C. Å¿ect. and Å¿o there could be no money due upon it.

To make an eÅ¿tate.The Action lies, 1. againÅ¿t him that Å¿ells Land to me, and promiÅ¿es to make an eÅ¿tate, and doth it not, 3 Hen. 7.14. 14 Hen. 8.15. 21 Hen. 7.41. 2 Hen. 7.11, 12. 20 Hen. 7.9. 22 Hen. 6.44. 20 Hen. 6.34. Lib. Intra. 5. D. Sect. 1. and 685. B. Å¿ect. 1. the Writ, Lib. Intra 6. A. Sect. 2. for I am thereby prejudiced in my title to the Land.
2. AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells Land to me, and promiÅ¿es to give me Å¿eiÅ¿in of it, and does not, RegiÅ¿t. 112. A. for he hath conÅ¿ented to paÅ¿s the Land by that kind of Conveyance.

3. A promiÅ¿es to convey Land to Å¿uch a perÅ¿on as B Å¿hall name, and the Defendant Å¿hews, that he conveyed it to B, this is good; for it Å¿hall be intended a nomination in B, inÅ¿omuch that he did accept of it, Mich. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. Huligo and Wilde; for he might nominate himÅ¿elf as well as another.
4. AgainÅ¿t him that firÅ¿t Å¿ells Land to me, and afterwards Å¿ells it to another, Lib. Intra. 685. B. Å¿ect. 1. Nat. br. 98. F. 20 Hen. 6.34. for I may be thereby troubled in my poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
5. The Å¿ame Law is, if he grant a Rent, and afterwards infeoff me, not giving me notice of the Rent, 20 Hen. 6.34. for thereby my Land is charged.
AgainÅ¿t one that promiÅ¿es to Å¿cour his Ditch,Ditch. and doth not, by which my Land is drowned, 3 Hen. 6.36. and I damnified.

AgainÅ¿t an Alien that brought Salt to London, Cranage. and promiÅ¿es to the Major to pay Å¿o much as Å¿hall be due for Cranage, 18 Eliz. Dyer 352. pl. 27: and doth it not, for here is damage by the loÅ¿s of the profit.

AgainÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or that promiÅ¿es,LeÅ¿Å¿or. that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee
Å¿hall enjoy pacifice & quiete, and is expulÅ¿ed by a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿or, 16 Eliz. Dyer 328. pl. 8. Q.
1. AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to amend his houÅ¿e,HouÅ¿e. 19 Hen. 6.49. and doth it not. Q. whoÅ¿e HouÅ¿e.
2. For not building a HouÅ¿e according to his promiÅ¿e, 2 Hen. 6.55. 21 Hen. 7.41. 20 Hen. 7.9. 14 Hen. 6.18. Nat. br. 145. G.
3. AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to cover a houÅ¿e, and doth it not, 3 Hen. 6.36. 14 Hen. 6.18.

4. A LeaÅ¿es a HouÅ¿e to B at will, and in conÅ¿ideration that he will permit him to enjoy it till Å¿uch a day, he promiÅ¿eth to keep A harmleÅ¿s from all damage, ratione inhabitationis & occupationis MeÅ¿Å¿uagii praedicti, and for every farthing hurt he will Å¿atisfie 2 d. upon requeÅ¿t: The Servant of B Å¿uffers the houÅ¿e to be burnt, 1. the AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it extends to negligent waÅ¿te, becauÅ¿e it is a damage to the LeÅ¿Å¿or; 2. the Plaintiff ought to Å¿hew how many farthings he is damaged, or elÅ¿e he cannot recover two pence for every farthing; 3. he ought to requeÅ¿t Å¿o many farthings due to him, and to demand two pence for every one in a groÅ¿s Å¿um; 4. upon the promiÅ¿e to the Tenant at will; 5. he needs not to averr, that he did there inhabit at the time, &c. for if he occupied it, it is Å¿ufficient; 6. by the aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it that B Å¿hould have it until, &c. And it being a LeaÅ¿e for years, ergo the Action lies not, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Coventry & Woody. Q.

AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to purchaÅ¿e Land for me of B, and doth not do it,PurchaÅ¿e. he is not excuÅ¿ed though B will not Å¿ell it, 11 Hen. 6.18. 3 Hen. 7.14. for by his promiÅ¿e he is bound to do it at his peril.
But if he be retained and do his endeavour he is excuÅ¿ed, 16 Hen. 6. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 44.
AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to make B. to releaÅ¿e to me,ReleaÅ¿e. and doth not, 14 Hen. 6.18. pl. 58.

div.head: For not doing of a thing which ought to be done by the agreement of the parties touching Chattels.AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it.
div.p: 1. AgainÅ¿t him that puts in Cattel without paying for the AgiÅ¿tment,AgiÅ¿tment. Nat. br. 86. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 92. A. the Writ there; for here is not quid pro quo in recompence.

Annual payment.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to pay 10 l. a year for Land for four years, and fails of the firÅ¿t payment, Action lies preÅ¿ently, Coke 3. part. 22. A. Walkers caÅ¿e, 3 Mariae. Dyer 113. pl. 54. pro tanto.
Trees cutting.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to cut Trees and carry them to my houÅ¿e, RegiÅ¿t. 109. B.
AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es an agreement,Arbitrement. and doth it not, Coke 5. part. 77. B. Sammons caÅ¿ee. Ne. Lib. Intra. 3. B. Å¿ect. 4. for the other thereby is delaied in his right.

A grants his term to B, if C agree, B promiÅ¿es 20 l. to C for his aÅ¿Å¿ent,AÅ¿Å¿ent. this is a good aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it, Trin. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. in the caÅ¿e of GrieÅ¿ly and Louther; for the aÅ¿Å¿ent Å¿hall be intended to be for his benefit.
1. AgainÅ¿t one that promiÅ¿es to re-deliver money, and doth not, Lib. Intr. 10. Å¿ect. 1.
2. AgainÅ¿t a Baily that takes upon him to keep Cattel Å¿afe, and doth not, Lib. Intra 9. A. Å¿ect. 1. & fol. 3. B. Å¿ect. 1. but they are loÅ¿t by his negligence.

3. But if he promiÅ¿e to guard the goods, and after refuÅ¿es, no Action lies, Doct. & Student.
102. B. if there were no conÅ¿ideration taken to do it.
1. AgainÅ¿t a Carrier that undertakes to carry goods Å¿afe, and doth not,Carrior. 2 Hen. 7.11. Lib. Intra. 2. D. Å¿ect. 1. the Carrier is chargeable without Å¿uch a promiÅ¿e per legem terrae.
2. AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to carry Wine, and breaks the Pipe by negligence, RegiÅ¿t. 110. A. for one man muÅ¿t not be prejudiced by anothers negligence.
So if Oyl be carried, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 112. A.
Charitable deeds.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es 10 l. for the curing a poor man, Doct. & Student. 104. A. and pays it not.
For upon every promiÅ¿e, if the party be charged with it, an Action lies, although the other have no benefit, Doct. & Student. 104. A. but there muÅ¿t be a benefit to Å¿ome body.
AgainÅ¿t him who promiÅ¿es to make a Coach,Coach. and doth not, Nat. br. 94. A.

But the Plaintiff ought to count, that he did give money for the doing it, other ways it is but Nudum pactum, unde non oritur actio, 3 Hen. 6.36. pl. 33. for there was not reaÅ¿on why he Å¿hould do it.

Gathering Tithes. A promiÅ¿es, if B will aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him in the gathering of the Tithes of CheeÅ¿e, and Apples, and other Tithes till Å¿uch a time, he Å¿hould have 20 s. and B Å¿hews, that he did aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him Å¿o long in the gathering the Å¿aid Tithes, and good; for non conÅ¿tat that there are other Tithes, if there be they ought to be Å¿hewed by the other party, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Baker & Secker.
AgainÅ¿t him that takes upon him to repair my Dove-houÅ¿e,Dove-houÅ¿e. and doth it ill, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 110. B. whereby my houÅ¿e becomes of leÅ¿s profit. A work ill done is accounted as not done.
AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to make a CroÅ¿s,CroÅ¿s. and doth not, RegiÅ¿t. 109. B. This Action it Å¿eems lies not at this day. Q.

Delivery of a deed. A promiÅ¿es to deliver a deed upon requeÅ¿t, the requeÅ¿t ought to be Å¿hewed preciÅ¿ely, otherways if it be of a thing due before, or upon a Å¿ale; for in the former caÅ¿e the requeÅ¿t is traverÅ¿able, but not in the latter, PaÅ¿ch. 28 Eliz. Com. Ban.
DiÅ¿charge of a PriÅ¿oner.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to pay me as much as the other owed him, if I will diÅ¿charge him of the PriÅ¿oner, 27 Hen. 8.24.
Farrier & Smith.1. AgainÅ¿t a Smith that takes upon him to Å¿hoe my HorÅ¿e, and doth not, 14 Hen. 6.18.
2. Or to cure him, 19 Hen. 6.49. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 119. B. but here muÅ¿t be a conÅ¿ideration precedent.

It is not Å¿ufficient to do all he can, but he is bound to cure him: But upon a general retainer, without taking upon him the Cure, it is not Å¿o; for there the Law implies only, that he would do his beÅ¿t endeavour to do it, 43 Edw. 3.33. 45 Edw. 3.17. 48 Edw. 3.6. 27 AÅ¿Å¿ize 56.
And the Writ Å¿hall not Å¿ay contra pacem, 43 Edw. 3.33.
3. Quare tam negligenter & improvide impoÅ¿uit medicinas, &c. quod equui mortuus eÅ¿t, 43 Edw. 3.33. pl. 38. 19 Hen. 6.49. for the Law punniÅ¿heth negligence.

1. AgainÅ¿t a Ferryman that takes upon him to carry one over the water,Ferryman. and doth it not, and
this without conÅ¿ideration, becauÅ¿e his fare is certain, 22 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41. and recoverable by Law; for the Law makes the Contract.
2. For Å¿urcharging his Boat, by which my BeaÅ¿t is drowned, 22 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 40. for this is a misÅ¿eaÅ¿ance.

An AdminiÅ¿tratrix deÅ¿ires to be forborn till Å¿uch a time, and then Å¿he will pay the debt;Forbearance. this is a good aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿ie, Coke 9. part. 94. A. Banes caÅ¿e; and the Plaintiff needs not Å¿ay in the Count that Å¿he hath aÅ¿Å¿ets, for it Å¿hall be intended; but it ought to be given in evidence, for Å¿he is not chargeable if Å¿he have not quid pro quo, Coke 9. part. 92, 93, 94. Banes caÅ¿e, & fol. 90. B. Pinchons caÅ¿e.
The Å¿ame Law is of a Strangers promiÅ¿e,Forbearance. Coke 9. part. 94. A. for though the Stranger it may be hath no benefit, yet the Plaintiff may be prejudiced.
But then he ought to Å¿hew that the Plaintiff agreed to it, Mich. 39 Eliz. Com. Ban. Milwards caÅ¿e.
Then the Count ought to Å¿hew how the debt grew due, Coke 10. part. 77. A. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ea; for if there were no debt, there can be no cauÅ¿e of Action.

A counts that B was indebted to him in 20 l. but Å¿hews not how long; and that the 10. of September 7 Jac. B. promiÅ¿es, if the Plaintiff would not arreÅ¿t him, but forbear till the 21. of September he would pay him; and Å¿ets forth, that he did forbear Å¿o long per Curiam: if the Plaintiff counts of the forbearance for a certain time, there it is good, without Å¿hewing when the debt grew due; but otherways when the forbearance is for a
time uncertain, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Dean & Nuby. Q. differentiam.

The Count was, that the InteÅ¿tate was indebted to him in a 100 l. and the AdminiÅ¿trator in conÅ¿ideration of forbearance for a reaÅ¿onable time aÅ¿Å¿umes to pay, and upon non aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it pleaded it was found for the Plaintiff; 1. Coke Chief JuÅ¿tice Å¿aid, foraÅ¿much as the InteÅ¿tate was indebted, and the AdminiÅ¿trator promiÅ¿ed, &c. and pleaded non aÅ¿sumpÅ¿it, it Å¿hall be intended he had notice of the debt, therefore good; to which there was no anÅ¿wer: 2. forbearance by a reaÅ¿onable time is a good conÅ¿ideration, becauÅ¿e the Court may judge of it: but forbearance per paululum temporis is not good, to which the Court agreed, Trin. 14 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Lingill & Broughton; for the Court cannot judge of it, becauÅ¿e it is incertain.

The Count was, that where A. was indebted to him in 32 l. for which he Å¿ued A. and that it was agreed between him and A. to Å¿tay the Å¿uit, and if he payed it not before Mich. he Å¿hould give Å¿ecurity; 1. he need not Å¿hew how the debt grew due, becauÅ¿e the forbearance is the cauÅ¿e of Action, but otherways when the TeÅ¿tator is indebted and promiÅ¿es, for there the debt is the cauÅ¿e of the Action; 2. Coke Chief JuÅ¿tice, that he needs not Å¿hew, that he did Å¿urceaÅ¿e his Å¿uit, becauÅ¿e it was but a reciprocal agreement; but if A. in conÅ¿ideration that the Plaintiff Å¿hall Å¿urceaÅ¿e his Å¿uit promiÅ¿es to pay it, then he ought to Å¿hew that he did Å¿urceaÅ¿e, PaÅ¿ch. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Fullers caÅ¿e; for that is the ground of the Action.

W indebted to B, delivers goods to L to pay him, L prays B to Å¿tay 2 or 3 days, and he will
