pay him, L pays it not, B Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t L; for it is a good conÅ¿ideration, inÅ¿omuch that L had goods to Å¿atisfie, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Brande & LiÅ¿ter, by his own confeÅ¿Å¿ion implied in his aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it.

A pledges goods to B for money, and if A pay not at Å¿uch a day, that B Å¿hall have the goods after and afore the day, &c. C requeÅ¿ts B to forbear till another day and he would pay it, B may have an Action againÅ¿t C, if he pay it not; for if C pay the money, then he may have a Detinue againÅ¿t B for the goods, for by the payment C had a Å¿pecial property, Trin. 13 Jac. Ban. Regis, Capper & DickinÅ¿on; per Coke Chief JuÅ¿tice.

AgainÅ¿t a Goaler that promiÅ¿es to the Sheriff to keep Å¿afe his PriÅ¿oners, and lets them eÅ¿cape,Goaler. RegiÅ¿t. 110. A, & B. for the Sheriff is anÅ¿werable for the Å¿afe cuÅ¿tody of the PriÅ¿oners within his County.
AgainÅ¿t him that warrants for 10 l. that my Boat Å¿hall come Å¿afe upon the Thames, Warranty. 34 Hen. 8. br. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 107. and it doth not; for there ought to be quid pro que.

A LeaÅ¿es to B rendering Rent,LeÅ¿Å¿or. and paying all out-Rents and making reparations; the LeÅ¿Å¿or in conÅ¿ideration of this, promiÅ¿es defendere & Å¿uÅ¿tentare Å¿tatum & poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ionem of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, quiete & pacifice abÅ¿que interruptione; 1. here is a good conÅ¿ideration: 2. the Å¿aid ClauÅ¿e amounts to Å¿o much as if he had Å¿aid, that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall quietly enjoy his Term, Mich. 7 Jac. B. R. Gamble & Terrell.

Marriage money.1. AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es in Marriage 10 l. if he marry his daughter, No. Lib. Intr. 2. B. Å¿ect. 2, & 4. B. Å¿ect. 1. Doct. & Stud. 104. A. 16 Hen. 3. Prohibition 22. for the Marriage is a good conÅ¿ideration.

2. A being to marry B, C living with A. Å¿ays to B, if Å¿he Å¿hould marry A and his Father do not make Å¿uch a Joynter to her, he would give her a 100 l. B marries A, the Joynture is not made, A and B Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t C; for peradventure the marriage had not taken effect, but in regard of the promiÅ¿e of C, Mich. 29 of Eliz. Ban. Regis.

3. A promiÅ¿es to B 100 l. in conÅ¿ideration that B marrie his Daughter; this is a good conÅ¿ideration, inÅ¿omuch that the advancement continues, being even as in Frank-marriage after the marriage is good, Trin. 29 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Marche & Rayneforde.

4. A promiÅ¿es to B, that whereas his Son was a Suiter to his Daughter, if B would give his aÅ¿Å¿ent A would give to B 50 l. This is a good conÅ¿ideration, 1. becauÅ¿e the Daughter ought to have the conÅ¿ent of her Parents; 2. becauÅ¿e the Son of A was to have advancement by the marriage, Trin. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. Greicely & Louther. Q. whether a man Å¿hall be intended to be advanced by marriage, except it be Å¿hewn.

5. A promiÅ¿es 50 l. to C, if he marries B. In an Action upon the caÅ¿e for the 50 l. he is not bound to Å¿hew that he did give notice of the marriage, neither to make requeÅ¿t, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Brently & Tod; for A might as well take notice of the marriage as B, and the bringing of the Action is a requeÅ¿t in Law.

6. A having Å¿peech with El. Stukely about marriage with her, promiÅ¿eth to M. the Daughter of the Å¿aid Eliz. that if Å¿he marry him without diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of her eÅ¿tate, he will give to M in marriage
40 l. and in an Action brought upon this, inÅ¿omuch that Å¿he did not averr in his count, that Å¿he had not diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of her eÅ¿tate, it was not good, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Kings caÅ¿e; for that was the Å¿ole conÅ¿ideration.
Obtains a LeaÅ¿e.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to obtain a LeaÅ¿e for me for 10 l. and gets it for himÅ¿elf, 3 Hen. 7.14. Quaere, whether an Action of Deceit doth not lie.

A in conÅ¿ideration of divers Å¿ums received of divers perÅ¿ons to the uÅ¿e of the Plaintiff amounting to 24 l. aÅ¿Å¿umes to pay this,Payment. and adjudged a good count, though he doth not Å¿hew of whom he received the Å¿ums, becauÅ¿e this is not traverÅ¿able, for it is a conÅ¿ideration executed, Trin. 14 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Beckingham & Lambert; for the Account is confeÅ¿Å¿ed by the promiÅ¿e to pay.

Counts that upon an in Å¿imul computaÅ¿Å¿et the Defendant was indebted to him in 20 l. and promiÅ¿ed to pay it, &c. Crook JuÅ¿tice Å¿aid it was a good conÅ¿ideration; and Doderidge Å¿aid, that in every Action of debt an Action of the caÅ¿e is implied, and when it appears how the debt grew due, then it is a good AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it, Trin. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Cullimore and EyniÅ¿on.
AgainÅ¿t him that takes upon him to plant Thorns, and doth not do it,Planting. Lib. Intr. 13. C. Å¿ect. 1. for the planting may be for my benefit.
Save harmleÅ¿s.1. My Servant being in priÅ¿on, I requeÅ¿t his enlargement, and promiÅ¿e to Å¿ave A harmleÅ¿s, an Action lies if I do it not; but without requeÅ¿t not, 10 Eliz. Dyer 272. pl. 31.

2. If one become Bail for the Servant, and after the MaÅ¿ter promiÅ¿e to Å¿ave him harmleÅ¿s, an Action
lies not; for here is no conÅ¿ideration continuing Quaere, if he continue his Servant.

3. A being Bail for B in Ban. Regis, B promiÅ¿e to Å¿ave him harmleÅ¿s; yet A Å¿hall not have a â¢ Action againÅ¿t B although he pay the money, i â¢ no Capias be awarded againÅ¿t the Principal, ãâã
Scire facias againÅ¿t the Bail, Trin. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis. Bolles & Jones error upon Judgment in Com. Bu â¢
for here is no due proceedings in Law againÅ¿t either.

4. A being indebted to B, prays C to be bound to B for the debt, and he will be bound to C, & C is bound to B, &c. A refuÅ¿eth to be bound to C, C Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t A, for it is a goo â¢ conÅ¿ideration inÅ¿omuch that C is liable to the d â¢â¢
Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Knyvet & Pledall, and it ãâã reaÅ¿on A Å¿hould Å¿ecure him.

5. A promiÅ¿es to B to diÅ¿charge him, and Å¿ â¢â¢ him harmleÅ¿s from all bonds in which he w â¢â¢â¢ bound for the Son of A, at the requeÅ¿t of the Å¿ â¢â¢â¢ Son B. brought his Action, and Å¿hews that he ãâã
fidei juÅ¿Å¿or was bound. 1. It is a good conÅ¿ideration. 2. He ought to Å¿hew preciÅ¿ely that his S â¢â¢â¢ requeÅ¿ted him to be bound, for although fidei ju â¢â¢â¢
imply a requeÅ¿t, yet it is not Å¿ufficient, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, SomerÅ¿ton & B â¢ rnby, & poÅ¿tea Mich.
ãâã
Jac. it is Å¿hewed that it was alledged, and for th â¢ judgment was given for the Plaintiff, Lib. Intr. ãâã C. Sect. 1.

6. An Infant borrows money,Infant. B is bound ãâã pay it, at full age the Infant promiÅ¿es to Å¿ave his harmleÅ¿s, Action lies upon it; for although th â¢ Infant was not liable in Law, yet in ConÅ¿cience ãâã was, and this Å¿ufficeth to maintain an Action upo â¢
the CaÅ¿e, which is an equitable Action; for the conÅ¿ideration is good, Trin. 29 Eliz. Ban. Regis adjudged.

A Widow promiÅ¿eth for following her Suits to pay 200 l. this is not good;Sollicitor. for it is maintenance per 2. JuÅ¿tices, but Dyer againÅ¿t them; becauÅ¿e it did not appear that they were Suits in Law, 19. Eliz. Dyer 356. and they may be Suits in equity, or at the Court.

A promiÅ¿es 10 l. to B, Sufferance if he Å¿uffer C to enjoy the Land â¢ ; there although C enjoy it not, yet if A agree and do not interrupt C the Action lies, PaÅ¿ch. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Taylor & Wilks; for he hath performed the conÅ¿ideration on his part.

A being a Copyholder makes B his Executor, and intends to Å¿urrender, to the intent that B Å¿hould Å¿atisfie a debt to D; the Son of A promiÅ¿es A that if he do not Å¿urrender, but Å¿uffer the Land to deÅ¿cend, he will Å¿atisfie the debt, A dies, B Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t the Son; for it is a good conÅ¿ideration, Hill. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Gray verÅ¿us Gray, yet continuing.

Tabling & Lodging. A promiÅ¿es to pay to B, for his reaÅ¿onable board for Å¿uch a time as he Å¿hall be with him; B Å¿hews that he was with him ten months, and that 5 s. the month is reaÅ¿onable, amounting in all to 50 s. this is good, PaÅ¿ch. 30 Eliz. Ban. Begis, Floyd & IriÅ¿h.

A being Å¿ick in an Inne, B promiÅ¿es to pay as much as Å¿hall be due for all neceÅ¿Å¿aries that the Inn-keeper Å¿hall provide for A; yet in the Action the Inn-keeper Å¿hall Å¿ay generally in the Writ
and Count, that he did provide neceÅ¿Å¿aries from Å¿uch a day, until, &c. in all to the value of 20 l. foraÅ¿much as the promiÅ¿e was general, the Writ and Count is good though it be not particular. 2. It is inconvenient and dangerous to Å¿hew all things that he did provide, &c. the Å¿ame Law is for: PhyÅ¿ician per Doderidge JuÅ¿tice. PaÅ¿ch. 13 Jac. Ban. Regis, Crips. & Baynton; for he may not remember all particulars, and Å¿o may miÅ¿take.
1. For money upon the Å¿ale of any perÅ¿onal things,Vendor. 33 Hen. 8 br. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 105, 110. 2 Rich. 3.14. Com. 102. upon an indebitatus aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it; for the Law creates a promiÅ¿e.
For in every Contract there is an aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it implied, Coke 4. part. 94. Slades caÅ¿e; the Count needs not Å¿hew, but Å¿aepius requifitus, PaÅ¿ch. 28 Elis. Com. Ban. Q.

2. In an Action for money upon the Å¿ale of a thing, he needs not count that he was poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t ut de bonis propriis, Trin. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Fitz Willi â¢â¢ & Blackman. viz. before the Å¿ale; for the Law implies they were his, elÅ¿e he would not have Å¿old them.
3. AgainÅ¿t a Purveyor or Servant that bought goods for his MaÅ¿ter, and promiÅ¿es payment, Dyer 230. pl. 56. 12 Hen. 8.12. Q. if it lies not alÅ¿o againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter.
4. AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to a Baker to pay Å¿o much as he Å¿hall deliver in Bread to B, 29 Hen. 8.25. for it may be intended he gave B the Bread.

5. Upon a promiÅ¿e to pay for Cloth bought, i â¢
B doth not, 12 Hen. 8.12. for there he becomes i â¢ the nature of a Surety for the payment for it.

6. A brought an action, and Å¿hews that he Å¿old a HorÅ¿e to B at Å¿uch a day, year, and place, to be payed at a day to come, and the Defendant ad tunc & ibidem ratione praemiÅ¿Å¿orum aÅ¿Å¿umes to pay, if, &c. B did not; this is nought, for the Contract, and the giving of day to B, ne fuit ad inÅ¿tantiam of the Defendant; but the Contract was compleat before, PaÅ¿ch. 28 Jac. Ban. Regis, Farmer & Field, without any relation to the Defendant and his promiÅ¿es ex poÅ¿t facto, and grounded upon no conÅ¿ideration.

7. A promiÅ¿es to pay to B Å¿uch Å¿ums of money as B Å¿hall disburÅ¿e of his own money for Cloth, to the uÅ¿e of A the Defendant, this is a good conÅ¿ideration: for by the buying of the Cloth the property was in A forthwith, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Moore & Moore; for it was bought for him.

8. A Å¿old to B two ways of Barley for as much as he Å¿old to others, the Plaintiff in the Action ought to count, 1. For what price he Å¿old to others; 2. he ought to give notice of this to B. So if A promiÅ¿e to B 20 l. if he marry C, yet B ought to give notice of the marriage; but a Tayler may have an Action for as much as he Å¿hall deÅ¿erve, and is not bound to give notice what he Å¿hall deÅ¿erve, becauÅ¿e it is not incertain, Hill. 13 Jac. Ban. Regis, Hall & Heminge. Q. for he muÅ¿t demand a certain Å¿um, and this is notice.

1. AgainÅ¿t a Seller of Corn to be delivered at a certain day, and doth not,Vendee. 21 Hen. 6.55. 20 Hen. 7.9.28 Hen 8. Dyer 22. pl. 138. & fol. 113. pl. 55. Coke 4. part. Slades caÅ¿e 94. B. Quaere, it no damage appear.
2. For delivering good and merchantable Corn, and doth not, 6 Edw. 2.6. Dyer 75. pl. 23. Lib. Intra. 4. B. Å¿ect. 2. but Å¿pecial dammage muÅ¿t be alledged.

div.head: The Judgment.
div.p: For not delivering of grain yearly, quaere if the Plaintiff Å¿hall recover dammage as well pro tempore futuro quam pro praeterito, 3 Mariae, Dyer 113. pl. 56.

AdminiÅ¿tratrix promiÅ¿es to pay a debt, &c. and the Action is brought againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, then the judgment againÅ¿t him Å¿hall be general, & praedictus P. & M. uxor ejus in miÅ¿ericordis, Coke 9. part. 93. Banies caÅ¿e, No. Lib. Intra. 2. C. Sect. 3.
But upon plea, that the TeÅ¿tator did not aÅ¿Å¿ume, coÅ¿ts and dammages Å¿hall be de bonis propriis, if the TeÅ¿tator had not Å¿uffici â¢ nt, No. Lib. Intra. 1. B. Å¿ect. 1. for the falÅ¿e plea.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: Upon aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it by the Husband and Wife, made to the Wife dum Å¿ola fuit, the Writ Å¿hall Å¿ay, ad dampnum ipÅ¿orum; for the Husband Å¿hall have the dammages, ideoque fuit ad dampnum ipÅ¿orum, Hill. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wolverton and his WiÅ¿e againÅ¿t Day.

div.head: For not doing a thing which ought to be done by Agreement touching the body.
div.p: 1. AgainÅ¿t a Barber that takes upon him to raze the Beard,Barber. and doth it with an unwholÅ¿om Razor, Lib. Intra. 2. C. Å¿ect. 1. for the body is endangered to be hurt thereby.

PhyÅ¿ician or Chirurgeon.2. AgainÅ¿t a PhyÅ¿ician or Chirurgeon for not curing a malady, or not applying a medicine, 14 Hen. 6.18. 43 Edw. 3.33. 21 Hen. 6.55. 48 Edw. 3.6. pl. 11. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. B. 112. A.
3. For adviÅ¿ing his patient to apply a certain medicine to cure him, and it did not, 19 Hen. 6.49. quaere.
For commanding his Servant to apply a medicine, and he doth it not, 11 Edw. 4.6. Q.
4. For applying a medicine that impairs the Mayheme, 11 Rich. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 37.11 Hen. 6.18. pl. 10. 21 Hen. 6.55. B.
But note in all theÅ¿e caÅ¿es he ought to take upon him the Cure abÅ¿olutely, 19 Hen. 6.49. 48 Edw. 3.6. elÅ¿e the Action lies not.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: The Writ ought to Å¿hew the place where he took upon him the Cure, 48 Edw. 3.36. for it is iÅ¿Å¿uable.

If A promiÅ¿e to cure me in London, and apply unwholÅ¿om medicines in MiddleÅ¿ex, the Action Å¿hall be in MiddleÅ¿ex, becauÅ¿e there was the wrong, 11 Rich. 2. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 37, and where the wrong is there muÅ¿t the trial be.

div.head: For not doing of a thing which ought to be done by agreement of the parties touching Suits in Law.AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t a Clerk that promiÅ¿es to enroll a Deed,Clerk. and doth it not, 34 Hen. 6.4.
Serjeant. CounÅ¿ellor.AgainÅ¿t a Serjeant or CounÅ¿ellor that promiÅ¿es to plead for me, and doth it not, 14 Hen. 6.18. if I retain him and give him his fee, elÅ¿e not.

div.head: For not doing of a thing where a man is bound to do it in one manner, and he doth it in another.
div.p: Plough my land.AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to plough my land, and doth it in unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable time, 14 Hen. 6.18. 3 Hen. 6.36. for the Law implies he muÅ¿t do it for my beÅ¿t advantage.
AgainÅ¿t an Attorney that takes an obligation in his own name,Attorney. when it Å¿hould have been in mine, 20 Hen. 6.25. Q. if an Action of Deceit do not lie.

AgainÅ¿t a Carpenter that undertakes to build a houÅ¿e in Å¿uch a form,Carpenter. and builds it in another, Nat. br. 145. G. 2. Hen. 4.9. 21 Hen. 7.41. 20 Hen. 6.35. Q. if he build it in a better form, and more for the benefit of the Owner, and to his own loÅ¿s.
AgainÅ¿t him that hath a Crane, and Å¿poils my Merchandize,Cranage. Lib. Intr. 3. C. Å¿ect. 1. this is miÅ¿feaÅ¿ance.
AgainÅ¿t a Farrier that takes upon him to cure my HorÅ¿e,Farrier. and applies unwholÅ¿om Medicines, &c. 19 Hen. 6.49. whereby my HorÅ¿e is made worÅ¿e.

For pricking my HorÅ¿e, 46 Edw. 3.2, 3.10. Nat: br. 94. D. 18 Edw. 3 6. pl. 11. for it is the duty of an Artificer to do his office well and truly; and this is implied in Law upon his undertaking to uÅ¿e his art.
For miÅ¿uÅ¿ing a LicenÅ¿e,LicenÅ¿e. 21 Edw. 4.76. quaere what.

AgainÅ¿t a Serjeant at Law that is retained to plead, and miÅ¿pleads,MiÅ¿pleader. 14 Hen. 6.18. for this is misfeaÅ¿ance, and to his Clients prejudice it may be, but if it be not tunc quaere. To miÅ¿plead is to plead otherwiÅ¿e than he is inÅ¿tructed by his Client.

div.head: For negligent Å¿uffering of a thing to be done to the damage of another.
div.p: A borrowed a HorÅ¿e of me, which dies Å¿uddenly,Borrowed. an Action lies not, 40 Edw. 3.6. for the borrower was in no fault.
But if the thing be uÅ¿ed in other manner than it was lent to be uÅ¿ed, and dies, an Action lies, Doct. & Stud. 29. for this is miÅ¿uÅ¿ing of it, and contrary to the agreement.
But if it be but in the Å¿ame manner that it was lent, and dies, no Action lies, Doct. & Stud. 29. for it was lent to be uÅ¿ed, though not miÅ¿uÅ¿ed.

A borrowed a HorÅ¿e, and a HouÅ¿e fell upon him; there if the houÅ¿e fell upon him being feeble, Action lies, otherwiÅ¿e not, Doct. & Stud. 128. for he might have foreÅ¿een the danger, and prevented it.

Burning a HouÅ¿e.AgainÅ¿t him that keeps not well his fire, by which my houÅ¿e is burned, being adjoyning, 2 Hen. 4.18. 8 Edw. 4.19. pl. 30. Choke; for we
muÅ¿t Å¿o uÅ¿e our own that we hurt not another.
Although his own houÅ¿e be burned, 33 Hen. 6.1. Lib. Intr. 8. A. Å¿ect. 1. for his own harm is no recompence to his Neighbour.

3. It lies although his Servant do it: but not if a Å¿tranger do it of malice, 33 Hen. 6.1. 2 Hen. 4.18. Doct. & Stud. 137. for the MaÅ¿ter muÅ¿t be anÅ¿werable for the actions of his Servants in civil matters, though not in criminal.
4. If a Servant bring fire in the Å¿treet and buro a houÅ¿e, his MaÅ¿ter is not chargeable; for when the Servant is out of his houÅ¿e he is not under his government.

5. It lies not if it be burned Å¿uddenly, and the cauÅ¿e not known, 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8.2 Hen. 4.18. for the Law delights in certainties, and doth things upon juÅ¿t and Å¿ure grounds, and not upon probabilities and Å¿urmiÅ¿es.

div.head: Barr.
div.p: That it was not burnt in default of good cuÅ¿tody of the fire of the Defendant, Lib. Intra. 8. A. Å¿ect. 1.
But by 28 Hen. 6.7. this is but a negative pregnant; for he might have pleaded non culp. which the other plea doth but imply.
That he guarded his fire well, abÅ¿que hoc that he guarded it negligently, Lab. Intra. 8. B. Å¿ect. 2. for here is a direct affirmative, and a traverÅ¿ing of Plaintiffs declaration.
AgainÅ¿t a Baily of Cloth, that Å¿uffers it to be conÅ¿umed with Moths.Baily. 27 Hen. 8.25.13 Hen. 7.1.18 Edw. 3.23. viz. by negligent keeping, which the Law implies he ought not to do.
AgainÅ¿t a Baily of a horÅ¿e that Å¿uffers him to periÅ¿h, 12 Edw. 4.13.26 Hen. 8 br. Action upon the CaÅ¿e 103. Lib. Intr. 3. B. Å¿ect. 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 107. A. for the former reaÅ¿on.
For loÅ¿ing a ReleaÅ¿e, 34 Hen. 6.4. for the ReleaÅ¿ee may be prejudiced thereby.
So of a box, Lib. Intra. 9. A. Å¿ect. 1.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿uffers his Dog to bite my Å¿heep,Dog. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 25. pl. 102. & fol. 29. pl. 195. 28 Hen. 6.7. pl. 7. Lib. Intr. 616. B. Å¿ect. 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 110. B.
But then the MaÅ¿ter ought to know that he would bite them, ibidem; for then he might have prevented it, and Å¿o is puniÅ¿hable for not doing it.
But Å¿ciens is not traverÅ¿able; but may be given in evidence, Coke 44. part. 188. for if he did not know it he may plead Not guilty, and the Plaintiff muÅ¿t prove he knew it.
If the owner of the Dog brings him to the MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿heep to do juÅ¿tice upon him, it lies not, 7 Edw. 3. bar 290. viz. upon the firÅ¿t notice or knowledge of it, otherwiÅ¿e not.

The Plaintiff declares, that the Defendant was poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of a Dog 8. Octobris 7 Jac. uÅ¿ing to bite, &c. and that the Dog 12. October in the Å¿ame year did bite his Lambs, &c. this is not good; for he ought to have Å¿hewn, that he continued his Dog at the time of the biting; for it Å¿hall not be preÅ¿umed that he continued it without Å¿hewing it, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Louder verÅ¿us Sounds, 21 Edw. 4.22. 15 Eliz. Dyer 320. for the Law will not preÅ¿ume any one will do an unlawful act, except it be proved.
4. For Å¿uffering his Dog to bite my Servant, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 111. A. per quod Å¿ervitium amiÅ¿it, elÅ¿e not, as it Å¿eems.
5. For hurting of an Ox, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 111. A. whereby he loÅ¿eth his work, or is hindred in his fatting.
6. For hurting of a HorÅ¿e after warning given, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 106. A. for the MaÅ¿ter ought to have kept him up.

1. AgainÅ¿t a Warden of the Fleet,EÅ¿cape. that Å¿uffers one to eÅ¿cape that was taken upon a Capias ad computandum, 15 Edw. 4.19. Lib. Intra. 8. C. Sect. 1. for thereby the Plaintiff is put to more trouble and charge, and is delayed in his Suit.
2. AgainÅ¿t a Sheriff, that Å¿uffers one to eÅ¿cape that was taken upon a Statute Merchant, Reg â¢â¢ . orig. 98. B. Nat. br. 93. A. the Writ there, upon the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

AgainÅ¿t an Inn-keeper,Innkeeper. that Å¿uffers the goods of his gueÅ¿ts to be Å¿tole, Coke 4. part. 32. Calyes caÅ¿e, Nat. 94. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 104. A, 105. A. 22 Hen. 6.21. 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 17. for the Law of the Land binds him to keep them Å¿afe at his peril.

1. But note, 1. this ought to be a common Inne, and it Å¿hall be Å¿hewed in the Count, but not in the Writ, 11 Hen. 4.45. 22 Hen. 6.21. pl. 38. Coke 8. part. 32. Calyes caÅ¿e, Dyer 206. pl. 9.2 Hen. 4. Not in the Writ, becauÅ¿e that is more Å¿hort, & ren breviter enarrat; but the Count ought to expreÅ¿s things more fully.

2. It ought to be a Traveller that lodges there, otherwiÅ¿e the Action lies not, Coke 8. part. 32. Calyes caÅ¿e; for the Law looks upon an Inn only
in reÅ¿pect of Travellers, for in reÅ¿pect of others it is no more than a private houÅ¿e.

4. He Å¿hall declare of nothing but what was within his Inn; for if he bid the Inn-keeper put his HorÅ¿e to paÅ¿ture, or put him to paÅ¿ture of his own accord, unleÅ¿s the Inn-keeper requeÅ¿t him to do it, it lies not, Coke 8. part. 32. A. Calyes caÅ¿e; for he is an Inn-keeper in reÅ¿pect of his HouÅ¿e, and not of his Land.

4. He ought Å¿afely to keep the goods within his Inn at his peril, 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 17. for it is no excuÅ¿e that he delivered the Key to the GueÅ¿t, 42 Edw. 3.11. pl. 13. 11 Hen. 4.45. 22 Hen. 6.38. or that the GueÅ¿t did not acquaint him with his goods, 42 Edw. 3.11. except the GueÅ¿t will not truÅ¿t the Inn-keeper, but will have the Key. Quaere.
Or that he knew not the Felons, 22 Hen. 6.38. A; for he muÅ¿t keep them Å¿afe againÅ¿t all perÅ¿ons, except forein Enemies.

But if the Companion or Servant, or any other that the GueÅ¿t deÅ¿ires to lie with him, rob him, the Inn-keeper Å¿hall not be accountable, Coke 8. part. 33. A. Calyes caÅ¿e, 22 Hen. 6.38. B. 22 Hen. 6.22. A. for that was his own fault to admit of Å¿uch Company.

Or if he Å¿ay his houÅ¿e is full, and the other Å¿ays he will make a Å¿hift, and be robbed, 5 Mariae, Dyer 158. pl. 32. for in Å¿uch caÅ¿e he is not properly his GueÅ¿t, nor takes any charge of him or his goods.

Or if he command him to put his goods in Å¿uch a place, and he will not, but Å¿uffer them to lie in the open Court, 10 Eliz. Dyer 266. pl. 9. for if
he cannot be MaÅ¿ter to order his houÅ¿e as he deÅ¿ires, it is no reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould be puniÅ¿hed for the diÅ¿order committed in it.

And although the Writ is but bona & catalla, yet Evidences and all other Deeds are included: the Writ in this caÅ¿e Å¿hall be general, but the Count Å¿pecial, Coke 8. part. 33. Calyes caÅ¿e. Deeds and Evidences are bona & catalla, though not valuable to any perÅ¿on but the owner of them.

But an Inn-keeper Å¿hall not be accountable for wrong done to the perÅ¿on of his GueÅ¿t, Coke 8. part. 33. A, & B. Calyes caÅ¿e; for this is a criminal matter, and hath no relation to him as an Inn-keeper.

1.Servant. AgainÅ¿t a Shepherd, that Å¿uffers my Å¿heep to be drowned, 2 Hen. 7.11. pl. 9. Coke 5 part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e. 12 Edw. 3.4.13. Dyer 121. pl. 17. B. Salops caÅ¿e. 12 Edw. 3.4.13. Dyer 121. pl. 17. by negligence.
2. AgainÅ¿t a Ploughman that Å¿uffers my Corn to be Å¿poiled, 7 Hen. 4.14. by negligence, or ignorance, as it Å¿eems. Q.

div.head: For Deceit in bargains and agreements with Warranty.Deceit in Bargains.
div.p: 1. The Warranty of a thing Å¿old is the cauÅ¿e of an Action in caÅ¿e of vendition, as well as of corruption, 19 Hen. 6.9.
2. And the Warranty ought to be at the time of the Å¿ale, 15 Hen. 7.41, Nat. br. 98. L. and not afterwards, 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 75. pl. 28. elÅ¿e not good.

3. It ought to be by the owner of the thing, and not by a Stranger; and upon the Å¿ale by the owner, and not by a Servant, 11 Edw. 4.6.
for Warranty relates immediately to him that warrants.
It is not material whether the price be paid or not, for debt lies for it, 9 Hen. 7.21. pl. 2.
AgainÅ¿t the Seller of a HorÅ¿e that is Å¿ick,HorÅ¿e. and is warranted Å¿ound, Nat. br. 94. C. 7 Rich. 2.42. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 108. A. Lib. Intr. 9. B. Å¿ect. 1. for this is deceit.
Or a lame HorÅ¿e warranting Å¿ound, 31 Hen. 6.11. Statham.
A Å¿trained HorÅ¿e it lies not, becauÅ¿e the buyer hath the view, 13 Hen. 4.1. pl. 4. Hank ford. Q. if he warrant him Å¿ound.
AgainÅ¿t a Seller of Cloth,Cloth. that warrants it well Å¿ulled when it is raw, 11 Hen. 6.221.

AgainÅ¿t him that warrants it of Å¿uch a length, and this upon Å¿ale and warranty of the Servant, it lies againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter, 11 Edw. 4 6. for it lies not againÅ¿t the Servant, ibidem, for the Cloth was the MaÅ¿ters.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells grain,Grain. and warrants it to be good, Lib. Intra. 9. B. Å¿ect. 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 111. A. whereas it is muÅ¿ty or corrupted.
AgainÅ¿t him that warrants Herrings,Herring. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 96. A. in the number and the goodneÅ¿s.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells a Saphire inÅ¿tead of a Diamond,Saphire. Kitchin 174.
AgainÅ¿t a Seller of wood,Wood. and Å¿hews part, and warrants the reÅ¿t to be good, 14 Hen. 6.22. pl. 66.
AgainÅ¿t a Seller of corrupt Wine with warranty,Wine. Nat. br. 94. C. 9 Hen. 6.35. 7 Hen. 4.14. pl. 19. that it is Å¿ound and wholÅ¿om.
If the Servant Å¿old it by covin of the MaÅ¿ter, Action lies againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter, 9 Hen. 6.53. pl. 37. for it is the MaÅ¿ters act.

div.head: For deceits in Bargains and Agreements, without Warranty.
div.p: Deceit in bargain.1. AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells a HorÅ¿e not Å¿ound, knowing him to be Å¿o without warranty, 20 Hen. 6.34. 13 Hen. 4.2. Kitchin 174. Q. for it Å¿eems it lies not; yet if it doth, it is becauÅ¿e the Law hates deceit in Contracts, for it hinders Commerce, which is beneficial to the Commonwealth.
For Å¿elling an HorÅ¿e to another that was not his own,HorÅ¿e. 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8. Coke 4. part. 18. B. for this is fraud.
For Å¿elling Cloth that is nought,Cloth. knowing it to be Å¿o without warranty, 21 Hen. 7.91. pl. 16. Crooke.
AgainÅ¿t him that promiÅ¿es to deliver good Gum,Gum. and doth not, Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, WeÅ¿ton & Deighton.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells Wine mixed with water,Wine. Nat. br. 88. F. for this is but part Wine, and Å¿o the buyer hath not what he paid for.
For uttering Corrupt victual,Victual. knowing it to be Å¿o, 19 Hen. 6.53. 22 Hen. 7.91. pl. 16. Crooke. 11 Edw. 4.6. B. Brian & Neal.
AgainÅ¿t him that Å¿ells good Wax and delivers ill,Wax. 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 75. pl. 18. Q. whether in all theÅ¿e caÅ¿es an Indictment at the Common Law will not lie: It Å¿eems it will.

div.head: Trover and Conversion.

list.head: In Law. In Deed.
list.item:
1. Delivery as to persons unknown, 33 Hen.
Trover Quid & Quotuplex. 8. Br. Action upon the Case 109. Trover for a Hawk with bells reclaimed and sold, knowing it to be the Plaintiffs, 14 Eliz. Dyer 306. pl. 66. for he cannot recover it against the Vendee. Q. The Sale here makes the Conversion. Sold as to persons unknown, Lib. Intra. 5. A. Sect. 1.
2. Wasting the goods, 34 Hen. 8. br. Action upon the Case 103. for this a Conversion in Law.

3. Denial to re-deliver. A brought an Action for Plate and Jewels, and shews, that upon request the Defendant refused to deliver them, this is good evidence to a Jury; but to find it at large, viz. without a request, is not a sufficient Conversion to warrant the Action, Coke 10. part. 46. B. Oxfords case, Hill. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Isack & Clarke, per 3 Justices, 33 Hen. 6.27. for the Count is in usum suum proprium convertit & disposuit; but a nude denial is not a Conversion, Q. viz. that he hath the goods.

div.p: But if it be for money out of a bag,Money. then it is a good Conversion, if he deny it, because it cannot be known, Pasch. 14 Eliz. in Le chequer, and so the Plaintiff cannot prove that it was his money which was denied.
Note, if the Plaintiff have not property in the things, it lies not, 20 Hen. 7. B. pl. 18. Q. what property he must have.

1 Pasch. Note. 43 in Eliz. Bushopps case it was a doubt, if A takes goods to the use of B, and afterwards B agree to the taking; quaere, if such Action lies against B. quia A divests the property by the taking, and not B by the consenting, as it seems.
2. The count ought to shew the place of conversion, Mich. 26, 27 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Stranhams case; because it is traversable and issuable.
So the day of the Conversion, Hill. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis; for the same reason, and without shewing that the Defendant knows not how to plead in bar.

If the count be of Trover, and the Jury find upon Bailment; yet good, for the Conversion is the point of action, Hill. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Isack & Clark, and not the Trover, for it is no fault to find a thing, for no property is gained by the bat finding, but by the Conversion.

div.head: Of what things it lies.
div.p: 1.Money. It lies for money out of a purse upon special matter, that he lost it and the other found it, Trin. 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. Hall & Wood; Pasch. 24 Eliz. in the Exchequer; but not generally, for money cannot be known, and so the Plaintiff can fix no property in himself.

2. The Master delivers Corn to the Servant to fell, and brings his action for the money and goods; 1. the possession of the Servant is the possession of the Master. 2. It lies of money, Mich. 4, & 41 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Holliday & Higges; for the money comes in lieu of the Corn.
It lies for 20 Sheep,Sheep. Coke 5. part. 109. Foxleys case.
It lies for a Chain-door, sound and sold,Chaindoor. Horse. 3 Mariae, Dyer 121. pl. 14.
It lies of a Horse.

But it is no plea for the Defendant that a person unknown stole them, and left them, & waiviavit, without shewing the circumstances when and where, Coke 5. part. Foxleys case 109. A. but if he had said, quidam ignotus waiviavit them, without saying any more, this is good; for the circumstances shall be intended; for waiviavit est vecabulum artis, and implies all, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Leader & Paschall.
1. To traverse the sale is a good plea, 3 Mariae Dyer 121. pl. 16. viz. to say, he did not sell them.

2. That he distrained them for a Rent charge absque hoc, that he converted them, this is nought; for it is no Conversion at all, ideoque it amounts but to the gneral issue, non culp. Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Davies & Knap.
That he is a Horse-breaker, and the Plaintiff delivered it for him, &c. Absque hoc, &c. this amounts but to the general issue, non culp. Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Lovelace & Martyn, and not good.

Husband and Wife shall have this Action for a Deed by which an Annuity was granted to the Wife;Deeds. for the Wife should have it, if she survive the Husband, Trin. 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. Russel & Catesby; and the Husband is to have it during his life, viz. to make use of upon occasion.
It lies for twenty Pooks of Corn,Frument and Grain. Trin. 38. Eliz. Com. Ban. Price versus Sr. Walter Sands.
It lies of four bushels of Wheat, Trin. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Hill & Hawkes.

The Defendant shews a prescription in the Baily of L. to elect a Belman, which ought to repair the street of the Market-place, and to cleanse it, and that he shall have of every bushel there brought to sell, one pint of Wheat, &c. and justifies, &c. this is good, because the custome is doubtful and may be put in issue, therefore a good bar; otherwise this plea would amount unto the general issue; Trin. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Hill & Hawks, and then it would not be good.
For delivering of Jewels, &c. in a Box to B, who dies,Jewels. and they come to C, who breaks the Box and converts them, 20 Hen. 7.4, pl. 13.

That he did not convert them to his own use is a good bar; for the Trover and breaking of the Box are but conveyances to the Conversion, 20 Hen. 7.4. pl. 13. per Fineux, and not the ground of the Action.

It lies of Quinquaginta pondus of Wool ad valentiam, Wool. &c. for per Curiam pondus shall be taken one pound weight, because this weight is more certainly known throughout all the Countrey, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Roe & Lloyd; & loquendum est ut vulgus.
It lies of a 100 load of wood, and 40 Beeches,Wood. No. Lib. Intr. 41. B. sect. 33. Q. whether loads be not incertain.

Of three Monkeys,Monkey. and error brought because that they did not Å¿ay they were tame, Mich. 9 Jac. in Exchequer Chamber, Shackley & Porter, if tame. Quaere, whether they are valuable and considerable in Law, being only Creatures of pleasure.

It lies of forty measures of Pippins, scil. Bushels,Pippins. Mich. 9 Jac. in Exchequer. Err. inter Claydon & Taylor. Q. for they are perishable things, and may be rotten before they can be recovered, and so not to be recovered in kind; yet dammages may be recovered, and so it may lie.

div.head: Covenant.
Conventio est quasi Transactio.

list.item: 1. Warranty de qui non est bact.
2. Covenant de que non est hact. be seized to use.
31 Edw. 3. cap. 11. Administrator shall have it, and be subject to a Covenant
32 Hen. 8. cap. 34. Grants against Lessees & Ã¨ converso.

div.head: In what Court Covenant lies, 1. Personal; 2. Real.
div.p: 1. IT lies in the County or Hundred Court, Nat. br. 145. E.
2. It lies in any Court of the Lord of a Mannor, Nat. br. 145. E.
3. In London, Nat. br. 146. A. and other Corporations.
1. Marshalsey between two of the Houshold of the King, Coke 10. part. 74. A. otherwise not.
2. In the Court of the Lord of a Mannor by special grant, 44 Edw. 3.28. pl. 18. & fol. 37. pl. 30. Lib. Intr. 296. A. sect. 1. 50 Assize pl. 9.
A Fine levied in the County Palatine of Lancaster, good, 37 Hen. 8. cap. 19. which is in nature of a Covenant.
In Banco Regis, 36 Hen. 6.34. A. Forteseue, but it shall be avoided by Writ of Error. Q. except it be meant of a fine.
In Ancient demesn, quaere per 6 Edw. 3.207. pl. 20. it seems it should lie.
But 44 Edw. 3.37. 50 Assize 9. Knivet, it is not good. Q.
But 22 Hen. 7.90. B. pl. 14. Crooke, a fine may be levied in Ancient demesn, per petty Writ of Right close.
In Eire, good, 1 Edw. 3.10. pl. 34. 8 Edw. 3.27. 18 Edw. 3.40. pl. 33. that is, before Justices in Eire or Itinerantes.
In Communi Banco.
Before the Justices of the grand Sessions in Wales, 34 Hen. 8. cap. 26.
Who Å¿hall have Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
If a man Covenant with another to enfeoff him, or to Å¿erve him, &c. the other Å¿hall have covenant, although he do not agree, Nat. br. 145. A.
But then it ought to be by deed, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. B. Nat. br. 145. A, & G. 7 Rich. 2. deeds 160. which is an eÅ¿toppel to Å¿ay the other did not agree.
Yet in London a man Å¿hall have covenant to levy a fine without deed per cuÅ¿tome, Nat. br. 146. A. 22 Edw. 4.2. pl. 6. VaviÅ¿or. 21 Hen. 6.10. Covenant 11.
AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have Covenant by the equity of the Stat. AdminiÅ¿trator. de 31 Edw. 3. cap. 11. Coke 9. part. 40. A. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, made for Executors.
But not before, 19 Edw. 3. Covenant 24.
AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have Covenant,AÅ¿Å¿ignee. where it is made to one and his AÅ¿Å¿igns, Nat. br. 145. C. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. B. for the AÅ¿Å¿ignee is in place of the AÅ¿Å¿ignor.

AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have Covenant without Å¿hewing the deed of covenant,AÅ¿Å¿ignee. for he may not have it, Trin. 36 Eliz. Banco Regis, Noke verÅ¿us Ander. But there, if the LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years by eÅ¿toppel grant over his term, the AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall not have Covenant, becauÅ¿e the AÅ¿Å¿ignor had nothing in the land, but only an eÅ¿toppel againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or not to out him.

A, Prior with the aÅ¿Å¿ent of his Covent by deed, covenants for him and his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors with B and his heirs, that he and his Covent Å¿hall Å¿ing in the Chappel of B, which is parcel of the Mannor of B, for the Lords of the Å¿aid Mannor.
The AÅ¿Å¿ignee of B Å¿hall have covenant, becauÅ¿e it is a Å¿ervice annexed to the Mannor, 42 Edw. 3.3. pl. 14. Coke 5. part. 17. B. Spencers caÅ¿e, 45 Edw. 3.3. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 24. pl. 149. 2 Hen. 4.6. pl. 25. and who Å¿o hath the Mannor, or is intereÅ¿Å¿ed in the Covenant.
But if the Å¿ervice is to be made in the Chappel of another, then the AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall not have covenant, becauÅ¿e it is not annexed to the Mannor, 2 Hen. 46. pl. 25.

And Å¿o if one covenant with a Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie to Å¿ing in his houÅ¿e, although that he Å¿urrender and take for years he Å¿hall have Covenant, becauÅ¿e it was annexed to his eÅ¿tate, 6 Hen. 4.1. pl. 5. viz. for life. Q.
AÅ¿Å¿ignee by word Å¿hall have covenant, Coke 3. part. 63. A. Lincoln Colledges caÅ¿e; for Å¿uch an aÅ¿Å¿ignment is good.
AÅ¿Å¿ignee of AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have covenant, Coke 5. part. 71. B. and Å¿o in infinitum, as it Å¿eems, Å¿o long as the eÅ¿tate aÅ¿Å¿igned continues, if the Covenant go with the eÅ¿tate.
AÅ¿Å¿ignee of one Coparcener Å¿hall have covenant againÅ¿t the other coparcener to acquit him of the Å¿uit, becauÅ¿e the covenant goes with the land, Coke 5. part. 18. A. Spencers caÅ¿e, 42 Edw. 3.3.

LeÅ¿Å¿or covenants to repair the houÅ¿e lett, the AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have covenant againÅ¿t him, becauÅ¿e this is annexed to the eÅ¿tate: Å¿o the husband of the wife that is a Termor, and a Tenant per Statute Merchant Å¿taple, and every one that comes to the land Coke 5. part. 17. Spencers caÅ¿e, to which the Covenant is annexed.
So in all caÅ¿es where it is annexed to the eÅ¿tate, Nat. br. 146. C. 48 Edw. 3. and not to the perÅ¿on otherwiÅ¿e than in relation to the Land.

AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a reverÅ¿ion Å¿hall have covenant as well as the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have it, per 32 Hen. 8. cap. 34. but this is when it concerns the things demiÅ¿ed, and not collateral Covenants, Coke 5. part. 18. A. Spencers caÅ¿e; for in reÅ¿pect of ReverÅ¿ion of the thing lett, he comes in room of the LeÅ¿Å¿or in privity of eÅ¿tate.

AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a ReverÅ¿ion for years when, the Tenant for years hath a greater Term, his AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have Covenant within, 32 Hen. 8. although the LeÅ¿Å¿or grant over his Term, Trin. 40 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rot. 123. Natures verÅ¿us WeÅ¿twood, quaere.
AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall have covenant, upon covenant in Law, Coke 4. part. 80. B. 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. where it goes with the eÅ¿tate.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants with the LeÅ¿Å¿or and his heirs to repair the houÅ¿e, the AÅ¿Å¿ignee of the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have covenant, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, BeÅ¿twicke & Wilborne; for it goes with the houÅ¿e.

Husband and WiÅ¿e.LeaÅ¿e for years to the Husband and Wife, the LeÅ¿Å¿or outs them, they may joyn in covenant, becauÅ¿e after the death of the husband Å¿he Å¿hall have a term, if he grant it not over, 47 Edw. 3.12. pl. 11. and Å¿o Å¿he hath a poÅ¿Å¿ibility of intereÅ¿t.

The Commonalty of D Covenants with the Major and Commonalty of L, Corporation. that they Å¿hall be quit of Toll, &c. in D, and after one BurgeÅ¿s in D takes toll of one in L, Covenant lies for one Corporation againÅ¿t another, 48 Edw. 3.17. pl. 2. It may be brought by the Major and Commonalty
of one Corporation againÅ¿t the Major and Commonalty of the other Corporation.

Executor Å¿hall have Covenant for Covenant made to his TeÅ¿tator for a perÅ¿onal thing,Executor. for the perÅ¿onal eÅ¿tate is his to the uÅ¿e of the TeÅ¿tators will, Nat. br. 145. D. and orig. RegiÅ¿t. 165. B. Note, de conventione pro executoribus non invenitur breve in RegiÅ¿tr. Å¿ed pro aÅ¿Å¿ignatis, tamen poteÅ¿t fieri pro executoribus tam bene quam pro aÅ¿Å¿ignatis, nam eadem eÅ¿t ratio de utriÅ¿que.

A leaÅ¿es to B for life for 12 years, and B dies within the 12 years, the Executors of B Å¿hall have it until 12 years, &c. B dies, A outs the Executors within 12 years, they Å¿hall have Covenant, 19 Edw. 3. Covenant 24.

Executor of an Executor.Executor of an Executor Å¿hall have Covenant by the Common Law, 19 Edw. 3. Covenant 24. pol. Com. 290. Chapmans caÅ¿e, Lib. Intr. 134. B. Å¿ect. 1. and Å¿o forwards, for the right dies not.

The Heir Å¿hall have covenant,Heir. if the deed be made to him and his heirs, Nat. br. 145. C. 16 Eliz. Dyer 338. pl. 39. but this was to enfeoff him and his heirs: Å¿o that this holds not generally, but where the heir is intereÅ¿Å¿ed in the Covenant.

A enfeoffs B in Å¿ee, rendring for 8 years one RoÅ¿e, and afterwards 20 RoÅ¿es, B dies, his heir within Age, the Lord recovers the Land by reaÅ¿on of ColluÅ¿ion, the Heir at full age Å¿hall have covenant, 18 Edw. 3 Covenant 7. in reÅ¿pect of his privity to the Covenant.

A covenants with B and C and their heirs,Joynttenant. & eorum utri
que
to make an eÅ¿tate to the heir of him which firÅ¿t dies (being Parcener) the heir of one Å¿hall have covenant Å¿ole, 16 Eliz. Dyer 338. pl. viz. of him that firÅ¿t dies.

When any of the Covenantees Å¿hall have Å¿everal intereÅ¿ts or eÅ¿tates, and the covenant is made with them & cum quolibet eorum, they Å¿hall have Å¿everal covenants, otherways not, Coke 5. part. 22. A. MatthewÅ¿ons caÅ¿e, in reÅ¿pect of their Å¿everal intereÅ¿ts.
LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years by deed Poll is outed by the LeÅ¿Å¿or,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. he Å¿hall have covenant, Nat. br. 145. L. 21 Edw. 4.30. pl. 25. for the leaÅ¿e implies a covenant to enjoy during the term.
But if a Å¿tranger outs him without title he Å¿hall not have Covenant, Nat. br. 145. L. 22 Hen. 9.52. pl. 26. But if he had a colourable title and ouÅ¿ts him. quaere.
Although it be by verdict, Coke 4. part. 80. B. Nokes caÅ¿e; for the verdict may not be according to Law. Q.
And although the LeÅ¿Å¿or warrant to him during the term, 26 Hen. 8.3. pl. 11. for the warranty is not Å¿o general: but if he warrant it againÅ¿t all men. Q.
But if a Å¿tranger that hath Title out him, then it lies, Nat. br. 145. 32 Hen. 6.32. pl. 27. Nedham; for that proves he had no power to lett.
But LeÅ¿Å¿ee for life Å¿hall not have Covenant upon Å¿uch outing, for this cannot diveÅ¿ts him of the Freehold, 26 Hen. 16. Covenant 10. Nat. br. 145. M. if in the covenant it be not expreÅ¿t.

But 13 Edw. 3. Å¿ines 165. per Shard, if a leaÅ¿e be to A without impeachment of waÅ¿te, and waÅ¿te be brought againÅ¿t him, A Å¿hall have Covenant; for the leaÅ¿e implies a Covenant, that he Å¿hall not be Å¿ued for waÅ¿te.
Tenant for life Å¿hall not have the benefit of warranty, if he be not in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 26 Hen. 8.3. pl. 11. viz. at the time of the warranty.
LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years Å¿hall have Covenant upon a demiÅ¿e and grant, Coke 4. part. 80. B. Nokes caÅ¿e, & 5. part. 17. A. that is, if the leaÅ¿e runs, that LeÅ¿Å¿or doth demiÅ¿e and grant. Q.

If the land be evicted, PaÅ¿ch. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Winchombe & Rigge. A leaÅ¿e made to A. per dedi & conceÅ¿Å¿i, the land is evict for years, A Å¿hall have Covenant againÅ¿t the leÅ¿Å¿or, for judgment was Å¿o entered, Mich. 9 Jac. But Williams & Yelverton Å¿aid, that it was without their privity; and Williams Å¿aid, that it lied not: quaere ergo.

RecuÅ¿ant Å¿hall not have an action of covenant for any thing Å¿eiÅ¿ed into the Kings hands,RecuÅ¿ant. 1 Jac. cap. 5. by vertue of the LeÅ¿Å¿ors recuÅ¿ancy; for the Common Law takes no notice of RecuÅ¿ancy.
SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have covenant upon a covenant made and broken in the time of his predeceÅ¿Å¿or,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. 4 Edw. 3.130. pl. 71. quaere what SucceÅ¿Å¿or, or whether any kind of SucceÅ¿Å¿or.
A covenants to levy a fine,Fine. the party to whom this covenant is made Å¿hall have covenant, Nat. br. 146. F.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Covenant lies, 1. PerÅ¿onal, 2. Real.
div.p: AdminiÅ¿trator is Å¿ubject to it,AdminiÅ¿trator. 13 Edw. 3. cap. 11. Coke 9. part. 40. A. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, upon a Covenant made by the InteÅ¿tate.

AÅ¿Å¿ignee of a Termor Å¿hall be liable without naming how the condition of the thing extendsAÅ¿Å¿ignee.
to the things in eÅ¿Å¿e parcel of the demiÅ¿e, Coke 5. part. 16. A. Spencers caÅ¿e, & fol. 24. WorceÅ¿ters caÅ¿e.
This extends to him that comes to the demiÅ¿e any way, Coke 5. part. 17. B. Spencers caÅ¿e; viz. any legal way: but quaere, if the LeÅ¿Å¿ee be outed by one who hath no intereÅ¿t.

So if the Covenant extends to a thing to be newly made, if it Å¿hall be made upon the demiÅ¿ed land, the AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall be bound by expreÅ¿s Covenant to the LeÅ¿Å¿or and his AÅ¿Å¿igns, Coke 5. part. 16. B. Spencers caÅ¿e, 25 Hen. 8. br. Covenant 32. LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants for him and his AÅ¿Å¿igns to repair a houÅ¿e, Covenant lies againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, and then againÅ¿t the AÅ¿Å¿ignee alÅ¿o for the Å¿ame breach, and no remedy but an Audita querela, per Brook. Q.

A leaÅ¿es for years to B, and covenants to Å¿uffer him to enjoy; there the AÅ¿Å¿ignee of A of the ReverÅ¿ion is liable, though not named, 9 Eliz. Dyer 255. pl. 4. for he comes in intereÅ¿t of eÅ¿tate in the room of A, who covenanted.

When the Covenant extends to a thing which had not eÅ¿Å¿ence at the time of the demiÅ¿e, the AÅ¿Å¿ignee is not liable without naming him, Coke 5. part. 16. B. as where the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Covenants to build a new houÅ¿e upon Land lett. Q. rationem.
When the demiÅ¿e is of a perÅ¿onal thing the AÅ¿Å¿ignee is not liable by expreÅ¿s name, Coke 5. part. 16.17. becauÅ¿e the Covenant goes to the perÅ¿on and not the eÅ¿tate.

If the demiÅ¿e be of Land and a perÅ¿onal thing the AÅ¿Å¿ignee is not bound by expreÅ¿s name for the perÅ¿onality, for there can be no privity between the LeÅ¿Å¿or and AÅ¿Å¿ignee, Coke 5. part. 16, & 17. but for the realty he Å¿hall be bound.
The Statute of 32 Hen. 8. cap. 34. extends to Covenants, which touch the thing demiÅ¿ed, and not to collateral Covenants which concern it not, for the Statute looks at the eÅ¿tate.

It lies againÅ¿t Executors,Executors. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. B. Nat. br. 145. H. and this is although they be not named, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 14. pl. 69. 45 Edw. 3.17. pl. 4. 47 Edw. 3.22. 48 Edw. 3.2. pl. 4. 9 Eliz. Dyer 255. pl. 4. for they repreÅ¿ent the perÅ¿on of the TeÅ¿tator, and come in his Å¿tead.
But all the Executors ought to be named, 47 Edw. 3.22. pl. 20. in the Writ and Declaration.

A LeaÅ¿e is made to A, the LeÅ¿Å¿or covenants to pay the quit Rents, &c. divers dues likewiÅ¿e; this is a perÅ¿onal thing, and binds not the Executor, 2 & 3 Mariae 114. pl. 6. of the LeÅ¿Å¿or. Q. for it is paid ratione terrae.

A LeaÅ¿e is made to the Husband and Wife,Feme. the Husband covenants to make aÅ¿Å¿urance for the Rent, this binds not the wife, becauÅ¿e it is collateral, 45 Edw. 3.11. pl. 7. for the LeÅ¿Å¿or hath remedy for the Rent without Å¿uch aÅ¿Å¿urance.
But if they covenant, that they will not aÅ¿Å¿ign without his conÅ¿ent; there the Wife is bound, if the husband die, 18 Hen. 8. Dyer 13. pl. 66. ShelÅ¿ey; for elÅ¿e the LeÅ¿Å¿ee is without remedy.
Heir Å¿hall be bound by covenant of his AnceÅ¿tor,Heir. if be named, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. B. elÅ¿e not.
And although it be broken by his AnceÅ¿tor, 4 Edw. 3.130. pl. 71. as well as if broken by himÅ¿elf.
But not if he be not named, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 14. pl. 69. 32 Hen. 6.32. p. 27. for then the Law will intend only, that the Executor or AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall be bound.
Infant cannot be bound by his Covenant to be an Apprentice per the Common Law,Infant. but by CuÅ¿tome of London he may, 21 Edw. 4.6. pl. 17.
But then he Å¿hall be of the age of 14 years, 21 Hen. 6.31. which are accounted years of diÅ¿cretion, to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h what may be for his benefit, and what not.

But an Infant of 12 years Å¿hall be bound by his Covenant to Å¿erve in husbandry, Nat. br. 168. D. 7 Hen. 4.5. pl. 29. 9 Hen. 6.10. pl. 28. 21 Hen. 6.31. Newton. for husbandry is for the good of the Commonwealth, and the knowledge and maintenance of it are much favoured in Law.

But if he be within 12 years, he Å¿hall not be bound, 2 Hen. 4.18. pl. 7. 29 Edw. 3.27. pl. 29. 41 Edw. 3.17. pl. 1. for under thoÅ¿e years he is indeed incapable of learning the Art, by reaÅ¿on of diÅ¿ability of body and underÅ¿tanding alÅ¿o.
LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants to leave the houÅ¿e in good caÅ¿e,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. it lies not againÅ¿t him till the end of the Term, Nat. br. 145. K. 12 Edw. 2. Covenant 2.
But if he covenant Å¿uÅ¿tentare & reparare, it lies preÅ¿ently, 45 Eliz. Dyer 324. pl. 34. and whenÅ¿oever it Å¿hall be out of repair, during the term.

So if he covenants to leave the Timber in good plight, this is void for the impoÅ¿Å¿ibility, Coke 5. part. 21. A. Mains caÅ¿e, 7 part. 15. A. Englefields caÅ¿e, Fitzberbert covenant 29. Nemo tenetur ad impoÅ¿Å¿ibile.
For if the Trees are thrown down by TempeÅ¿t, it lies not, 40 Edw. 3.6. A. Coke 1. part. 98. A. Shelleys caÅ¿e; for this could not be prevented.

But if the houÅ¿e be waÅ¿ted by Enemies or TempeÅ¿t, he ought to repair by reaÅ¿on of the Covenant,
or build it, 40 Edw. 3.6. A. Moris. Doct. & Stud. 66. B. 29 Hen. 8. Dyer 33. pl. 10. if there be an expreÅ¿s Covenant to do it.
LeÅ¿Å¿or is bound by expreÅ¿s Covenant or Covenants in Law.LeÅ¿Å¿or.
It lies againÅ¿t a LeÅ¿Å¿or, if he outs his Termor, Nat. br. 145. L. 21 Edw. 4.30. pl. 25. Coke 9. part. 80. A. 32 Hen. 6.32. pl. 27. without cauÅ¿e, and during the term.
A ParÅ¿on leaÅ¿es his Glebe,ParÅ¿on. and reÅ¿igns during the term, covenant lies againÅ¿t him, becauÅ¿e it is his own act and wrong, 12 Hen. 4.3. and the SucceÅ¿Å¿or may avoid the LeaÅ¿e.

Where a Parcener upon partition covenants to Å¿ue a Writ of Partition,Parcener: the other aÅ¿Å¿igns his eÅ¿tate to B, which covenants againÅ¿t the Covenanter and good, Coke 5. part. 17. B. 42 Edw. 3.3.
If one become pledge for another to perform Å¿uch a Covenant, the Action lies againÅ¿t the pledge,Pledge. Nat. br. 146. B. for he is in the place of the Principal.
But then he ought to charge him as principal, 39 Edw. 3.9. pl. 14.
Or Å¿hew that the Principal is not Å¿ufficient, 40 Edw. 3.5. Covenant 16.
It lies againÅ¿t a SucceÅ¿Å¿or,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. Lib. Intra. 136. B. Sect. 2. quaere what, or whether againÅ¿t all.
It lies againÅ¿t him that Å¿hould make a Deed,Deed. Nat. br. 146. F. that covenants to do it, and does it not.

div.head: For what things Covenant lies, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p: Guardian in Soccage.Guardian in Soccage grants the cuÅ¿tody of the Ward to A, who covenants to render an Accou â¢â¢ to the Heir at full age, Covenant lieth for not doing of it, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. B. Nat. br. 145. H. Å¿o the Guardian. Q. whether an Account lies no â¢ for the heir.
Covenant lies againÅ¿t him that doth not according to his Covenant by deed, Nat. br. 145. A. th â¢ is, doth not perform the whole covenant.

Edw. 3.130. pl. 71. for the Heir is bound by his Fathers covenant.

A Termor deviÅ¿eth the term by will to his wif â¢
Termo â¢
during her Widowhood, the remainder to C, and dies, the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿ells the Fee to the wiÅ¿e, and covenants that he would diÅ¿charge all former Titles, &c. Å¿he marries C in the mean time, Covenant lies againÅ¿t the Bargainor by the Baron and Feme, if C do ouÅ¿t them during the term; for it was his own folly to make Å¿uch a Sale and Covenant. Coke 10. part. 51. Lampets caÅ¿e.

A leaÅ¿es to B for years, if C lives Å¿o long,LeaÅ¿e. and covenants that he had power to do it, C being dead at the time, Covenant lies, if A had not a good eÅ¿tate in it, Coke 9. part. 60. BradÅ¿haws caÅ¿e, though C was dead; for if he had no good eÅ¿tate, he had no power to lett, and Å¿o his Covenant implied in Law is broken.

A leaÅ¿es to B for years Lands in which C had a Copyhold eÅ¿tate, and covenants that the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall Å¿uffer him quietly to hold the Å¿ame, without trouble either of the LeÅ¿Å¿or or any other. B enters, C outs him, Covenant lies not, becauÅ¿e all the Å¿equel depends upon this word [Å¿uffer,] the which extends only to the LeÅ¿Å¿or, and his Executors and AÅ¿Å¿igns, 9 Eliz. Dyer 255. pl. 4. and not to the Copyholder, who hath a diÅ¿tinct intereÅ¿t from the LeÅ¿Å¿or.

A leaÅ¿es to B for years, and covenants, quod pacifice gauderet, &c. Å¿ine interruptione alicujus, Covenant lies, if any interrupt him, 16 Eliz. Dyer 328. pl. 8. for the word alicujus is a general word, and includes all perÅ¿ons.

LeÅ¿Å¿or covenants, that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall quietly and peaceably have, &c. without the diÅ¿turbance or hindrance of the LeÅ¿Å¿or, the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿ues the LeÅ¿Å¿ee in Chancery, and Å¿uppoÅ¿es that the LeaÅ¿e was only made to try a Title, an Action of
Covenant lies not for Å¿uch breach, Trin. 11 Jac. Com. Ban. Rot. 384. Selby verÅ¿us Shute; for this was but a LeaÅ¿e in truÅ¿t only for the benefit of the LeÅ¿Å¿or, and not of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee by deed Poll Å¿hall have a Covenant againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. if he out him, Nat. br. 145. l. 35 Hen. 8. Dyer 57. pl. 24. Shelley. for the Action ariÅ¿eth upon the covenant of the LeÅ¿Å¿or, which may be by deed Poll.
But not upon outing by a Å¿tranger without Title, Nat. br. 145. L. 22 Hen. 6.52. pl. 26. Hill. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. TiÅ¿dale & EÅ¿Å¿ex; yet quaere, if he had a colourable Title.
Although it be by Recovery, by Verdict, Coke 4. part. 80. B. Nokes caÅ¿e. vid. antea.
But if a Stranger hath Title, then it lies, Nat. br. 145. L. 32 Hen. 6.32. pl. 27. Nedham; for the â¢ the LeÅ¿Å¿or could not lett.

But Tenant for life Å¿hall not have Covenant for Å¿uch ouÅ¿ting, Nat. br. 145. M. 26 Hen. 6. Covenant Å¿o. for ouÅ¿ting is intended of a term, and not of a Freehold, for Å¿uch ouÅ¿ting is a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in.
If it be not expreÅ¿t, Nat. br. 145. M. for that declares what ouÅ¿ting was meant by the parties.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years Å¿hall have Covenant upon a demiÅ¿e and grant, Coke 4. part. 80. B. Nokes caÅ¿e 5. part. A. Spencers caÅ¿e; viz. upon the words demiÅ¿e and grant in the LeaÅ¿e, for they imply a Covenant.
LeaÅ¿e for years with warranty, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee outed Å¿hall have Covenant, 26 Hen. 8.3. pl. 13. by all 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. for the warranty implieth a Covenant for quiet enjoying.

Tenant for anothers life leaÅ¿es for years with warranty, he for whoÅ¿e life the LeaÅ¿e was dies, the firÅ¿t LeÅ¿Å¿or enters, Covenant lies, 32 Hen. 6.32. pl. 27.9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ee for life upon his warranty, becauÅ¿e his eÅ¿tate was but a contingent eÅ¿tate, and the warranty Å¿uppoÅ¿ed t abÅ¿olute.
But if it be without warranty it lies not, 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. for he letts no greater eÅ¿tate than he hath.
A Covenants to Å¿erve B for years, and dies, no Action lies, quia mors omnia Å¿olvit, 48 Edw. 3.2. B. pl. 4. Finchden.

Hill. 33 Eliz. Ban. Regis, WilÅ¿on & Mapes. A ParÅ¿on leaÅ¿es his Rectory, and covenants to Å¿ave harmleÅ¿s the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, concerning the lands and profits for one year againÅ¿t Blunt, Blunt enters within the year; Covenant lies, becauÅ¿e it is expreÅ¿Å¿ed againÅ¿t a certain perÅ¿on. Quaere, if it had been generally.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants, that he will not aÅ¿Å¿ign his Term over, by which it may come to D; the LeÅ¿Å¿ee aÅ¿Å¿igns it to K per Curiam, Covenant lies, for he hath put the power out of him, Trin. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. Guines caÅ¿e, and it may come to D whether he will or no.
Of a Fine levied of Rent, a Writ of Covenant lies, 22 Edw. 4.2. pl. 6.

div.head: The Count in Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p:
The Count was, that per Indenturam Å¿uam teÅ¿tat. exiÅ¿tit, that the Defendant covenanted Å¿o and Å¿o, this is good; but Å¿uch plea in bar is not good,
Mich. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wyrdnam verÅ¿us Fankner, 2 Mariae 117. pl. 78. but he muÅ¿t plead Covenants performed, and tender an iÅ¿Å¿ue.

Prior and Covent leaÅ¿es to two for years with warranty,Count. per Indenture, rendring Rent; one dies after poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, the other Å¿urvives, and was Å¿ole poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿t, the Prior dies, the Defendant fuit elect â¢â¢ & praefectus Prior, & tali die expulÅ¿us & ejectus eÅ¿t, the Survivor by the new Prior, and Å¿o the Defendant did not hold Covenant made between the late Prior and the Å¿aid Survivor, Lib. Intr. 135. D. Å¿ect. 2. this is a good Count, for the Covenant lies by the Survivor againÅ¿t the SucceÅ¿Å¿or.
Count upon covenants to make a new LeaÅ¿e, Com. 2. Chapmans caÅ¿e, and good.

A leaÅ¿es to B for 6 years, if C live Å¿o long, and covenants that he had power to demiÅ¿e it, &c. B in covenant needs not count that C was in life, for if he were dead at the time of the demiÅ¿e, yet Covenant lies; 2. he need not Å¿hew that he had the better right, becauÅ¿e he did purÅ¿ue the words of the Covenant negative, Coke 9. part. 60. BradÅ¿hawes caÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e it cannot appear it is the Covenant upon which the Action is brought.

Count by the LeÅ¿Å¿or againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, that Covenants to pay all charges, and pays not the tenths granted per Parliament, Lib. Intr. 136. C. Å¿ect. 4. for the word Charges includes the Tenths, for they are charges iÅ¿Å¿uing out of the Land, or payable ratione terrae.

The Count Å¿hall be general, that he hath broken covenants between them, to the dammage, &c. the other Å¿hall Å¿ay, that they are performed,
the Plaintiff may reply, that they are not, becauÅ¿e he Å¿hall have Å¿everal dammages for every Covenant broken; but upon an Obligation he ought to Å¿hew in what he hath made a breach, becauÅ¿e he Å¿hall have the forfeiture for one breach, 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 34. if but one breach.

Tenant for life leaÅ¿es for years rendring Rent, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants and is expulÅ¿ed by him in remainder, 1. he ought to count that he was poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd; 2. he ought to Å¿hew the eÅ¿tate for life, and the remainder certain, 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. becauÅ¿e it is a Å¿pecial ouÅ¿ter, and not by the LeÅ¿Å¿or; and for the firÅ¿t, if he were not in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, he cannot be Å¿aid to be ouÅ¿ted.

div.head: Writ in Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p: Rex, In Comitat. &c. juÅ¿ticies A. quod. teneat B. conventionem inter eos factam, de quibuÅ¿dam defectibus, in Manerio ipÅ¿ius B. de N. exiÅ¿tentibus Å¿umptibus ipÅ¿ius A. competenter emendand. Å¿icut, &c. ne amplius, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 167. A. This is in the County Court, as it Å¿eems.

Rex, In Banco. &c. praecipe A. de B. quod juÅ¿te, &c. teneat W. conventionem, inter eos factam de viginti acris terrae in K. frumento & alio blado competenti Å¿eminandis, & de bladis & terris praedict. creÅ¿centibus metend. & ad domus ipÅ¿ius W. Å¿umptibus ejuÅ¿dem A. in eadem villa cariandis, & niÅ¿i fecerit, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 166. A. This in the Common Pleas.
The Writ Å¿hall be brought where the Covenant was made, Nat. br. 146. E. 11 Rich. 2. viz. in that County where it is a real Covenant.
But it is no plea to abate the Writ unleÅ¿s the Deed bears date in another County, Nat. br. 146. E. than where the Covenant is brought, and it may be a Covenant by parol.
The Writ for outing the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall be de dampuis & de perditis occaÅ¿ione expulÅ¿ionis, &c. 9 Eliz. Dyer 257. pl. 13. for if he be not damnified no Action lies.

The Writ ought to mention all the Executors which did adminiÅ¿ter, 47 Edw. 3.22. pl. 20.48 Edw. 3.2. pl. 4. where an Action of Covenant is brought againÅ¿t Executors; for all the Executors are but one Executor in Law, for they have a joynt truÅ¿t and intereÅ¿t.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s in Covenant, 1. Before appearance; 2. After.
div.p: Covenant PerÅ¿onal.1. By the Common Law the ProceÅ¿s before appearance was but a diÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, 22 Hen. 6.13. Br. exigend. 29. 48 Edw. 3.29. pl. 15. and no Capias.

2. After appearance the parties appear, and day is given over; (Å¿alvis partibus, &c.) the Defendant makes default at the day, a diÅ¿treÅ¿s was awarded againÅ¿t him, Lib. Intra. 134. B. Sect. 1. and not a Capias.

Quia non fit breve de Attachiamento, Covenant Real. quia oporteat quod partes compareant perÅ¿onaliter in Curia, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 165. A. and here was day given over Å¿alvis partibus, which was no perÅ¿onal appearance.

div.head: The Bar in Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p: 1. When a certain duty accrues by the Covenant at the time of the making of it,Accord. an Accord with Å¿atisfaction is no plea, Coke 6. part. 44. A. Blakes caÅ¿e; for Å¿uch an Accord cannot diÅ¿charge the duty. But a releaÅ¿e may be pleaded in bar.

But where no certain duty accrues until the Å¿ubÅ¿equent act or wrong, there Accord with Å¿atisfaction is a good plea, Coke 6. part. 44. A. Blakes caÅ¿e; for he may make Å¿atisfaction for the wrong by the agreement of the Covenantee.

Covenant to a ParÅ¿on for the enjoying his Benefice, and the ParÅ¿on deÅ¿erts, the Cure is void, if he deny it after Å¿uch deÅ¿ertion, 14 Eliz. cap. 11. RaÅ¿tall, LeaÅ¿es 244. D. 23 Eliz. Dyer 372. pl. 11. This is after the ParÅ¿on is abÅ¿ent forty days in the year, and not otherwiÅ¿e; for that is a deÅ¿ertion in Law whereby he may be deprived.

A covenants to gather the Rents in D, DiÅ¿turbance. and he pleads, that he was interrupted by the Plaintiff, and Å¿o could not do it; this is a good bar, Crooke 13. Hen. 7.34. pl. 2. for the Plaintiff Å¿hall not take advantage of his own wrong.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee covenants to Å¿urrender before the term ends, and a Stranger that hath right enters upon the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, this is a diÅ¿charge, becauÅ¿e the LeÅ¿Å¿ee is diÅ¿abled by an act in Law, Hill. 41 Eliz. Com. Ban. Andrews verÅ¿us Nedham, 45 Edw. 3.48.
Performance generally a good plea,Performance. 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 34.

In a Covenant upon a demiÅ¿e by Indenture and an eviction by a Stranger, by a higher Title, it is
no Bar to traverÅ¿e the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Plaintiff without particular cauÅ¿es Å¿hewing how the other had title, becauÅ¿e it is by Indenture, Trin. 3 Jac. Ban. Regis, Stile verÅ¿us Hearing, which is a general eÅ¿toppel without Å¿hewing of Å¿pecial matter to avoid it.

A covenants to make a good eÅ¿tate in Copyhold land to B before EaÅ¿ter, during the life of Cox; it is no plea to Å¿ay, that it was Å¿urrendred to the Lord by his procurement to the uÅ¿e of C, if he Å¿hews not that he was admitted; for nothing veÅ¿ts in him to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e it is till admittance, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Stiles verÅ¿us Smith, and Å¿o the Lord was not diÅ¿abled to perform the Covenant.

ReleaÅ¿e is no Bar before the Covenant is broken,ReleaÅ¿e. viz. generally, Coke 4. part. 71. Hors caÅ¿e, 5 Eliz. Dyer 217. pl. 2. Coke 1. part. 99. A. Shelley â¢
caÅ¿e.
If it be not by expreÅ¿s words, Coke 5. part. 71. A. 35 Hen. 8. Dyer 57. pl. 24. Bramly; for Å¿o the Covenant may be releaÅ¿ed.

div.head: Judgment in Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p: Judgment againÅ¿t an Executor for a Covenant broken after the death of the TeÅ¿tator, is of the TeÅ¿tators goods, 15 Eliz. Dyer 324. pl. 34. for he is in the TeÅ¿tators Å¿tead, and truÅ¿ted with his eÅ¿tate.

If a LeÅ¿Å¿ee recovers being outed by the LeÅ¿Å¿or, he Å¿hall recover his term, viz. the remainder unexpired, Nat. br. 145. M. 47 Edw. 3.24. pl. 61. 20 Edw. 3. Judgment 177. and alÅ¿o Dammages, Nat. br. 145. M.

div.head: Execution in Covenant, 1. PerÅ¿onal; 2. Real.
div.p: 1. Per Common Law; 2. Per Statute Law.
By the Common Law it is but a Levari facias, PerÅ¿onal. Lib. Intra. 133. D. Å¿ect. 2. & fieri facias, Lib. Intra. 138. A. Å¿ect. 1. extending but to goods and Chattels.
But no other Execution, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e.
And this only within the year; for if the year be paÅ¿t it was an Action of debt upon the Judgment, Coke 3.12. A.
UnleÅ¿s the ProceÅ¿s were continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33. for the continuance of it made it, as if no time were paÅ¿Å¿ed, but continued a preÅ¿ent Judgment.
By the Stat. by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 45. a Scire facias was given after the year, Coke 3. part. 12. A. to revive the Judgment, and Å¿o the party is not now forced to bring an Action of debt upon it.
And per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 18. Elegit is given, Coke 3. part. 12. A. which extends to lands as well as goods.
By the Stat. of 23 Hen. 8. cap. 14. Capias ad exigend fuit given in ProceÅ¿s, and by conÅ¿equence a Cap. ad Å¿atisfaciond. in execution againÅ¿t the perÅ¿on.

By the Common Law it was but a Writ de fine facto; 2. Real. or to pay a fine, as it Å¿eems, which was but a Writ of Covenant in its nature, 43 Edw. 3.12. B. Belknap. Glanvil. lib. 8. cap. 4. vide the Writ there.
But entry was congeable to execute it, 8 Edw. 3.277. 24 Edw. 3.40. pl. 49. Coke 7. part. 32. and to hold till Å¿atisfaction made, as it Å¿eems.
If Land be tailed to one by fine,Fine. he Å¿hall have a Formedon in Remainder, 6 Edw. 3.185. pl. 9. Herle to execute the Fine.
But when the King levies a find, he ought to make Letters Patents to the ConuÅ¿ee to enter, Coke 7. part. 32. for the King paÅ¿Å¿eth nothing but by Record.
A Fine levied of an AdvowÅ¿on, this may be executed by a Quare Impedit, 24 Edw. 3.69. pl. 78.
But if an uÅ¿urpation be, no Scire facias lies, 33 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 193. Knivet, againÅ¿t the UÅ¿urper.
Fine levied of Services, there Å¿hall be a per que Å¿ervitio, 29 Edw. 3.46. pl. 9. to execute the Fine.
If a Fine be levied of Rent, there may be ãâã Writ of Covenant, 22 Edw. 4.2. pl. 6. to execute the Fine.
Tenant grants to do his Å¿ervices, there Å¿hall be but a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 10 Edw. 3.371. pl. 3. for that is the proper remedy to recover them, and there needed no Covenant. Tamen quaere.
Fine levied of a ReverÅ¿ion, there Å¿hall be a quid juris clamat to execute this.

And if the Tenant alien, yet the Writ Å¿hall be againÅ¿t him, and his AÅ¿Å¿ignee Å¿hall be bound by his Attornment, 8 Hen. 6.17. B. 18 Hen. 6.3. B. pl. 2. by the Judgment given againÅ¿t the AÅ¿Å¿ignor and himÅ¿elf.

ConuÅ¿or of a Fine dies, there Å¿hall be no quid juris clamat againÅ¿t him that claims; but if the ConuÅ¿ee only die, quaere if his Heir Å¿hall have the Writ, 34 Hen. 6.7. B. Moyle, againÅ¿t the party that hath the particular eÅ¿tate.
Fine levied before memory, there Å¿hall be no Execution, 1 Edw. 4.6. pl. 13. for it Å¿hall be intended there was Execution formerly, or that there was to be none.
By WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 44. Scire facias is given after the year to revive the Fine, which is a Judgment in Law; but within the year Å¿uch Execution as in other Judgments.

div.head: In what Court Detinue lies, 1. of Chattels; 2. of Deeds for Land.
div.p: In Comitatu.1. IT lies in the County Court Nat. br. 138. B.
In any other Court, Nat. br. 138. C.
In the Common Bank, Nat. br. 138. B.
It lies not in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, Coke 10. part. 76. A. 72. A. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, Q. if both parties be of the Kings houÅ¿hold, if it lie not.

It lies not in any Court without a Writ, and if it be Å¿ued Å¿o a Prohibition lies, Nat. br. 138. C. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 159. B. viz. upon a plaint as is uÅ¿ed in inferiour Courts.
