The Lord Å¿hall have a Detinue for a Heriot cuÅ¿tome, if it be taken before Å¿eiÅ¿ure,Lord. becauÅ¿e he had the property before Å¿eiÅ¿ure, 13 Edw. 3. Br. Hariot, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis CreÅ¿Å¿es caÅ¿e, per Curiam in a Prohibition, vide 10 Hen. 4. 4 Hen. 6.
But the 14 Edw. 3. Bar 277. (Wilby) a than Å¿hall not have an Action for a Harriot. Q â¢ erg â¢ , not a Detinue.
If a thing be delivered to A to deliver to B, UÅ¿e. yet B Å¿hall have a Detinue, 18 Hen. 6.9. A. Newton; for the property is adjudged in B, becauÅ¿e it was delivered to A for his benefit only.
Husband and wife may joyn in Detinue for a deed of Lands,Husband and wife. 38 Hen. 6.25. Lib. Intr. 209. D. Å¿ect. 3. & fol. 217. A. Å¿ect. 2. viz. concerning Lands of the wife.

But this is when the Defendant comes not to the Deed by bailment, for if the Husband bail them he Å¿hall have it alone, ibidem. 8 Edw. 4.15. 38 Hen. 6.25. A. for the privity lies betwixt the Bailor and the Bailee.
Vide tamen, Lib. Intra. 217. A. Å¿ect. 2.

If Bailment be before coverture they ought to joyn, 21 Hen. 7.29. for conformity: But upon bailment during the Coverture the Husband Å¿ole Å¿hall have a Detinue, 8 Edw. 4.16. for that is adjudged his bailment only.
The Donor in tail Å¿hall have a Detinue for the Indenture after the death of the Donce withou â¢ IÅ¿Å¿ue,Donor. Nat. br. 138. F. in reÅ¿pect of his reverÅ¿io â¢ which depends upon the deed.

An EÅ¿tranger Å¿hall not have a Detinue for deed unleÅ¿s he makes title to the Land,EÅ¿tranger. but upon requeÅ¿t to deliver them, and a refuÅ¿al, he Å¿hall hav â¢ an Action upon the CaÅ¿e, 33 Hen. 6.26. pl. 1 â¢
PriÅ¿ot, if the Deeds do concern him.

If one have Deeds and Å¿ome concern warrant â¢ Å¿ome not,FeoÅ¿ â¢ ee. and enfeoff B with warranty, B Å¿ha â¢â¢ not have a Detinue for the deeds, which Å¿erv â¢â¢
to deraigne the warranty per amount, Coke 1. part. 2. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e, 44 Edw. 3.11. B. becauÅ¿e they do not wholly concern him.

Neither is it material for to maintain the title, Coke 1. part. 1. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e. But they Å¿hall have them which concern the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion only, ibidem. viz. of the Land; and the Feoffor is to have the Deeds to maintain his warranty.

But if a Feoffment be made without warranty the Feoffee Å¿hall have a Detinue for all, Coke 1: part. 1. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e; viz. all the Deeds that do any ways concern the title, that he may be able to defend it.
UnleÅ¿s it be per dedi, then it is expreÅ¿s warranty during the life of the Feoffor, per Å¿tatutum de Bigamis, cap. 6. Coke 1. part. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e 1. for the word Deed implies Å¿o much.

But note, that in all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es the Feoffee Å¿hall have Detinue for them againÅ¿t a Stranger, that cannot intitle himÅ¿elf by the Feoffor, Nat. br. 138. G. Coke 1. part. 2. A. 7 Edw. 4.26. becauÅ¿e a Stranger cannot pretend any colour.

And note, if the thing which lies in grant, as a LordÅ¿hip, Rent, AdvowÅ¿on, &c. be granted to A with warranty, which grants it to B with warranty, B Å¿hall have a Detinue for the Ancient deed; becauÅ¿e he cannot make a title without the Ancient deed, Coke 1. part. 1. B. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e. quaere.

So in all other CaÅ¿es the Feoffee Å¿hall have a Detinue for every deed which concerns the making of his eÅ¿tate good, Nat. br. 138. K. for the Law favours Titles to Land, and loves the maintenance of them.

Note,Note. if A bail deeds of Land to B to re-bail them to him and his Heirs, and afterwards enfeoff C in fee; yet C Å¿hall not have a Detinue againÅ¿t B, for it is a charge to A, per cauÅ¿e of Bailment, Crooke 18 Hen. 7.48. pl. 3.

If one enfeoff another with warranty, the Feoffor Å¿hall have the ancient deeds,Feoffor. which contain the warranty, or which are material for the maintenance of the Title, Coke 1. part. 1. B. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e.
If A grant a thing that lies in grant to B with warranty, B Å¿hall have a Detinue for the Ancient deed, becauÅ¿e this makes his title, Coke 1. part. 1. B.

A enfeoffs B per dedi, A Å¿hall have the Ancient deed, which comprehends the warranty, becauÅ¿e dedi makes an expreÅ¿s warranty, Coke 1. part. 2. B. and therefore it is good reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould have the deed to make out the warranty by.
A makes a deed of Feoffment, and delivers this upon condition, if the Condition be not performed he Å¿hall have a Detinue, 37 Hen. 6.37. B. for the deed for the property was not abÅ¿olute out of him.

Heir general.The Heir general Å¿hall have the Ancient deeds comprehending warranty, or neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the maintenance of the title, where the Feoffor obliges him and his heirs to warranty; for he is bound by his Fathers act, and its reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould have the deed to maintain it, Coke part. 1. B. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e, Nat. br. 138. L.
Feoffment per dedi the heir of the Feoffee Å¿hall not have the Ancient deeds, becauÅ¿e he is not bound to warranty, Coke 1. part. 2. B. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e; but the heir of the Feoffor. Q.
The heir of the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have a Detinue for the deeds, Nat. br. 138. L. for he is in by deceit, and the Law will judge his title good till it be evicted.

Heir Å¿pecial.The Heir in tail Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t the DiÅ¿continuee for the deed of entail, Nat. br. 138. H. 9 Edw. 4.52. pl. 15. for it belongs to him to make out his Title by virtue of the entail.
And although there be a warranty to the Feoffee by his Father, 9 Hen. 6.15. pl. 5. 4 Hen. 7.10. pl. 4. for the heir in tail comes in paramount the Father.

One Joytenant Å¿ole delivers the deed to redeliver to him,Joyntenant. he alone Å¿hall have a Detinue per cauÅ¿e of this Å¿pecial Bailment, 13 Rich. 2. bre. 648. though the deed doth belong unto both; for the bailment is the cauÅ¿e of the Action.

Joyntenant Å¿urvivor. A enfeoffs B and C, and the heirs of B, and delivers all the deeds to B, which dies; C Å¿hall have a Detinue for the deed of Feoffment, but not for the other deeds, 34 Hen. 6.1. A. Coke 1. part. 2. A. Nat. br. 138. F. viz. which concern the Inheritance; but the deed of Feoffment concerns the eÅ¿tate for life, as well as the Inheritance.
If A makes a ReleaÅ¿e to B and C, and this delivers to B, which dies, C Å¿hall not have it, ibidem. for the Parchment and the Wax do belong to him to whom it was delivered.

But if A and B Joyntenants per defeaÅ¿ible title, and S. J. makes a ReleaÅ¿e to them, the Survivor Å¿hall have it, 34 Hen. 6.1. per the Report Coke 1. part. 2. A. for this concerns the Land, and Å¿hall Å¿urvive with the eÅ¿tate.

Feoffment to two in Fee, the Å¿urvivor Å¿hall have
all the deeds, Coke 1. part. 2. B. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the eÅ¿tate Å¿urvives which the deeds concern.

If deeds concern more Lands, if the Tertenant of any part happen upon the deed, he may detain it, becauÅ¿e he hath an intereÅ¿t, 4 Hen. 7.10. pl. 4. 2 Eliz. Dyer 183. pl. 57. and it is reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould have the deeds to maintain it as well as any other.
RecuÅ¿ant Å¿hall not have an Action for any thing Å¿eiÅ¿ed into the hands of the King,RecuÅ¿ant. 3 Jac. cap. 5. By Stat. vid.

22 Hen. 6.1. A Tenant for life dies,Remainder. he in the Remainder Å¿hall have Detinue for the deed, 9 Hen. 6.54. pl. 39. for now his title is come in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿o the deed that created it belongs to him.
But if the Donor releaÅ¿e to the Tenant for life, he in the Remainder Å¿hall not have a Detinue, 9 Hen. 5.54. pl. 39. Q.

If Tenant for life die, he in the Remainder of a Copyhold Å¿hall have it, Coke 4. part. 22. B. for Copyholds are in many things governed by the rules of the Common Law, and Å¿o no difference betwixt them and other eÅ¿tates.

Land is given to A for the life of B, the Remainder to C in Fee, B dies, C Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t A without requeÅ¿t; becauÅ¿e he had intereÅ¿t in the deed during the life of B, 33 Hen. 6.30. B. 35 Hen. 6.9. A. Moyle, in reÅ¿pect of his Remainder.
But there quaere, whether it lies againÅ¿t the HuÅ¿band, when the wife is dead without iÅ¿Å¿ue, without requeÅ¿t and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, becauÅ¿e he is a Stranger to the eÅ¿tate.
Tertenant Å¿hall have a Detinue for the deeds,Tertenant. Coke 1. part. 2. A. which concern the Lands in his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
The Lord by EÅ¿cheat Å¿hall have a Detinue,Lord. Coke 1. part. 2. A. 10 Edw. 4.14.6. Moyle, for the deeds which concern the Land eÅ¿cheated.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Detinue lies, 1. Of Chattels; 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: Detinue lies againÅ¿t an Abbot and his Commoigue for a thing delivered to his Commoigue fore-deliver,Abbot. 3 Edw. 3.83. pl. 32. a thing delivered to them.

An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿old a thing,AdminiÅ¿trator. the Executor proves the Will, he Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t the Vendee of the AdminiÅ¿trator, Com. 275. Foxes caÅ¿e; for now the AdminiÅ¿trators title and property is deÅ¿troyed, and the Å¿ale accounted void irrepleviÅ¿able, that is, that the Cattel or Goods ought not by Law to be replevied again.

Avowant returns irrepleviÅ¿able,Avowant. the other tenders amends, and upon refuÅ¿al Å¿hall have a Detinue, Coke 8. part. 147. A. for the property is in him, 10 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 14. notwithÅ¿tanding the diÅ¿treÅ¿s; for the diÅ¿treÅ¿s did but put them into the cuÅ¿tody of the Law, and altered not the property.

Baily of goods.Goods delivered to A to keep, and they are Å¿tole, yet Detinue lies againÅ¿t him, Coke 4. part. 83. B. Southcots caÅ¿e; for he ought to have kept them at his peril, and he Å¿hall have his remedy againÅ¿t the Thief.

But if he take them to keep, as he would keep
his own, and they are Å¿tole, Detinue lies not, Coke 4. part. 83. for here he warrants not the Å¿afe keeping of them, for he cannot warrant his own from Å¿tealing.

Goods delivered to B to deliver to C, yet C Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t B, 18 Hen. 6.9. A. Nat. br. 138. A. for the delivery of them to be delivered to B, veÅ¿ts the property of them in B, and not in C.
Husband and wife.It lies not againÅ¿t husband and wife, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing they detain, 38 Edw. 3.1. pl. 1. 13 Rich. 2. Breve 644. for the wife cannot detain, but it is the detainer of the Husband.
But of bailment to the WiÅ¿e, dum Å¿ola fuit, and that the Husband did detain, 43 Edw. 3.18. pl. 1. Lib. Intra. 219. D. Å¿ect. 4. it lies.

A Carrier loÅ¿eth B's goods,Carrier. or they are Å¿tole from him, yet Detinue lies againÅ¿t him, Coke 4. part. 84. A. 2 Hen. 7.11. B. TownÅ¿end; for the property was in the owner, and the Law chargeth the Carrier with them.
It lies againÅ¿t an Executor,Executor. but he Å¿hall not be charged but for his Detainer, 39 Edw. 3.5. pl. 21. in his own time, and not for the TeÅ¿tators Detainer.

Crooke 118. pl. 62. A bails goods to B, which dies; in Detinue againÅ¿t the Executors the queÅ¿tion was, whether they Å¿hall be named Executors or not, and it Å¿eemed they needed not, for the Detainer is the point of Action. Quaeret â¢
men, for they detain by virtue of their ExecutorÅ¿hip.

For Hill. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, IÅ¿ack & Clark 13 Hen. 4.12. pl. 2. 11 Hen. 4.45. pl. 20. 2 He â¢
5.6. pl. 29. 21 Hen. 6. pl. 1. one Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer without the other, therefore they are charged for the Detainer only. Quaere tamen, for although they make but one perÅ¿on, yet this proves not but that they detain as Executors, and are Å¿o to be charged, as it Å¿eems.
It lies againÅ¿t an Executor upon a rationabile parte bonorum, 17 Edw. 3.9. pl. 29. brought by the Feme of the TeÅ¿tator.

An Executor Å¿hall have a Detinue for goods in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Executor of his Joynt-executor, if the Å¿aid Joynt-executor will pay a debt to the value. 3. Eliz. Dyer 187. pl. 6. for the ExecutorÅ¿hip Å¿urvives.
It lies againÅ¿t a Stranger when they come to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of two,EÅ¿tranger. 4 Edw. 4.9. pl. 11. Nat. br. 138. E. Q.

LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have a Detinue for implements leaÅ¿ed with the houÅ¿e, at the end of the term,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, although they are waÅ¿ted, 20 Hen. 6.16. pl. 2. for the property of them was not diveÅ¿ted out of the LeÅ¿Å¿or by the leaÅ¿e.
Trover of goods.AgainÅ¿t him that finds goods, if they be waÅ¿ted per wilful negligence; otherways if it be by caÅ¿ual means, Doct. & Stud. 129. B. or a Trover lies, for that he could not prevent.
If a HorÅ¿e be Å¿tole and Å¿old in a market,Vendee. but not according to the Statute, the Owner Å¿hall have a Detinue, per 3 Mariae cap. 7. for the Å¿ale is void, and Å¿o the property is not altered.

AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿old a thing, the Executor proves the Will, he Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t the Vendee of the AdminiÅ¿trator, Com. 275. Foxes caÅ¿e. See the reaÅ¿on before, that the Å¿ale is made void.
It lies againÅ¿t a Sheriff,Sheriff. where he returns upon a returna habenda quod averia elongata Å¿unt, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 2. 9 Hen. 6.42. See before the reaÅ¿on.
A Wife Tenant in tail dies before iÅ¿Å¿ues,Husband. quaere, if a Detinue lies againÅ¿t the Husband without requeÅ¿t, 33 Hen. 6.30. B.

A Feme Å¿ues goods dum Å¿ola fuit, and takes a Husband, Detinue lies againÅ¿t the husband and wife, Lib. Intr. 209. D. Sect. 4. 43 Edw. 3.18. pl. 1. for now the goods are come into poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the husband by the marriage, and Å¿o they are both to be Å¿ued; for the cauÅ¿e of Action begun whilÅ¿t the Feme was Å¿ole, and it is continued in the husband by the intermarriage and detainer Å¿ince.

If A. enfeoff B. with warranty,Feoffor. B. Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t A. for deeds that comprehend warranty, or are material for the Title, Coke 1. part. 2. becauÅ¿e the warranty is for his benefit.
If A. enfeoff B. without warranty, B. Å¿hall have it againÅ¿t A. for all the deeds concerning the land, the Feoffor needs not any deeds to make out the warranty.
And if the thing lies in grant, then it lies againÅ¿t the Feoffor, for all Coke 1. part. 1. BuckhurÅ¿ts caÅ¿e; for there is no warranty for him to make out, as it Å¿eems.
And Å¿o in any caÅ¿e for a deed that makes his eÅ¿tate good, Nat. br. 138. K. for it is reaÅ¿on to let him have weapons requiÅ¿ite for his neceÅ¿Å¿ary defence.

AgainÅ¿t a LeÅ¿Å¿ee for life.A LeaÅ¿e made to A. for the life of B. remainder over to C. B. dies, C. Å¿hall have a Detinue againÅ¿t A. without requeÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e C. had intereÅ¿t
in it before, 33 Hen. 6.30. B. and he knows that by the death of B. his eÅ¿tate is determined; Å¿ed quaere, if A. do not know B. is dead.

div.head: For what things Detinue lies, 1. Of Chattels; 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: Detinue ought to be of a thing certain,Certain. Nat. br. 138. A. becauÅ¿e the very thing detained is to be recovered.
A Detinue lies for money in a Bag, or Box, or Coffer, Nat. br. 138. A. for that may be certainly known.
And this although the Seal be broken, 21 Edw. 4.30. pl. 25. Littleton, Å¿o that the bale be not broken.
But otherwiÅ¿e it lies not, Nat. br. 138. A. 22 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 137. for then the money cannot be known.
Note, a Detinue was brought for one piece of Dornex of the value of 22 s. and tried at GlouceÅ¿ter AÅ¿Å¿izes, 5 Martii 15 Jac. Q. what Judgment.
Vide tamen 21 Hen. 7.82. pl. 3. Detinue brought of a piece of Å¿ilver. Quaere what piece.
It lies of Rationabile parte bonorum, Rationabile parte bonorum. Heir. 17 Edw. 3.9. pl. 29. by cuÅ¿tome. See before.
CuÅ¿tome, that the Heir Å¿hall have the principal goods. Detinue lies for them, 30 Edw. 3.2. pl. 9. 39 Edw. 3.6. pl. 24. & fol. 9. pl. 15. See before.
Land leaÅ¿ed with implements,Implements. at the end of the term Detinue lies for them, although waÅ¿ted, 20 Hen. 6.16. pl. 2. See before.
Goods loÅ¿tIf goods are loÅ¿t Detinue lies, Nat. br. 138. E. againÅ¿t him that finds them, or a Trover.
Goods bail.Goods bailed to deliver over, Detinue lies, Nat. br. 138. A. 18 Hen. 6.9. A. againÅ¿t the bailee, by the party to whom they Å¿hould have been bailed over. See before.
A. bails goods to B. which are Å¿tole, Detinue lies againÅ¿t B. for them, Coke 4 part. 84. Southcots caÅ¿e. Vid. antea.
But if he receive them to keep, as he doth his own goods, and they are Å¿tole, it lies not, Coke 4. part. 83. Southcots caÅ¿e, 9 Edw. 4.40. pl. 22. Danby. Antea.
Carrier loÅ¿eth goods.Carrier loÅ¿eth goods, or is robbed, yet Detinue lies againÅ¿t him, Coke 4 part. 84. 2 Hen. 7.11. B. TownÅ¿end. Antea.
A. contracts for Corn to be delivered at a day to come,Corn. he Å¿hall have a Detinue at the day for this, No. Lib. Intra. 169. B. Å¿ect. 1. for by the contract he had a property in the Corn.
After divorce it lies for goods given in marriage,Divorce. Nat. br. 139. A. 26 Hen. 8.7. pl. 1. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 13. pl. 61. Vid. antea.
It lies of a HorÅ¿e, Cow, &c. or more Cows o â¢ HorÅ¿es, Nat. br. 138. A. be the number what it will.
It lies for the Plaintiff in Replevin,Replevin. for goods taken in Withernam, becauÅ¿e he from whom they were Å¿o taken had not the property in them, 2 Hen. 4. br. debt 51. 6 Hen. 7.8. B.
Quaere, if the Avowant Å¿hall have a Detinue for his goods taken in Withernam after appearance and claim of the property, 11 Hen. 4.10. pl. 21. for he claim makes not the property.

Tender amends in Replevin.The Plaintiff in a Replegiare after return irrepleviÅ¿able upon tender of amends Å¿hall have a Detinue for the goods, Coke 8. part. 147. A. for he had the property in them, 10 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 14. notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿uch Writ. Vid. antea.

Corn. Wine. A delivered B Corn and Wine, &c. and they periÅ¿h, yet Detinue lies for them, Doct. & Stud. 129. A. Q. what Å¿hall be recovered, dammages
â¢ t videtur.

But if it be a thing that be to be redelivered,HorÅ¿e. as a HorÅ¿e, &c. if it be uÅ¿ed in other manner than was agreed, and if it periÅ¿h in default of the party to whom it was delivered, and Action lies, Doct. & Stud. 129. A. Vid. antea.
But if it be uÅ¿ed but in Å¿uch manner as it was agreed, and it periÅ¿h, but not by default of the party to whom it was delivered, Action lies not, Doct. & Stud. 129. A. Vid. antea.
Note,Note. in brevi de chartis reddendis Å¿emper debet poni cerius numerus chartarum vel Å¿criptorum, RegiÅ¿t. orig 159. B. Nat. br. 138. B. Et Å¿ic (ut videtur) eÅ¿t de aliis bonis & catallis.

div.head: The Count in Detinue, 1. Of Chattels; 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: The Count ought to name all things certain,Count. and the value, 1 Rich. 3.20. A. 3 Hen. 6. viz. time and place.

The Count was,Bailment. that Å¿uch a year day and place A bailed to B bona & catalla, &c. Å¿cilicet, one Cup of Silver, &c. ad valentiam, &c. Å¿alvo cuÅ¿todiend. & eidem querenti cum inde requiÅ¿itus fuiÅ¿Å¿et redeliber and. &c. Lib. Intr. 212. B.
A counts de bailment of Spoons,Spoons. &c. ad valentiam, &c. Lib. Intr. 211. D. Å¿ect. 2. naming the number.

The Count was, Devenerunt Ag. Executors. quod cum ipÅ¿e, the year, day and place, deliberaÅ¿Å¿et W. in vita Å¿ua, catalla, &c. poÅ¿teaque praedictus W. obiit, &c. & poÅ¿t ejus mortem praedictam, &c. devenerunt Å¿uch a day, year and place, to the hands of the aforeÅ¿aid Executors, praedictus W. nec praedicti Executores, &c. Lib. Intra. 212. C. Sect. 4. This againÅ¿t an Executor.
Per Executor.Count per Executor, Com. 275. A. Foxes caÅ¿e. vid. the Count there.

Count upon bailment to B, Trover. which loÅ¿es it, and that the Defendant found it, and yet detinet lies, Lib. Intra. 212. B. Å¿ect. 3. for neither by the bailment, nor by the loÅ¿ing and finding it, is the property altered or diveÅ¿ted out of the Bailor.
Count of a HorÅ¿e found, No. Lib. Intr. 169. D. Sect. 2.

A counts upon a bargain for Corn to be delivered at a day to come,Contract. that Å¿uch a day, year and place he bargained for eight quarters of Corn, ad valentiam, to be delivered, &c. No. Lib. Intra. 169. B. Å¿ect. 1. Vid. antea, by the contract the property was diveÅ¿ted out of A.
For two Obligations,Obligation Lib. Intra. 220. A. Sect. 1.

Husband and Wife for box with deedsThe Husband and Wife count, that they were poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of a Box Å¿ealed with Deeds concerning Lands of the Wife, &c. and loÅ¿t them, and they came to the hands of the Defendant Å¿uch a year, day and place, per Trover, &c. Lib. Intra. 209. B. Sect. 3.
Count of a box with Deeds, Lib. Intra. 202. B. Sect. 7. Though unÅ¿ealed, yet it lies. Q. whether he muÅ¿t not Å¿hew what deeds particularly.

Heir againÅ¿t huÅ¿band and wife.Counts that his Brother, whoÅ¿e Heir he is, was Å¿eized of Land in Fee, and of a box Å¿ealed with Writings touching the Land, and he loÅ¿t the box, and it came to the hands of the wife dum Å¿ola f â¢ it, and that his brother dies without iÅ¿Å¿ue and the Lands deÅ¿cended to him, and that the woman takes a Husband per quod, &c. Lib. Intra. 209. D. Å¿ect. 4. the Action lay againÅ¿t them; for the marriage gains no property where the wife had none before.
Heir againÅ¿t Executors,Heir. Lib. Intra. 210. A. Å¿ect. 5. of the AnceÅ¿tor for things touching the Lands he inherits.

The heir in a Detinue for a box with deeds ought to count that it was Å¿ealed, for otherwiÅ¿e it belongs to the Executors, 36 Hen. 6.27. pl. 26. 39 Edw. 3.7, 8. 41 Edw. 3.2. 11 Hen. 49. A. PaÅ¿ton. Q. how the Å¿ealing Å¿hould make a difference.
And yet the Å¿ealing is not traverÅ¿able, 41 Edw. 3.2.
The heir ought to count of the certainty of the Land, and alÅ¿o how it was conveyed to him, 3 Hen. 6.19. pl. 31. 19 Hen. 11. pl. 29. or elÅ¿ it cannot appear the deeds belong unto him.
He ought to count as heir, if he claims as heir, 7 Hen. 6.31. pl. 25. for every one ought to make his caÅ¿e as it is.

But if he counts upon Bailment to rebail to him and his heirs, he need not to Å¿et forth the Title to the Land, 19 Hen. 6.41. pl. 84. for
there the Action is meerly founded upon the bailment and detainer.
If a Feoffee with warranty make a Feoffment with warranty, his Heir Å¿hall have a Detinue, and count Å¿pecially, Coke 1. part. 2. A. BuckburÅ¿ts caÅ¿e, as his caÅ¿e is.

The heir counts that his Father was Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee, and demands the deed of the eÅ¿tate tail, and good; for his Father may diÅ¿continue and take it again in Fee, 38 Hen. 6.24. pl. 11. and therefore his count Å¿hall be preÅ¿umed to be good.
Count per Feoffee,Feoffee. Lib. Intra. 210. Å¿ect. 6.

Note,Note. if the Writ be of bona & catalla the Count cannot be of Charters, 22 Edw. 4.12. pl. 32. for bona & catalla are not proper words generally to expreÅ¿s Charters by, becauÅ¿e they belong to the real, and not perÅ¿onal eÅ¿tate, and Goods and Chattels are uÅ¿ually intended perÅ¿onal things.
And needs not Å¿ay in the Count how the Defendant came to them, 9 Hen. 5.14. pl. 22. 4 Edw. 4.9. pl. 11. Lib. Intra. 213. A. Å¿ect. 2.
If the Writ be of a box with Deeds, the Count Å¿hall be accordingly, and not of a deed certain, 41 Edw. 3.2. pl. 5. 14 Hen. 6.4. A. Pleading ought to be plain and certain.

The Plaintiff in a Detinue for Deeds for Land ought to make title to the Land in the Count, 33 Hen. 6.26. pl. 12. PriÅ¿ot; for otherwiÅ¿e he ought to make requeÅ¿t for the deeds, and then an Action upon the CaÅ¿e lies, if they be detained from him.

div.head: The Writ in Detinue, 1. Of Chattels; 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: 1. In Comitatu dicitur injuÅ¿te detinet, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. B. that is, in the County Court.

Si quis rem mobilem vendicaverit, ex quacunque cauÅ¿a oblatam vel commodatam, debet in actione Å¿ua definire pretium, & Å¿ic proponere actionem Å¿uam; quia ille Ã quo res petitur non tenetur precitÃ¨ ad rem reÅ¿tituendam, Å¿ed Å¿ub disjunctione, vel ad rem, vel ad pretium, Bracton Lib. 3. fol. 102. B. Where you may recover dammages for the thing detained, the value of it muÅ¿t be Å¿et forth, that the Jury may judge of them.
If it be againÅ¿t an Executor it needs not name him Executor, becauÅ¿e he is only charged with the Detainer, 29 Edw. 3.38. pl. 12. quaere tamen, for the Detainer is not in his own right.

Rex, In Comitatu. praecipimus tibi quod juÅ¿ticies L. quod juÅ¿te, &c. reddat T. quandam chartam, vel duas chartas, vel quoddam Å¿criptum obligatorium, vel conventionale, vel acquietantiae, vel quiete clamantiae, vel teÅ¿tamentarium, vel quoddam Chirographum, quod, quas vel quae, ei injuÅ¿te detinet, ut dicit, Å¿icut rationabiliter monÅ¿trare poterit, ne amplius, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 159. B. Nat. br. 138. B.
Rex, In Banco. praecipe F. quod reddat W. quandam chartam, &c. quam ei injuÅ¿te detinet, ut dicit, & niÅ¿i fecerit, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 159. B. Nat. br. 138. B.
The Writ for Deeds in a Bag, Box, or CheÅ¿t. vid. RegiÅ¿t. 159. B. Lib. Intra. 209. C. Sect. 1.

Note, when a man demands Writings in a bag, box, or cheÅ¿t, he needs not make mention in the Writ or Count what Writings they were, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 160. A. becauÅ¿e they were together and entire; but if looÅ¿e it is otherwiÅ¿e.

If one Å¿ue for Deeds in any Court without a Writ, a Prohibition lies; vide the Writ, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 159. B. Nat br. 139. C. for men muÅ¿t proceed as the Law directs, and they are compellable Å¿o to do.

A bails Deeds to rebail to him and his Heirs, there the Heir need not mention that he is Heir in the Writ, 5 Edw 3.159. pl. 24. for the Action is grounded upon the bailment. Yet quaere, for here is a Å¿pecial bailment.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s in Detinue, 1. Before appearance. 2. After.
div.p: Detinue for Chattels.By the Common Law it was but a diÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, Nat. br. 139. A. 14 Hen. 6.1. that is, â¢ o diÅ¿train him by his goods and Chattels until he appear.
But per 25 Edw. 3. cap. 17. a Capias was given to arreÅ¿t the body of the party, to bring him in.
But lies not in a Detinue for deeds, 5 Eliz. Dyer 223. pl. 24. viz. a Capias. Q. rationem, it may be, becauÅ¿e that may not be Å¿atisfactory to the party to have the perÅ¿on.
Detinue for deeds.The ProceÅ¿s at Common Law was a Summons, Attachment and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, Nat. br. 139. A. 14. Hen. 6.1. viz. for deeds.

But if the Deeds are in a box a Capias lies,
20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 12. 7 Hen. 4.2. pl. 8. 14. Hen. 6.1. pl. 1. 40 Edw. 3.25. pl. 28. Quaere rationem.
But then it ought to count of a Deed in certain, 14 Hen. 6.1. pl. 12 and not generally.

The GarniÅ¿hee may be Å¿ummoned by word,GarniÅ¿hee.
â¢
Hen. 5.13. as well as by Writ.
The GarniÅ¿hor may have a Soire facias to iÅ¿Å¿ue out againÅ¿t the GarniÅ¿hee, and if he make default, judgment Å¿hall be given againÅ¿t him, Lib. Ietra. 217. B. Å¿ect. 3. upon a nihil dicit.

div.head: The GarniÅ¿hment in Detinue, 1. Of Chattels. 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: GarniÅ¿hment is granted for Å¿aving the Condition,GarniÅ¿hment. if it be not performed; only upon this, whether the Defendant did perform it or not, and for no other cauÅ¿e, 40 Edw. 3.11. pl. 24.

The Defendant in Detinue pleads, that the Plaintiff and B delivered this upon condition, and prays GarniÅ¿hment,
ãâ¦ã
and had it allowed for a good plea, without Å¿hewing what the conditions were, 3. Hen. 4.18. for that will appear upon the Interpleader of the parties.
And alÅ¿o the reaÅ¿on is Å¿aid to be, becauÅ¿e the Conditions come not in debate between the Plaintiff and Defendant.

GarniÅ¿hment was prayed of the Heir and Executor of B, and accounted good; becauÅ¿e it did not appear whether the Deeds in the box were real or Chattels, 14 Edw. 4.1. pl. 3. 21 Edw. 3.41. pl. 44. 48 Edw. 3.30. pl. 19. and Å¿o not certain, whether the Heir or Executor was to be Å¿ued.
GarniÅ¿hment granted againÅ¿t an Executor, becauÅ¿e it was Å¿uppoÅ¿ed that the TeÅ¿tator was one that delivered the deeds, 14 Hen. 6.11. pl. 42.
The Defendant Å¿hall have GarniÅ¿hment, although the GarniÅ¿hee was a Å¿tranger to the Delivery, 14 Edw. 4.2. Q.

If the the GarniÅ¿hee be returned dead, then his Heir or Executor Å¿hall be Garnie, and if it be for a Chattel, and it is returned that he is dead inteÅ¿tate, the Ordinary Å¿hall be Garnie, 48 Edw. 3.3. pl. 19. viz. before letter of AdminiÅ¿tration granted.
So of the SucceÅ¿Å¿or of a GarniÅ¿hee, Lib. Inter. 217. C.
Executor Å¿hall have GarniÅ¿hment upon a delivery to his TeÅ¿tator, Lib. Intra. 216. D. Sect. 1. and an Action thereupon brought againÅ¿t him.

div.head: Enterpleader in Detinue, 1. Of Chattels. 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: Note,Enterpleader. that there Å¿hall be no Enterpleader vnleÅ¿s the Defendant pray it, 18 Edw. 3.22. pl. 3 for the Enterpleader is to Å¿ecure him againÅ¿t both parties, and if he deÅ¿ire not relief, the Court will not put him upon it.

If the parties are by Attorneys, day Å¿hall be given over, becauÅ¿e they Å¿hall not enterplead be in perÅ¿on, 9 Edw. 3.334. pl. 12. 24 Edw. 3.24 pl. 3. which they cannot then do, becauÅ¿e they appear by Attorney.

And if one come at his day by Attorney, the other Å¿hall not have Judgment againÅ¿t him, â¢
Edw. 3.334. pl. 12. for there is no default in him.
Upon Å¿everal Bailments there Å¿hall be no Enterpleader, 19 Hen. 6.2. pl. 6. for there is no privity between the parties.
But if the DeÅ¿endant Å¿aid that he was Joynttenant, abÅ¿que hoc that it was Å¿everal, 19 Hen. 6.3. pl. 6. then it Å¿eems there Å¿hall be an Enterpleader.

In Detinue the Defendant pleads another Writ, hanging by another, and prays Enterpleader, and it was granted for the miÅ¿chief that might be; for other wiÅ¿e both might recover the Deeds, and Å¿o the Defendant be twice charged, 3 Hen. 6.43. pl. 20. which is unreaÅ¿onable; for nemo his pu
â¢ iri debet pro uno Å¿olummodo delicto.
But there ought to be two Å¿everal Writs depending at one time, for the Å¿ame thing, 3 Hen. 6. 35. pl. 31. and theÅ¿e ought to be returned at one day, 9 Hen. 6.36. pl. 9. Q.
If the Defendant and the GarniÅ¿hee do not agree in plea, there Å¿hall be no Enterpleader, 14 Hen. 6.11. for then the garniÅ¿hment will be to no purpoÅ¿e to determine the queÅ¿tion.
There Å¿hall be no Enterpleader unleÅ¿s the Defendant alledge, that both demanded one thing, 8 Edw. 4.6. for the Enterpleader is to determine, who hath the right to that one thing.
If the Defendant after GarniÅ¿hment make default, yet there Å¿hall be an Enterpleader, 2 Rich. 2. Enterpleader 13. for his default Å¿hall not prejudice a third perÅ¿on.
If it be returned at Å¿everal days, then a day Å¿hall be given over, at which day they Å¿hall Enterplead, 33 Hen. 6.25. pl. 8. viz. two Writs of Detinue for the Å¿ame thing.

But if two Writs bear the Å¿ame date, then he that firÅ¿t comes and demands anÅ¿wer, Å¿hall be anÅ¿wered, 19 Hen. 6.4. Lib. Intr. 213. A, & B. Å¿ect. 1. Vigilantibus, non dormientibus jura Å¿ubveniunt.

OtherwiÅ¿e he that the Court aÅ¿Å¿igns, 19 Hen. 6.4. that is, where they demand anÅ¿wer at the Å¿ame time; for where the parties have equal right, it is in the diÅ¿cretion of the Court which CauÅ¿e they will firÅ¿t proceed in, for they cannot proceed in both together, and Å¿uch favour is no InjuÅ¿tice.

div.head: Barr in Detinus; 1. Of Chattels. 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: Accord is a good plea in Detinue of any goods perÅ¿onal,Accord. Coke 9. part. 78. B. Petoes caÅ¿e; but not of real.
Barr that the goods were attached and delivered to him,Attachment. only the cuÅ¿tome of the City, Lib. Intr. 112. C. Å¿ect. 5. of London can warrant this plea in London.

A lent Sheep to a Woman Å¿ole,Command. which took a Husband, which commanded the owner to take them again, who refuÅ¿ed; this is a good barr as to the bailment in Detinue, 43 Edw. 3.21.10. for by the intermarriage the husband had power to redeliver the goods.
A good barr that they were lent to deliver over,To deliver over. of the which he had a deed, Nat. br. 138. M. to prove it. Quaere, whether he ought not to plead in Curia hic prolat.
A good plea by the Executor upon bailment to the TeÅ¿tator, that he, viz. the Executor, had delivered them to him that had the right in the goods, 9 Hen. 6.58. A.
Detinue is no plea, that the Plaintiff gave him the goods, becauÅ¿e he may wage his Law,Given. 22 Edw. 4.29. pl. 10. that the goods were not delivered to him to redeliver.
Detinue upon Trover, the Defendant pleads,DiÅ¿treÅ¿s. that he did diÅ¿train for Rent reÅ¿erved upon a LeaÅ¿e, a good barr, 27 Hon. 8.22. pl. 15. for here can be no Trover.

In Detinue of a HorÅ¿e,EÅ¿tray. a good plea that he did eÅ¿tray into his ground, and that he proclaimed him and offered the HorÅ¿e to the owner, if he would pay for his meat, which he refuÅ¿ed to do, No. Lib. Intr. 169. D. Å¿ect. 2. for Å¿uch a detainer is lawful.

A good barr to Å¿ay,Malady. the HorÅ¿e was Å¿ick in Detinue at the time of the demand, 21 Edw. 4. Detinue br. 42. and Å¿o could not be delivered without danger of his death; and the Law loves the preÅ¿ervation of things, and not their deÅ¿truction.
Non detinet a good barr, Lib. Intra. 211.Non detinet. D. Å¿ect. 1. & 2. fol. 112. C. Å¿ect. 4, & 5. for it is directly contrary to the Å¿uppoÅ¿al of the Writ, and Å¿o a good iÅ¿Å¿ue is tendred.
And this may be by the Countrey, Lib. Intra. 211. D. Sect. 1, and 112. Sect. 4. C. viz. tried by a Jury as matter in fact.
Or by wager of Law, 22 Edw. 4.29. pl. 10. Lib. Intra. 112. C. Sect. 5. 5 Edw. 3. 145. pl. 4. 27 Edw. 3.83. pl. 6. 4 Edw. 3.41. by the Oath of the Defendant.
Although the bailment be by deed, for the Detinet is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Action, 27 Hen. 8.22. pl. 14. and not the bailment.
An Executor may wage his Law, 11 Hen. 6.40. pl. 25. 3 Hen. 6.38. Martin, of a bailment made to the TeÅ¿tator. Quaere, or whether upon the detinet.
Non detinet by the Law gager, although the bailment be by others hands, 8 Hen. 6.10. pl. 26. 33 Hen. 6.8. B. Moyle, is a good barr.
If an Executor pays a debt of the Bailors to the value of the goods,Payment to the value. and dies, this is a good barr in Detinue brought againÅ¿t the Å¿urviving Executor, 3 Eliz. Dyer 187. pl. 6. Q
The Defendant Å¿aid,Pledge. that the Plaintiff pledged them for money, which is not paid; this is a good barr, 34 Hen. 6.42. pl. 13. for here is no bailment, but the goods are in cuÅ¿tody of the Law.
Corn is lent, &c. and it periÅ¿heth; this is no barr,PeriÅ¿h. Doct. & Stud. 129. A. in a Detinue for the Corn, for the Borrower ought to make it good at his own peril.
A HorÅ¿e uÅ¿ed in other manner than was agreeds no barr if he periÅ¿h. Vid. antea; for he is a truÅ¿t abuÅ¿ed, which the Law hates.

But if he be uÅ¿ed in the Å¿ame manner, if he periÅ¿h not in deÅ¿ault of the party to whom he was lent, it is a good barr, Doct. & Stud. 129. A. for here was no truÅ¿t deceived, nor fault in the Bailee.

No plea for a Carrier or Ferryman, that he was robbed,Robbery. Coke 4. part. 84. Southcots caÅ¿e, ãâã
Hen. 7.11. B. TownÅ¿end, but they muÅ¿t take their remedy againÅ¿t the Thieves, and they are by Law anÅ¿werable to the owners of the goods.

So if goods are delivered to keep, Coke 4. part. 83. B. for Å¿uch an acceptance implies a warranty
to keep them Å¿afe, and to redeliver them.
But it is a good plea, if they are taken to keep as my own, Coke 4. part. 83. for there is no Å¿uch warranty implied. Vid. antea.
Recovery in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s a good barr in Detinue,Recovery. 20 Hen. 7.58. B. Crooke; for there Å¿hall not be a double recovery for one thing.
The bailment is not traverÅ¿able where he may wage his Law,Travers. 8 Edw. 4.3. pl. 7. for there his Oath that he detains not is Å¿ufficient; for if he detains not, there could be no bailment.
No barr that the HorÅ¿e was Å¿old in a Market overt, unleÅ¿s it were tolled,Vendee. according to the Statute, 1 & 2 Phil. & Mariae, cap. 7. for no property is altered by Å¿uch a Å¿ale. Vid. antea.
Detinue for Deeds as Heir,BaÅ¿tardy. BaÅ¿tardy is a good plea, 35 Hen. 6.9. pl. 12. for if a BaÅ¿tard, he is no Heir.

A bailed to B to rebail, and dies,FeoÅ¿tment having two Sons, which makes partition, he which had the Land comprehended in the deed delivered enfeoffs B; this is a good barr, 17 Edw. 3.12. pl. 45. for by the purchaÅ¿e the deed belongs to B.
Warranty and AÅ¿Å¿ets is no barr againÅ¿t the iÅ¿Å¿ue in Tail in Detinue,Warrant, 9 Hen. 6.15. pl. 5. 4 Hen. 7.10. pl. 4. for he comes in by the Donor.
Rebailment in another County a good barr,Rebailment. becauÅ¿e he cannot wage his Law, 22 Hen. 6.15. pl. 27. becauÅ¿e the bailment was in one County, and the Action is brought in another County.
ReleaÅ¿e per the Plaintiff a good barr,ReleaÅ¿e. Lib. Intra. 290. B. Sect. 1. for by the ReleaÅ¿e the property was altered.

The Defendant pleads bailment of deeds by the Plaintiff,Retainer. upon condition, that if his wife the PlainteÅ¿s Å¿urvive the Plaintiff, that the Defendant Å¿hould retain it, and that his wiÅ¿e is alive, a good barr; but then he ought to Å¿hew what Lands they concern, 18 Edw. 4.18. that it may be known unto whom the deed belongs.
Infancy is no plea,Infancy. becauÅ¿e he may avoid an obligation in debt, 14 Hen. 6.11. pl. 41. by pleading deins age.

A good bar that the GarniÅ¿hee brought a Detinue againÅ¿t the Defendant,Recovery. and prays GarniÅ¿hment againÅ¿t the Plaintiff, which makes default, and he had judgment, 34 Hen. 6.47. pl. 13. 21 Hen. 6.35. pl. 2. per Newton.
GarniÅ¿hee pleads releaÅ¿e between the time of this Action brought,ReleaÅ¿e. and the delivery, & quaere, 20 Hen. 6.28. pl. 23. 49 Edw. 3.13.
But 39 Edw. 3.13. adjudged, that it is a good barr, and Å¿o it Å¿eems the Law to be.

div.head: The Judgment in Detinue; 1. Of Chattels. 2. Of Deeds.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t the Defendant. 1. Quod praedictus W. recuperet verÅ¿us praefat. J. praedicta octo quarteria frumenti, vel valorem eorundem, No. Lib. Intra, 169. C. Sect. 1. Lib. Intra. 218. B. Sect. 4. & dampua Å¿ua, &c. and upon the return of the Writ, if it appears that W. did not deliver the Corn, then the judgment Å¿hall be for the value with dammages and coÅ¿ts. So Å¿ee the difference, where the Plaintiff himÅ¿elf delivers the thing, and where another.
The Plaintiff Å¿hall have judgment to recover the thing named,Plaintiff 17 Edw. 3.45. 1 Rich. 3.1. & 2. or the value of it, and dammages for detaining of it, as appears above.
The judgment was, that he Å¿hould recover his Chattels, and his dammages, 21 Hen 6.36. A.
Bracton, Lib. 3. fol. 102. B. non tenetur preciÅ¿e ad rem reÅ¿tituend. Å¿ed Å¿ub disjunct. vel ad rem, vel ad pretium; either the thing, or the value of it indammages.

AgainÅ¿t the Defendant.The judgment was, that he Å¿hould recover the deeds, if they are found, and alÅ¿o d â¢ mmages for the detainer; and if not found, then all in dammages, 7 Hen. 6.31. pl. 25. 22 Hen. 6.41. pl. 17. as well for the deeds as for the detainer of them.
And this Å¿hall be, although it be proved that the Defendant burnt the deed, 17 Edw. 3.45. pl. 1. for that Å¿hall not excuÅ¿e.
Ideo confideratum eÅ¿t, quod praedictus. A. recuperet verÅ¿us praefat. B. pyxidem praedictam cum chartis, &c. Lib. Intra. 218. A. Sect. 1. the box with the writings.
The Heir in Detinue had judgment to recover one box, with as much as was in it contained that belongs to him, 5 Edw. 3.159. B. intended to be of writings.

AgainÅ¿t the Defendant and the GarniÅ¿hee.The judgment was, that he Å¿hould recover the deeds againÅ¿t the Defendant, & haberet liberationem verÅ¿us the GarniÅ¿hee, 21 Hen. 6.36. A. Lib. Intra. 219. D. Å¿ect. 17. 9 Hen. 6.38. pl. 13.7. Hen. 6.45. pl. 27. This is a double judgment, viz. of the right, and of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

But if Judgment be given upon default of the GarniÅ¿hee before appearance, no dammages Å¿hall
be given, 20 Hen. 6.4. pl. 27. for this is not the Defendants fault.
If the Plaintiff and Defendant make default, the GarniÅ¿hee Å¿hall have Judgment, and the Plaintiff and Defendant in miÅ¿ericordia, 40 Edw. 3.39. pl. 15. for his unjuÅ¿t vexation.

div.head: Execution in Detinue; 1. Of Defendant. 2. AgainÅ¿t the GarniÅ¿hee. 3. Of what Lands. 4. Of what Goods.
div.p:
Execution againÅ¿t the Defendant by diÅ¿treÅ¿s for the thing detained and recovered,Chattels. Nat. Lib. Intr â¢ . 169. C. Å¿ect. 1. 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 12. No. Lib. Intr â¢ . 170. D. 17. A. 6 Rich.
â¢ . Execution.
But if the thing be not delivered to the Plaintiff, then he Å¿hall have execution for the dammages by Capias, Lib. Intra. 216. B. Å¿ect. 6. 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 12. againÅ¿t the perÅ¿on of the Defendant.
For a Capias was given in the main ProceÅ¿s per 25 Edw. 3. cap. 17. and by conÅ¿equence a Capi â¢â¢ ad Å¿atisfaciend. in execution by the equity of that Statute.
At the Common Law execution was for dammages by fieri facias, and alÅ¿o for the goods, Lib. Intra. 216. B. Å¿ect. 8. to be levied upon the goods of the Defendant.
For dammages by fieri facias, and for the thing by diÅ¿treÅ¿s of the Goods and Chattels, 6 Rich. 2. Execution 45.
The Plaintiff and Defendant make default, GarniÅ¿hee had Judgment and diÅ¿treÅ¿s againÅ¿t the Defendant, 40 Edw. 3.39. pl. 15. Vid. antea.
DiÅ¿treÅ¿s iÅ¿Å¿ued forth in execution, Lib. Intra. 215. C. Å¿ect. 1. 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 12. 22 Hen. 6.41. pl. 17.
But Capias lies not, 5 Eliz. Dyer 223. pl. 24. 21 Hen. 6.42. vid. antea.
If the deeds concern Lands, 8 Hen. 6.29. pl. 24. 14 Hen. 6.1. pl. 1.
But for the dammages, if they will not deliver them, a Capias lies, 22 Hen. 6.41. pl. 17. 20 Edw. 43. pl. 12.
If deeds are in a box, then a Capias ad Å¿atiÅ¿faciendum lies in execution againÅ¿t the perÅ¿on, 7 Hen. 4.2. pl. 8. 14 Hen. 6.1. pl. 1. 40 Edw 3.25. pl. 28.
But for dammages at the Common Law it was but a fieri facias, Lib. Intra. 216. B. Å¿ect. 7. upon the goods and Chattels.
Or a levari facias, Coke 3. part. 12. A. upon Lands and goods.
And this only within the year, for after the year the party had but an Action of Debt, Coke 3. part. 12. A. vid. antea.
UnleÅ¿s the Suit be continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33.

But by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 450. a Scire facia â¢
is given after the year to revive the judgment, and by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 18. an Elegit is given, antea, upon the Lands.

And by the twenty fifth of Edw. 3. cap. 17. Capias is given in ProceÅ¿s for deeds in a Box, and by conÅ¿equence a Capias ad Å¿atisfaciend. in execution, Lib. Intra. 216. A. Sect. 3.40. Edw. 3.25. pl. 28. antea.
If dammages Å¿hall be recovered againÅ¿t a GarniÅ¿hee,Deeds. the execution Å¿hall be of the goods and Lands of the GarniÅ¿hee, 7 Hen. 6.45. pl. 27. 9 Hen. 6.38. pl. 13. 19 Hen. 6.4,
But not of his body, becauÅ¿e he was not party to the Writ, 7 Hen. 6.45. pl. 27. 9 Hen. 6.38. pl. 13. upon which the Action was brought, but comes in by GarniÅ¿hment.

But the Book of Entries 216. B. Å¿ect. 6. Capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum was a warded againÅ¿t a GarniÅ¿hed for dammages recovered againÅ¿t him. Quaere, if as well for the detainer as for the thing detained.

ture.
