div.head: Debt, in what Court it lies.
div.p:
IN the County Court,
â¢â¢ o â¢â¢
Nat. br. 119. G. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. A.
In a Village, City, and Burrough Liberty, Natâª br. 119. K.
In Pypowders, viz. a Court held in a Fair.

But by the 17 Edw. 4. cap. 2. the Plaintiff or his Attorney ought to Å¿wear that it was in the Fair, and within the JuriÅ¿diction, 1 Rich. 3. cap. 6. and if he refuÅ¿e, the Defendant Å¿hall go quit by the Statute; for it appears not that the Court had JuriÅ¿diction to hold plea.

It lies in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, if both are of the houÅ¿hold of the King, otherwiÅ¿e not; but the Plaintiff needs not Å¿hew this in his Count, and the proceeding there is by bill, Coke 10. part. 61. CaÅ¿e of MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey; for if it be not Å¿o the Defendant may demur to the juriÅ¿diction of the Court.
In Chancery, for a perÅ¿on priviledged de â¢â¢ lies, viz. in that Court; for the Chancery to Å¿ome purpoÅ¿es is a Court of Law as well as of equity.

In the Exchequer by quo minus, Coke 8 part. 6 â¢
A. Trollops caÅ¿e; but then the Plaintiff ãâã make himÅ¿elf an Accountant to the King.

So if one uÅ¿urp upon a FranchiÅ¿e of the King where the Plaintiff had Fee Farm, the Fee Far â¢ e â¢ Å¿hall Å¿ue by a Quo minus, 32 Hen. 6.24. pl. 7. ãâã the Exchequer; for he is an Accountant to ãâã King.
An Executor Å¿hall have a Quo minus, when ãâã is a debtor to the King by his own act, 8 Hen. 4.10. pl. 19. as Executor.
In Com. Ban. Nat. br. 119. G.

Debt lies not for a popular Action,Note. or upon penal Law, but in one of the four Courts of Record at WeÅ¿tm. per Statut. 18 Eliz. cap 5. G â¢ k â¢â¢ part. Gr â¢ gories caÅ¿e; for thoÅ¿e Courts are fine to interpret Statutes, and not inferiour CourÅ¿s.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have Debt.
div.p: If a Baily account for his MaÅ¿ter,Accountant. and Å¿urpluÅ¿age be found due to his MaÅ¿ter, he Å¿hall have debt for it, Nat. br. 121. I. the Count, Lib. Intra. 150. D. Å¿ect. 1. quaere, if it be not meant where the Baily accounts with his MaÅ¿ter.
But a Receiver Å¿hall not, Nat. br. 121. I. 38 Hen. 6.5. pl. 14. Mich. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, CounteÅ¿s of Suffolke & Floyde; for the Law takes not Å¿o much notice of a Receiver, as of a Baily.
AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall not have debt until,AdminiÅ¿trator. 31 Edw. 3. cap. 11. Nat. br. 120. D. Coke 9. part. 39. A. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e; for the Common Law takes no notice of an AdminiÅ¿trator.

1. An AdminiÅ¿trator ought to count, that he which committed the AdminiÅ¿tration, was the Ordinary of the place where the inteÅ¿tate died, 31 Hen. 6.23. pl. 5. Com. 277. A. per Dyer. If it be a particular JuriÅ¿diction, he muÅ¿t Å¿ay, cui adminiÅ¿tratio pertinuit.
2. he ought to name the place where the AdminiÅ¿tration was to him committed, 35 Hen. 6.31. pl. 39. Danby & Moyle; becauÅ¿e it is traverÅ¿able.
3. He needs not name the Ordinary by his ChriÅ¿tian name, 7 Hen 4.10. pl. 18. for the place where makes it certain enough who it is.
But in a Writ de Colligend. he Å¿hall be named. Q. de ceo brief.
An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have debt upon, 1 Edw. 2. cap. 14. for money given to Chantery.

If the Ordinary releaÅ¿e a debt to a Debtor of the InteÅ¿tate, and afterwards grants AdminiÅ¿tration to A; yet A Å¿hall have debt againÅ¿t the Debtor, for the ReleaÅ¿e is void in Law, 18 Hen. 6.23. Coke 9. part. 39. A. vide Crooke 127. pl. 90. for the Debt is not the Ordinaries.
Attorney Å¿hall have Debt for his Fees,Attorney. and Fees of CounÅ¿el, and coÅ¿ts of Suits, Nat. br. 121. L. 21 Hen. 6.4. Quaere of CounÅ¿ells Fees, if not expended by his Clients direction.

If J. deliver money to bail over,Bailor. or to a Merchant to trade with for me, or to be given is Alms, or upon a condition to rebail, if he break the truÅ¿t, J. Å¿hall have debt againÅ¿t him, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 135. 11 Hen. 6.39. pl. 3. 42 Edw. 3 9. pl. 7. Crooke, 21 Hen. 7.69. pl. 2. per Fro â¢
icke; for if the truÅ¿t be not performed, the money belongs to the Bailor.
A is bound to the Husband and Wife,Husband. the Husband alone Å¿hall have the Action, 3 Hen. 6.37. pl. 35. 12 Rich. 2. bre. 637. in his own name only, if he will.
Or in both their names, 39 Edw. 3.5. pl. 19. 43 Edw. 3.10. pl. 31. 3 Hen. 6.37. pl. 35. 12 Rich 2. bre. 639. 16 Edw. 4.8. for the Husband may intereÅ¿t his Wife in the debt.

Husband and wife.Husband and Wife aÅ¿Å¿ign Auditors to receive ãâã debt due to the Wife dum Å¿ola fuit, and brought debt for the Arrearages in both their names, and good; becauÅ¿e the wife was the cauÅ¿e of the Action, 16 Edw. 4 8. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e the debt was due to her dum Å¿ola.

Husband and wife leaÅ¿e for years Lands of the wife rendering Rent. the Husband dies, and the
Å¿econd Husband brought debt, and good, 28 Edw. 3.90. pl. 4. for the Law creates a privity in him.

A Woman leaÅ¿es at will rendering rent, and takes a husband, the Rent is behind, they joyn in debt, and good, Coke 5. part. 10. HenÅ¿teads caÅ¿e; for the marriage Å¿hall not determine her will Å¿o as to extinguiÅ¿h the debt.
A Woman Å¿hall not have an Action againÅ¿t her husband, although Å¿he is Executrix, 8 Edw. 3. 330. pl. 48. for Å¿he cannot Å¿ue her Å¿elf, and the husband and wife are but one perÅ¿on in Law.

A is bound to the husband and wife, and they are divorced cauÅ¿a prae-contractus, and they brought debt in both their names, No. Lib. Intra. 121. Å¿ect. 5. for the divorce makes the marriage void ab initio, and Å¿o the obligation is void, and therefore the Action not well brought, as it Å¿eems.

B had a Rectory in right of his wife for years, and they both joyned in debt upon the Statute of 2 Edw. 6. for not Å¿etting forth of Tithes, Hill. 39 Eliz. Ban. Regis Rot. 699. and good; for the Action is grounded by reaÅ¿on of the wife.
LeaÅ¿e for years rendering Rent by the husband and wife, husband may have debt in his own name, 7 Edw. 4 5. pl. 16. for the Rent belongs to him.

The Å¿ame Law is, if the ReverÅ¿ion be aÅ¿Å¿igned to the husband and wife, although that the huÅ¿band count as AÅ¿Å¿ignee, Trin. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wyats caÅ¿e. Quaere, whether in both caÅ¿es the Action may not be brought in both their names.
Husband and wife Å¿old the Land of the wife, the husband alone Å¿hall have debt, 48 Edw. 3.18. pl. 4. for the money belongs only to him.
Husband and wife recover dammages, the husband alone Å¿hall have debt for them, 16 Hen. 6. bre. 939. for the husband Å¿hall have them.

A woman Tenant in dower of Rent takes a husband and dies, the husband Å¿hall have debt for the Arrearages during the Coverture, Nat br. 121. C. 14 Hen. 6.26. A. 10 Hen. 6.11. 22. Hen. 6.25. 26 Edw. 3.64. for the Rent was due to him.
And by 32 Hen. 8. Ca. 37. the husband Å¿hall have debt for the Arrearages before the Coverture, Coke 5. part. 51. A. Ognels caÅ¿e, elÅ¿e the Rent would be loÅ¿t.

Annuity to the wife that takes a husband, Arrearages incurr, the wife dies, the husband Å¿hall have debt, becauÅ¿e it is more than a thing in Action, Hill. 29. Eliz. Com. Ban. St. Legers, for it is a duty incurred.

But if it be but for a thing in action before the Coverture, as an Obligation, the husband Å¿hall not have it, Nat. br. 121. C. 39. Hen. 6.26. pl. 38. becauÅ¿e of the incertainty, whether it were due to the wife, or not.
But during the Coverture the husband may releaÅ¿e it, 17 Edw. 3.66. pl. 78. Hill; for that paÅ¿Å¿eth nothing but by way of extinguiÅ¿hment of his right, if he have any.

Husband makes his wife Executrix, which takes a husband, and makes him Executor, and dies; the husband brought debt for the debt to the former husband, and good, 4 Hen. 6.31.
for now it is become due to him as Executor of an Executor.

Clerk of the Peace.It lies in the name of the Clerk of the Peace for the Hundred againÅ¿t the Village, where default is made in Hue and Cry, by the Statute of 27 Eliz. cap. 13. and reaÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e thereby the Hundred becomes liable to pay the money robbed.
Colledge in Oxon. A Colledge Å¿hall have debt for Commons of any Student, PaÅ¿ch. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Colledge of St. Johns in Oxford verÅ¿us Brickeden. Q. if the Student be of the Foundation.

Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians.Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians, for practiÅ¿ing without LicenÅ¿e Å¿hall have debt upon the Statute; but the MaÅ¿ter Å¿ole Å¿hall not, Hill. 11 Jac. Ban. Regis, Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians verÅ¿us Dr. Tenant, Lib. Reports, title Plaints. Q.

Debt lies by a ConuÅ¿ee of a Statute or Recognizance,Stat. Merchant Staple. ConuÅ¿ee. According to 23 Hen. 8. Recogn. CounÅ¿ellor Nut br. 122. D. 11 Hen. 6.49. pl. 7. 36 Hen. 6.2. pl. 2. 39 Hen. 6.3. pl. 5. 22 Eliz. Dyer 369. pl. 52. 13 Rich. 2. bre. 649. upon the Statute or Recognizance.
Debt upon a retainer to be his CounÅ¿ellor for 40 s. per annum; but then he ought to count that he was of his counÅ¿el, or was ready to be, 37 Hen. 6.8. B. PriÅ¿ott, if required.
But if I retain a Sergeant at Law for A, he Å¿hall not have debt for his Å¿alary againÅ¿t me, 31 Hen. 6.9. B ForteÅ¿cue; for he is retained for his Client, and it is reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould pay him.
ExecutorExecutor Å¿hall have debt for a debt due to the TeÅ¿tator, 11 Hen. 6.7. for he is in place of the TeÅ¿tator.
Executor of an Executor Å¿hall have debt, 25 Edw. 3. Ca. 5. & Å¿ic in infinitum, as it Å¿eems.

Executor Å¿hall not have debt before probat of the TeÅ¿tament, 7 Hen. 4.18. Coke 5. part. 28. A. Midletons caÅ¿e, Com. 278. Foxes caÅ¿e, Perkin 193. for before that he is not Executor in the eye of the Law.
But if (pendente breve) the TeÅ¿tament be proved, it Å¿ufficeth, PaÅ¿ch. 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. WalmeÅ¿ly; for that relates to the death of the TeÅ¿tator, and Å¿o includes the time of hanging the Action.

Feme.Rent Å¿ervices granted to the husband and wife for life, the husband dies, the wife Å¿hall have the Arrearages that did accrue in the life of the huÅ¿band, and debt for them after the eÅ¿tate ended, 29 Edw. 3.40. pl. 19. for here is a Å¿urviving eÅ¿tate in the wife.
Grantee of a ReverÅ¿ion. Annuity.Grantee of a ReverÅ¿ion Å¿hall not have debt for Rent upon a LeaÅ¿e for years before Attornment, Nat. br. 121. N. for before Attornment the ReverÅ¿ion paÅ¿Å¿ed not.
But a DeviÅ¿ee Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 121. N. Mich. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Bayliffs and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es caÅ¿e of IpÅ¿wiche; for there it paÅ¿Å¿eth by the will.
So Bargainee Å¿hall have it, Coke 3. part. 24. A. Walkers caÅ¿e; for it paÅ¿Å¿eth by enrolment of the Deed.
Heir. A is bound to B and his heirs, B dies, his heirs Å¿hall not have debt, Nat. br. 120. I. but the Executor; but contrary where A binds himÅ¿elf and his heirs to B.

But if a penalty be granted to one and his heirs, then the heir Å¿hall have debt, Nat. br. 120. M. 11 Hen. 4.84. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 24. pl. 149. for that is a preÅ¿ent duty, wherein the heir hath intereÅ¿t.
The heir Å¿hall have debt for the reaÅ¿onable part of the goods, where the cuÅ¿tome gives it him, Nat. br. 122. L. for this is a cuÅ¿tomary duty, for which the Law will give a remedy.

But if there be no Å¿uch cuÅ¿tome it lies not, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 142. B. 40 Edw. 3.38. pl. 19. 7. Edw. 4.20. pl. 23. 30 Edw. 3.26. A. Å¿eton. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 141. B. for the Common Law takes no Å¿uch notice of the heir, to have any goods as heir.

For the Statute of Magna Charta is but one forÅ¿pris, and for that an Action Å¿hall not be founded upon it, vide Lib. Intra. 541. by reaÅ¿on of the incertainty of the meaning of the Statute in that point.
But Nat. br. 122. L. Glanvill, Lib. 12. cap. 20. 17 Edw. 3.9. pl. 29. this is by the Common Law. quaere.

CuÅ¿tome, that the heir Å¿hall have the principal Chattels, &c. he Å¿hall have debt for them, 30 Edw. 3.2. pl. 9. 39 Edw. 3.6. pl. 24. & fol. 9. pl. 15. The Law takes notice, and maintains ancient CuÅ¿tomes.

LeÅ¿Å¿or.LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have debt for Rent reÅ¿erved upon a LeaÅ¿e at will, Coke 5. part. 10. HenÅ¿teads caÅ¿e, Littleton 15. by reaÅ¿on of the privity of the Contract betwixt the LeÅ¿Å¿or and the LeÅ¿Å¿ee.
And Å¿o for a LeaÅ¿e for years, 7 Rich. 2. this Å¿eems a Å¿tronger caÅ¿e.

Tenants in Common make a LeaÅ¿e rendring Rent, they ought to joyn, Littleton 72. in the
Action in reÅ¿pect of their joyning in the LeaÅ¿e, and Å¿o a joynt intereÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿ed.

Ordinary.The Ordinary Å¿hall not have debt, becauÅ¿e he hath not abÅ¿olute intereÅ¿t in the things of the InteÅ¿tate, Coke 9. part. 33. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, Nat. br. 120. D. but hath it only as a Conduit-pipe, to derive it to others to whom the Law directs.
ParÅ¿on.A ParÅ¿on Å¿hall have debt for not Å¿etting out of Tithes, by the Stat. of 2 Edw. 6. cap. 13. and recover treble dammages.
PhyÅ¿ician.A PhyÅ¿ician Å¿hall have debt for PhyÅ¿ick and Diet, Lib. Intra. 187. B. Sect. 1. upon a quantum meruit, if there be no Å¿pecial contract.
RecuÅ¿ant.RecuÅ¿ancy Å¿hall be pleaded in diÅ¿ability for Å¿uch Lands and Tenements which are not Å¿eized into the Kings hands, 3 Jac. cap. 5. in diÅ¿ability of the perÅ¿on to Å¿ue. Q.
Robbery.The party robbed Å¿hall have an Action againÅ¿t the Hundred per le Stat. 27 Eliz. cap. 13.
But he ought to bring his Action within the year after the Robbery done, 27 Eliz. cap. 13.
And the day of the Robbery Å¿hall be accounted parcel of the time, PaÅ¿ch. 15. Jac. Com Ban. per 2 JuÅ¿tices, as it Å¿eems, becauÅ¿e the Law is penal. Quaere tamen.
Steward.Steward of a Court retained by word for Å¿uch a Å¿um per annum, Å¿hall have debt for his Å¿alary, 8 Eliz. Dyer 248. pl. 79. Coke 4. part. 30. A.
Servant.Servant Å¿hall have debt for his Å¿alary, 11 Hen. 6.10. pl. 20. upon the contract which created a duty.

One retained in England to do Å¿ervice beyond the Sea, Å¿hall have debt in England where the retainder was, Nat. br. 120. E. and not where
the Å¿ervice is done, becauÅ¿e it is beyond Sea; aliter quaere.

Servant retained by a Corporation without deed, Å¿hall not have debt for his Å¿alary, 4 Hen. 7.6. Com. 91. B. for Å¿uch Retainer is null in Law, and the Servant could not have been compelled to Å¿erve.

SucceÅ¿Å¿or. Sole Corporation conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of one perÅ¿on.One Å¿ole Corporation Å¿hall not have a perÅ¿onal thing in SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, Coke 4. part. 65. A. Fulwoods caÅ¿e, 19 Hen. 6.44. pl. 94. 20 Edw. 4.2. vide 32 Hen. 8. Dyer 48. pl. 14. for perÅ¿onal things ceaÅ¿e with the perÅ¿on.
UnleÅ¿s the CuÅ¿tome will warrant it, Coke 4 part 65. A. Fulwoods caÅ¿e. CuÅ¿tome, if it be not unreaÅ¿onable, makes a Law.
But a Corporation aggregate, that is, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of many perÅ¿ons, Å¿hall have an Action for a perÅ¿onal thing in Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion, Coke 4. part. 65. A. 20 Edw. 4.2.
MaÅ¿ter of an HoÅ¿pital recovers dammages, the SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have them, 19 Hen. 6.44. pl. 94. for the benefit of the houÅ¿e.

Abbot recovers dammages in battery, and is removed or created BiÅ¿hop; his SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have them, becauÅ¿e he recovered them, but to the uÅ¿e of his houÅ¿e, 22 Hen. 6.4. B. for he could Å¿ue in no other capacity being a dead perÅ¿on in Law.
A is bound to an Abbot Å¿ole, the SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have debt, 47 Edw 3.23. pl. 57. the Count, Lib. Intra. 179. A. Å¿ect. 7. for it was to the uÅ¿e of the houÅ¿e.

An Obligation made to Churchwardens, their SucceÅ¿Å¿ors Å¿hall not have an Action being their Executors, for this is but an Office and cannot
be derived to others; but as their SucceÅ¿Å¿ors ãâã Å¿eems it may. Q

If A contracts for B with the Chirurgeon Å¿ â¢â¢ Å¿o much as to cure him,Chirurgeon. if B die the Chirurge â¢â¢ Å¿hall have debt againÅ¿t A, for it is a good contract 37 Hen. 6.9. A. Moyle, to bind it. Q.

If J Å¿ell a HorÅ¿e, and earneÅ¿t is given or â¢â¢â¢
Å¿et, J Å¿hall have debt for the money, 14 Hen. 8.19. br. Contract. 15. Coke 3. part. 22. A. Walken caÅ¿e, and the loÅ¿ing of the EarneÅ¿t will not avoid the Contract, as the vulgar opinion is.

If J Å¿ell a Mannor,Vendor. debt lieth for the money, and yet the Vendee cannot enter before livery, 37 Hen. 6.8. pl. 18. PriÅ¿ott, upon the Contract, ãâã the Vendee may force him to make livery.

The Sheriff Å¿hall have debt for his Fees,Sheriff. Tris. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, Sheriff of London againÅ¿t
â¢ lichel, per le Stat. 28 Eliz. cap. 14. for the La â¢ creates the duty, when he hath performed his office.
If A gives money to B to carry to C, UÅ¿e. yet C Å¿hall have debt, count, Lib. Intr. 159. Å¿ect. 1. for the delivery was for his benefit.
Outlawed perÅ¿on Å¿hall not have debt,Outlawed perÅ¿on. 16 Eds. 44.7. Hen. 4.1. pl. 6. nor other Action; for he that will not obey the Law, ought not to recei â¢â¢ benefit by it.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Debt lies.
div.p:
An Abbot Å¿hall be charged for Debt due by him which enters into Religion,Abbot. Nat. br. 121. O.
â¢
Hen. 5.8. pl. 18. into the houÅ¿e whereof he is Abbot; for the perÅ¿on himÅ¿elf cannot be charged, and the Abbot takes into the Covent cum caret â¢ iÅ¿ua.
If Accountant be found in Arrearages,Accountant. debt lies againÅ¿t him; for here is a duty created by adjudging him in Arrear.

Debt at the Common Law lay againÅ¿t the Committees of the Ordinary;AdminiÅ¿trator. but this was by the name of Executors, and only for goods which came to their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 38 Edw. 3.26. 42. Edw. 3.2. Coke 9. part. 39. B. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e.

But by 31 Edw. 3. cap. 11. they are chargeable by the name of AdminiÅ¿trators, in the Å¿ame manner as Executors are, 38 Edw. 3.2. pl. 3. 41 Edw. 3.2. pl. CÃ²ke 9. part. 39. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, viz. by Å¿hewing how.
PlenÃ¨ adminiÅ¿travit Å¿pecial, No. Lib. Intra. 269. B. a good plea for Executors or AdminiÅ¿trators.

A Recovery againÅ¿t one AdminiÅ¿trator upon a nihil dicit is no plea in debt againÅ¿t all, Hill. 38 Eliz. Com. Ban. Furthow verÅ¿us Furthow; for they are all liable, and it may be there was no Å¿atisfaction upon the recovery.

If an AdminiÅ¿trator waÅ¿te the goods, and after the AdminiÅ¿tration is diÅ¿Å¿olved and granted to
another, D â¢ bt lies againÅ¿t the former, Coke 6. part. 18, & 19. Packmans caÅ¿e; for at the time of the waÅ¿ting he was AdminiÅ¿trator, and chargeable.

A being Executor of his own wrong takes AdminiÅ¿tration, quaere how he Å¿hall be Å¿ued, Greeke 127. pl. 91. It Å¿eems as AdminiÅ¿trator, for in the other condition he was but a tort Feoffor upon the matter.
Termor aÅ¿Å¿igns his term to another,AÅ¿Å¿ign. the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have debt againÅ¿t the AÅ¿Å¿ignee, Coke 3. part. 25. B. Walkers caÅ¿e; for by the AÅ¿Å¿ignment here is a privity created.

If there be two Joynt-tenants of a Term,Joyntenant. the one aÅ¿Å¿igns to B, the other dies, debt lies for the rent againÅ¿t the AÅ¿Å¿ignee, and the Executor of the dead for rent after his death by Å¿urvivor; for it Å¿hall be miÅ¿chievous to compel the LeÅ¿Å¿or to bring Å¿everal Actions for one thing. Mich. 14. Jac. Ban. Regis, Bayl â¢ ffes and BurgeÅ¿Å¿s de IpÅ¿wich's caÅ¿e.

If an Attorney Å¿uffer another to follow any matter in his name,Attorney. he forfeits 20 l. and the party grieved Å¿hall have Debt per the Stat. of 3. Jac. cap. 7. This Statute was made to prevent Å¿oul practice.
Debt lies againÅ¿t a perÅ¿on attainted,Attainder. Mich. 38, & 39 Eliz. Com. Ban. BaniÅ¿ter & TruÅ¿Å¿els cÃ¢Å¿e, No. Lib. Intra. 148. A. Quaere, what Attainder; for it Å¿eems not to be general.

Bailee.If J. deliver money to deliver over for Merchandizing, or to give in Alms, or upon a Condition to be performed to redeliver, if the party breaks the truÅ¿t, debt lies, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 22.
pl. 135. 11 Hen. 6.39. pl. 31. 42 Edw. 3.9. pl. 7. Crooke 21 Hen. 7.69. pl. 2. per Frowicke. Vid. entea.
Husband.If the husband give authority to his wife to make a Contract, he Å¿hall be charged by the contract made by her, otherwiÅ¿e not, Nat. br. 120. G. for Å¿uch authority makes it his own contract.
UnleÅ¿s it be for Apparel convenient for his wife, 11 Hen. 6.30. B. for for that he is chargeable, though he give her no authority to contract for it.
But unleÅ¿s it be convenient he Å¿hall not, 7 Eliz. Dyer 234. pl. 17. that is, Apparel neceÅ¿Å¿ary and â¢ eting for her degree to wear.
The husband alone Å¿hall be charged for Arrearages of Rent-Å¿ervice Arrear in his time, Nat. br. 121. C. Crooke 125. pl. 83. for the Land of his wife after her death.

And Å¿o of a Rent-charge, Coke 4. part. 49. B.
â¢ 6 Edw. 3.64. iÅ¿Å¿uing out of his wives Land.

But for an Obligation made by the wife afore coverture, he Å¿hall not be charged after the death of the wife, Nat. br. 121. C. 120. F. 49 Edw. 3. 25. B. 20 Hen. 6.22. for that is but a thing in action.
UnleÅ¿s recovery be had upon it during the life of the wife, Nat. br. 121. C. for by the recovery it becomes a duty.
A woman covert being a Å¿ole Merchant, may be Å¿ued in London by the cuÅ¿tome of the City without the husband; but not in Com. Ban. 9 Edw. 4.3. becauÅ¿e that Law extends not out of the City.

If A and his wife covert by the name of his
wife Å¿ole are obliged, it lies not againÅ¿t the wife, becauÅ¿e it is a void obligation as to the wife, 14 Hen. 4.30. pl. 39.
Husband and wife are bound, the husband alone Å¿hall be Å¿ued, becauÅ¿e it is void againÅ¿t the wife, 43.Edw. 3.10. pl. 31. 45. Edw. 3.11. pl. 7. 3 Hen. 4.1. pl. 4. but good as to the HuÅ¿band.
Husband and Wife.Debt lies againÅ¿t the husband and wife, for rent upon a LeaÅ¿e made to the husband and wife, 45 Edw. 3.11. pl. 7. in reÅ¿pect of the intereÅ¿t the wife may have in the term.
So if it be covenanted or agreed that they double the rent, 45 Edw. 11. pl. 7. for this is, as it were a new rent reÅ¿erved.
But not if it be with a nomine poenae, 45 Edw. 11. pl. 7. for then he muÅ¿t hold him to the penalty, which Å¿hall not fall upon the wife. Q.
When a woman in debt takes a husband they both Å¿hall be Å¿ued, Coke 5. part 36. A. 12 Hen. 4. 1. pl. 1. Nat. br. 120. F. for the marriage makes it both their deeds.

ConuÅ¿or.Debt lies againÅ¿t a ConuÅ¿or of Statute Merchant, Staple or Recognizance, Nat. br. 122. D. 11 Hen. 6.49. pl. 7.Coke 3. part. 15.Harberts caÅ¿e, 36 Hen. 6.2. pl. 2. 22 Elix. Dyer 369. pl. 52. 39 Hen. 6.3. pl. 5. for here is a duty. vid. antea.
CuÅ¿tomer.Debt lies againÅ¿t a CuÅ¿tomer after Liberate delivered to him pay the Å¿um to the party, if he hath AÅ¿Å¿ets, Nat. br. 121. F. elÅ¿e not.
So after a Tallee delivered to pay the party, 27 Hen. 6.9. pl. 1.
So againÅ¿t a Collector of Tenths and Fifteens, 37 Hen. 6.15. pl. 5. granted by Parliament.
Debt lies againÅ¿t an Enfant for Tabling and Apparel, 18 Edw. 4.3. A. Enfant. for theÅ¿e are neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Å¿upport of the Enfant.
For Rent upon a LeaÅ¿e for years, 21 Hen. 6.31. B. upon the words yielding and paying, which make it a duty.
For a EÅ¿cape, if he be a Goaler, Doct. & Stud. 147. B. for the Å¿um for which the priÅ¿oner was committed to him.
For a thing due to one as Executors Coke 5. part. 27. B. RuÅ¿Å¿els caÅ¿e.
Debt lies againÅ¿t an Executor although he be not bound, 45 Edw. 3.17. pl. 4.Executor. becauÅ¿e he is in place of the TeÅ¿tator, who was bound, and hath the eÅ¿tate chargeable.
Debt by the Daughter againÅ¿t the Executor of her Father, which had levied aid to marry her, per WeÅ¿tm. 1. cap. 35. Nat. br. 83. A. & 122. G. and had not paid it to her to whom it properly belonged.
Debt lies againÅ¿t Executors of the Ordinary, which will not deliver the AdminiÅ¿tration to another, Nat. br. 120. D. Com. 280. A. vid. ante to whom they belong.
Debt lies againÅ¿t an Executor of an heir, Lib. Intr. 172. C. Å¿ect. 4.18 Eliz. Dyer 344. pl. 1. where the heir is bound.

AgainÅ¿t an Executor of a Sheriff, for not returning a Knight of the Parliament duly elected, 23 Hen. 6. cap. 15. for dammages are to be recovered, with which the Executor is chargeable, if be have AÅ¿Å¿ets.

Debt againÅ¿t an Executor of his own wrong, Coke 5. part. 30. Coulters caÅ¿e, & 33, & 34. Reads
caÅ¿e, for he hath made himÅ¿elf liable by meddling with the eÅ¿tate, which was chargeable.
And the Count was general, although he took Letters of AdminiÅ¿tration afterwards. Quaere, & vid. antea.

Executor Å¿hall not be charged upon a Å¿urpluÅ¿age of an account made by the TeÅ¿tator, Coke 9. part. 87. A. Pinchons caÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e the TeÅ¿tator may wage his Law, 29 Edw. 3.26. 22 Hen. 6.41. 38 Hen. 6.6. 14 Hen. 6.24. that he owed nothing upon the Account, which would have been a good bar to the Action.
But if an Executor aÅ¿Å¿ign Auditors they Å¿hall be charged in debt for the Å¿urpluÅ¿age, 10 Hen. 6.24. pl. 84. becauÅ¿e there they Å¿ubmit to the Account, and Å¿tand upon their juÅ¿tification.
If an Executor account before Auditors, debt lies for the Arrearage, 2 Hen. 4.13. pl. 2. 19 Hen. 6.5. A. ForteÅ¿cue; for by his Accounting he Å¿ubmits to pay what Å¿hall be found arrear.

An Executor Å¿hall not be charged for Arrearages found due upon an account before the Å¿ame party to whom he is to account, Lib. Intra. 149. B. Å¿ect. 3. for this is as if no account had been, and is but a voluntary act, and not binding.
But for Arrearages before Auditors he Å¿hall, becauÅ¿e Auditors are Judges of Record, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. Lib. Intra. 149 B. Sect. 5. Å¿ee the Count there.

Debt againÅ¿t an Executor for Arrearages of an Annuity due in the uÅ¿e of the TeÅ¿tator after it is determined, Lib. Intra. 151. C. Å¿ect. 1. 45 Edw. 3. Execution 71. becauÅ¿e then he cannot diÅ¿train.

In Debt againÅ¿t an Executor the pleading of an Outlawry in the TeÅ¿tator no good bar, 14 Hen. 6.14. 21 Hen. 6.3. quaere, 3 Hen. 6.17. for to plead it generally is not good, for it might be reverÅ¿ed before his death.

But an Outlawry at the time of the death is a good bar, or where he was a Villain to the King, 8 Edw. 4.6. pl. 7. Doct. & Stud. 11, 12. 36 Hen. 6.27. pl. 38. for there he died in a diÅ¿ability to Å¿ â¢ e.

Debt lies not againÅ¿t an Executor upon an EÅ¿cape Å¿uffered by the TeÅ¿tator, unleÅ¿s Judgment be given againÅ¿t the TeÅ¿tator, 10 Eliz. Dyer 271. pl. 26.15 Eliz. Dyer 322. pl. 15.41 AÅ¿Å¿ize 15. Coke 9. part. 87. A. for that proves the eÅ¿cape, and makes a duty to the TeÅ¿tator.
It lies not againÅ¿t an Executor upon a Tailee enÅ¿ealed by the TeÅ¿tator, 12 Hen. 4.23. 25 Edw. 3.40. pl. 9. for this makes a duty acknowledged.

It lies not upon a Å¿imple contract of the TeÅ¿tator; but if he plead in barr, and it be found againÅ¿t him it Å¿hall, Com. 182. A. 10 Hen. 6.24. for there he wants his advantage which the Law gives, and Å¿tands upon his juÅ¿tification.
But in London by CuÅ¿tome 1 Edw. 4.6. it lies.
LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years grants his Term, his Executor Å¿hall not be charged for Rent due after his death, Coke 3. part. 24. A. Walkers cafe; for he died not poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of it. Quaere tamen.
Debt for one retained according to the Statute of Labourers lies againÅ¿t the Executor without Å¿pecialty, for the detainer makes the duty, 2 Hen. 4.14 4 Hen. 6.19.
Goaler reÅ¿uÅ¿ing to receive one committed by the Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians forfeits double the Fine,Goaler. per Marlebridge 1. cap. 9. Q. the Stat.

If a man levy Aid for the marrying of his daughter,Heir. and dies, if his Executors have not Å¿ufficient, Debt lies againÅ¿t the Heir, Nat. br. 83. A. per WeÅ¿tm. 1. cap. 35. Nat br. 122. G. for this is for the advancement of the Family.
Debt lies againÅ¿t an Heir upon the obligation of his Father, if he hath AÅ¿Å¿ets by deÅ¿cent, and be bound, Nat. br. 120. C, & I. otherwiÅ¿e not; for generally Executors are to pay debts.

But if he alien the AÅ¿Å¿ets before the Action brought, he Å¿hall not be charged, Coke 5. part. 60. A. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. A. 27 Edw. 3.7. B. 10 Hen. 4. pl. 14 19 Hen. 6.46. pl. 95. 42 Edw. 3.10. pl. 1 â¢ . 48 Edw. 3.32. pl. 22. for it was the Latches of the party that brought his Action no Å¿ooner.
UnleÅ¿s it be fraudulent to deceive Creditors, Coke 5. part. 60. Geoches caÅ¿e; for the Law will not countenance fraud.
And if they be heirs in Gavel-kind, they Å¿hall all be charged as one heir, 7 Eliz. 239. pl. 39. Dyer vid. the Count, Lib. Intra. 208. D. 11 Edw. 3. Debt 7.
But if all alien but the eldeÅ¿t, he Å¿hall be charged Å¿ole; for he is chargeable in reÅ¿pect of his AÅ¿Å¿ets.
The Count againÅ¿t an heir, Lib. Intra. 172. B. Å¿ect. 1. No. Lib. 126. B.

The Count needs not Å¿hew that he hath aÅ¿Å¿ets, for it Å¿hall be intended, unleÅ¿s the contrary be Å¿hewed, 18 Eliz. Dyer 344. pl. 2. 11 Hen. 6.2. pl. 6. and if he have not, he may plead riens per deÅ¿cent.
For nothing by deÅ¿cent in Fee-Å¿imple is a good bar by him, Lib. Intra. 172. B. Sect. 1. the day of the purchaÅ¿e of the Writ.
But debt lies not againÅ¿t an heir upon a Statute-Merchant, Staple, or Recognizance, becauÅ¿e he is not bound, Coke 3. part. 15. A. Harberts caÅ¿e; but the Lands are bound, and may be extended.
Goaler Å¿uffers an eÅ¿cape, his heir Å¿hall not be charged, 15 Eliz. Dyer 322. pl. 25. for this is a perÅ¿onal wrong, and only dammages recoverable.

Grandfather, Father, and Son, or Father and his two Sons, or Grandfathers two Sons, who have two Sons, the heir mediate Å¿hall be Å¿ued in debt as well as if they were immediate heirs, 22 Dyer 368. pl. 14.7. Eliz. Dyer 239. pl. 39. that is, in caÅ¿e the heir immediate die, for the heir mediate is bound by the word Heir.
A Right Å¿hall not be AÅ¿Å¿ets, for it is a diÅ¿putable thing, and no certainty of it to be reduced into poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

What Å¿hall be AÅ¿Å¿ets to the Heir.DiÅ¿Å¿elÅ¿ee obliges him and his heirs, and dies; this is not AÅ¿Å¿ets, for it is but a Right deÅ¿cended, PaÅ¿ch. 6. Jac. Com. Ban. Molineux verÅ¿us Molineux, for his AnceÅ¿tor died out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

Right without an eÅ¿tate in PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, ReverÅ¿ion, or Remainder, is not AÅ¿Å¿ets, until it be reduced into poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Coke 6. part. 58. Bredimans caÅ¿es, and then it Å¿hall releaÅ¿e to the time of the death of the AnceÅ¿tor.
Land in ancient demeÅ¿n Å¿hall be AÅ¿Å¿ets, 7 Hen. 4.14. pl. 11. Q. to whom, and where pleadable.

Copyhold Land is not AÅ¿Å¿ets to the heir,
Coke 4. part. 22. A. for it doth not deÅ¿cend, but depends upon the Lords admittance.

If an heir alien bona fide before the Action brought, it Å¿hall not be AÅ¿Å¿ets, Coke 5. part. 60. A. Gooches caÅ¿e, 27 Edw. 3.78. pl. 16.10 Hen. 7.8. pl. 17. 19 Hen. 6.46. pl. 95. 42 Edw. 3.10. pl. 12. 48 Edw. 32. pl. 22. Vid. antea. for he is not tied from Å¿ â¢ lling the Land.
If Land deÅ¿cend to the heir, although he enter not, yet it is AÅ¿Å¿ets, 42 Edw. 3.10. pl. 12. for he might have entered, and may do when he will.

the Grandfather makes a F â¢ offment in Fee to the uÅ¿e of the heir of his body and dies, per 26 Hen. 8. the Father enters, and obliges him and his heirs, and dies, quaere, 182 Mariae Dyer 111. pl. 46. whether the Grandchild be bound.

A ReverÅ¿ion expectant upon an eÅ¿tate Tail is not AÅ¿Å¿ets, becauÅ¿e it lies in the will of Tenant in tail to dock and barr it at his pleaÅ¿ure, Coke 6. part. 58. B. Bredimans caÅ¿e, & 42. A. Mildmays caÅ¿e. Q. if it be AÅ¿Å¿ets when it happens.
Franktenement deÅ¿cendible expreÅ¿s is not AÅ¿Å¿ets, Coke 10. part. 98. A. Seymors caÅ¿e; for it is an incertain eÅ¿tate.
Rent-Å¿eck deÅ¿cendible is not AÅ¿Å¿ets until Å¿eiÅ¿in of it, Coke 6. part. B. Bredimans caÅ¿e; for before Å¿eiÅ¿in he hath no eÅ¿tate in it.

If the heir had AÅ¿Å¿ets in debt brought againÅ¿t him, and afterwards AÅ¿Å¿ets come to his hands, the firÅ¿t judgment is no barr of the Action, 19 Hen. 6.37. A. Markham; becauÅ¿e there was no Å¿atisfaction made, which may now be by matter ex poÅ¿t facto.

The profits taken by the heir at the time of the deÅ¿cent are Å¿ufficient, and if this be Å¿hewed to the Court, and the heir cannot deny it, there Å¿hall be a general judgment againÅ¿t him, per Dyer 18 Eliz. Dyer. 344. pl. 1. to pay the debt and dammages quod querens recuperet.

The heir confeÅ¿Å¿es the action, and Å¿ays, that he had nothing but a ReverÅ¿ion deÅ¿cended to him, there the Plaintiff Å¿hall have judgment to recover upon the Å¿aid ReverÅ¿ion, and the Debt to be levied when it comes in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Å¿pecial Writ of extent, 23 Eliz. Dyer 373. pl. 14. mentioning the Å¿pecial matter.
If the Father recover, and Error be brought againÅ¿t the Son, and a recovery againÅ¿t him, he Å¿hall not render dammages, unleÅ¿s he hath AÅ¿Å¿ets of Land in Fee-Å¿imple from his Father.
If one be robbed,Hundred. he Å¿hall have debt againÅ¿t the Hundred, per 27 Eliz. cap. 13. antea.
Debt lies againÅ¿t a LeÅ¿Å¿ee at will for rent during the Term,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. Coke 5. part. 10. antea. Quaere, if he hold over.
So againÅ¿t a LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years, Nat. br. 120. H.
And this during the term, Coke 4. part.
Or after the term ended by effluction of time, Coke 3. part. 23. B. for rent due during the term.
By limitation ended,

By condition in Law, or in deed,
Common Law, Nat. br. 120. H.
Statute Law, 19 Hen. 6.42. A. waÅ¿te, Nat. br. 120. H. re-entry Coke 3. part. 23. B. Walkers caÅ¿e, 30 Edw. 3.7.17 Edw. 3.48. & fol. 73. pl. 107.
It lies not againÅ¿t Tenant for life Å¿o long as his eÅ¿tate continues,Life. Coke. 4. part. 49. A. 11 Hen. 6.14. pl. 4. viz. for rent, for the Land is charged.
But yet by the Statute, 32 Hen. 8. cap. 37. the Executors of a LeÅ¿Å¿or for life Å¿hall have debt during the eÅ¿tate for life, Coke 4. part. which Å¿eems but reaÅ¿onable.

Debt lies not againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter upon the buying of the Servant,MaÅ¿ter. unleÅ¿s it comes to his uÅ¿e or by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 137. A. for otherwiÅ¿e it might be miÅ¿chievous to the MaÅ¿ter.

Debt lies againÅ¿t an Ordinary,Ordinary. when a man dies inteÅ¿tate, Nat. br. 120. D. Coke 5. part. 83. A. Snellings caÅ¿e, & 9. part. 39. B. 11 Hen. 7.12. 9 Edw. 4.33. Danby. 18 Hen. 6.23. com. 277.8 Eliz. Dyer 247. if the goods come into the hands of the Ordinary.

The Ordinary adminiÅ¿ters, and then grants AdminiÅ¿tration, yet debt lies againÅ¿t the Ordinary; but it was Å¿aid, that Å¿uch AdminiÅ¿tration ought to be alledged in the DioceÅ¿s of the Ordinary, 12 Rich. 2. AdminiÅ¿trator 21. elÅ¿e it might be prejudicial to the Creditors.
But note, no Debt lies againÅ¿t the Ordinary after that he hath committed AdminiÅ¿tration to another, 8 Eliz. Dyer 247. pl. 73. viz. where he never adminiÅ¿ters.

Debt was brought againÅ¿t the Father for the Sons Commons in a Colledge in Oxon, although the Father had delivered it to the Tutor of the Son, PaÅ¿ch. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, St. Johns in Oxford againÅ¿t Brick â¢ nden; for the Father, and not the Tutor, is hable; yet quaere, for this is not uÅ¿ually practiÅ¿ed.
Debt lies againÅ¿t him that becomes pledge without deed,Pledge. Nat. br. 122. K. 18 Edw. 3.13. pl. 7. Finchden, if the principle pay it not.

A borrowed of B 20 l. to pay it at Michaelmas, at which day D prays B to take him for his Debtor, and he gives him day over, and D obliges him to pay it by one Tally enÅ¿ealed; Debt lies not againÅ¿t D, becauÅ¿e A was not by this diÅ¿charged, 44 Edw. 3.21. pl. 23. and Å¿o he may recover one Debt twice, if D Å¿hould be chargeable.

A Purveyor contracts for fat wares for the King,Purveyor. and makes a Bill of receipt to the uÅ¿e of the King, and for this obliges himÅ¿elf to pay it, but Å¿eals it not; he Å¿hall be charged by AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it, and the King by Debt, and by no other way, 8 Eliz. Dyer 230. pl. 56. in an Action upon the CaÅ¿e upon his promiÅ¿e only; for it is the Kings Debt, and not the Purveyors.

Debt lies againÅ¿t a Receiver,Receiver. which takes more than he ought, per 7 Edw. 6. cap. 6. Lib. Intr. 191. B. Å¿ect. 1. com. 201. Stradlings caÅ¿e; for that Å¿hall be accounted money borrowed only.
An Abbot Å¿hall be charged with the borrowing of his predeceÅ¿Å¿or,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. if it come to the uÅ¿e of his houÅ¿e, Nat. br. 121. K. Lib. Intr. 152. A. Å¿ect. 1. but not otherways.
The Count Å¿hall be general. Coke 7. part. 10. B. Æ²ghtreds caÅ¿e, and he needs not Å¿hew it, for it Å¿hall be Å¿o intended.
Praecipe Å¿ocietati Lombardiorum London mercatorum de Florentia, Society. and this was good, 19 Hen. 6.80. pl. 11. for they are in nature of body Politick.
Sheriff Under-Sheriff.Debt upon an eÅ¿cape of one in execution upon an account, it lies per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. and as of the Debtor, per 1 Rich. 2. cap. 12.
For not returning a Knight of the Parliament, per 23 Hen. 6. cap. 15. the Count com. 118. Buckleys caÅ¿e, Lib. Intra. 186. A. Å¿ect. 1. antea. for the penalty given by the Statute.

A Sheriff takes an obligation for Appearance of the Defendant, which doth not appear; yet debt lies not againÅ¿t the Sheriff by the Plaintiff, Trin. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. if he return a Cepi; but an Action on the CaÅ¿e lies, and the Sheriff may bring his Action upon the Bond.
Outlawed perÅ¿on. It lies againÅ¿t a perÅ¿on Outlawed, Mich 38 & 39 of Eliz. Com. Ban. BaniÅ¿ter verÅ¿us TruÅ¿Å¿el, No. Lib. Intr. 248. A. 7 Hen. 6.10. for another debt, or in another Action. Q.

div.head: For what things Debt lies.
div.p: It lies for money lent to another,Lent. Nat. br. 119. G. this moÅ¿t properly.

For a HorÅ¿e lent till Å¿uch a day, and then to give 10 l. for him, or the HorÅ¿e: after the day debt lies for the one or the other, Nat. br. 121. B. at the election of the Plaintiff; but before the day, or at it, it was in the Defendants election.
A borrowed money for the Servant, Debt lies not againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter, unleÅ¿s it came to his uÅ¿e, or was borrowed by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 137. A. antea.
Upon a delivery to redeliver debt lies,Bailment. if it be not redelivered, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 135. 11 Hen. 6.39. pl. 31. 4 Edw. 3.9. pl. 7. although the Receipt be not by deed.

Upon a delivery to redeliver over to another, if it be not performed, debt lies, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 22. pl. 135. 11 Hen. 6.39. pl. 31. 42 Edw. 3.9. pl. 7. Mich. 40. 41 Eliz. com. Ban. Britons caÅ¿e: for no property was altered.
But 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 33. if A. ought to pay an Annuity in Å¿ee to B. and deliver money to C. to pay it to B. yet B. Å¿hall not have debt againÅ¿t C. for there is no truÅ¿t or privity between them.
LeaÅ¿e for life of another debt lies not for the Rent during the term.Contract. Coke 4. part 49. A. Ognels caÅ¿e. vid antea. it lies by ceÅ¿tuy que vie.
But by the 32 Hen. 8. cap. 37. the executors or adminiÅ¿trators Å¿hall have debt during the eÅ¿tate for life, Coke 4. part 49. A. antea.
But after the eÅ¿tate ended, debt lies, Coke 4. part 49. A. for then there is no other remedy.
So it is by the death of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, Coke 4. part 49. A. antea.
Or by Limitation of the term.

Or by condition.Antea.
in deed, 39 Edw. 3.22. pl. 11. Nat. br. 120. H. Coke. 23. B. 6 Hen. 7.3.30. Edw. 3.7.
in Law,
Statute Law.
19 Hen. 42. A. waÅ¿te.
Common Law.

LeaÅ¿e for years by a Bayliff the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have debt for the Rent, Lib. intra. 174. D. Å¿ect. 3. for it is accounted the LeaÅ¿e of the MaÅ¿ter; for no intereÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿eth from the Bayliff being but an inÅ¿trument only.

A Corporation made a LeaÅ¿e for years rendring to P. 10 l. at Mich. or 20 days after, after verdict, it was moved in arreÅ¿t of judgment that they
Å¿hewed not the deed, Å¿ed non allocatur, becauÅ¿e it was after verdict, and Å¿o the LeaÅ¿e was Å¿ound, 2 good, although they had brought debt for the rent due for 6 years ended at Mich. to P. and not 20 days after, for the rent was due at Mich. Mich, 9 Jac. Ban. Regis. Baldry. defendant in debt by the Corporation of Brewers.

Bargainec of a reverÅ¿ion, in debt for rent, ought to Å¿hew in what court the Deed was enrolled, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Welby & Putley. by which the reverÅ¿ion was granted; for the enrolment is traverÅ¿able, and muÅ¿t be punctually Å¿et forth, and the enrolment may be in divers places, for that the debt cannot take notice where.

Debt lies for the agiÅ¿tments for Cattel for Å¿o long time as they went in Å¿uch Lands,AgiÅ¿tment Lib. intra. 150. A. Å¿ect. 1. count Lib. intra. 151. A. Å¿ect. 1. but then he muÅ¿t Å¿hew the certainty of the time and Å¿um.

A. promiÅ¿es 20 l. to B. to marry his Daughter;Marriage-money. B. Å¿hall have debt, Nat. 120. K. count Lib. intra. 178. A. Å¿ect. 1.37. Hen. 6.8. pl. 18.16 Hen. 3. prohibition 22. for the conÅ¿ideration creates a duty if performed.

But if he promiÅ¿e 20 l. in marriage with his Daughter, he Å¿hall not have debt, but Å¿hall Å¿ue in court chriÅ¿tian, Nat. br. 50. S. 16. Hen. 3. pro 22. vide RegiÅ¿t. 46. B. Q. differentiam. It Å¿eems becauÅ¿e no Money is promiÅ¿ed him.
But if it be by deed, then it is otherwiÅ¿e; Å¿ee 45 Edw. 3.24. for the Deed is triable at the Law, though the Marriage be not, but in the Spiritual Court.

Bracton. Lib. 5. cap. 16. Sic de rebus datis ul promiÅ¿Å¿is ob cauÅ¿am matrimonii principaliter, Regula. & Å¿e de rebus quae accidunt matrimonio; ut Å¿i pecunia promiÅ¿Å¿a fuerit, ob cauÅ¿am matrimonii, quia ejuÅ¿dem juris id eÅ¿t, & juriÅ¿dictionis eÅ¿Å¿e debet acceÅ¿sorum cujus eÅ¿t principale. The Marriage is the principal, and the Portion the acceÅ¿Å¿ory.

Upon Partition betwixt two,Partition. one promiÅ¿eth the other 20 l. for equality of partition, debt lies for it, Nat. br. 122. H. 14 Edw. 3. Debt. 137. if it be not paid, for the promiÅ¿e upon the partition made it a Duty.

Rent upon a perÅ¿onal thing.If a perÅ¿onal thing be leaÅ¿ed, rendring rent, debt lies for it, Coke 3. part 22. A. Walkers caÅ¿e. as a HorÅ¿e, Sheep, or the like, the loan implies a duty upon the contract.
An Attorney Å¿hall have debt for his fees,Salary. and for fees of counÅ¿el, and coÅ¿ts of Å¿uit, Nat. br. 121. L. Count Lib. intra. 202. B. Å¿ect. 6. vid. antea.

A CounÅ¿ellor Å¿hall have debt for his fees, 3 Hen. 6.33. pl. 26. 21 Hen. 6.4. pl. 6. but then he ought to count that he was of his counÅ¿el, or was ready, 37 Hen. 8. B.. Q. for a CounÅ¿ellors Å¿ee is not certain; and is rather honorarium than mercenarium.
But 31 of Hen. 6.9. B. ForteÅ¿cue. Serjeant at Law Å¿hall not have debt for his fees, and is not bound to be retained without. Q. for he is bound to be of counÅ¿el till he receive his fee.

A Servant Å¿hall have debt for his Å¿alary,Servant. Coke 9. part. 87. 3 Hen. 6.42. 11 Hen. 6.48. although it be to do his Å¿ervice beyond the Å¿ea, Nat. br. 120. E. for the labourer is worthy of his hire whereever the work be done. And beyond Å¿ea it
is done with more hazard to the Å¿ervant.
The Count, Lib. intra. 201. D. Å¿ect. 1.
Steward of a Court retained by word Å¿hall have debt,Steward. 8 Eliz. Dyer. 248. pl. 79. Coke 4. part. 30. A. for his Å¿alary.
Count for a Chaplain for his Å¿ee promiÅ¿ed, Lib. intra. 153. B. Å¿ect. 11.
Count for a PrieÅ¿t, Lib. retained circa Å¿acra, intra. 202. B. Å¿ect. 5.
Count for one retained, &c. Lib. intra. 203. B. Å¿ect. 12. viz. a Å¿ervant according to the Stat.
If I. promiÅ¿e to a Chirurgeon 40 s. to cure R, he Å¿hall have debt,Surgery. becauÅ¿e it is a good contract, 37 Hen. 6.9. A. Moyle. for it ariÅ¿eth from charity, and is for the preÅ¿ervation of man.

Debt lies againÅ¿t him that tables with me,Tabling. 37 Edw. 3.87. pl. 37.9. Edw. 4.1. The count lib. intra. 153. B. Å¿ect. 10. & 177. D. Å¿ect. 1. viz. upon a contract as a Å¿ojourner, but not as a gueÅ¿t as it Å¿eems. Q. tamen if not upon a quantum meruit.
Goaler Å¿hall have debt for tabling of a priÅ¿oner, Coke againÅ¿t the priÅ¿oner. 9. part. 87. B. 28 Hen. 6.4. pl. 21.
Inn-keeper Å¿hall have debt for Lodging or Victual, 39 Hen. 6.18. pl. 24. provided for his GueÅ¿ts; for here the Law makes the contract.
Tabling & PhyÅ¿ick.A PhyÅ¿ician Å¿hall have debt for tabling and phyÅ¿ick, Lib. intra. 187. B. Å¿ect. 1. vide the count there, upon a quantum meruit, if there be no Å¿pecial contract.

If I. put my Cloth to a Taylor to make a garment,Taylor. he, viz. the Taylor, Å¿hall have a Å¿pecial action for making the garment, for the putting of
the cloth is a Å¿ufficient contract in Law, Coke 8. part. 147. Carpenters caÅ¿e, to bring the action upon
But not a general action of debt without declaring upon a contract in deed, ibid.
If I Å¿ells a Mannor,Vendition Debt lies for the money, yet I. Å¿hall not have it before Livery, 37 Hen. 6.8. pl. 18. PriÅ¿ot. Q. for before the Livery the contract is not perfect.

I bargain for a HorÅ¿e, Debt lies for the money, 14 Hen. 8.19. br. contract, 15. Coke 4. part.

B. Slades caÅ¿e. upon the contract in Law.
If a man makes an obligation for a Debt due by contract, debt lies not upon the contract, Nat. br. in. M. Coke 6. part. but upon the Obligation; for by the taking of it the contract is gone.
BecauÅ¿e the obligation drowns the contract, for the obligation is of a higher nature.
Upon an emiÅ¿Å¿et Å¿everal ways, the count, No. Lib. intra. 125. B.

If I. give authority to my Bayliff or Servant to buy for me, debt lies againÅ¿t me,Servant. Nat. br. 120. G. Doct. & Stud. 137. A. 6. Eliz. Dyer. 130. pl. 56. 2 Rich. 2. Debt 13. otherwiÅ¿e not; but with my authority the act of the Bayliff or Servant is accounted the MaÅ¿ters act.
And Å¿o if he bought it without command, if it come to the uÅ¿e of the MaÅ¿ter by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 137. A. for the aÅ¿Å¿ent afterwards doth make it his own act ab initio.

And likewiÅ¿e if he bought it in his own Name, and it comes to the uÅ¿e of his MaÅ¿ter, it lies againÅ¿t his MaÅ¿ter, ibidem. for the MaÅ¿ters making uÅ¿e of it Å¿hews his aÅ¿Å¿ent, and that it was for his benefit.

So if the Bayliff which uÅ¿ed to Å¿ell, fold ãâã HorÅ¿e for twelve buÅ¿hels of wheat, this is goodâª and the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have debt, 27 AÅ¿Å¿iz. pl. 5. for it is accounted the maÅ¿ters Å¿ale.

The Servant Å¿ells, the MaÅ¿ter agrees, this i â¢ the Å¿ale of the MaÅ¿ter, and debt lies. 27 Hen. 8.25. B. Fithams. otherwiÅ¿e not, except he uÅ¿ed ãâã Å¿ell; for it is not incident to a Å¿ervant, as a Å¿ervant only, to buy or Å¿ell for his MaÅ¿ter.

A Factor receives money, and gives a bill of exchange, if the MaÅ¿ter accept the Bill, by it â¢ e becomes debtor by the cuÅ¿tom of Merchants. Tr â¢â¢
43 Eliz. com. ban. per legem mercatoriam,
ãâã for the advancement of Trade.

The wife buyes a thing,Wife. the husband agrees, this is the emption of the husband. 27 Hen. 8.25. B. Fittiams. but if he aÅ¿Å¿ent not, he is not bound, for Å¿he is no more than a Å¿ervant in this reÅ¿pect.

One condemned taken in WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-Hall,Voluntary per Crier. kep â¢ by a Crier aÅ¿Å¿igned, which Å¿uffers him to eÅ¿cape, debt lies not, 1. becauÅ¿e it was no priÅ¿onerâª 1. becauÅ¿e he had no command by Writ, 33 Hen. 6.55. pl. 50. and Å¿o not chargeable by Law; for he is not an Officer to Å¿uch intent.

If a PriÅ¿oner eÅ¿cape by aÅ¿Å¿ent,Sheriff. although the Sheriff take him again, yet debt lies. Coke 3. p â¢â¢
44. Boytons caÅ¿e. 19 Hen. 4.10. viz. aÅ¿Å¿ent of the Sheriff or Gaoler; for thereby the debt is diÅ¿charged as to the priÅ¿oner.

UnleÅ¿s the Sheriff brought one per habeas C â¢â¢
pus, then if he had him at the day, it Å¿ufficeth Coke 3. part 44. Boytons caÅ¿e. yet he ought not ãâã Å¿et him at large in the mean time.

UnleÅ¿s the party be in execution, Coke 5. part.
â¢ 9. FroÅ¿ts caÅ¿e. 7. Hen. 4.30. for then debt lies againÅ¿t him; but if it be but upon mean proceÅ¿s, â¢ n action of the caÅ¿e only lies to recover what the party is damnified.
Or upon a capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum, although the Writ be not returned. Coke 3. part. 52. Rigw â¢ yes caÅ¿e. If the party be taken upon it; for then he is in cuÅ¿tody.
And if it be returned, and he had not the body, debt lies, 7 Hen. 4.11. br. retorn 107. for it fall be intended that he let him eÅ¿cape.
A writ of priviledge for a BurgeÅ¿s of Parliament, the Sheriff Å¿uffers him at large, debt lies not, 36 Hen. 8. Dyer 6. pl. 17. 1 Jac. for this is but a mean proceÅ¿s.

Negligent eÅ¿cape per Sheriff.If one be taken by a capias utlagat. after the year and eÅ¿cape, debt lies. Coke 5. part. 89. FroÅ¿ts â¢â¢ Å¿e. 88 B. Garnons caÅ¿e. vide 7 Hen. 6.5. in forgery; for the proceÅ¿s is well executed as to the Sheriff, and he ought not to Å¿uffer the eÅ¿cape.

The ancient Sheriff makes no mention of one in execution in his indenture delivered to the new Sheriff, of priÅ¿oners in his cuÅ¿tody; this is an eÅ¿cape in the old Sheriff, but not in the new; for the new is not charged with him: but if the old Sheriff die, the other ought to take notice of the priÅ¿oners; but if the eÅ¿cape be in the vacancy, viz. before the new Sheriff is elected and Å¿worn, debt lies not. Coke 3. part. 71 & 72. WeÅ¿tbyes caÅ¿e. 10 Edw. 3.375. pl. 28. for before he was not chargeable, for he was no offender in Law.
If one be in execution, yet debt lies againÅ¿t the Sheriff, 7 Eliz. Dyer. 241. pl. 47. 16 Edw. 4.3. pl. 7. Q. de hoc.

The Plaintiff and chief JuÅ¿tice aÅ¿Å¿ent for â¢ oe time that the priÅ¿oner Å¿hall go at large, and after he Å¿uffers an eÅ¿cape, debt lies. 10 Eliz. Dye â¢ . 275. pl. 46. for this was not a finall diÅ¿charge d â¢ the priÅ¿oner. Q.
A capias upon a recognizance in Chancery, the party taken eÅ¿capes, debt lies, Coke 8. part. 142. Druries caÅ¿e; for this is in nature of an execution.
The Writ was that 6 were in execution and eÅ¿caped, and the doubt was whether they might count for one only, and by the better opinion ãâã was good, Crooke. 26 Hen. 7.67. pl. 11. Q.
If one be MarÅ¿hal of the priÅ¿on, whether it be by right or wrong,MarÅ¿hal. debt lies againÅ¿t him, 39 He â¢ . 6.33. A. for the Plaintiff is not to examine his Title.

Count that he was in execution in C, and removed to the upper Bench priÅ¿on, and committed to the MarÅ¿hal, which Å¿uffers him to eÅ¿cape, debt lies, 38 Hen. 6.28. pl. 10. for it is all one as I he had been originally committed thither.

Deputy of a MarÅ¿hal Å¿uffers an ceÅ¿cape,
â¢ eputy. debt lies againÅ¿t him, 11 Eliz. Dyer. 278. pl. 5. viZ. the MarÅ¿hal himÅ¿elf. Q. if not againÅ¿t the Deputy.

Debt lies againÅ¿t a Mayor of the Staple uponâª recognizance taken before him.Mayor de Staple. 5 Hen. 6.11. He â¢
6.49. B. 12 Hen. 6.2. pl. 9. if he Å¿uffer ãâã PriÅ¿oner to eÅ¿cape.
The count, Lib. intra. 171. D. Å¿ect. 6.

Dean and Chapter of Pauls having return ãâã Writs,Lord de Franchize and making a Bayliff that Å¿uffers an eÅ¿cape Action lies not againÅ¿t the Dean and Chapter, becauÅ¿e
cauÅ¿e they are not Bayliffs, PaÅ¿ch. 14 Eliz. Com. Ban. but againÅ¿t the Bayliff, for he is the Officer the Law takes notice of. Qâª tamen.
For a Nomine poenae granted, this is caÅ¿ual; yet debt lies for it, Nat. br. 120. M. 2 Hen. 8.8. Dyer, Grant penalty. 24. pl. 149; for it is a duty ab origine, if forfeited.
And this is but hac vice, if there be no other words to Å¿hew the continuance of it, 32 Hen. 6.10. A. Billinge.
And Å¿o upon any grant hac vice certain or uncertain. Q.

2. Annuity or Rent-charge granted for years,Annuity. debt lies not during the term. But the 5 Edw. 4. 42 B. debt lies; and it Å¿eems this is Law; if it lie not, it Å¿eems it is becauÅ¿e the Grantee may diÅ¿train and charge the Land.
But againÅ¿t a cuÅ¿tomer it lies, if it be to be paid out of the cuÅ¿toms of London after delivery of a Liberate, Nat. br. 121. F. for then it is a duty veÅ¿ted.
It lies for Executors or adminiÅ¿trators of the Grantee per Stat. 32 Hen. 8. cap. 37. viz. of an Annuity or Rent-charge.
And after the term ended, it lies for the Grantee, Lib. Intra. 151. C. Å¿ect. 1. for then there is no other remedy for it.
3. Annuity for life,For Life. debt lies not for this during life, 19 Hen. 6. 42 A. 37 Hen. 6.35. A. But a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s or a Writ of Annuity, and the Land is chargeable.
But againÅ¿t a cuÅ¿tomer it lies, Nat. br. 121. F. â¢ nteaâª for his perÅ¿on is chargeable ratione officii.

AlÅ¿o if a ParÅ¿on or Prebend, &c. hath Å¿uch annuity
and reÅ¿igne or be diÅ¿poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed, it lies for the arrerages, Coke 4. part. 48. B. Ognels caÅ¿e. For by his reÅ¿ignation it is meerly a perÅ¿onal thing, and the Land is not chargeable.
So his Executors Å¿hall have debt by the common Law, Coke 4. part. 49. A 22 Eliz. Dyer. 37. pl. 62. Coke 10. part. 61. B. For it is accounted part of the TeÅ¿tators perÅ¿onal eÅ¿tate.
But if it be a Rent-charge Å¿eck or Å¿ervice, debt lies not for any Å¿o long as the EÅ¿tate continues, Coke 4. part. 49. A. Ognels caÅ¿e. For there the perÅ¿on is not chargeable.
Although it have continuance but to a Å¿pecial intent, Coke 7. part. 39. B. For the Law takes not notice of Å¿uch intents, but looks on it as upon a continuing EÅ¿tate.

But after it be determined, debt lies for the party or his Executor, Coke 4. part. 49. Ognels caÅ¿e. Nat. br. 121. E. Coke 4. part. 49. Ognels caÅ¿e. 27 Hen. 6.1. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e the realty is reÅ¿olved into the perÅ¿onality, and Å¿o the perÅ¿on chargeable.
4. Annuity in Tayl general or Å¿pecial, debt lies not during the annuity, Coke 4. part. 48. B. for the former reaÅ¿on.
So of a Rent-Å¿eck, Å¿ervice or charge, vid. antea.
But if the eÅ¿tate be determined, quaere at the common Law.
But by the 32 Hen. 8. cap. 37. the Executor or AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have debt for the Arrerages.
Annuity in fee during the annuity, debt lies not,Annuity or Rent in Fee. Coke 4. part. 48. B. 6 Hen. 4.7. pl. 33.

UnleÅ¿s it be in a Å¿pecial caÅ¿e, as when a ParÅ¿on or Prebend reÅ¿ignes, Coke 4. part. 49. A. Nat. br. 121. D. 19 Hen. 6.41 & 42. Nat. br. 121. H
â¢ ntea. For there the eÅ¿tate is determined as to him that reÅ¿ignes.
So if a ParÅ¿on dies, his Executors Å¿hall have debt, Nat. br. 120. L. Coke 4. part. 49. A. 37 Hen. 6.8. pl. 18. For there is no other remedy for to recover it.
And by the 32 Hen 8. cap. 37. the Executors or AdminiÅ¿trators of every one Å¿hall have debt.
But after the Annuity determined every one Å¿hall have debt by the common Law. Coke 4. part 49. A. 45 Edw. 3.45. execution 71.

list.item: Ancient DemeÅ¿n. in any Mannor. For Fine or Amerciament.

div.p: Judgment given in debt for the principal.If a man brings debt upon a recovery in com. Ban. he ought to bring it in MiddleÅ¿ex, where the Record is, becauÅ¿e it is the Original, upon the which the Action is brought; but a Å¿cire facias to execute a Judgment Å¿hall be where the original Action was brought, becauÅ¿e it ought to follow it. Hil. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, MuÅ¿grave verÅ¿us Wharton; for the Å¿cire facias is in purÅ¿uance of it, and to have execution upon it.

Upon Arrerages recovered in a Å¿cire facias upon a Judgment in Annuity brought againÅ¿t the predeceÅ¿Å¿ors, debt lies upon it, Nat. br. 122. E. 22 Edw. 4.1. pl. 6. for by the recovery it is become a Duty.
A Debt was recovered in a Court of Pypowders, and debt brought upon it in com. Ban. Å¿uper tenorem recordi, and good, 7 Hen. 6.19. The record muÅ¿t be mentioned in the Count.

For damages and coÅ¿ts.If a man recover dammages in waÅ¿te, he Å¿hall have an action of debt for the dammages, Nat. br. 122. C. 43 Edw. 3.2 pl. 5. the count Lib. Intra. 197. C. Å¿ect. 15. for the recovery of them hath made them duty.
Debt lies for dammages recovered in AÅ¿Å¿ize, 32 Hen. 6.29. pl. 23. but then this debt Å¿ued for ought to agree with the Record. See the count Lib. Intr. 194. D. Å¿ect. 7.
So for dammages in a Mort-daunceÅ¿ler, 46 Edw. 3.25. pl. 10.

If the Plaintiff in com. ban. is non-Å¿uited, and
the Record removed by Writ of Error before the CoÅ¿ts paid upon the NonÅ¿uit, the Defendant in the Writ of Error Å¿hall have debt for his coÅ¿ts, 29 Hen. 8. Dyer 32. pl. 5. for the Law makes them a duty.

Dammages recovered in ancient d meÅ¿ne, and the tenour of the Record was removed by Certiorari, debt lies upon it for the dammage, 39 Hen. 6.3. pl. 5. count Lib. intra. 195. C. Å¿ect. 11. for they are become a duty.
Dammages recovered before the Mayor of Hull, debt lies there, 11 Hen. 4.12. but not in another Court.
Debt lies for a Fine,Fine. Coke 8. part. 41. B. GreiÅ¿leys caÅ¿e. 7. Hen. 6.2. B. Q What fine and where.
Debt lies for an amerciament in a Leet,Amerciament. Lib. Intra 151. B. Å¿ect. 1. 23. Hen. 8. br. Leet. 37. The count Lib. intra. 151. B. for it is a duty.
Debt lies in a Court Baron, No. Lib. intra. 118. B. Å¿ect. 1. for a debt grown due within the juriÅ¿diction thereof.
Judgment out of Court as Statute.Debt lies upon a Statute Merchant, or Staple, according to the Stat. 23 Hen. 8. Nat. br. 122. C. 11 Hen. 6.49. pl. 7. for the Statute makes it a duty.
Debt lies upon a Recognizance it Å¿elf,Recognizance. Nat. br. 122 C. 11 Hen. 6.49. pl. 7. Eliz. Dyer 306. pl. 63. The count Lib. intra. 192. B. Å¿ect. 1. for it is in the nature of a Judgment.
Or upon the tenour of the Recognizance, 39 Hen. 6.3. pl. 5. 22 Eliz. Dyer. 369. pl. 52.

So upon a Recognizance taken before the Mayor
of Hull, 36 Hen. 6.2. pl. 2. In Hull. Q. if elÅ¿ewhere.
Debt brought upon a Recognizance after the Recognizance taken, and afore the enrolment of it, and good, PaÅ¿ch 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. For the Enrolment makes not the duty.
Account at the common Law.Debt lies upon Arrerages of Account at the Common Law, the count Lib. intra. 149. A. Å¿ect. 1.
AlÅ¿o a Bayliff Å¿hall have debt upon the Å¿urpluÅ¿age of account, Nat. br. 121. I. 38. Hen. 6.5. 19 Edw. 2. Debt 176. againÅ¿t his MaÅ¿ter, for the Law makes it a duty in the MaÅ¿ter.
He ought to count the place and day where the Auditors were aÅ¿Å¿igned, Hil. 32. Eliz. Com. Ban. Lord Dacres caÅ¿e. before whom accompted, and the Accompt Å¿tated; for they are traverÅ¿able.
But if the Lord will not hear his Accompt, he hath no remedy for the Å¿urpluÅ¿age, 7 Edw. 3.12. per Herle. For then it appears not whether any thing be due to him or not.
But it lies not by a Receiver, 38 Hen. 6.5. pl. 14. Mich. 12. Jac. Ban. Regis. CounteÅ¿s de Suffolk verÅ¿us Floyde. For a receiver is not to lay out for his MaÅ¿ter.
But a receiver for Merchandize Å¿hall have it, 38 Hen. 6.5. PriÅ¿ott & Moyle; becauÅ¿e he receives it for to be employed, and the MaÅ¿ter is to Å¿tand to the gain and loÅ¿s if there be any.

Debt lies upon an Arbitrement,Arbitrement. Nat. br. 121. G. Coke 9. part. 92. B. the count Lib. intra. 153. C. Å¿ect. 1. For an Arbitrement is a judgment by conÅ¿ent of both parties, and by it a duty is created.
By-laws or Ordinances.Debt lies upon an Ordinance, or by-Law, Coke 5. part. 64. A. Q. What Ordinance.

A Pain is laid upon one in a Leet to reform a NuÅ¿ance, and afterwards it is preÅ¿ented that it is not done, the Lord Å¿hall have debt, 23 Hen. 8. br. Leet 37. for the Å¿ame, for it is a duty conditionally upon the non-feaÅ¿ars.
For a Penalty inflicted upon one in London per the Common Council, debt lies for it in Ban. Regis. Mich. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis. by the cuÅ¿tom of the City, as it Å¿eems.
Matter in Law, as for Aid.Debt lies for the Daughter for Ayd to marry her, Nat. br. 83. A. & 122. G. vid. antea. For the Ayd is for her advancement.

For an Annuity againÅ¿t a CuÅ¿tomer, &c. after delivery of a Liberate. A man having an Annuity of the King, delivers a Writ to a CuÅ¿tomer to pay it, who hath aÅ¿Å¿ets, he Å¿hall have debt, Nat. br. 121. F. againÅ¿t the CuÅ¿tomer, elÅ¿e not.
So if he deliver a Tally to a CuÅ¿tomer. 27 Hen. 6.9. pl. 1. For that is a Å¿ufficient warrant to him to pay it.
So if he deliver a Tally to a Collector of Tenths and Fifteens, 37 Hen. 6.15. pl. 5. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
Debt lies pro rationabili parte bonorum, where the cuÅ¿tom gives Å¿uch part,Pro rationabili parte bonorum. Nat. br. 122. L. 3 Edw. 3. Debt 156. for him that is to have Å¿uch part.

The count was that the Son or Daughter which is not heir, nor preferred in the life of the Father Å¿hall have a reaÅ¿onable part, and Å¿hews the
things to the value, &c. Lib. intra. 564. B. Å¿ect. 1. The value is to be Å¿hewed to reduce it to a certainty.
But Å¿hall not have this Writ, but where Å¿uch cuÅ¿tom is, 40 Edw. 3.38. pl. 13. Mowbray. 7 Edw. 4.20. pl. 23. for the common Law takes no notice of Å¿uch reaÅ¿onable part.
For it cannot be founded upon Magna Charta cap. 8. becauÅ¿e it is but only forepriÅ¿ed, RegiÅ¿t. orig 141. B. 30 Edw. 3.26. A. Seton. and not ordained or enacted.
But other Books Å¿ay it lies at Common Law, Nat. br. 122. L. Glanvil Lib. 12. cap. 20. 17 Edw 3 9. pl. 29. Q. tamen; for cuÅ¿tom makes Law in many caÅ¿es.
And the account is upon the Common Law, No. Lib. intra. 565. A. Å¿ect. 2. viz. per legen terrae.

So debt lies where the cuÅ¿tom is that the heir Å¿hall have the principal goods, 30 Edw. 3.2. pl.
â¢ . 39 Edw. 3.6. pl. 24. & fol. 9. pl. 15. for thereby they are a duty veÅ¿ted in him.

For a relief per Executor.Executor Å¿hall have debt for a relief, becauÅ¿e it is but an improvement of a rent-Å¿ervice, Coke 4. part. 49. B. 34 Edw. 1. Avowry, 233. 11 Hen. 6.15. pl. 4. and is not a rent-Å¿ervice.
And it is a chattel to the Executor, 34 Edw. 3. Avowry, 233. and ought to be aÅ¿Å¿ets in his hands.
But the Lord Å¿hall not have debt, Coke 4. part. 49. B. 7 Hen. 6.13. For it is no Chattel to the Lord, 34. Edw. 1. Avowry 233.
Toll Å¿hall be recovered by debt, 20 Hen. 7.1. pl. 2. but vide librum & quaere, for it Å¿eems it is a duty certain.
For EÅ¿cuage.Debt lies for EÅ¿cuage after that it is aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed per Parliament, for then it is a duty certain, Crooke 133. pl. 111.
Simple Obligation conditional.Debt lies upon a Å¿imple Obligation; Count, Lib. Intra. 178. B. Å¿ect. 1. for there is a duty certain.
Or upon an Obligation with a Condition.
Vide per Attorney vel Å¿ervientem ad legem, fol. 174. D. Sect. 5 & 6. Q.

Debt upon a Bill to pay within a month after that the Plaintiff Å¿hall come from JeruÅ¿alem, he needs not give notice, to the Defendant of his return, becauÅ¿e he is bound to pay it at his peril, Hill. 9. Jac. Ban. Regi â¢ , Edmonds. Q.
Obligation with condition to perform Covevants, No. Lib. Intra. 130. B. Sect. 14.

Obligation to diÅ¿charge and Å¿ave harmleÅ¿s the Sheriff of all eÅ¿capes of perÅ¿ons in Execution, a good breach to Å¿hew that one was in execution, per Capias, &c. and that he Å¿uffered him to go at large; without Å¿hewing, 1. that he was at large; 2. without giving notice of it, and requeÅ¿t to Å¿ave him harmleÅ¿s; 3. without Å¿hewing that the Capias was returned, Trin. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. Norton verÅ¿us Smyth, for the Capias Å¿hall be intended to be well executed.
Upon a Å¿ingle Bill obligatory and the Count, Lib. Intra. 178. B. Å¿ect. 1, 2, 3.
Upon a Bill obligatory with condition, Lib. Intr. 178. C. Sect. 4. antea.
Debt upon an obligation made in England to be paid in Flanders, Lib. Intra. 158. C. Sect. 1.
Debt lies upon a Tallee Å¿ealed, Nat. br. 122. I. 2 Rich. 2. Debt 4. vide 44 Edw. 3.24. pl. 23. antea.

div.head: The Writ in Debt; 1. In the County. 2. In Com. Ban.
div.p: Rex, &c. praecipimus tibi quod juÅ¿ticies A, quod juÅ¿te & Å¿ine dilatione reddat B 20 l. quas ei debet, County. ut dicit, & Å¿icut rationabiliter monÅ¿trare poterit, quod ei reddere debeat, ne amplius inde clamorem audiamus pro defectu JuÅ¿titiae, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. A. Nat. br. 119. H.
In Comitatu. Pro debito Å¿emper dicitur quas ei debet tantum, & pro catallis detinet tantum, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. B. & non ut dicit Å¿en ut dicitur.
But for Executors it is always in the detinet, ibidem; for the debt is due to the TeÅ¿tators eÅ¿tate, and is only detained from the Executors, in retardationem teÅ¿tamenti TeÅ¿tatoris.
If Debt be by AdminiÅ¿trators,AdminiÅ¿trator. all of them muÅ¿t be named, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. A. for they have a joynt Authority, which muÅ¿t be purÅ¿ued.
The Writ Å¿hall be in the Detinet only, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. B. for the former reaÅ¿on.

If one recover againÅ¿t AdminiÅ¿trators, and bring debt upon the Record, the Writ Å¿hall be detinet only, 11 Hen. 4.56. pl. 2. vide 11 Hen. 6.7. 16.39. For by Newton, fol. 37. debet imports his proper debt, being upon his own Contract, 20 Hen. 6.5. A. ForteÅ¿cue; for they owe nothing themÅ¿elves, but only do detain in anothers place.

Husband and Wife.If Husband and Wife bring Debt, the Writ Å¿hall be debet & detinet eis, Coke 5. part. 36. A. Walkots caÅ¿e, 12 Hen. 4.1. pl. 1. 7 Hen. 7.2. B. debet in reÅ¿pect of the wife, and detinet in reÅ¿pect of the husband, from whom the debt is withheld.
But the Count Å¿hall be Å¿pecial, 7 Hen. 7.2. B. and Å¿hew how, and to whom the debt became due.
So in debt againÅ¿t them for debt due before Coverture, 7 Hen. 7.2. B. in the debet in reÅ¿pect of the wife, and detinet as to the husband.

AgainÅ¿t a Collector.Bill againÅ¿t a Collector, after that he hath accounted there ought to be nuper Collector, 15 Edw. 4.27. for after his account he is out of his office, and cannot be called Collector.

By Executors.Debt per Executors, the Writ Å¿hall be detinet only, although the duty accrue in their time; for it is due to the TeÅ¿tators eÅ¿tate only, and not to them, Coke 5. part. 31. B. Hargraves caÅ¿e, Nat. br. 119. M. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. A. So for goods of the TeÅ¿tators Å¿old by them, 19 Hen. 8.8. 11 Hen. 6.36. A. 20 Hen. 6.5. B. and Å¿o for Rent due in their time, for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
So if they Å¿ell a thing, and take an obligation for the money, 17 Edw. 3.64. pl. 78. 25 Edw. 3.40. pl. 7. for this is to the uÅ¿e of the TeÅ¿tator.
Et RegiÅ¿t. orig. 138 B. 9 Hen. 6.11. B. 20 Hen. 6.4. B. PaÅ¿ton.

In ancient time in Å¿uch caÅ¿e it was in the debet & detinet; but not at this day, becauÅ¿e that debet Å¿uppoÅ¿eth a property which the Executor hath not; Å¿o that it is to be noted, that ancient PreÅ¿idents
may be altered upon good grounds.

All Executors ought to joyn in Debt, although that Å¿ome refuÅ¿e the AdminiÅ¿tration, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. B. 22 Edw. 3.19. pl. 8.7. 41 Edw. 3.22. pl. 10. 21 Edw. 4.24. 36 Hen. 6.8. Coke 9. part. 37. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, 24 Edw. 3.40. B. Thorpe, 19 Hen. 6.31. quaere, if they refuÅ¿e to prove the Will, for then it Å¿eems they were not Executors.

Vide tamen, 38 Edw. 3.9. pl. 7. L. where an Executor Å¿old goods and brought Debt Å¿ole for the money, and it was awarded good without his Companions; it Å¿eems it was, becauÅ¿e he Å¿olely made the Å¿ale. Quaere tamen.
An Executor and an Executor of his Fellow Executor joyned in debt, and good, 7 Edw. 3.26. pl. 22. Q.
But the 28 Edw. 3.92. pl. 11. Wilby, this is not Law; for 29 Edw. 3.49.23. the Å¿urviving Executor Å¿hall have it Å¿old, and Å¿o I conceive the Law to be.

Wife Executrix.A Wife executrix in debt, by her and her huÅ¿band the Writ Å¿hall Å¿uppoÅ¿e both Executors, â¢ 2 Hen. 6.49. pl. 8. for conformities Å¿ake; for the wife cannot Å¿ue without her husband.
Feme covert Executrix Å¿hall not have debt without the husband, 8 Edw. 3.330. pl. 48. 10 Edw. 3.381. pl. 63. 21 Hen. 6.30. pl. 17. Markeham, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. for the aforeÅ¿aid reaÅ¿on.
AgainÅ¿t ExecutorsThe Writ Å¿hall be detinet only, Nat. br. 119. M. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. B. antea.
But for Rent due in the time of the Executor, it Å¿hall be in the debet & detinet, Coke 5.31. Hargraves caÅ¿e, 7 Edw. 6.81. for it may be for the benefit of the Executor.
A man being Executor of his own wrong takes AdminiÅ¿tration, quaere how he Å¿hall be Å¿ued, Crooke 127. pl. 91. A. it Å¿eems as AdminiÅ¿trator, for that is his beÅ¿t condition.
It Å¿ufficeth to name them only that be AdminiÅ¿trators, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140 A, & B. 19 Hen. 6.31. Coke 9. part. 37. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, 33 Hen. 6.38. pl. 15. in the Writ and Count.
Debt againÅ¿t an Executor, which pleads joynt executorÅ¿hip with another; they both may plead Å¿o, but the former only cannot, 29 Edw. 3.11. pl. 32. for they are but one Executor.
Debt lies againÅ¿t an Executor of right and of his own wrong, 39 Hen. 6.45. pl. 19. for the latter hath made himÅ¿elf liable.
But not againÅ¿t an Executor, and an Executor of an Executor, 41 Edw. 3.13. pl 3. for this would be to recover one thing twice.
Two Executors, viz. a Man and a Woman, adminiÅ¿ter, and intermarry, debt lies againÅ¿t both, 22 Hen. 6.59. pl. 12. for the marriage drowns not the ExecutorÅ¿hip in the woman.
The Heir ought to be named,Heir. 30 Hen. 6.5. pl. 2. in debt brought againÅ¿t him as heir, that it may be known in what capacity he is chargeable.
But RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. A. he was named Heir in the Count only, and not in the Writ, and yet good. Quaere tamen.

He was named Heir apparent, and it was erronious, PaÅ¿ch. 35 Eliz. Ban. Regis 242. Audleys caÅ¿e; for he is not chargeable during the life of his AnceÅ¿tor, for the Heir is bound, and not heir Apparent.

It Å¿hall be againÅ¿t him in the debet & detinet, and not in the detinet only, becauÅ¿e he hath AÅ¿Å¿ets in his own right, Coke 5. part. 36. Walkots caÅ¿e, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 140. A. Com. 441. A. Pepys caÅ¿e, by intendment of Law, till the contrary appear.

Debt againÅ¿t the Ordinary, and the Writ. Praecipe A. EpiÅ¿cop. London ad cujus manus bena & catalla quae fuerunt B. qui obiit inteÅ¿tat. ãâã dicitur, devenerunt, quod juÅ¿te & Å¿ine, &c. reddat, &c. C. Å¿olidos, quos idem B. ei debuit, & praedict â¢â¢ EpiÅ¿cop. ei injuÅ¿te detinet, ut dicit, & niÅ¿i, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 141. A. Nat. br. 120. D.
Et ibidem vide the Writ againÅ¿t an Executor of the Ordinary, who is liable, and not his SucceÅ¿Å¿or, for that might be inconvenient.

But it lies not for the Ordinary, Nat. br. 120. D. Coke 9. part. 39. HenÅ¿loes caÅ¿e, for he hath no proper intereÅ¿t in the eÅ¿tate; tamen vide, the Writ for the Ordinary in the RegiÅ¿t. orig. 141. A. Quaere, if it lie not, what remedy the Ordinary hath to recover the eÅ¿tate, and to puniÅ¿h the tort feÅ¿or.
Nota, Nota. when a man demands money it Å¿hall be debet & detinet, Nat. br. 119. G. viz. where the Action lies in the debet & detinet.
And if it be for any other thing it Å¿hall be in the detinet only, Nat. br. 119. G. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 139. B. 34 Hen. 6.12. pl. 23. for a man is not properly Å¿aid to owe goods, but to detain them.
And the Writ Å¿hall make mention of the value of the goods, 17 Edw. 3.48. pl. 17. 29 Edw. 3.39. pl. 14. & fol. 45. pl. 6. that the charge may be certain.

And if it be for money, or other things together with it, then it Å¿hall Å¿ay 10 l. quas ei debet & injuÅ¿te detinet, & 10 l. quarters of Corn, quae ei
injuÅ¿te detinet, Nat. br. 152. B. 3 Hen. 4.13. pl. 20. 11 Hen. 6.48. pl. 6. 12 Hen. 6.1. pl. 3. vide 39 Hen. 6.34. pl. 46. debt for 300 l.

A man cannot demand 10 l. by one Writ, and 10 l. by another, where the contract was for 20 l. 1 Hen. 5.6. B. but the charge thuÅ¿t be entire as the contract was, otherwiÅ¿e there will be unneceÅ¿Å¿ary charge.

For in Mich. 14 Jac. Ban. Regis, in the caÅ¿e of the Bailies of IpÅ¿wich Houghton JuÅ¿tice Å¿aid, that A was indebted to the King in 3000 l. the King granted to B 1000 l. parcel of it, yet B Å¿hall not have debt for the 1000 l. as was adjudged in the Chequer, int. Yorke & Allen, for this were to alter the debt.
A was bound in 6 l. FlemmiÅ¿h, quaere what Writ he Å¿hall have, 34 Hen 6.12. pl. 23. 29 Edw. 3.19. pl. 5. viz. for what Å¿um, whether it Å¿hall be reduced into Å¿terling money.
For Lib. Intra. 158. C. Å¿ect. 1. the Writ was for 28 l. and the account of the bill was 19 l. 16 s. FlemmiÅ¿h, which is 14 l. EngliÅ¿h, and for the Remnant, &c. the Action brought.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s in Debt, 1. Before appearance. 2. After appearance.
div.p: At the Common Law the ProceÅ¿s was but a Summons, Attachment, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, Coke 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e.
But by 25 Edw. 3. cap. 17. Capias was given, yet the ProceÅ¿s is yet a Summons, Attachment, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 3. a Capias and an Exigend. 14 Hen. 6.20. A.
But if Debt be in the County per JuÅ¿ticies, and the Baily return a Nihil habet, and afterwards this is removed, quaere if a Capias lies, 3 Hen. 5.4.
Nota, Nota. that a Capias lies not upon a Recognizance, 23 Hen. 7.100. pl. 1. Crooke, for that is in the nature of a Judgment, upon which a mean ProceÅ¿s lies not.

Nor againÅ¿t a Peer of the Realm, Coke 6. part. 52. B. 11 Hen. 4.15. 3 Hen. 6.48. 29 Edw. 3.30. pl. 40. & 42. pl. 3. 5 Edw. 4.108. B. becauÅ¿e he is intended to have Land Å¿ufficient to pay his debts.
But if a BiÅ¿hop of Wales or Ireland be Å¿ued upon a Nihil habet returned, a Capias lies, ibidem. Quaere of a WelÅ¿h BiÅ¿hop.
For arrearages of account.Debt lies for Arrearages of Account, that he owes nothing is a good barr, Lib. Intr. 149. B. Å¿ell. 2. for this may be put in iÅ¿Å¿ue.
1. Before Auditors.And this may be by wager in Law, becauÅ¿e it is within the Statute, 22 Hen. 6.35. pl. 53. 9 Hen. 5.3. pl. 9. 43 Edw. 1. pl. 3.
2. Before Auditors.And Å¿o if it be before an Auditor, Coke 10. part. 103. A. 4 Hen. 6.25. pl. 3. 20 Hen. 6.16. pl. 4. 13 Hen. 7.3. B. Conesby.

If it be for Arrearages of account before Auditors, impriÅ¿onment by Auditors is a good Bar; but then he ought to be committed forthwith by the Auditors, 27 Hen. 6.8. pl. 7. Coke 8. part. 119. B. Com. 17. for this is as it were the Execution againÅ¿t him.
Non computavit a good barr, 3 Mariae Dyer 122. pl. 18. for if there were no Account, there can be no Arrearages found upon it, for which to bring the Action.
Nul tiel account, 34 Hen. 6.22. A. Danby, a good barr.

Arbitrement for Arrearages of the account no barr, becauÅ¿e one is matter of Record, but the Arbitrement is not, 3 Hen. 4.5. pl. 23. 4 Hen. 6.17. 6 Hen. 4.6. pl. 28. 8 Hen. 5.3. pl. 13. Hull, 3 Hen. 6.55. A. and Å¿o cannot diÅ¿charge a matter of Record.
Auditors diÅ¿charged by the Plaintiff a good barr, Lib. Intra. 150. A. Sect. 9. in Account, for this deÅ¿troys the account upon which the Action is brought.
Obligation made to the Plaintiff for Arrearages no barr, 11 Hen. 4.79. for an obligation is but a thing in Action. Q.
Payment in another County a good barr, Lib. Intra. 150. A. Å¿ect. 10. for the place of payment is not material or traverÅ¿able.
That he owes nothing per patriam, a good barr, Lib. Intra. 150. A. Å¿ect. 1.4 Mariae Dyer 145. pl. 63. for this is a direct tender of an iÅ¿Å¿ue.

That he owes nothing by the Law no barr, becauÅ¿e Auditors are Judges of Record, 2. cap. 11. Coke 103. A. Denbounds caÅ¿e, 4 Hen. 6.17. 8 Hen. 6.5. 14 Hen. 19. pl. 21. 9 Hen. 5.3. pl. 9. and they have adjudged him to owe.

But the Plaintiff may be examined by the Auditors, and if it be not found that the Defendant is in Arrearages, the Defendant may wage his Law, per the Statute, 5 Hen. 4. cap. 8. Coke 10. part. 103. A. 8 Hen. 6.10 & 15. 19 Hen. 6.43. pl. 90. 20 Hen. 6.32. AÅ¿hton, for then he is not concluded by the Auditors.

And if the Plaintiff or his Attorney refuÅ¿e to
be examined, the Defendant Å¿hall wage his Law, 33 Hen. 6.24. pl. 5. for then the Defendant may be believed as well as the Plaintiff.

But if the Executor brings Debt for Arrearages of account in vita teÅ¿tatoris, he Å¿hall not be examined; but his Attorney Å¿hall, but not upon Oath, 3 Hen. 6.40. pl. 2. 19 Hen. 6.8. 10 Hen. 6.20. 34 Hen. 6.32. AÅ¿hton, 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 24. for the Executors Å¿hall not be intended to be privy to the contracts of the TeÅ¿tator.
But 21 Hen. 6.4. pl. 10. the Executor was examined, but not preciÅ¿ely, which Å¿ignifies little; for in generalibus non eÅ¿t certitudo.
So if another brought Å¿uch Action againÅ¿t an Executor, he Å¿hall not be examined, 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 14. viz. the Plaintiff.

So if it be found that they Å¿ubmit themÅ¿elves to Arbitrement, Å¿o that they were not Auditors, but Arbitrators, they Å¿hall wage their Law, 22 Hen. 6.41. pl. 13. for Arbitrators are not Judges of Record.

The Lord Å¿hall Å¿ay that he owes nothing,Lord. and waged his Law, WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 11. doth not extend to the Lord, 14 Hen. 6.24. 22 Hen. 6.41. 38 Hen. 6. A. 29 Edw. 3.26. pl. 20. Coke 9. part. 87. A. Pinchons caÅ¿e. Q.
The Defendant alledges before Auditors, that he delivered to the Plaintiff one Statute Merchant in lieu of the Å¿um, the Plaintiff wages his Law, 30 Edw. 3.4. pl. 19. upon the delivery. Quaere.
Lending: to PredeceÅ¿Å¿or.SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall wage his Law upon a thing lent to his predeceÅ¿Å¿or, 13 Edw. 4.4. pl. 9. becauÅ¿e not privy to the contract.

To the party.That he owes nothing by the Law, a good barr, Lib. Intra. 152. C. Å¿ect. 5. although the thing lent be by others hands, 29 Edw. 3.26. pl. 24. for the Law wager is upon the receipt, and not the delivery.

Debt upon bailment,Bailment. the Defendant pleads that they were delivered to be redelivered to B, the which he had done, a good barr, Nat. br. 138. M. for the truÅ¿t was performed, and the contract thereby diÅ¿charged.

Contract Real, 1. for years. 2. for life. 3. at will.Arbitrement of Rent, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, and payment of the thing awarded, a good barr without Å¿aying he owes nothing, 10 Hen. 7.4. pl. 4. Q. for thereby the agreement is waved.
An Accord, a good plea, 10 Hen. 7.24. 2 Rich. 3. Debt 100. Coke 9. part. 97. A. Peytoes caÅ¿e, for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
Acquittance of the laÅ¿t day Å¿hall diÅ¿charge all Arrearages, 11 Hen. 4.24. 10 Eliz. Dyer 271. pl. 26. due before; for it Å¿hall be intended there was nothing due when the Acquittance was given.

The LeÅ¿Å¿ee pleads the command of the LeÅ¿Å¿or to repair the houÅ¿e with the rent, becauÅ¿e it was decayed; this is no good plea, becauÅ¿e it is waÅ¿te, 34 Hen. 6.17. 14 Hen. 4.27. pl. 35. 11 Rich. 2. Barr, in the LeÅ¿Å¿ee to Å¿uffer the houÅ¿e to decay, if he was not LeÅ¿Å¿ee at will.
But if the grand Timber be in decay, perchance it may be a good barr, ibidem; becauÅ¿e LeÅ¿Å¿ee at years is not bound to repair them, except he be tied by Å¿pecial Covenant, as it Å¿eems. Quaere.

The LeÅ¿Å¿ee was Advocate in the Spiritual Court, the LeÅ¿Å¿or promiÅ¿es that he Å¿hall keep
the Rent for his Fees, this is no barr, for Å¿teppage is no plea, but he hath a good ground to have an AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it to recover his fees, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Jarvis verÅ¿us Lea, and here is no conÅ¿ideration for the promiÅ¿e, for he was his Advocate upon another ground.

The LeÅ¿Å¿ee pleads, that the LeÅ¿Å¿or entred before the day of payment, and ejected him, a good barr, 27 Hen. 6.10. pl. 6. 46 Edw. 3.1. pl. 1. Lib. Intra. 175. D. Å¿ect. 10, 11, 12. for then the Rent could not be due, for it was payable for the whole term, and cannot be apportioned, for it is entire.
A good barr to Å¿ay, that the LeÅ¿Å¿or entred before his day without any more, 34 Hen. 6.21. pl. 40. for the entry implies an ejectment; for both cannot be in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
So if the LeÅ¿Å¿or enter but in part, a good barr, Coke 3. part. 22. B. Walkers caÅ¿e; for the Rent is payable for the whole thing lett, and is entire.
But if the LeÅ¿Å¿ee enter again before the day of payment, no barr; for then he regains the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and hath elected to wave this advantage of the entry made upon him.
So if the LeÅ¿Å¿or cuts the Trees, no barr, becauÅ¿e the LeÅ¿Å¿or ejects not the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, 33 Eliz. but is only a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er.
Entry by a Stranger which hath a better title, a good barr, Perkins 163. Lib. Intra. 176. A. Sect. 13. 45 Edw 3.8. pl. 10. for that makes void the LeaÅ¿e.
But not for Arrearages due before the entry, 9 Hen. 6.17. B. CotteÅ¿more, 19 Hen 6.42. B. PaÅ¿ton, 20 Hen. 6.20. pl. 15. for Å¿o long the LeaÅ¿e continues in being.

Debt for Rent in com. M. where the Land is in com. E. levied by diÅ¿treÅ¿s is a good plea, without Å¿aying more, 4 Hen. 6.5. pl. 12. 22 Hen. 6.31. pl. 19. 28 Hen. 6.6. pl. 2. Although the LeaÅ¿e be by Indenture, 4 Hen. 6.5. pl. 12. 18 Hen. 6.17. A. per 2 JuÅ¿tices, 11 Hen. 7.4. pl. 16. for it Å¿hall be intended to be levied where the Land lies, which cannot be tried where the Action is brought.

But if it be in the Å¿ame County where the land is, then it ought to conclude that he owed nothing, becauÅ¿e the Countrey may have notice whether he did or not, 28 Hen. 6.6. pl. 2. 33 Hen. 6.4. pl. 12. and may try the iÅ¿Å¿ue.
But the 9 Edw. 3.33.4. pl. 16. Herle, it is good without Å¿uch concluÅ¿ion. Q. It Å¿eems, he thought levied by diÅ¿treÅ¿s doth imply that he owes nothing.
Debt upon a LeaÅ¿e for Tithes, levied by diÅ¿treÅ¿s is no barr, becauÅ¿e there is nothing Å¿ubject to diÅ¿treÅ¿s, 22 Hen. 6.35. pl. 53. 11 Hen. 4.40. br. debt 234. and Å¿o the plea is impoÅ¿Å¿ible.
A good barr that the LeÅ¿Å¿or diÅ¿trained, and Å¿old the diÅ¿treÅ¿s for the Rent by the aÅ¿Å¿ent of the Defendant, 2 Rich. 2. Debt 235. for Å¿o he might do, but not without his conÅ¿ent.

Payment in another County, a good barr without Å¿aying more, 22 Hen. 6.36. pl. 1.34. Hen. 6.17. B. Moyle, 9 Hen. 5.2. pl. 6. 11 Hen. 7.4. pl. 16. 1 Hen. 5.6 & 7. 20 Hen. 6.16. B. 22 Hen. 6.35. pl. 53. for the payment is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and the place it not traverÅ¿able.
For otherways it Å¿hall be tried where the Writ is brought, 4 Hen. 6.5. pl. 12. viz. if he plead payment generally, for that Å¿hall be intended to be where the Action is laid.
