To Å¿ay, that the LeÅ¿Å¿or covenanted to repair the houÅ¿e, or that the cuÅ¿tome is that he Å¿hould repair it, and did not do it; this is no barr, becauÅ¿e it is but a Covenant upon which the Defendant may take his remedy: but if the LeaÅ¿e be that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee repair â¢ d it, and paid the rent for Reparations, this is a good barr, that the LeÅ¿Å¿or did not repair it, 27 Hen. 6.10. pl. 6. Q.

But upon a leaÅ¿e by Indenture, and that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hould repair the houÅ¿e at the coÅ¿t of the LeÅ¿Å¿or, it is a good plea to Å¿ay, that he did expend the Rent in repairing of the houÅ¿e, 2 Rich. 2.235. for this agrees with the LeaÅ¿e.

That the LeaÅ¿e was upon a condition, and upon the breach of the condition the LeÅ¿Å¿or entred before there was any thing in arrear, no plea, for he ought to anÅ¿wer the debet, Crooke 153. pl. which he doth not by this plea, which is no more but a negative pregnans.
Surrender before the day a good barr, Lib. Intr. 176. C. Å¿ect. 17. for thereby the LeaÅ¿e was drowned before the rent due.

Contract perÅ¿onal.Accord a good plea, Coke 6. part. Blakes caÅ¿e, Lib. Intra. 205. C. Sect. 11. And Å¿o, that the Plaintiff had an obligation for the Å¿ame duty, 3 Hen. 4.17. for this is Å¿uch Å¿atisfaction as the LeÅ¿Å¿or accepted of in lieu of the payment of the Rent.

Payment to the Servant no barr,Servant. unleÅ¿s the Servant was commanded by his MaÅ¿ter to receive it, or that the money came to the uÅ¿e of his MaÅ¿ter by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 138. A. for a Servant is not a Receiver without Å¿pecial warrant.

Rent upon a perÅ¿onal thing.Upon a LeaÅ¿e for years of a Å¿tock of Cattel, or other perÅ¿onal thing rendring Rent at Å¿everal days,
debt lies not till the days be incurred, Coke 3. part. 22. A. Walkers caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the Rent is entire, though the days of payment be Å¿everal.
That he owes nothing by the Law a good barr, 1 Hen. 6.1. pl. 3. 9 Edw. 4.1.

Salary for a CounÅ¿ellor.That he owes nothing a good barr, although the Plaintiff be a Serjeant at Law, 3 Hen. 6.33. pl. 26. 21 Hen. 6 4. pl. 6. who Å¿ues for his Fees; for Å¿uch payments uÅ¿e to be private.

The Defendant Å¿hall not wage his Law againÅ¿t an Attorney,Attorney. becauÅ¿e the Court compels him to be Attorney for the party, and Å¿o no voluntary retainer; otherways, if it be upon Å¿uit in a baÅ¿e count, 21 Hen. 6.4. pl. 5. ForteÅ¿cue Newton; for there he is not bound to be his Attorney.
That he departs his Å¿ervice within the term,Servant. a good barr, 40 Edw. 3.25. pl. 27. againÅ¿t a Servant that Å¿ues for wages; for the wages is due for the whole time.
That he diÅ¿charged him of the Å¿ervice within the term to which he agreed, is a good barr, 10 Hen. 6.23. pl. 78. for this diÅ¿charge is accepted in Å¿atisfaction.
That he retained him not modo, Å¿orma, &c. a good barr, 38 Hen. 6.22. pl. 41. viz. according to the Statute.
Payment without Å¿pecialty is not a good barr in debt, brought by a Servant retained in husbandry, 40 Edw. 3.21. pl. 27. becauÅ¿e he is retained by Statute.

And Å¿o if one be retained, but not according to the Statute, the MaÅ¿ter may wage his Law in debt for the Å¿alary, elÅ¿e not, Coke 9. part. 87 & 88. Pinchons caÅ¿e, 3 Hen. 6.42. pl. 13. 11 Hen. 6.48.
4 Hen. 6.19. B. 2 Hen. 4.14. 39 Hen. 6.18. pl. 24. 38 Hen. 6.22. B. for Å¿uch retainer is but a private agreement, whereof the Law takes no notice.
But he may not plead, that the Servant demands 40 s. per annum, and the Statute allows not this, becauÅ¿e he was not retained according to it, 11 Hen. 6.10. pl. 20.
So if he be retained in all occupations, although that husbandry be comprehended within it; but he muÅ¿t be retained particularly in husbandry.
If a general receiver retain one by deed, yet the MaÅ¿ter may plead that he owes him nothing by the Law, 28 Hen. 8 Dyer 20. pl. 12.4. for he hath no authority to retain him.
If one be retained in husbandry, although he be not compellable to Å¿erve, yet his MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall not wage his Law, 38 Hen. 6.22. B. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e the Retainer is by Statute.

A retains B to be his Steward of his Court for one year or more,Steward. he Å¿hall have debt although the retainer be by word; but not for an Annual penÅ¿ion, unleÅ¿s the retainer be by deed, Crooke 1 Hen. 8.158. pl. 6. becauÅ¿e that is of longer continuance, and therefore the contract ought to be more Å¿olemn than by parol.

Infancy no barr,
â¢ abilng. 18 Edw. 4.3. A. VaviÅ¿or, 10 Hen. 6.14. A. Perkins 4. in debt for diet and neceÅ¿Å¿aries, becauÅ¿e the Law makes Å¿uch Contracts good.
That he owes nothing by the Law, a good barr, 9 Edw. 4.1. B. 19 Hen. 6.10. pl. 25. 39 Hen. 6.18. pl. 24. Moyle & Danby, 27 Edw 3.87. pl. 37. for the payment may be private as well as the contract.
So if a contract for tabling be made with B. 22 Hen. 6.13. pl. 18. for a third perÅ¿on.

So if an Inn-keeper brings debt for Diet or Lodging becauÅ¿e they cannot depart till they pay for it, 39 Hen. 6.78. pl. 24. therefore it is reaÅ¿on to wage their Law to gain their liberty, if the Debt be paid.

But debt brought by the Lieutenant of the Tower for a priÅ¿oners diet, the Defendant Å¿hall not wage his Law, becauÅ¿e the Lieutenant ought to find him ordinary Diet, Coke 9 part. 87. B. and therefore here Å¿hall be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed a Å¿pecial contract which muÅ¿t be Å¿pecially pleaded to.

The Defendant Å¿aid that it was in another place,Vendition viz. the Å¿ale upon which the action is brought, and that it was made upon condition, and that the condition was not performed; a good bar to the Action, 34 Hen. 6.6.42. pl. 13. 44 Edw. 3.28. pl. 6. vide 47 Edw. 3.20. pl. 44. becauÅ¿e the condition not being performed, the Å¿ale was null and void.

Debt upon a Å¿imple Contract, the Defendant pleads that the Plaintiff took an obligation for it, a good barr, Coke. 6. part. 45. Heggins. 3 Hen. 4.17. 11 Hen. 4.79. 9. Edw. 4.50, 51. For this amounts to a diÅ¿charge of the Contract.
Payment without an Acquittance no plea, 1 Hen. 5.6. B. in debt upon a Å¿pecialty, becauÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be diÅ¿charged by a thing of as high a nature.

He cannot plead to the Country for part, and wage his Law for the other; but if it be for 20 s. that the Action is brought, the Defendant may Å¿ay that the contract was for 10 s. without this
that it was for 20 s. and as to the 10 s. he wages his Law: but quaere if he may tender part, and wage his Law for the remnant, Crooke. 17 Hen. 7.40. pl. 12. It Å¿eems not, for there may be more due, and therefore it ought to be put in iÅ¿Å¿ue.

In debt upon a Å¿ale that he owes nothing by the Law, a good bar, although the Defendant bought it of the Å¿ervant of the Plaintiff; for the contract of the Servant is the contract of the MaÅ¿ter, 30 Edw. 3.19. pl. 27. If the Servant had authority to buy and Å¿ell, or that the thing bought came to the MaÅ¿ters uÅ¿e.
UnleÅ¿s the Contract be by deed, 39 Hen. 6.35. pl. 46. Which muÅ¿t be avoided by Deed, and not by the Oath of the party.

Debt againÅ¿t the Husband and Wife upon a contract of the wife dum Å¿ola fuit, the Husband wages his Law, as now he may, for now it is his debt; but if at the day of the doing of his Law, the Wife be not there, the Husband Å¿hall be condemned, 33 Hen. 6.43. pl. 23. For the debt originally was hers, and therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t join.

That he recovered in an Action upon the CaÅ¿e, upon an AÅ¿sumpÅ¿it, a good bar, Coke. 4. part. 94. B. Slades caÅ¿e. in debt upon a Contract; for it was in his election to bring his Action upon the CaÅ¿e.
The breaking of the PriÅ¿on by Enemies or a TempeÅ¿t,EÅ¿cape. a good bar, 33 Hen. 6.1. pl. 3. in debt againÅ¿t a Gaoler upon an eÅ¿cape; for he could not prevent it, nor can have Å¿atisfaction.
But not by Rebels, 33 Hen. 6.1. pl. 3. For Rebels may be compelled to make the Gaoler Å¿atisfaction.

The Sheriff pleads that his predeceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿uffered him at large, and that he did take him again, &c. a good b â¢ r, 2 Edw. 6.67. pl. 17. in debt brought againÅ¿t him for an eÅ¿cape in his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors time.
Enfancy no plea, becauÅ¿e the Statute is general. Doct. & Stud. 147. B. In debt for neceÅ¿Å¿aries vid. antea.

Debt againÅ¿t a Bayliff, becauÅ¿e the Sheriff had not made out his Warrant for apprehending one in execution, and yet returns that he was taken, and was not, quaere whether the Bayliff Å¿hall Å¿ay no Å¿uch Warant againÅ¿t the return of the Sheriff, 5 Edw. 4.1. It Å¿eems not, but muÅ¿t have his remedy againÅ¿t the Sheriff.
Non permiÅ¿it ire ad largum, a good bar, 10 Hen. 4.10. 38 Hen. 6.29. 3 Mariae, Dyer. 121. pl. 18. in debt brought upon an eÅ¿cape; for this is a direct tender of an iÅ¿Å¿ue that there was no eÅ¿cape.
A Return by a Bayliff of a Liberty, that the Precept was not come to him at the time, and that afterwards he was not in the Liberty, 18 Edw. 3.35. is a good bar in debt againÅ¿t him.

Taken again before the Action brought, a good bar, if that he agree not to the eÅ¿cape, and make freÅ¿h Å¿uit, Coke 3. part. 52. Rigwayes caÅ¿e. 34 Edw. 1. debt. 162. OtherwiÅ¿e not; for then he is particeps criminis.

That he owes nothing, is no Plea, becauÅ¿e this Action is brought, not upon a contract, but upon a Å¿pecial clauÅ¿e of the Statute, 2 Rich. 2. IÅ¿Å¿ue 160. Which cannot be diÅ¿charged by a plea parol, but he muÅ¿t anÅ¿wer to the Statute.

Account upon a recovery of dammages, and the party committed in execution, Nul tiel record, a good bar, 30 Hen. 6.6. For the Action is grounded upon the Record, and if there be no Å¿uch Record, there can be no Action.
Judgment in Court.Debt upon a Judgment in Pypowders, a good bar that he was taken in execution, 7 Hen. 6.18. upon the Judgment given in the Court of Pypowders.

Upon a recovery in a Court Baron, if an Action of debt be brought, the Defendant Å¿hall Å¿ay that he owes nothing by the Law, 49 Edw. 3.3. A. Hanmer. 13 Hen. 7.3. B. Conesby. For Å¿uch recoveries are of an inferior nature.
Debt for dammagesDebt for Dammages recovered in AÅ¿Å¿ize of the Plaintiff after Verdict, and before Judgment pleaded, quaere 2 Mariae, Dyer. 107. pl. 24.
Levied by the Sheriff, a good bar, 11 Hen. 4.58. pl. 8. For that is Å¿atisfaction in Law, as to the party.
Elegit pleaded in Bar good, 13 Eliz. Dyer. 299. pl. 34. For by the Elegit he hath elected his Execution.

Upon a recovery of Dammages in ancient demeÅ¿ne, debt is brought againÅ¿t the Defendant, he Å¿hall not Å¿ay that he owes nothing, but Å¿hall plead Non tiel Recovery, quare 34 Hen. 6.49. A. pl. 15. Littleton. For it Å¿eems he may as well here as upon debt brought upon a recovery in a Court Baron. vide antea.
For an Amerciament in a Leet, that he owes nothing,For fine, or amerciment. by the Law no plea. 12 Rich. 2. Law 33. For a Court-Leet is the Kings Court, and not a baÅ¿e Court.
For an Amerciament in a Court-Baron, that he owes nothing, by the Law a good plea, 12 Rich. 2. Stathan, debt 35. No. Lib. intra. 119. A. Å¿ect. 1. vid. antea.

In Debt upon a Statute Merchant with a defeaÅ¿ance, the Defendant Å¿aid that he was a Lay-man, and not Learned, and that the condition Å¿hould have been but to bind him to pay 40 l. and it was made 60 l. This is a good plea; for the Action is brought as upon an Obligation with a condition; but otherwiÅ¿e if execution be Å¿ued upon it as a Statute, Hil. 9. Jac. Banc. Regis. Fox verÅ¿us Brooke. For then Å¿uch plea comes too late; for the Statute is extended as a Judgment.

Arbitrement is no Bar in debt for arrerages of account before Auditors,Arbitrement. becauÅ¿e the Å¿um being due by matter of Record, ought to be anÅ¿wered by matter of as high a nature, 3 Hen. 4.5. pl. 23. 6. Hen. 4.6. pl. 28. 8 Hen. 5.3. pl. 13. H â¢ ll. 3 Hen. 6.55. A. quaere. 4 Hen. 6.17. pl. 3. 10 Hen. 7.4. A. which an Arbitrement is not.

Debt upon an in Å¿imul computaverunt that he was not accountable by the Countrey, no bar; for where the Defendant may wage his Law, the Contract is not traverÅ¿able, Crooke. 13 Hen. 7.39. pl. 4. For the Action Å¿uppoÅ¿eth that he aÅ¿Å¿ented to the accompt, Å¿o that that is not to be put in iÅ¿Å¿ue.
Nullum fecerunt arbitrium, a good Bar, becauÅ¿e this lies in notice of the Countrey, Crooke. 13 Hen. 7.39. pl. 4. In action of debt upon a Bond, to perform an award.

But if he plead Å¿uch a plea, he cannot rejoyn
afterwards, and Å¿ay that the Arbitrators gave no notice, but muÅ¿t plead it in Bar, and not by way of Rejoynder, Crooke. 7 Hen. 8.155. pl. 8. For Å¿uch a Rejoynder confeÅ¿Å¿es an Award, and the Bar denies it; Å¿o that the Bar and the Rejoynder cannot Å¿tand together.
The Arbitrators gave no notice, no Bar unleÅ¿s the Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion be Å¿o, viz. that the Arbitrators Å¿hould give notice; for elÅ¿e the parties are to take notice at their peril.

The Defendant Å¿aid, that before the Arbitrement made, he diÅ¿charged the Arbitrators; this is a good Bar, 21 Hen. 6.30. 28 Hen. 6.6. Coke 8. part. 82. B. Æ²niors caÅ¿e, and needs not to aver that the Arbitrators had notice; for they muÅ¿t be diÅ¿charged without notice.

Debt upon an Obligation, accord with Å¿atiÅ¿faction is no Bar,Obligation Å¿imple accord. becauÅ¿e the duty being certain, ought to be avoided by matter of as high a nature as it was created, which cannot be by parol. Coke 6. part. 44. A. Blakes caÅ¿e.

But if the duty accrue not until Å¿ome Å¿ubÅ¿equent act be performed, there accord with Å¿atisfaction a good plea, Coke 6. part. 44. A. For there the duty was not certain, but depended upon a matter ex poÅ¿tfacto.

A. obliged to B. in 100 l. Å¿hews 3 Acquittances,Acquittance. 1, of 10 l. 2, of 20 l. and 3, of 20 l. which amount to a receipt of 50 l. parcel of the 100 l. in which he was bound to pay 50 l. this is a good Bar, becauÅ¿e it appears that it was but 50 l. principal debt, for which the Bond was made, though the penalty was 100 l. 43 Edw. 3.31. pl. 26.

Foreign Attachment in London is a good Bar,Attachment. as it Å¿eems, No. Lib. intra. 139. C. Å¿ect. 20. 22 Hen. 6.47. pl. 2. By the CuÅ¿tom there. Q. tamen. for it may be unduly attached, and no Judgment upon it.
But a Legacy cannot be attached, becauÅ¿e it may not be due in reÅ¿pect of payment of the TeÅ¿tators debts, Mich. 14. Jac. Ban. Regis. Vaughans caÅ¿e. and Å¿o it is a thing uncertain.
Attainder of Felony no plea,Attainder. Mich. 38 & 39. Eliz. com. Ban. BaniÅ¿ter verÅ¿us TruÅ¿Å¿elle. in debt, for the Attainder doth not diÅ¿charge the debt.
Nil debet. Nil debet in debt upon a Obligation is no plea, becauÅ¿e an Obligation Å¿hall not be avoided by a nude Averment, but by matter of as high a nature, Doct. & Stud. 22.

Non compos mentis. Non compos mentis pleaded by the party, is no good Bar. Trin. 37. Eliz. ban. Regis. Strode verÅ¿us MarÅ¿hal. vide 5 Edw. 3.70. For the party Å¿hall not plead in his own diÅ¿ability.

Payment without acquittance no plea,Payment. in debt without a Å¿pecialty, 33 Hen. 8. Dyer. 51. pl. 10. Coke 5. part. 43. Doct. & Stud. 22. 20 Hen. 6.3. A. PaÅ¿ton. 26 Hen. 8. Dyer. 6. pl. 3. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer. 25. pl. 160. 41 Edw. 3.7. pl. 15. becauÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be avoided by a matter of as high a nature.

A. by indenture Å¿old Land for 20 l. and there were Covenants in the Deed; for the performing of which, he bound himÅ¿elf in 40 l. Debt was brought for the 40 l. Payment without Acquittance is no plea, 26 Hen. 8. Dyer 6. pl. 3. & fol. 25. becauÅ¿e the Action is grounded upon the Indenture and the Bond.

A Defeazance upon a Statute-Merchant to pay 20 l. thereof without an Acquittance, is a good plea; for the Defeazance is inÅ¿tead of an Acquittance, and this is without bringing an audita querela, when the party is not in execution, 17 Edw. 3.3. pl. 10. For if he be in execution, there he muÅ¿t have an audita querela.

Obligation conditional. A. is bound by obligation to pay his Rent, there payment without an Acquittance is a good bar, 46 Edw. 3.1. pl. 1. becauÅ¿e the obligation was but conditional, and made no preÅ¿ent duty.
When the original contract is for money,Accord. an accord with Å¿atisfaction is a good bar, Coke. 9. part. 79. A. Petoyes caÅ¿e. 22 Edw. 4.25. A. For thereby the contract is diÅ¿charged.
But an accord made with a general receiver is no bar to his MaÅ¿ter, if he had not a Å¿pecial authority, Doct. & Stud. 137. B.

But when the condition of the agreement is for a collateral thing, there an accord is no bar, Coke 9. part. 79. A. 12 Hen. 4.23. 9 Hen. 7.4. 4 Hen. 8. Dyer. 1. For Å¿uch a thing cannot be accorded for.

And if it be before the day of doing the thing, then part of the Å¿um received is a good bar, Coke. 5. part. 117. Pinnels caÅ¿e. 27 Edw. 3.84. to the Action, becauÅ¿e the Action is brought upon the whole Contract, part whereof was diÅ¿charged before the time agreed on for performing it.

But at the day, or after, it is no bar, unleÅ¿s it be in another place, Coke 5. part. 117. Pinnels caÅ¿e. BecauÅ¿e then the whole duty was due upon the entire contract; part received is a good bar in another Country, elÅ¿e the party Å¿hall be without remedy for Å¿o much as he paid.

The Defendant pleads, he paid Å¿o much in full Å¿atisfaction, the which the Plaintiff received, and not that he paid Å¿o much, the which the Plaintiff received in Å¿atisfaction, Coke 5. part. 117. A. Pinnels caÅ¿e, and good; for he muÅ¿t receive the money as it was paid, and not as he will receive it.
Conditions performed.Conditions performed is a good barr, 41 Edw. 3. 10. pl. 7. & fol. 25. pl. 19. Thorpe, in an action of Debt upon a Bond for performance of Conditions.

One pleads part of the Arbitrement,Arbitrement. it Å¿hall be intended all that was arbitrated, until the contrary be Å¿hewed by the other party. 2. The other may Å¿hew the remnant, and traverÅ¿e abÅ¿que hoc, that they arbitrated that only as he pleaded it. 3. The other needs not to rejoyn to more, but joyn iÅ¿Å¿ue, becauÅ¿e elÅ¿e it Å¿hall be a departure from his Plea, which muÅ¿t not be in pleading, PaÅ¿ch. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, LinÅ¿ey verÅ¿us AÅ¿hton.

Condition to levy a Fine.Upon an Obligation with a Condition to levy a fine upon GarniÅ¿hment, the Sheriff returns him garniÅ¿hed in debt, he pleads that he was not by the Law, 28 Edw. 3.100. pl. 42. 29 Edw 3.44. pl. 4. and good; becauÅ¿e it is penal unto him, and the Bond is but conditional, and no preÅ¿ent duty, and therefore the Sheriffs return Å¿hall not bind him.

Deed poll. A enfeoffs B by Deed poll, provided that if he pay 20 l. to B he may re-enter, and is bound to perform all Covenants and Payments contained in the Deed poll; he is not bound to pay the 20 l. for it is at his election to pay it or loÅ¿e the Land, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, BriÅ¿coe verÅ¿us
Knight, Rott. 271. for if the ProviÅ¿o be not performed, the Feoffment is abÅ¿olute, and the Bond is but to Å¿trengthen the Feoffment.

A is bound to B to pay a Å¿um granted by C by Indenture to B, and to levy it of his goods and Chattels, viz. of C; this is void, and therefore no barr in Debt brought by C, 41 Edw. 3.7. pl. 15. Belknap, 46 Edw. 3.18. pl. 17. Belknap. Quaere. A thing void in Law cannot be pleaded in barr.

A Conditions that B Å¿hall leaÅ¿e to C the Land in his occupation,Condition except the Trees, this exception is not good, unleÅ¿s they were excepted in the Original LeaÅ¿e, and then B ought to Å¿hew it, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, Dores caÅ¿e; for he letts him not the land in his occupation, if he had the Trees and excepted them.

A Conditions that LeÅ¿Å¿ee for life Å¿hall make a LeaÅ¿e for 10 years, and he makes one for ten years, if he live Å¿o long; this is good, for it was implied before, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis, per Montague Chief JuÅ¿tice, Woolridge & Banbury; for Å¿uch a LeaÅ¿e could be made but conditionally.

A Condition to deliver Å¿uch a LeaÅ¿e as Å¿hall be deviÅ¿ed by the Judge of the Court of Audience, Non deviÅ¿avit aliquid, &c. is no barr, for he ought to procure him to make one at his peril, Coke 5. part. 23. B. Lambs caÅ¿e, the Pleading. No. Lib. Intr. 130. A. for the Condition is for the Obligors benefit, and therefore he muÅ¿t do his beÅ¿t to Å¿ee it performed.

ImpoÅ¿Å¿ible condition. A is obliged to B in 20 l. upon Condition to pay 10 l. to Å¿uch a perÅ¿on, at Å¿uch a place and
time as B Å¿hould name in his Will, B makes his Will and names none, the Executors Å¿hall not have it, for the Condition is become impoÅ¿Å¿ible, for he ought to be named in deed, Trin. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. PeaÅ¿e & alii verÅ¿us Mead, Mich. 11 Jac. Rott. 945.

The Defendant Å¿aid that he made another obligation to the Plaintiff, the which he did accept in Å¿atisfaction of the former; this is no barr, becauÅ¿e it is but a thing in Action, Mich. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. Rand. & Strut. Trin. 6 Jac. Com Ban. Rott. 10001. Lovelace, and one thing in action cannot be diÅ¿charged with another thing in action.
Payment according to the Condition a good barr, Coke 8. part. 58. A. Beechers caÅ¿e;Payment. but he muÅ¿t Å¿hew the place where he made the payment, 9 Edw. 4.141. B. becauÅ¿s it is material.

Payment of parcel hanging the Writ, is not good to abate the Writ without an Acquittance, 3 Hen. 7.3. pl. 12. 5 Hen. 7.10. pl. 15. 7 Edw. 4.15. Vide 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 6. pl. 3. becauÅ¿e the duty was by Å¿pecialty.

A is bound to B in 10 l. and after the date is a clauÅ¿e that he Å¿hall pay him 5 l. the Obligation is void as to the 10 l. payment there without Acquittance is good, 30 Edw. 3.3. pl. 12. Q. becauÅ¿e the Obligation is void.
But payment after the day is not good without Acquittance, 46 Edw. 3.29. pl. 23. 47 Edw. 3.13. pl. 14. 5 Hen. 7.41. pl. 5. becauÅ¿e then it is a duty veÅ¿ted.

A is bound to pay 20 quarters of Maule, and if he pay it not at the day, then 40 quarters; in Debt for the 40 quarters he may plead payment
of the 20 quarters without Acquittance, becauÅ¿e it is to Å¿ave a penalty; but not in debt for the 20 quarters, 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 24. pl. 154. 1 Hen: 5.7. A. becauÅ¿e that was the original duty.

Three are bound to pay their Rent, one pays it, the other pleads payment without Acquittance, 45 Edw. 3.4. pl. 9. and good; for the payment of one is the payment of all, and he may not have an Acquittance.

A is bound by an Obligation dated 17th of November, 12 Jac. with condition of payment the 19th November next enÅ¿uing, per Curiam payment 19th November 13 Jac. is Å¿ufficient, for it Å¿hall not be intended 19th November in the Å¿ame month, Mich. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. Price & Coe; for it Å¿hall not be intended that an Obligation Å¿hould be made for two days, and the next enÅ¿uing Å¿hall relate to the month and not the day.

ConuÅ¿ee of a Statute had Execution for 20 l. and by Indenture grants, that if the ConuÅ¿or pay 8 l. at a day to come, the Statute Å¿hall be void; this is a good diÅ¿charge, 20 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 7. Quaert, whether the Statute or the Execution Å¿hall be void.
Payment to a Deputy a good barr, 42 Edw. 13. pl. 35 Q. what Deputy.
Payment to the Baily of a BiÅ¿hop without his command is a good barr, 22 Edw. 4.25. pl. 5. for it is payment to the BiÅ¿hop.
But payment to a Servant without command is no barr, unleÅ¿s it comes to the uÅ¿e of his MaÅ¿ter, Doct. & Stud. 38. A. for a Servant as a Servant is no Receiver.
Payment to a Creditor of the Obligee by his command is a good barr, 46 Edw. 3.33. pl. 45. Perkins 145. A. for it is a payment to himÅ¿elf, being for his benefit.
But then he ought to Å¿hew that the Creditor was the Creditor of the Obligee, 27 Hen. 6.6. pl. 1. viz. in his plea.

In debt upon an Obligation with a Condition to pay 20 l. to B aÅ¿Å¿oon as he comes to the Age of 21 years. 1. The Defendant ought to Å¿hew in performance of the Condition, that B is of full Age. 2. He ought to Å¿hew the place where he paid it, for otherwiÅ¿e there cannot be any traverÅ¿e, Mich. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, HalÅ¿e.
Condition to permit one to enjoy,Permit. &c. he pleads that he did permit him, and good, 10 Eliz. Dyer 279. pl. 6. for that anÅ¿wers the Condition fully.
The Defendant Å¿aid that the Plaintiff was indebted to him,Retainer. and that he commanded him to retain it, a good barr, 22 Edw. 4.25.65. for Å¿uch retainer is Å¿atisfaction in Law.
Barr general to an obligation. Acquittance.Acquittance a good barr, from the party himÅ¿elf.

But an Acquittance by a general Receiver without receipt of the money by his MaÅ¿ter, is not good, unleÅ¿s he be Receiver by deed, and hath authority to make Acquittances, Doct. & Stud. 137. B. for then his MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall be eÅ¿topped by the deed, to Å¿ay he was not his Receiver.

A brought debt in Ban. Regis againÅ¿t B, and that depending brought debt for the Å¿ame debt in London, and had goods attached in the hands of C, and had judgment upon them; this is a good
barr in debt, brought by B againÅ¿t C for the goods attached: but if A brings debt againÅ¿t B, and after the debt is attached in London, and Judgment given there, if the Creditor Å¿ue B he cannot plead the Attachment in barr, becauÅ¿e he might have pleaded it to the Action brought againÅ¿t him in Com. Ban. Mich. 39 & 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. Jaques verÅ¿us Lewkner, in barr of the Action brought in London, and Å¿o have avoided the Attachment.

A Debt is attachable before the day in which it is payable, becauÅ¿e it is a duty, and the debtor debet, although non detinet; but an obligation made to perform Covenants is not attachable, Mich. 39 & 40 Eliz. Com. Ban. Beacher verÅ¿us Minors; for this is incertain whether it may ever become a duty.
Coverture a good barr,Coverture. Lib. Intr. 168. B. Å¿ect. 1. in an Action of debt brought againÅ¿t a Feme Covert, upon an obligation made during Coverture.
Infancy a good barr,Infancy. Lib. Intra. 163. A. Å¿ect. 1. for an Infant cannot be bound, nor contract to his prejudice.

Non eÅ¿t factum. Non eÅ¿t factum a good barr, but not if the deed be inrolled, 16 Hen. 5. B. 9 Hen. 6.60. A. Babington, 39 Hen. 6.32. pl. 45. becauÅ¿e the party hath acknowledged it to be his deed before the Judge or MaÅ¿ter of the Chancery.

When a deed is but voidable, non eÅ¿t factum no plea, Coke the 5. part. 119. A. WhelpÅ¿dales caÅ¿e, 11 Hen. 7.15. for non eÅ¿t factum is a plea to deÅ¿troy the deed, and to make it abÅ¿olutely void, and not ad libitum.

When an obligation is once good, and after and before the plea becomes void, non eÅ¿t factum may be pleaded, Coke 5. part. 119. A, B. WhelpÅ¿dales caÅ¿e; for the Plea was true at the time of the pleading of it, which Å¿ufficeth to make the Plea good.

When 3 are bound Å¿eparatim, and the Seal of one is broken, the other cannot plead non eÅ¿t factum, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿everal Obligations, Coke 5. part. A. MathewÅ¿ons caÅ¿e; otherwiÅ¿e it is where they are joyntly bound.
But it is not Å¿o when 3 are bound without any more, Coke 11. part. 28. B. Pigots caÅ¿e; 3 Hen. 7.5. Coke 5. part. 23. A. for there they Å¿hall be intended to be joyntly bound.
But if two be bound in debt againÅ¿t one only it cannot be pleaded, Coke 5. part. 119. A. WhelpÅ¿dales caÅ¿e; for it is the debt of both of them.
A Recovery in an inferiour Court of Record with Execution a good barr,Recovery. Coke 6. part. 45. B. Higgins caÅ¿e; but not, if it be not in a Court of Record, or if there be no Execution.
But without Execution not, Coke 6. part. 45. A. for that is all one as if there were no Recovery had, and Å¿o there is no Å¿atisfaction.
A Recovery is a good barr Å¿o long as it is in force, viz. if it be in one of the Courts at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, Coke 3. part. 44 B. Higgins caÅ¿e.
ReleaÅ¿e a good barr:ReleaÅ¿e. A ReleaÅ¿e deÅ¿troys the duty, and conÅ¿equently the remedy to recover it.

Two bound to B, who makes the wife of one of them his Executrix, and deviÅ¿es his goods to her; this is a good releaÅ¿e of the debt, for the debt is part of his goods; for if the obligee make
the wife of the Obligor his Executrix; this is a ReleaÅ¿e in Law to the husband, becauÅ¿e the Obligation is Å¿uÅ¿pended pro tempore by the act of the party himÅ¿elf, Trin. 12 Jao. Com. Ban. Fryer verÅ¿us Gildridg; for the wife cannot Å¿ue the husband to recover the debt.
A ReleaÅ¿e of all advantages in account, a good barr in debt upon an account, 9 Edw. 4.49. Coke 8. part. 152. A. Althams caÅ¿e; for Arrearages are advantages ariÅ¿ing upon the account.
A is bound to B to the uÅ¿e of C, the releaÅ¿e of C is a good barr, 36 Hen. 8. br. Obligation 27. becauÅ¿e the Obligation was for the benefit of C, and Å¿o upon the matter he was bound to C.

The Defendant Å¿aid that the agreement was for the obtaining a Benefice;Simony. this is nought, 1. BecauÅ¿e the Statute makes the contract void, becauÅ¿e Simoniacal. 2. It cannot be averred out of it, being a matter dehors and not appearing, Mich. 40 & 41 Eliz. Com. Ban. Gregorie verÅ¿us Olden.

The Defendant pleads that the Obligee accepted of a Statute for the Obligation after the day of payment;Statute. this is no barr, becauÅ¿e the Obligation is in force notwithÅ¿tanding the acceptance, for ought appears to the contrary, Coke 6. part. 44. B. Higgins caÅ¿e.

The condition of a Counter-bond was to Å¿ave the Surety harmleÅ¿s; it is no plea that the former Bond was uÅ¿urious,Statute-Law. becauÅ¿e the Counter-bond was not for payment of money, but to Å¿ave harmleÅ¿s, Mich. 40 & 41 Eliz. Com. Ban. Dowman verÅ¿us Button, and Å¿o it matters not to him upon what conÅ¿ideration the former Bond was entred into.

div.head: The Judgment in Debt.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t an Executor.The Judgment, Lib. intra 173. B. Å¿ect. 1.

Arrerages of account, the Executor pleads no Å¿uch account, or nothing in arrear or outlary in the Plaintiff, and it is found againÅ¿t him, the Judgment Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 34 Hen. 6.22. A. Danby, and not de bonis propriis, for here is no devaÅ¿tavit. Q.
A Covenant broken after the death of the TeÅ¿tator, the Judgment Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 15 Eliz. Dyer. 324. pl. 34. For the Covenant concerns him only as Executor.
Nothing in Arrear in Debt for rent due in vita TeÅ¿tatoris, or no Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e, the Judgment Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 34 Hen. 6.22. A. Danby. For Å¿uch pleas an Executor may plead.

An Acquittance or a ReleaÅ¿e pleaded and found againÅ¿t him, if it be pleaded made to the Executor, the Judgment Å¿hall be general. 11 Hen. 6.8. A. Danby. 34 Hen. 6.24. A. PriÅ¿ot. Quod recuperet de bonis propriis.

Non AÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it of the TeÅ¿tator to pay the debt, the Judgment is of coÅ¿ts and dammages of Å¿uit de bonis propriis, if the TeÅ¿tator had not Å¿ufficient. No. Lib. intra. 1. B. Å¿ect. 1. for putting the Plaintiff to a needleÅ¿s Å¿uit, which it is likely the TeÅ¿tator would not have done.

The Executor found in a CheÅ¿t a Grant of the next avoidance of an advowÅ¿on made to the TeÅ¿tator, and preÅ¿entation thereupon in a Recovely in a quare impedit, againÅ¿t him, the Judgment Å¿hall be of his proper Goods, 34 Hen. 6.22. B.
PriÅ¿ot. For he Å¿hall not prejudice the TeÅ¿tators EÅ¿tate by his own wrong.

Co-executor pleads, and found againÅ¿t him, the Judgment Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 9 Hen. 6.44. 11 Hen. 6.7. 34 Hen. 6.32. A. as well as where both are Å¿ued; for one Executor may anÅ¿wer if he pleaÅ¿e.

ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Action by the Executor, where he ought not to have done it, the Judgment Å¿hall be general againÅ¿t him, viz. de bonis propriis, becauÅ¿e he ought to have pleaded that he had not more than 20 s. and againÅ¿t the other Executor it Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 14 Hen. 4.12. pl. 1. Hull; for he is in no fault, and Å¿hall not therefore be puniÅ¿hed for his companions ill pleading.

And by 33 Hen. 6.2. it Å¿hall be of the goods of the TeÅ¿tator, if the Executor hath none for the dammages of the goods of the Executor that confeÅ¿Å¿es the action; becauÅ¿e the Plaintiff may otherwiÅ¿e loÅ¿e his dammages.
But 4 Eliz. Dyer. 210. pl. 23. it Å¿hall be but de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris in both caÅ¿es, 28 Hen. 6.3. pl. 13. 40 Edw. 3.2.7. pl. 3. Q. Ergo.
So in a rationabili parte bonorum upon confeÅ¿Å¿ion of one Executor, 28 Hen. 6.4. pl. 20. 33 Hen. 6.24. pl. 1.

Ne unques Executor found againÅ¿t him Å¿hal be general, 11 Hen. 4.5. 11 Hen. 6.8. A. Danby. de bonis propriis for his falÅ¿e plea; for his falÅ¿hood Å¿hall not prejudice the TeÅ¿tators EÅ¿tate, if he can make Å¿atisfaction.

But the Judgment Å¿hall be de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris,
ãâã &c. and if not de bonis propriis, 9 Hen. 7.15.
pl. 1. 2 Edw. 4.4. 33 Hen. 6.23. 11 Hen. 6.10. B. Q.

One pleads ne unques Executor, the other plenÃ¨ adminiÅ¿travit, all but 40 s. and found againÅ¿t the former, and Judgment given that there Å¿hould be recovered againÅ¿t both as much as there was in their hands, and the reÅ¿idue againÅ¿t the other, 11 Hen. 6.37. B. PaÅ¿ton. 46 Edw. 3.9. B. for his falÅ¿e plea, and it Å¿hall be intended that he hath aÅ¿Å¿ets, elÅ¿e he would have pleaded Å¿o, and not a Å¿hifting plea.

One dies inteÅ¿tate, and AdminiÅ¿tration is committed to D, by the Ordinary, and the Defendant pleads that he comes as Å¿ervant to D. to adminiÅ¿ter, abÅ¿que hoc that he did adminiÅ¿ter in any other manner; this is no plea, becauÅ¿e he did not Å¿hew that it was the Ordinary of the place, and Judgment de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, 31 Hen. 6.13. pl. 5. as he ought, becauÅ¿e it is traverÅ¿able. This is an unskilful, and not a falÅ¿e plea, therefore the Judgment Å¿hall not be de bonis propriis.

17 Edw. 3.20. pl. 58. where one Executor pleaded non factum, and found againÅ¿t him, there the Judgment was againÅ¿t him of the goods of his own, as well as of the goods of the TeÅ¿tator, and againÅ¿t the other, of the goods that he had at the day of the Writ, vide 17 Edw. 3.20. pl. 1. Å¿tat. 9 Edw. 3. cap. 3. Å¿tatute 1.17 Edw. 3.46. pl. 3. becauÅ¿e by the Deed the TeÅ¿tators EÅ¿tate is chargeable, and by the falÅ¿e plea his own.

In PlenÃ¨ adminiÅ¿travit pleaded, the Judgment was for Å¿o much of the principal debt as they had, and for the dammages de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, Å¿i, &c. if there were Å¿ufficient, and if not, then for dammages
de bonis propriis, and for the reÅ¿idue, as much as they had, Coke 8. part 134. Shipleys caÅ¿e. 34 Hen. 6.32. B. PriÅ¿ot. com. 440. B. Pepyes caÅ¿e. vide 17 Edw. 3.66. pl. 83. 46 Edw. 3.9. pl. 6. Judgment Å¿pecial for the debt.

Upon Å¿uch a plea of the Defendant the Plaintiff may pray execution forthwith, becauÅ¿e it is a confeÅ¿Å¿ion of the debt; but no execution Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue, until the Defendant hath goods of the TeÅ¿tators, Coke 8. part. Shipleys caÅ¿e. vide 21 Hen. 6.40.
But if it be found for the Plantiff, no Å¿cire facias lies againÅ¿t them, 4 Hen. 6.4. pl. 8. Q.
UnleÅ¿s he prays Judgment upon the plea.

But yet 33 Hen. 6.24. pl. 1. is, That a Å¿cire facias lies; yet Coke 8. part 53. A. Syms his 04 caÅ¿e, that if it be for Land, he Å¿hall not have a Å¿cire facias, becauÅ¿e there is no Record upon which it may be founded. Q.

AgainÅ¿t an heir.In debt, if the heir confeÅ¿s the Action for as much as did deÅ¿cend, then there Å¿hall be a Å¿pecial Judgment againÅ¿t him of Å¿o much as did deÅ¿cend, Com. 440. A. Pepyes. caÅ¿e. 22 Eliz. Dyer. 373. pl. 4. the Judgment Lib. intra. 172. D. and he Å¿hall be charged for no more.
But if he plead any other plea, and it be found againÅ¿t him, the Judgment Å¿hall be general, Com. 440. Pepyes caÅ¿e for the whole, for his falÅ¿e plea.

So if he confeÅ¿s the Action, and Å¿hew as much as deÅ¿cends, if it appear to the Court that the profits of the Land from the time of the deÅ¿cent, until the time of the execution, are Å¿ufficient for the debt, the Judgment Å¿hall be general, elÅ¿e not. per Dyer. 18 Eliz. Dyer. 344. pl. 1.

Execution in debt.
1. For the Plaintiff.
2. For the Defendant.
3. Of what Lands.
4. Of what Goods.
At the Common Law it was but a fieri facias, Coke 3. part. 12. or a levari facias, Coke 3. part. 12. A. and this is of Chattels and Profits of Lands and Rents, com. 441. A. Pepyes caÅ¿e.

And this only within the year; for if the year were paÅ¿t, the party was put to his action of debt upon the Indictment, Coke 3. part 12. A. Herberts caÅ¿e, unleÅ¿s the proceÅ¿s be continued, 33 Hen. 6.49. pl. 33. For if it be continued, then is the cauÅ¿e Å¿till freÅ¿h before them, otherwiÅ¿e the Court will take no notice of it.

But for a recovery againÅ¿t an heir, then it was but a Liberate of the Land, Com. 441. A. Pepyes caÅ¿e. Lib. Intra. 172. D. 173. A. 3 Edw. 3. Execution, 107. For the heir is only bound in reÅ¿pect of the Lands deÅ¿cended to him.
But by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 45, a Scire facias was given after the year, and per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 18. an Elegit was given, Coke 3. part. 12. A.

If a man have an Elegit filed on Record, and there be a Nichil returned, he Å¿hall never have any other Execution, 19 Hen. 6.4. 5 Edw. 4.41. 15 Hen. 7.15. Fairfax. for it is the laÅ¿t and higheÅ¿t Execution; and the Court cannot deÅ¿cend Ã majore ad minorem executionem. But if it be not filed, it is otherwiÅ¿e.

And by the Stat. of 25 Edw. 3. cap. 17. a Capias was given in debt; and per conÅ¿equence a Capias ad Å¿atisfaciendum in execution of a Judgment,
in debt, Coke 3. part. 12. A. Harberts caÅ¿e. Fo â¢ it is reaÅ¿on an Execution may be of as high a nature as the mean proceÅ¿s in the Action was, and ãâã the Å¿ame nature.

Mich. 41 & 42 Eliz. com. Ban. if the Plaintif â¢ die after Execution, yet the Sheriff may levy ãâã and if there be no Executor or AdminiÅ¿trator, the Moneys Å¿hall remain in Court until AdminiÅ¿tration. Q. whether the Ordinary may not ha â¢â¢ it. But if the Defendant die before Execution, there the Sheriff cannot make Execution; ãâã the words of the Writ are, That it Å¿hall be levied of the Goods of the Defendant. Thoroughgu â¢â¢
caÅ¿e. Q if it may not be againÅ¿t the Executor, becauÅ¿e the TeÅ¿tators Goods in their hands may be Å¿aid to be the Defendants Goods.

Upon a non eÅ¿t inventus returned of the Principal upon a Capias upon a Judgment in com. Ban. the party Å¿hall have Execution againÅ¿t the Ba â¢â¢ , becauÅ¿e the debt being by Original is certain; ãâã it is mentioned particularly in the Writ, and there the Lands of the Bail, which they had ãâã the day of the taking the recognizance, Å¿hall be liable, but quaere in ban. Regis, if more Lands a â¢â¢ liable than they had the day of the Judgment, becauÅ¿e the debt is uncertain, Mich. 15. Jac. Ban Regis, Baskervile & Brocket. Å¿pecial verdict.
The Defendant for Dammages and CoÅ¿ts Å¿hall have the Å¿ame execution as the Plantiff Å¿hould have had, if he had recovered againÅ¿t the Defendant, per 23 Hen. 8. cap. 15.

Viz. Of the Lands which he had at the ãâã of the Judgment, and not before, Coke 8. pa â¢â¢
171. Fleetwoods caÅ¿e. 42 Edw. 3.11. pl. 13. â¢
Edw. 193. pl. 14.

But if the Judgment be the laÅ¿t day of the Term, the Lands which he had the firÅ¿t day of the Term are liable, becauÅ¿e all the Term is but one day in Law, 42 AÅ¿Å¿iz. 17. as to the Judgment; for a Judgment given the laÅ¿t day is a Judgment of the firÅ¿t day.

If two Joint-Tenants are for life, and one of them and againÅ¿t whom the Judgment is given, dies before execution, this Å¿hall not be put in execution, 13 Hen. 7.22. A. viz. againÅ¿t the other, becauÅ¿e he was not party.

Land in ancient demeÅ¿ne Å¿hall be put in execution, Coke 5. part. 105. A. Aldens caÅ¿e. Hill. 11. Jac. Com. Ban. Rot. 2541. Cox & BarneÅ¿ly. upon a Judgment in debt given at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter; for the judgment is well given.

The Goods that he had at the time of the execution Å¿hall be only liable to execution, Coke part. 171. A. Fleetwoods caÅ¿e. 2. Hen. 4.14. 9 Hen. 6.58. 11 Hen. 4.7. 34 Hen. 6.23. B. PriÅ¿ot. 21 Hen. 7.87. pl. 1. Crooke.
UnleÅ¿s it be in caÅ¿e of Executors, 34 Hen. 6.23. B. PriÅ¿ot. For they may have other goods of the TeÅ¿tator come to their hands afterward.
But Å¿ale by covin after Judgment cannot hinder the execution, 22 AÅ¿Å¿iz. 72. 13 Hen 4.4. pl. 9. Q. if Å¿ale be made pending the Suit before Judgment by covin.

Hill. 40. Eliz. Com. Ban. per Curiam, if a Writ of execution be awarded for debt or dammages, and between the TeÅ¿t of the Writ and Execution, the party Å¿old the goods bona fide, yet theÅ¿e are liable to the execution. Q. If Å¿o, where the Vendee knows not of the Judgment;
for it Å¿eems hard, and yet it Å¿eems as hard on the other Å¿ide alÅ¿o.

div.head: Ejectment.
In what Court it lies.
div.p: IT lies not in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, Coke. 10. part. 72. A. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey. For no Title for Land could be tried there.

list.item: In the Exchequer it lies for a party priviledged, Coke 1. part. 3. A. Pelhams caÅ¿e; and this was by Bill. It Å¿eems it lies as well on the Pleas Å¿ide, and more properly than by Bill.

div.p: But if it be for ancient demeÅ¿ne-Land, it lies not in the Court of the King, Coke. 5. part. 105. A. Aldens caÅ¿e. 9. part. 77. B. but in the Court of the Mannor by their priviledge; but by conÅ¿ent it may be, as it Å¿eems, tried elÅ¿ewhere.
BecauÅ¿e the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion is to be removed in Å¿uch action, per Hobart Chief JuÅ¿tice, Hill. 11. Jac. com. Ban. Rot. 25.41. Cox verÅ¿us Barnibee.
But none can plead this out ter-tenant of the Land in ancient demeÅ¿ne, becauÅ¿e the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion doth only concern him, 2 Hen. 7.17. pl. 1.

But if the Plaintiff do not put in his declaration until the end of the Term, the Defendant cannot plead ancient demeÅ¿ne the next Term, but muÅ¿t move the Court that the Plaintiff put in his declaration Å¿o late, and pray no advantage may be taken againÅ¿t him, and then the advantage Å¿hall be Å¿aved, Trin. 12. Jac. Ban. Regis. and he Å¿hall have liberty by rule of Court to plead ancient demeÅ¿ne the next Term.
But he may plead this after view, becauÅ¿e by this he may confeÅ¿s if it be frank fee or not, 50 Edw. 3.9. pl. 20. Q.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have an Ejectione firmae.
div.p: LeÅ¿Å¿ee for years only Å¿hall have it,PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion. Nat. br. 120. F. becauÅ¿e this action is only to recover the preÅ¿ent poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and concerns not the Title, but ex obliquo, or collaterally.

And this only upon the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in deed; for he Å¿hall not have it upon a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in Law, 23 Hen. 8. br. quia ejecit, infra, &c. 5. For that is not an actual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿o there is no preÅ¿ent diÅ¿turbance.
Nor upon a LeaÅ¿e to commence in futuro, 37 Hen. 6.18. A. For the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, and it may be it may never come in eÅ¿se.

Note that Tenant for years needs not count that he entred,Note. but that a LeaÅ¿e was made to him, by virtue of which he has poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed, com. 503. B. Grendons caÅ¿e. For the Word PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿uppoÅ¿eth an Entry, or at leaÅ¿t a taking of the Profits.

Tenant for years leaÅ¿es to B. at will, who is outed by a Å¿tranger, tenant for years Å¿hall not have an action, becauÅ¿e he had not the actual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, PaÅ¿ch. 11 Jac. in the Exchequer inter Sir Richard Grebham & Stone. Q. if Tenant at will may for the feebleneÅ¿s of his eÅ¿tate; it Å¿eems he may.

Tenant for years.Tenant for years leaÅ¿es for one year, or a LeaÅ¿e is made for years, the remainder for years, a Å¿tranger enters, none Å¿hall have an ejectment but the Tenant in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Crooke 130. pl. 99. for none elÅ¿e is diÅ¿turbed.
LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall have an ejectment after the term ended,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. and recover all in dammages, 21 Edw. 4.30. pl. 25. Brian. 7 Edw. 4.6. B. Fairfax: For other remedy he hath not to recover them.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee which may have a real Action, cannot have an ejectione firmae, Com. 419. B. Bracebridges caÅ¿e. For real Actions are to be preferred before poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ory and perÅ¿onal, becauÅ¿e of a higher nature, and thereby juÅ¿tice is more Å¿peedily done.

Husband and wife.Husband and Wife ought to to join, if it be in right of the Wife, 21 Edw. 4.10. pl. 1.30. pl. 25. 7 Edw. 4.6. B. Fairfax. Com. 418. B. Bracebridges caÅ¿e. For the Husband cannot declare of a LeaÅ¿e made to himÅ¿elf, though he be intereÅ¿Å¿ed in it by reaÅ¿on of the Marriage; and the LeaÅ¿e may come again to the Wife by his Death.
But if the term be ended, the Husband alone Å¿hall have it, becauÅ¿e nothing Å¿hall be recovered but dammages, 7 Edw. 4.6. B. Fairfax. Which do only concern the Husband.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee for one year of a Copy-holder Å¿hall have an ejection firm, Coke 4. part. 26, For he is a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿or for a term of years, becauÅ¿e the time is certain, and of leÅ¿s term certain than for years the Law takes no notice.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee of a Copy-hold for more years,Copy-hold. Å¿hall have an ejection firm, although that Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e be a forfeiture, for it is a good LeaÅ¿e againÅ¿t all but the Lord, Trin. 36 Eliz. Ban. Regis. Downings caÅ¿e; and it may be the Lord will take no advantage of it.
Executor of a LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall have it,Executors No. Lib. intra. 195. D. Å¿ect. 6. becauÅ¿e the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion is come to him, and he is damnified by the diÅ¿turbance.
Executor Plaintiff, Husband and Wife Coexecutors, Defendants, and the Count. Lib. intra. 252. B. Å¿ect. 6.
Executor Å¿hall have an ejection firm in vita TeÅ¿tatoris, per the equity of the Statute, 4 Edw. 3. cap. 6. Coke 9. part. 78. B. Peytoes caÅ¿e. elÅ¿e he Å¿hould loÅ¿e the term.

Churchwardens Å¿hall have it of Land leaÅ¿ed to them, 15 Hen. 7.8. in right of the Church,Church-wardens. for it is their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion pro tempore. Q. If new be elected before the trial, what Å¿hall be done.
Tenant by Elegit. Tenant by Elegit Å¿hall not have an ejectione firmae, Crooke 109. pl. 29. For he hath no certain term; for the Owner may redeem the Land when he will.
Tenant in common.Tenant in Common Å¿hall have it againÅ¿t his Companion, Littleton. 73. A. For they have diÅ¿tinct intereÅ¿ts in Law.

Father and Son having Å¿everal inheritances in divers Lands, the Father levies a Fine of it all, the Son being beyond Å¿ea at the time, dies, his IÅ¿Å¿ue enters and leaÅ¿es it (being within Age) to A, without rendring any Rent, A. enters, the ConuÅ¿ee of the Fine enters, and leaÅ¿es it to B, yet B. Å¿hall not have an ejectione firmae againÅ¿t A, if he be outed, without expreÅ¿s outing of A, becauÅ¿e as to the moyery the Plantiff had not title; for of that the Father might levie the Fine, and the Defendant had none, becauÅ¿e there was no Rent reÅ¿erved, and Å¿o had for the preÅ¿ent nothing in the Land, PaÅ¿ch. 32 Eliz. com. ban. Rot. 1017. Smye verÅ¿us June, and others.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Ejectment lies.
div.p: Husband and wife.It lies againÅ¿t Husband and Wife, Lib. intra. 253. C. Å¿ect 11. Coke 9. part. 77. B. Petoyes caÅ¿e. Com. 187. Wortleyes caÅ¿e. Where the Husband outs one by colour of his Wifes Title.

It lies againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger that wrongfully outs one,EÅ¿tranger. 6 Rich. 2. Ejection. firm. 2. 21 Edw. 4.30. pl. 25. Brian. Nat. br. 220. F. Coke 9. part. 80. A. 32 Hen. 6.32.27. S. to gain the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and to recover dammages for the diÅ¿turbance.

It lies not againÅ¿t a Feoffee of a LeÅ¿Å¿or,Feoffee. becauÅ¿e he cannot do wrong, Nat. br. 198. A. 21 Edw. 4.10. pl. 1. Choke. 21 Edw. 4.30. 32 Hen 6.32. pl. 27. 38 Edw. 3.33. pl. 44. For
he comes in lawfully as to the reverÅ¿ion.
UnleÅ¿s the Feoffee make a Deed preÅ¿ently upon the outing, to paÅ¿s the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion to another, then it lies againÅ¿t him, Nat. br. 198. A.
Or if he enter upon the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, afterwards that the LeÅ¿Å¿ee had entred upon him, to regain his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Nat. br. 198. A.

LeÅ¿Å¿or grants a ReverÅ¿ion to A, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee attornes,Grantor. A outs him, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall have an ejectione firmae, Nat. br. 221. A. 1 Hen. 5.3. pl. 3. For by the Attornment only the Rent and the ReverÅ¿ion paÅ¿Å¿ed, and not the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
It lies againÅ¿t the Heir of the LeÅ¿Å¿or,Heir. Nat. br. 198. K. if he out the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, in caÅ¿e his AnceÅ¿tor had power to leaÅ¿e.

It lies againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or that outs the LeÅ¿Å¿ee,LeÅ¿Å¿or. Nat. br. 220. F. 21 Edw. 4.10. pl. 1. Choke 30. pl. 25. 38 Edw 3.33. pl. 44. Coke 9. part. 80. A. Nat. br. 198. K. without lawful cauÅ¿e, and he Å¿hall make title by the LeÅ¿Å¿or.

LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿uffers a Recovery,Recoverer the Recoverer outs the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, he Å¿hall have an Ejectione firmae againÅ¿t the Recoverer by the equity of the Statute, 21 Hen. 8. cap. 15. Nat. br. 220. J. 198. E. For the Recovery Å¿hall not deÅ¿troy the LeaÅ¿e, except the LeÅ¿Å¿ee be party to it.
It lies againÅ¿t the Lord per EÅ¿cheat,Lord. which outs one, Nat. br. 221. I. B. 198. K. For the LeÅ¿Å¿ees Title was para â¢â¢ ount the Lords.
It lies againÅ¿t the Lord of a Villain which enters upon the Termor, Nat. br. 221. C. 198. K. that had a LeaÅ¿e of the Land before the Villain purchaÅ¿ed it.
Tenant in common.It lies againÅ¿t Tenant in common per his companion, Littleton 73. A. vid. antea.

div.head: Of what things an Ejectmont lies.
div.p: It lies upon a LeaÅ¿e for Cattel,Cattel. becauÅ¿e it is a perÅ¿onal thing, 1 Hen. 6.1. CotteÅ¿more. granted for a certain time.
It lies of a Wood leaÅ¿ed for years,Wood. Com. 223. B. Barkleyes caÅ¿e, the count there.
It lies of a Chamber,Chamber. Mich. 30. Eliz. Ban. Regis. Brand againÅ¿t Cage.
It lies of Tithes,Tithes. per 32 Hen. 8. cap. 7.2, 3 Mariae, Dyer. 116 pl. 17. the count ought to Å¿hew the nature or quality of the Tithes, Coke 11. part. 24. B. Harpers caÅ¿e. vid. antea.
It lies of a Garden,Gardon, &c. Barn and Tithes, 9 Eliz. Dyer. 258. pl. 16. together, for they are all perÅ¿onal things.

But if all the Tithing conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of a modus decimandi, and a LeaÅ¿e be made thereof, an ejectione firmae lies not, Coke 11. part. 25. B. Harpers caÅ¿e. For there is no poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of any thing lett but things which lie in prender.
It lies of a Water-courÅ¿e,WatercourÅ¿e. Com. 288. B. Brown. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 227. B. viz. of the Å¿oil where the water runs, or for the water to paÅ¿s through.
It lies of a Hundred,Hundred. becauÅ¿e it is liberum tenementum, 15 Hen. 7.8. pl. 1. and Å¿o it may be lett for years.

It lies of a Mannor,Mannor. and the Writ RegiÅ¿t. orig. 227. B. Nat. br. 220. G. Com. 229. A. Barkleyes caÅ¿e. which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in demeÅ¿nes and
Å¿ervices. Q. of a reputative Mannor.
The Count. Lib. intra. 252. A. Å¿ect. 4.
Count of a DemiÅ¿e of 300 Acres by the name of a Mannor: habendum Manerium cum, &c. and good, 13 & 14 Eliz. Dyer. 340. pl. 5.7. for this is a good deÅ¿cription of the thing lett.
It lies of a MeÅ¿Å¿uage,MeÅ¿Å¿uage. Coke 11. part. 55. A. Sauls caÅ¿e. For that is a thing certain.
The Count No. Lib. intra. 184. A. Å¿ect. 1.3.197. C. Å¿ect. Lib. intra. 252. B. Å¿ect. 5.6. Coke 1. part. A. Pelhams caÅ¿e.
It lies of a HouÅ¿e, Goods and Chattels altogether.
The Count lib. intra. 252. B. Å¿ect. 7. For they are all perÅ¿onal things.
It lies de medietate MeÅ¿Å¿uagii, Lib. intra. 256. D. Å¿ect. 14. The Count, Com. 459. B. Studs caÅ¿e. For it is certain enough what it doth mean..
It lies de tribus partibus duorum MeÅ¿Å¿uagiorum, No. Lib. intra. 195. D. Å¿ect. 6.

It is not formal to have it of a Chappel,Chappel. but it Å¿hall be called a HouÅ¿e, Coke 11. part. 25. B. Harpers caÅ¿e. For the Plaint in AÅ¿Å¿ize Å¿hall not be of â¢ o HoÅ¿pital, but Å¿hall Å¿ay MeÅ¿Å¿uage, 8. AÅ¿Å¿ize 29. For the Law takes no notice of LeaÅ¿es of Å¿uch things, not what is meant by them as to lay uÅ¿e.
It lies of a Mill,Mill. No. Lib. intra. 192. A. Å¿ect. 5. But it Å¿eems he muÅ¿t Å¿hew what kind of Mill it is.
It lies of 300 Acres of PaÅ¿ture,PaÅ¿ture. the Count Lib. intra. 251. D. Å¿ect. 2.
It lies of a LeaÅ¿e of paÅ¿turing of an Oxe,Oxe. Com. 228 B. Brown. RegiÅ¿t. 227. B.
It lies of 100 Acres of Meadow,Medow. Lib. Intra. 252. A. Å¿ect. 13.
It lies of a Rectory,Rectory. 15 Hen. 8. pl. 1. 16 Hen. 7.8. pl. 6.13 & 14 Eliz. Dyer. 304. pl. 25. The Count Lib. intra. 253. A. Å¿ect. 9, 10. For it Å¿eems that is certainly known. Q.
It lies not of a ReverÅ¿ion.ReverÅ¿ion. Com. 159. B. Thracies CaÅ¿e per Dyer. For of that there can be no poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion recovered.
It lies of 100 Acres of Land:Land. The Count Lib. intra. 251. C. Å¿ect. 1. For it Å¿hall be intended arable Land; terra dicitur Ã terendo, becauÅ¿e broken up by the Plough.

But it lies not of a CloÅ¿e containing three Acres, but Å¿hall be of Å¿o many of the Acres by name. Coke. 11. part. 55. Savels CaÅ¿e. to wit, 3 Acres called Crowlands, or the like; for the word CloÅ¿e is uncertain.
For by Crooke JuÅ¿tice, Mich. 15 Jac. Wicks & Sparrow, the Land of every man is encloÅ¿ed, and therefore an Ejectione firmae cannot lie of it for the uncertainty of the word CloÅ¿e.

But Coke 11 part. 55. Savels CaÅ¿e was, it Å¿eems, that if it be of a CloÅ¿e containing three acres of PaÅ¿ture, it is good; becauÅ¿e the quantity is Å¿hewed, and alÅ¿o the quality which makes it more certain, and Å¿o it was adjudged, Mich. 15. Jac. Banc. Regis. Q. tamen. For it may be more certain.

It lies not of a piece of ground called Michels piece, Trin. 38 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rot. 450. Palmer & Humphreys; for that is incertain both in the quantity and quality, and other Lands may be called of the Å¿ame name, and Å¿o that makes no certainty in it.
It lies not of a virge of Land, 38 Eliz. Rot. 453. Mell verÅ¿us Moor, for that may be incertain, and may differ in reÅ¿pect of the place.

div.head: The Count Generally.
div.p: If it be of a LeaÅ¿e made by a BiÅ¿hop,BiÅ¿hop. it ought to count upon the Deed, No. Lib. Intr. 186. D. Sect. 2. and Å¿et it forth; becauÅ¿e it is not an ordinary LeaÅ¿e whereof the Law takes notice.

But if it be of a LeaÅ¿e made by the husband and wife,Husband and wife. he needs not count that it was by Indenture, Lib. Intra. 252. C. Sect. 8. Coke 2. part. 61. B. WiÅ¿cots caÅ¿e; but it Å¿ufficeth to Å¿ay that they lett, and the Law will Å¿upply the reÅ¿t.

If it be of a LeaÅ¿e made by a PerÅ¿on tunc & ad â¢ uc Å¿eized of the ReverÅ¿ion,PerÅ¿on. it is good without averring of the life of the perÅ¿on, 13 & 14 Eliz. Dyer 304. pl. 52. for the LeaÅ¿e is good whether he be alive or not.

If the Account be of a LeaÅ¿e made by three, where two have nothing in it, it is not good, although they all joyned in the LeaÅ¿e, for they could not all lett; but contrary, if he count by him only that hath right, per Williams & Crooke, Mich. 10 Jac. Ban. Regis, Longs caÅ¿e; for he did only in truth lett, though the others joyned.

A LeaÅ¿e to commence at Michaelmas next after the death of A, LeaÅ¿e. the Count ought to Å¿hew that A is dead, 1 Mariae Dyer 97. pl. 46. & fol. 89. 19 Eliz. Dyer 357. pl. 46. for elÅ¿e the Plaintiff Å¿hews no title, but Å¿hews matter againÅ¿t himÅ¿elf.

The Plaintiff Counts that A demiÅ¿ed to him per Indenture dated 27 Martii, DemiÅ¿e. 11 Jac. & primum delibat. 10. decimo Aprilis eodem anno, for 21 years from Michaelmas next before, and the Ejectment 12 Aprilis, this is good though the year be miÅ¿taken; or he may Count that by Indenture dated 27 Martii, & primum delibat. 10 Aprilis, Mich. 11 Jac. Ban. Regis, Michels caÅ¿e, which is more plain and certain.

The Count upon the Imparlance Roll was upon a LeaÅ¿e made 10. of December, 10 Jac. and upon the Plea-roll it was upon a LeaÅ¿e made 30 Januarii, 10 Jac. babendum from the 20. of Decomber before; this is not good, Hill. 14 Jac. Milward & Wats Ban. Regis, for it cannot be the Å¿ame LeaÅ¿e upon which he counted, Å¿o there is no certainty in the pleading to which the Defendant may anÅ¿wer.

The Count was that J. S. was Å¿eized, and Å¿o Å¿eiÅ¿ed, leaÅ¿ed to the Plaintiff, 9 Eliz. Dyer 258. pl. 16. Com. 416. A. Bracebridges caÅ¿e, Com. 187. A. Adams caÅ¿e, Com. 223. B. Barkleys caÅ¿e, Com. 530. B. Howel & CroÅ¿ts caÅ¿e; here is a good colour of a Title to his LeÅ¿Å¿or, and to his own LeaÅ¿e.

But 14 Eliz. Dyer 340. pl. 57. he doth not count of the Å¿eiÅ¿in, Coke 11. part. 3. B. Coke 3. part. 16. A. BoraÅ¿tons caÅ¿e, Coke 3. part. 45. Browns caÅ¿e, Coke 4. part. 96. A. Lamberts caÅ¿e, Com. 459. B. Studs caÅ¿e, Com. 504. B. Snowes caÅ¿e; but only
declares upon a LeaÅ¿e made unto him by the LeÅ¿Å¿ â¢ r, and it Å¿eems good enough.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p:
In Wales it may be by plaint without an original Writ, for this action is out of the Statute, 26 Hen. 8. cap. 6. Hill. 36 Eliz. Ban. Regis 610. Griffin
â¢â¢â¢ Å¿us Eliot & Wilkins, and is there Å¿till as it was ãâã the Common Law.

It is Vi & armis, 1 Hen. 5.3. Coke 9. part. 78. 1. Petoes caÅ¿e, 21 Edw. 4. pl. 1. Choke, which al

But Hill. 36 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rott. 610. Griffin

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s, 1. before; 2. after appearance.
div.p:
The ProceÅ¿s is Attach, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and ProceÅ¿s of Outlawry, Nat. br. 220. H. 35 Hen. 6.6. per
Wangford & Moyl, Com. 228. B. Coke 9. part. 78 A. Peytoes caÅ¿e: Attachment againÅ¿t the perÅ¿on DiÅ¿treÅ¿s againÅ¿t the goods, Outlawry againÅ¿t perÅ¿on, and goods, and lands. The laÅ¿t ProceÅ¿s in Law is the Å¿tricteÅ¿t and moÅ¿t Å¿evere.

div.head: The Barr.
div.p:
Accord with Å¿atisfaction a good barr,Accord. Coke

part. 78. A. Petoyes caÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e it is but in the nature of a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s; for here is no land in queÅ¿tion, but only a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
DureÅ¿s a good barr,DureÅ¿s. Lib. Intra. 253. B. Å¿ect. 10. viz. that the Plaintiff gained the LeaÅ¿e by diÅ¿teÅ¿s for the Law hates fraud and force, and will protect no perÅ¿on in them.

Non ejecit a good barr,Ejecit. Å¿i bona & catalla are not in the Writ, 7 Edw. 6.89. pl. 111. 19 Hen. 6.56 for that is a barr only as to the Land; for a man cannot be properly Å¿aid to be ejected out of goods Quaere.
But if Å¿uch words be in, quaere whether it be good.
It is a good barr,Entry. that the LeÅ¿Å¿or had it but in right of his wife, and he entered after the death of the LeÅ¿Å¿or in right of his wife, Lib. Intra. 252. D. Å¿ect 8.
That he Å¿urrendred before the Action brought,Surrender. & quod non ejecit, a good barr, 21 Edw. 4.10. pl. 1.30. pl. 25. Q. if there Å¿hould not be a traverler it Å¿eems it needs not.

IMpedire eÅ¿t pedem ponere in jus alienum,Quid. qui â¢ quis habet in jure praeÅ¿entandi, Bracton. lib. 4. cap. 6. Å¿ol. 247. A.

An AdvowÅ¿on is an intereÅ¿t to preÅ¿ent an able man to a Benefice, 5 Hen. 7.38. B. Brian and TownÅ¿end.

OneroÅ¿um, a burthen to his conÅ¿cience, if he preÅ¿ent one not able. Quart, for he is not Judge of the Ability, but the Ordinary.

div.head: In what Court it lies.
div.p: Bracton Lib. 3. fol. 160. A. Immediate in â¢ uria Domini Regis terminari debent placita de advocationibus EccleÅ¿iarum, quia Å¿i alius Ã Rege mandaret EpiÅ¿copis de admittendo Clericum, & ipÅ¿e non obumperabit, alius Ã Rege co â¢ rcionem non haberet, quia EpiÅ¿copus ad alterius mandatum quÃ m Regis Clerieum admittere non tenetur; & per conÅ¿equens ãâã temporis Rex habebatur caput EccleÅ¿iae, & Stat. de H. 8. factum fuit Å¿olummedo in affirmatione legit.

Quare Impedit of an AdvowÅ¿on in Wales ought to be in Com. Ban. in England, and Å¿hall be tried ãâã the County next adjoyning to Wales; and the reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e the Lords there have not power to Å¿end to the BiÅ¿hop, 36 Hen. 6.33. B. ForteÅ¿eue, 35 Hen. 6.30. pl. 35. 3 Edw. 3.163. pl. 35. 8 Edw: 3.319. pl. 15. 24 Edw. 3.3. pl. 26. for the King is Supream Head of the Church in all his Dominions.

No plea to the JuriÅ¿diction to Å¿ay, that it is Ancient demean, becauÅ¿e they cannot in their Court award a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 7 Hen. 6.35. for the former reaÅ¿on no Liberty or FranchiÅ¿e can be endowed with this high prerogative.

In Ban. Regis it lies for the King, for he may Å¿ue there, if he pleaÅ¿es, Nat. br. 32. G. 47 Edw. 3.4. pl. 9. or in the Exchequer, as it Å¿eemeth. It Å¿eems alÅ¿o that it lies in Banco Regis for a common perÅ¿on.

The King grants Majori Ballivis & juratis Quinque Portuum, that they Å¿hall not be impleaded;
for no Land in no Court, nor for other cauÅ¿e, unleÅ¿s it be within the Five Ports, Å¿cil. at Shepway, before the Warden of the Five Ports: this extends not to a Quare Impedit, 21 Hen. 7.88. pl. 7. Crooke, for that is intended for Temporal matters only.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit.
div.p: He that is out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the AdvowÅ¿on Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit; Note. which a man may be five ways, 1. by PreÅ¿entation, 2. by diÅ¿continuance of the Land, to which the AdvowÅ¿on was appendant, &c. 3. by DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, 4. by DeÅ¿cent, 5. by Recovery in the Writ of Right of AdvowÅ¿ons or Quare Impedit. He that is out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of an AdvowÅ¿on cannot PreÅ¿ent, and therefore cannot be hindred, and Å¿o the Writ cannot lie; for a Writ muÅ¿t Å¿uggeÅ¿t the truth, elÅ¿e it is naught.

Husband and Wife having an AdvowÅ¿on in jure uxoris, they Å¿hall joyn in a Quare Impedit, Coke 5. part. 57. Specots caÅ¿e, 50 Edw. 3.13. pl. 4. 7 Hen. 7.2. B. 38 Hen. 6.3. pl. 9. 28 Hen. 6.8. pl. 3. for the Wife is intereÅ¿ted in the jus Patronatus notwithÅ¿tanding her marriage.
But the Husband may bring this without the Wife, 14 Hen. 4.12. pl. 12. 22 Rich. 2. br. 937. for the particular wrong done to the Husband in hindering him to preÅ¿ent hac vice.

The Church is void, the Wife dies, the HuÅ¿band Å¿hall have the Quare Impedit, becauÅ¿e the PreÅ¿entation was a Chattel veÅ¿ted in the Husband, 21 Hen. 6.56. becauÅ¿e the Church became void during his wites life.
The Husband preÅ¿ents, and after they are divorced, the Husband Å¿hall have the Writ, 31 Hen. 8. br. Divorce 8. if he be hindred in this preÅ¿entation, for the Divorce Å¿hall not look back.

CeÅ¿tui que uÅ¿e Å¿hall not have it,CeÅ¿tui que uÅ¿e. but the Feoffees of the Land; for the preÅ¿entation is always firm to the AdvowÅ¿on which is in the Feoffees, Crooke 17 Hen. 7. A. Frowick & ibidem, 2 Hen. 8.160. B. pl. 1. Q. if the Statute of UÅ¿es alter not the Law in this point.

The Lord Chancellor Å¿hall preÅ¿ent to all Churches under 20 Marks per annum, Chancellor. which are belonging to the Crown; but not if the King have them by other Title, Nat. br. 35. K. 38 Edw. 3.3. pl. 14. Com. 528. B. as by PurchaÅ¿e, Attainder, &c.
But vide Br. PraeÅ¿cript. 86. that at this day the Chancellor preÅ¿ents to all under 20 l. per Annum. Twenty Marks anciently was more than 20 l. in Å¿ucceeding times, and that may be the reaÅ¿on.
The Defendant Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Plaintiff, if his Clerk be not InÅ¿tituted,Defendant Nat. br. 35. C. for without it he is not a perfect Incumbent.

The elder Brother preÅ¿ents and dies,Half-blood the Brother by the half-blood Å¿hall not have the next Avoidance, Nat. br. 36. E. 3 Hen. 7.5. becauÅ¿e, as it Å¿eems, he Å¿hall not be inheritable of the AdvowÅ¿on.
But the 19 Edw. 2. Quare Impedit 177. Contra. Ergo quaere; for he may come in by the Father or Grandfather, as Heir to them.

Two SiÅ¿ters by Å¿everal venters make compoÅ¿ition for the PreÅ¿enting, and one dies before PreÅ¿entment, the other Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 36. E. for the Agreement laÅ¿ts but during their lives, and the Executor Å¿hall take no advantage of it.
Corporation. BiÅ¿hop. Ratione Patronatus. The BiÅ¿hop Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit ratione Patronatus, if he be diÅ¿turbed.
Patronage of a Deanary belongs to him of common right, 17 Edw. 3.40. pl. 17. yet the King uÅ¿ed of late times to beÅ¿tow them.

The BiÅ¿hop Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit ratione LapÅ¿us, for by the LapÅ¿e a Title to preÅ¿ent accrues to him hac vice, and the Writ Å¿hall be general, but the Count Å¿hall be of the Collation, Nat. br. 33. D. 17 Edw. 3.64. pl. 69. Lib. Intra. 501. A. and Å¿hew how he is to preÅ¿ent.

If LapÅ¿e accrue to the Metropolitan, he may put his Clerk in without the Ordinary of the place, Doct. & Stud. 125. B. becauÅ¿e he is Å¿upream Ordinary. Yet quaere in that caÅ¿e, whether he Å¿hall do it without the King, who is caput ExcleÅ¿iae.
The Ordinary is deprived after LapÅ¿e accrues, quaere who Å¿hall have it, 7 Edw. 6. Dyer 87. pl. 203. it Å¿eems the King, or it may be the Metropolitan, yet be an inferiour Ordinary.
In quo caÅ¿u Ordinarius loci providebit EccleÅ¿ie viduitati, Bracton, Lib. 2.34. fol. 76. B.
But Bracion Å¿ays, Lib. 3. that LapÅ¿e was but by the Council of Lateran, and before that the Patron might preÅ¿ent at any time EccleÅ¿ia vacante.

If it be Å¿ound for one Patron in a jure Patronatus, and the PreÅ¿enter prays not to be admitted,
the Ordinary Å¿hall preÅ¿ent by LapÅ¿e, 34 Hen. 6.12. pl. 22. for the Ordinary is to take care to have the Church provided in convenient time.
Although a Ne admittas be Å¿ued, yet the Ordinary of the place Å¿hall preÅ¿ent by LapÅ¿e, Nat. br. 48. L. for he only looks upon the vacancy of the Church.
LapÅ¿e is, when the Patron doth not preÅ¿ent in Å¿ix Months, then the Ordinary preÅ¿ents by LapÅ¿e, Doct. & Stud. 124. B. by the Council of Lateran; by Bracton.

Although the Patron be an Infant or Feme covert, Nat. br. 34. T. 3 Edw 3. Quare Impedit 41. for the Law takes care of the infancy of the Church above all other infancy, in reÅ¿pect of the Cure of Souls.
But this rule of LapÅ¿e admits divers exceptions, Scil.

1. So long as the Church is void the Patron may preÅ¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 126. A. for the Title by LapÅ¿e is not a Chattel veÅ¿ted in the Ordinary, though after Å¿ix months, if the Ordinary have not preÅ¿ented.

2. It Å¿hall not be a LapÅ¿e of a Chappel Donative or Chantry, unleÅ¿s the Patron make it preÅ¿entative, and then it Å¿hall, for then the nature is altered, Nat. br. 35 E. 6 Hen. 7. br. PreÅ¿entment 43. PaÅ¿ch. 3 Jac. Ban. Regis, Fairefield verÅ¿us Gaire, or be Å¿o expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the foundation, 13 Edw. 4.3.
3. An AdvowÅ¿on approprlate Å¿hall not be LapÅ¿ed, Nat. br. 35 F. for there the Church Å¿hall be intended to be otherwiÅ¿e provided for, and not by preÅ¿entation.
4. If the Ordinary be named a DiÅ¿turber in the Quare Impedit, 5 Edw 3.2. B. 22 Hen. 6.28. And at this day he is named in the Writ to prevent the LapÅ¿e, 39 Edw. 3.15. pl. 4. Statham.

For otherways the LapÅ¿e incurrs, 5 Edw. 4.115. for then he can take no notice of the Suit; but it Å¿eems that the Ordinary cannot collate him that was the Incumbent, and made Defendant in the Å¿uit; for this would be to prevent the trial of the Right.
5. In many caÅ¿es LapÅ¿e Å¿hall not incurr without notice, viz. where the Patron cannot take notice of the Avoidance of the Church. As,
In what caÅ¿e LapÅ¿e cannot incurr without notice.1. Upon a ReÅ¿ignation, Nat. br. 35. H. 1 Hen. 7 9. 5 Edw. 4.116. A. for this is a private act.
If the Ordinary dies his SucceÅ¿Å¿or ought to give notice, Crooke 18 Hen. 7.41. pl. 2. Quaere of what; it Å¿eems of the Churches being void.
2. Upon privation, Nat. br. 35. H. 1 Hen. 7.9. 5 Edw. 4.118. A. for this is alÅ¿o a private act, which the Patron is not bound to take notice of without notice.
Although the Incumbent be meerly Laicus, 13 Eliz. Dyer 293. pl. 3. Q.
And although the party be party to the Suit, Coke 6. part. 29. Greens caÅ¿e, 22 Eliz. Dyer 369. pl. 54.
And although the Title of LapÅ¿e be devolved to the King, per LapÅ¿um temporis, 18 Eliz. Dyer 348. pl. 12. 22 Eliz. Dyer 369. pl. 54.
3. If it be Litigious, 34 Hen. 6.40. B. PriÅ¿ot. Lib. Intra. 511. D. whether the Church be void or not.
4. If the Church be void by any clauÅ¿e of the Statute, 13 Eliz. cap. 12. for Å¿uch Statute it Å¿eems is not a general Law. Quaere tamen, for it Å¿eems Patrons ought to take notice of it.

5. Where he Å¿hall loÅ¿e his Benefice, per 2 Edw. 6. cap. 20. for refuÅ¿ing to pay Tithes, 12 Eliz. Dyer 294. pl. 3. for of Å¿uch a miÅ¿demeanour the Patron is not bound to take notice, for it Å¿hall not be preÅ¿umed the Incumbent will commit Å¿uch an offence.
6. If one have a Benefice within 8 l. per ann. and takes another, and be Inducted, Coke 4. part. 79. and Å¿o forfeit the former.
7. If the former be of 8 l. without Induction, no LapÅ¿e without notice, Coke 4. part. 79. B. Digbies caÅ¿e.
But after Induction no notice is requiÅ¿ite, Coke 4. part. 75. 7 Eliz. Dyer 237. pl. 29. 8 Eliz. Dyer 255. pl. 5. for that is a notorious act, whereof the Patron may take notice.
And the value of the Living Å¿hall be according to the true value, and not according to the Book of Tithes and FirÅ¿t-Fruits, 7 Eliz. Dyer 237. pl. 29. which is at an undervalue.
8. Upon refuÅ¿al of a Clerk to be admitted, Nat. br. 35. I. 15 Eliz. Dyer 327. pl. 7. for of this the Patron cannot take notice, nor Å¿hall he preÅ¿ume it.
But Crooke 18. Hen. 7.49. pl. 2. per Frowick, if it be a Spiritual Patron, then it is not requiÅ¿ite to give notice, becauÅ¿e he is preÅ¿umed better knowing in Å¿uch matters than a Lay-Patron.

So for Avoidance per Creation of the Incumbent to be a BiÅ¿hop, CeÅ¿Å¿ion, or Death, Doct.
& Stud. 116. B. 5 Edw. 4.115. Quaere of Death.

After privation the Patron grants the AdvowÅ¿on to A, the Ordinary collates A; he cannot be removed, for notice ought not to be given him, for it was void to all but the Grantor; for the Ordinary is not bound to take notice of the Grant to A, becauÅ¿e it is a private act, Mich. 42 & 43 Eliz. Com. Ban. Rot. 3579. Leake againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop of Coventry.

Notice is to be given as to the LapÅ¿e only, for as to the preÅ¿entation, the Patron may be put out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the preÅ¿entation for Å¿ome other cauÅ¿e, although no notice is given him, PaÅ¿ch. 39 Eliz. Com. Ban. Scriven verÅ¿us EpiÅ¿copum Lincoln.
A ParÅ¿on Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit for the Vicarage,ParÅ¿on. for of common right it belongs unto him to preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 33. Æ².
For if the Vicarage be void, and the ParÅ¿on be made a BiÅ¿hop, yet he Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, for it was a Chattel veÅ¿ted in him whilÅ¿t he was ParÅ¿on, Nat. br. 34. N. 24 Edw. 3.26. Q.
A ParÅ¿on ImparÅ¿onee or Incumbent, Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, 17 Edw. 3.51. pl. 25. for the Vicarage.
For a Prebendary,Prebendary. although the Prebend reÅ¿ign after uÅ¿urpation upon him, 26 Edw. 3.3. Q.

Dean and Chapter.The Chapter brought a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Dean, and good; for their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions are Å¿everal, though they be one body Politick, 9 Edw. 3.134. & fol. 354. pl. 33. 17 Edw. 3.64. 40 Edw. 3.28. B. Finchden, 7 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 72. Lab. Intra. 500. A.
An HoÅ¿pital which hath no Spiritual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions,Aggregate nether are a Colledge, nor have a Seal, yet the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit.
Corporation mixt.For a Corporation mixt, as in caÅ¿e of the King, 1. In right of the Crown, Nat. br. 32. E. the Writ.
2. By reaÅ¿on of LapÅ¿e incurred, for this makes him Supream Patron, Doct. & Stud. 124. B. Com. 498. 18 Edw. 3.19.
Therefore after LapÅ¿e accured to the King, the Patron cannot preÅ¿ent, Doct. & Stud. 126. A. 10 Eliz. Dyer 277. pl. 55. for the Kings Title Å¿hall be preÅ¿erved and preferred above all other Titles.
Nor the Ordinary collate after LapÅ¿e is accrued to the King, 17 Eliz. Dyer. 339 pl. 47. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

In his own right.But in caÅ¿e, where notice is requiÅ¿ite, the King cannot preÅ¿ent without notice, 18 Eliz. Dyer 348. pl. 12. 22 Eliz. Dyer 369. pl. 54. for the King Å¿hall not take advantage againÅ¿t one, where there was no negligence in the party.

If the Dean of the Chappel Royal preÅ¿ents not within Å¿ix months, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 34. F. 27 Edw. 3.84. Chappel-Royal is the Kings Chappel, or of his foundation, and he is inÅ¿tead of the Ordinary.

A ParÅ¿on created is a BiÅ¿hop,Creation. the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, 21 Edw. 3.31. pl. 14. & fol. 41. 11 Hen. 4.37. vide 6 Eliz. Dyer 228. for the Patron could not have preÅ¿ented till the death of the ParÅ¿on, and Å¿o here is but putting in one perÅ¿on for another, and Å¿o he hath no injury.

Ratione temporalium.21 Edw. 3.5. pl. 13. the Writ was, quia pertinet ad Regem praeÅ¿entare ratione. EpiÅ¿copatus nuper vacantis, and good, when a Living fell, which belonged to a BiÅ¿hoprick, Å¿ede vacante.
The Count, Lib. Intra. 530. C. Å¿ect. 15.

And the King needs not Å¿ay in the Count, for that the Temporalties were Å¿eized, 42 Edw. 3.7. pl. 27. for that Å¿hall be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed; for by the death of the BiÅ¿hop the Temporalties are immediately in the Kings hands.

If a Church be void during the time that the Temporalties are in the hands of the King, although he makes reÅ¿titution of the Temporalties, yet the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 33. N. Stanford 44 Edw. 3.17. pl. 8. 18 Edw. 3.22. pl. 39. for it was veÅ¿ted in the King by the vacancy, whilÅ¿t the Temporalties were in his hand.

If the Church become void, and the BiÅ¿hop dies, the King Å¿hall have it, and not the Executors, Nat. br. 33. Q. 9 Edw. 3.2. Quare Impedit 11. becauÅ¿e the King is now Patron, and finds the Church empty.
And although the BiÅ¿hop collate, Nat. br. 34. K. 11 Hen. 4 9. A. 24 Edw. 3.30. 44 Edw. 3.3. for that makes not the party collated to be Incumbent, but his Induction.
But if he die after Induction, although it be the Å¿ame day, the King Å¿hall not have it, 44 Edw, 3.3. for then the Church was full.
If a LapÅ¿e accrues to the BiÅ¿hop, who dies, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, 25 Edw. 3.53. pl. 20. for he is in place of the BiÅ¿hop.

It a LapÅ¿e accrues after the death of the BiÅ¿hop, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 34. G.
in reÅ¿pect of the Temporalties in his hands.
So if he have judgment to have the Temporalties,Outlawry. 21 Edw. 3.29. for that is all one as if he were in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of them.

By Outlawry, of, the Patron in a perÅ¿onal Action, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 34. R. 8 Rich. 2. Quare Impedit 200. 21 Hen. 6.56. if the Church become void during the Outlawry. Quaere, if afterwards the Outlawry, be reverÅ¿ed before the King preÅ¿ents.

A enfeoffs. B of a Mannor, to which, &c. and before was outlawed, and preÅ¿ents per permiÅ¿Å¿ion of B, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, becauÅ¿e the preÅ¿entation is a Chattel, 5 Hen. 5. pl. 4. and was forfeited to the King by the Outlawry.
For Simony, upon 31 Eliz. cap. 6.
The Pleadings, No. Lib. Intr. 405. C. Å¿ect. 516. B. 531. D.
Note per 25 Edw. 3. cap. 1. the King Å¿hall not preÅ¿ent in anothers right,Note. but for the Avoidance in his own time, 11 Hen. 4.7. pl. 16. which is in his own right.

Note, if the King preÅ¿ents one that dies before Induction, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent again, for he had not a compleat preÅ¿entation before, Coke 9. part. Holts caÅ¿e, vide RegiÅ¿t. orig. 31. B. for his Clerk was never in.

But if the King have title hac vice, and another preÅ¿ents A, which dies, the King hath loÅ¿t his turn, Coke 7. part. 28. Baskerviles caÅ¿e, No. Lib. Intra. 489. A. for he was to have but this numerical preÅ¿entation, and is not like the having of the next preÅ¿entation.

Yet if one qualified to have two Benefices takes another incompatible, the firÅ¿t is void by two years; the Patron preÅ¿ents where the King ought to have preÅ¿ented, and after Induction his Clerk refuÅ¿es to pay his Tenths, and this is certified according to the Statute of 26 H. 8. the BiÅ¿hop being Patron collates, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent notwithÅ¿tanding, for this refuÅ¿al is as it were a ReÅ¿ignation to the BiÅ¿hop, which Å¿hall be intended a ColluÅ¿ion betwixt him and the BiÅ¿hop, to take away the Title of the King, Mich. 29 & 30 Eliz: Com. Ban. Rot. 22 99. the King againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop of Lincoln.

12 Eliz. Dyer 292. pl. 70. 25 Edw. 47. the King preÅ¿ents to a Prebendary ratione temporalium, and revokes it before the InÅ¿tallment of the Prebend; and yet he is Inducted, and the King confirms it, and after he is made a BiÅ¿hop, the Prebend dies, the King Å¿hall preÅ¿ent again, and not the BiÅ¿hop, for the confirmation of the King was void, becauÅ¿e the Prebend was not in ex praeÅ¿entatione Regis, for that was revoked before the Confirmation.

Nat. br. 38. D. the King recovers a Prebendary, and gives it by Letters Patents to A, who dies, the King gives it to B, he Å¿hall have Writ to the JuÅ¿tices to make execution for him, viz. of th â¢â¢ Court where the Prebendary was recovered.

DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit before his entry into the Mannor,DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee. to which the AdvowÅ¿on belongs, 21 Hen. 6.9. B. 19 Hen. 6.33. 33 Hen. 6.33. B. Nat. br. 33. Q. 24 Hen. 8. Dyer 5. pl. 6. Crooke 6 Hen. 8.169. A. Pollard; for the AdvowÅ¿on was not diveÅ¿ted by the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in.

DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or preÅ¿ents, DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee enters into the Mannor to which, &c. and preÅ¿ents, he Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, if it be within Å¿ix months, 14 Hen. 6.24. Fulthorp; for by his entry he hath regained the Mannor, and avoided the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ors preÅ¿entation.

Add if the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or preÅ¿ents, and the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee enters into the Mannor, to which, &c. and enfeoffs B thereof, with the AdvowÅ¿on, the Church voids, B Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit; for by the entry of the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee he was in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the AdvowÅ¿on, 3 Hen. 4 7. pl. 33. 14 Hen. 6.16. pl. 52. and Å¿o it paÅ¿Å¿ed with the Mannor by the Feoffment.
But 33 Hen. 6.33. PriÅ¿ot to the contrary; for there it is Å¿aid, that until Recovery the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall not have the AdvowÅ¿on. Q.

DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or dies Å¿eized of a Mannor to which the AdvowÅ¿on belongs, the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit, 24 Hen. 8. Dyer 5. pl. 6. 33 Hen. 6.33. B. vide 19 Hen. 6.33. in reÅ¿pect of the deÅ¿cent, which takes away his entry into the Mannor, and Å¿o he muÅ¿t recover the Mannor before he can have the AdvowÅ¿on.

But if it void in the time of the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have it, although the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or died Å¿eized afterwards of the Mannor, to which, &c. 24 Hen. 8. Dyer 5. pl. 6. for there was no deÅ¿cent barr when the Church became void, and Å¿o it was a Chattel veÅ¿ted.

A DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or Å¿uffers a UÅ¿urpation, DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee enters into the Mannor, DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, Nat. br. 36. F. 14 Hen. 6.14. 3 Hen. 4.7. for the uÅ¿urpation is defeated by the entry of the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee.

Executor of the King Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit, Executor. but the SucceÅ¿Å¿or of the King, for this is a Chattel Royal, 7 Hen. 4.25. pl. 3. 1 Edw. 3.17. pl. 8. 5 Edw. 3.149. pl. 15. which Å¿hall not go to an Executor, for it is veÅ¿ted in the Crown.

Executor of a Common perÅ¿on Å¿hall have a preÅ¿entment to a Church, which was void in the time of the TeÅ¿tator, although the TeÅ¿tator were but Tenant in tail, Nat. br. 33. P, & Æ². becauÅ¿e it was a Chattel veÅ¿ted in the TeÅ¿tator.

Although the Heir be in ward to the King, Nat br. 33. R. for the King in reÅ¿pect of the WardÅ¿hip Å¿hall not be in a better condition, than the Heir Å¿hould have been, if he had been at full age at the death of his AnceÅ¿tor.
If one recover in a Quare Impedit and die, the Heir Å¿hall not have execution, but the Executors, 9 Hen. 6.57. A. Rolfe; for the recovery made it a Chattel veÅ¿ted in the TeÅ¿tator.

At the Common Law the Infant was bound by Å¿uffering an UÅ¿urpation,Enfant. 35 Hen. 6.6. that is, to Å¿uffer one to preÅ¿ent in his Å¿tead, 31 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 186. 10 Edw. 2. Quare Impedit 43. for the Common Law reÅ¿pects the Churches good, before Infants, Widows, or Orphans, although it be tender of all.
But at this day he is not, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. The Law before Å¿eemed too hard againÅ¿t Infants, who may be preÅ¿umed not conuÅ¿ant of the Law, and ignorant of his title.

UnleÅ¿s he be a PurchaÅ¿er, 10 Edw. 2. Qu. Imped. 43. 35 Hen. 6.60. Nat. br. 31, & 34. It Å¿eems he is not within the Statute: He may, if a PurchaÅ¿er,
be preÅ¿umed not Å¿o well conuÅ¿ant of his title as if he had it by deÅ¿cent.
Or that the party that uÅ¿urps be remitted to an eigne title, Nat. br. 35. M. for then the preÅ¿entation did not belong to the Infant.

If he Å¿uffer UÅ¿urpation, having it by deÅ¿cent, he is bound till full age, 16 Edw. 3.9. Quare Impedit 62. for he Å¿hall be judged better conuÅ¿ant of Å¿uch eÅ¿tate than of a purchaÅ¿ed eÅ¿tate; and he might have preÅ¿ented himÅ¿elf.

And if in his minority he Å¿uffer UÅ¿urpation, and at full age enfeoff B of the Mannor, to which, &c. yet B Å¿hall not be in, Nat. br. 34. X. becauÅ¿e it was out of the Feoffor at the time of the Feoffment, and Å¿o it paÅ¿Å¿eth not.
But by 16 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 67. Coke 6. part. BoÅ¿wels caÅ¿e, the Infant is alÅ¿o bound in all theÅ¿e caÅ¿es. Q.
Feme Covert.The UÅ¿urpation at the Common Law Å¿hall bind a Woman Covert, 35 Hen. 6.6. PriÅ¿ot, 31 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 180. 10 Edw. 2. Quare Imped. 43. vid. antea.

The husband Å¿uffers an UÅ¿urpation, where the Woman is the purchaÅ¿er, Å¿he Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit, but the husband; but if Å¿he had it by deÅ¿cent, Å¿he Å¿hall have the next turn, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. Nat. br. 34 S. to preÅ¿ent.
