The husband diÅ¿continues one Acre of his wives Mannor, to which an AdvowÅ¿on is appendant with the AdvowÅ¿on, the wife may not preÅ¿ent, unleÅ¿s after the Alience Å¿ever the AdvowÅ¿on from the Acre, Nat. br. 32. 17 Edw. 3.5. pl. 12. for then the AdvowÅ¿on is not appendant to any thing.

Feoffee or Grantee, 1. of the King; 2. of another.The King grants the AdvowÅ¿on in Fee, the Church being void, the Grantee preÅ¿ents, Nat. br. 33. N. for the grant Å¿hall be taken moÅ¿t beneficially for the Grantee.

But this is intended when the King hath but one Title to the AdvowÅ¿on, 10 Eliz. Dyer 269. pl. 19. 9 Edw. 3.26. Stamford. Praerogat. 44. 16 Hen. 7.7. 18 Edw. 3.22. A. Pole. for if he have two, the Grant Å¿hall not be taken to two intents.

For if he had two Titles the Grantee Å¿hall not preÅ¿ent, 13 Eliz. Dyer 300. pl. 36. 18 Eliz. Dyer 300. pl. 36 Eliz. Dyer 348. pl. 12. for it is incertain which Title was granted, nor can be known with what Title he preÅ¿ents.

But 9 Edw. 3.348. pl. 24. the orders of the Templers were diÅ¿Å¿olved, the Church belonging to them to preÅ¿ent to voids, and after the AdvowÅ¿ons, &c. appendant to their mannors, were given to the HoÅ¿pitallers per Parliament; the King Å¿hall not have the preÅ¿entation, for here the King had but one Title, and alÅ¿o acts of grace Å¿hall be conÅ¿trued largely againÅ¿t the King.

A Common perÅ¿on grants the AdvowÅ¿on in Fee when the Church was void, the Grantee Å¿hall not have the preÅ¿entation, becauÅ¿e it is a thing in action, 11 Hen. 4.54. which lies not in grant, but may paÅ¿s by Act of Parliament.
So of a Feoffment of Land, to which an AdvowÅ¿on is appendant, 24 Eliz. Staffords caÅ¿e, the Church being void at the time of making of the Feoffment.

But if the Feoffment be upon condition, and the Church becomes void, and afterwards the
Feoffor enters for the Condition broken, the Feoffee Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, becauÅ¿e it is a Chattel veÅ¿ted in him, 24 Edw. 3. before the entry of the Feoffor.

If there be a Feoffment of the third part of a Mannor, the Feoffee Å¿hall not have the third preÅ¿entment, 6 Edw. 3.215. A. for the AdvowÅ¿on is not appendant to it, for it cannot be appendant by parcels.
UnleÅ¿s it be with three preÅ¿entments, 9 Edw. 3.341. pl. 31. viz. where three preÅ¿ent to the AdvowÅ¿on by turn. Q.
Grantee of the next Avoidance Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, 39 Hen. 6. Quare Imp. 95. for he hath a good Title to preÅ¿ent hac vice.
The Count, Lib. Intra. 520. D.

And if the Grantee of a Mannor to which an AdvowÅ¿on is appendant, levies a Fine of the AdvowÅ¿on, yet this puts him not out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the AdvowÅ¿on, 19 Edw. 3. Quare Imped. 154. becauÅ¿e it puts him not out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Mannor to which it appertains.

Grantee by Parliament Å¿uffers a uÅ¿urpation; this doth not put him out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 16 Hen. 7.8. Keble, becauÅ¿e he is in by Title of Å¿o high a nature, which Å¿hall not be intercepted by an ordinary act of the party.
Grantor by Fine uÅ¿urps; this Å¿hall not trouble the Grantee, 31 Edw. 1. Quare Impedit 187. for a Fine is of a high nature, and barrs the ConuÅ¿or of all right.

Tenant in tail for life, or years, grants their EÅ¿tate in an AdvowÅ¿on, the Church voids, the Grantee Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, becauÅ¿e it is a Chattel veÅ¿ted, 9 Edw 3.366. pl. 4. in the Grantee during the eÅ¿tate tail, and for life.

If the Daughter Å¿uffers a UÅ¿urpation,Daughter. the So â¢ afterwards born Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit 11 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 138. for he was not ãâã
rerum natura at the time of the uÅ¿urpation, and ãâã had no right.
A Founder of a Church Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit of common right,Founder. for he is preÅ¿umed Patron, and becauÅ¿e he enters upon the diÅ¿Å¿olution 12 Edw. 4.30. A. Catesby. Q.

One of them,Joynttenants. viz. Joyntenants, Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the other, Nat. br. 34. Æ². 14 Eliz. Dyer 304. pl. 54. 33 Hen. 6.11. B. in reÅ¿pect of their undivided and undiÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hable intereÅ¿t.
Nor againÅ¿t a Stranger; but they muÅ¿t joyn, or elÅ¿e the DiÅ¿turber might be twice Å¿ued for one diÅ¿turbance.
But where one pleads Joyntenancy of part of the AdvowÅ¿on, the Plaintiff ought to entitle himÅ¿elf to the whole AdvowÅ¿on, or Å¿hew that he is Incumbent of all, 31 Hen. 6.51. B.
Joyntenancy of part is no Plea, 14 Hen. 6.14. 14 Hen. 4. Joyntenants 32. for it cannot be; for Joyntenants are Å¿eiÅ¿ed per my & per tout.
Joyntenant preÅ¿ents Å¿ole; this Å¿hall not put his Companion out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 27 Hen. 8.13. for it Å¿hall be intended, he intended it not but to preÅ¿ent Å¿o, as the Law requires.
But 11 Hen. 4.44. Hanford e contra. Ergo quaere.

If they make compoÅ¿ition, and preÅ¿ent accordingly, yet afterwards, if one be diÅ¿turbed, he Å¿hall not have an Action without his Companion, 20 Edw. 3.72. for that compoÅ¿ition concerns not Strangers, but is only a private act betwixt themÅ¿elves.

Nominator to a Living.Nominator to a Living Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t him that preÅ¿ents, Nat. br. 33. A. becauÅ¿e by the Nomination he had the fruit of the AdvowÅ¿on, 14 Hen. 4.11. pl. 9. 14 Edw. 4.2. pl. 2. 32 Hen. 8. Dyer 48. pl. 16. 22 Edw. 3.77. pl. 103. 24 Edw. 3.69. pl. 78. And the Writ Å¿hall be general, Nat. br. 33. A. 24 Edw. 3.69. pl. 78. as in caÅ¿e of Patronage.

For if it be [Nominare] this Å¿hall abate the Writ, 14 Hen. 4.11. 21 Hen. 6.17. A. for the Law takes no notice of Å¿uch a term; but the Count Å¿hall be Å¿pecial, Nat. br. 33. A. and Å¿et forth the whole matter how he is enabled.
For in 14 Hen. 4.11. per Hill. Nominator is in a manner the very Patron, and Å¿o taken notice of in Law as Å¿uch, 24 Edw. 3.69.

A grants to B that he Å¿hall have the next Nomination to the Church of D when it is void, and that he Å¿hall preÅ¿ent his Clerk to the BiÅ¿hop, if the Grantee be diÅ¿turbed, he Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, for he is the Patron hac vice by the words of the Grant, Crooke 2 Hen. 8.161. pl. 1. per Read.

The eldeÅ¿t Parcener Å¿hall have the firÅ¿t preÅ¿entment,Parceners. Nat. br. 33. L. 38 Hen. 6.9. pl. 19. Doct. & Stud. 115. B. Nat. br. 34. Æ². Crooke 12 Hen. 7.1. A. and Å¿o in order by turns, if there be more than two.
So the Husband of the eldeÅ¿t being Tenant by CourteÅ¿ie, Nat. br. 33. L. 5 Hen. 5.10. pl. 24. for he is in upon his wifes right and title, originally.

So he that hath the eÅ¿tate of the eldeÅ¿t, for his intereÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿eth with the eÅ¿tate, Nat. br. 34. Æ². but Crooke 18 Hen. 7.49. pl. 5. by Frowicke, if he
grant this when the Church is void before any preÅ¿entment by him; the Grantee Å¿hall not have the firÅ¿t preÅ¿entment, becauÅ¿e he is a Å¿tranger in blood, and the Feoffee cannot claim that priviledge in Law.
Where a Parcener grants his EÅ¿tate to B (the Church being void) yet the Parceners ought to joyn in a Quare Impedit, 11 Hen. 5.54. in reÅ¿pect of their joynt right and title at the time of the Grant.
The pleading of a Partition between Parceners, No. Lib. Intra. 468. B, & C.

If they make partition to preÅ¿ent by turn, and the youngeÅ¿t dies, his Heir in ward to the King, he, viz. the King, Å¿hall preÅ¿ent during the Nonage, 21 Edw. 3.32. pl. 14. 22 Edw. 4. for his wardÅ¿hip Å¿hall not make him loÅ¿e his right to preÅ¿ent.
Parceners agree to preÅ¿ent by turn, this is a good partition as to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 20 Edw. 3. Quore Imp. 63, 65. viz. of the AdvowÅ¿on.
But Nat. br. 33 L. Ã¨ contra, becauÅ¿e the Inheritance is not. Quaere ergo.
Doct. & Stud. 11. the King Å¿hall have the firÅ¿t preÅ¿entment, the eldeÅ¿t the Å¿econd. Quaere in what caÅ¿e.

But 38 Hen. 6.9. pl. 19. the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the eldeÅ¿t Coparcener was in ward to the King, there three others by their pleading Å¿hew a partition of the Mannor in Carvel, except the AdvowÅ¿on, and Å¿ue to the King to preÅ¿ent, after the fourth Å¿ues for the AdvowÅ¿on; the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the eldeÅ¿t Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, becauÅ¿e the preÅ¿entment of the King was in right of them all, and not in right of the turn of the IÅ¿Å¿ue.

Upon compoÅ¿ition to preÅ¿ent by turn, if it be inrolled in a Court of Record, they Å¿hall have a Scire facias one againÅ¿t the other, when their turn comes to preÅ¿ent, Nat. br. 34. H. 21 Edw. 4.6. pl. 36. B.

So againÅ¿t a Stranger that uÅ¿urps in their turns, if the partition be of Record only, the Law takes no notice of it, Nat. br. 36. C. but they may joyn in a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t a Stranger, for the Law takes notice of their joynt title, and alÅ¿o preÅ¿ent in common; but by this the compoÅ¿ition is waved, Nat. br. 36. D. for it Å¿hews, they rely not upon the compoÅ¿ition, but hold there to that way of preÅ¿entation that the Law gives them.

The Å¿urprize of one Parcener Å¿hall not put the other out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, when his turn comes again, for he gains no title by it, Nat. br. 34. J. 6 Edw. 3.210. pl. 13. 7 Edw. 3.239. pl. 27.17 Edw. 3.38. pl. 10. 30 Edw. 3.15. pl. 15.
Although that it be made by the King in right of one Parcener, being in ward to the King, 22 Edw. 4.8. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

My Procurator preÅ¿ents as to his own AdvowÅ¿on,Procurator. as Procurator to me, by this I Å¿hall have again the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and out him, Nat. br. 35. O. 17 Edw. 3.60. pl 60. for by preÅ¿enting as my Procurator he acknowledgeth my right.

Recoverer in right of an AdvowÅ¿on Å¿uffers an uÅ¿urpation,Recoveter. he Å¿hall not have a Quaere Impedit, 45 Edw. 3. Quare Imped. 139. becauÅ¿e he was not in actual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it by the Recovery, and Å¿o hath but a meer right Å¿till.

Tenant for life or years of an AdvowÅ¿on Å¿uffers an uÅ¿urpation,ReverÅ¿ioner. the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall not be aided by
his own, WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. for it is a fault to lett it to Å¿uch a Tenant.
But his Heir Å¿hall be, Nat. br. 31. G. for he is in no fault.
But 33 Hen. 6.12. pl. 3. 34 Hen. 6.27 pl. 8. Ã¨ contra. Ergo quaere.

If Tenant for years or a Gardein brings a Quare Impedit, and a Writ be awarded to the BiÅ¿hop for the Defendant, yet the Tenant of the Franktenement is not out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, for the PreÅ¿entee is in by courÅ¿e of Law, 50 Edw. 3.14. B. Coke 6. part. 50. B. BoÅ¿wells caÅ¿e; and therefore the Tenants or Gardians intereÅ¿t Å¿hall not be prejudiced.

The Queen Å¿hall have it alone,Queen. becauÅ¿e Å¿he is a Å¿ole perÅ¿on exempt by the Common Law, and cannot joyn with any in a Suit; and the Writ Å¿hall not Å¿ay unde queritur, becauÅ¿e Å¿he Å¿hall not find Pledges, 18 Edw. 3.2. pl. 6. for it were diÅ¿honourable for her to find Pledges, for Å¿he Å¿hall be preÅ¿umed to be Å¿ufficient, and Å¿o deal juÅ¿tly with all.
The Lord that hath an AdvowÅ¿on by EÅ¿cheat,Lord. Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, the Count, Lib. Intra. 500. D. in reÅ¿pect of his Title accrued by Law.

If an Abby, which hath an Appropriation, be diÅ¿Å¿olved, the Lord that hath the Mannor to which it was appendant Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit to preÅ¿ent to the AdvowÅ¿on, Nat. br. 33. K. Coke 2. part. 47. B. Canterburies caÅ¿e, 21 Hen. 7.4. B. Frowick, 20 Edw. 4.14. B. Com. 501. Grendons caÅ¿e; for by the diÅ¿Å¿olution the Appropriation is extinguiÅ¿hed, and the Lord in of his old right to the Patronage.

Tenant in Tail.Tenant in tail Å¿uffers an UÅ¿urpation, he hath no remedy, for it was his own Latches to Å¿uffer it; but his IÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, 49 Edw. 3.14. pl. 9. This is by the equ ty of WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. Coke 6. part. 50. B. BoÅ¿wells caÅ¿e, who Å¿hall not be prejudiced by his Fathers act.

Tenant in tail of a Mannor to which an AdvowÅ¿on belongs, enfeoffs A of the Mannor, which grants the AdvowÅ¿on to B, and re-enfeoffs the Tenant in tail; the IÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit, becauÅ¿e the other had no remedy, Nat. br. 35. B. 19 Hen. 6.30. and Å¿o Å¿hall not be in a better condition, and by the Grant of the AdvowÅ¿on apart it ceaÅ¿eth to be appendant.

Tenant in tail leaÅ¿es his EÅ¿tate over, the Church voids, he dies, the IÅ¿Å¿ue in tail Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, 9 Edw. 3.10. and not the LeÅ¿Å¿ee of the Mannor; for the preÅ¿entation is not comprized in the LeaÅ¿e.

Tenant in tail Å¿uffers an UÅ¿urpation before the Statute, the IÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit after the Statute, 8 Edw. 2. Quare Imp. 167. for before he was in no better a condition than his AnceÅ¿tor, and the Statute was made for the bepefit of the IÅ¿Å¿ue in tail.

Tenant in Dower Å¿hall have the third preÅ¿entment, where Å¿he is Dowable of the Thirds,In Dower. Nat. br. 33. L. 33 Hen. 8. br. PreÅ¿entment 55. 15 Hen. 7.17. Q. what Å¿he Å¿hall have when Å¿he is Dowable of the half, during her Widowhood, by the cuÅ¿tome of Gavel-kind.
So if Å¿he have the third part of a Mannor to which an AdvowÅ¿on belongs, Nat. br. 34. Q. 6 Edw. 3.215. in the reÅ¿pect of intereÅ¿t in the Mannor, proportionable to it.
Tenant for life Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, For life. in reÅ¿pect of his Freehold.
The Count, Lib. Intra. 513. A.

But if he Å¿uffers an UÅ¿urpation, he Å¿hall not have a Quare Impedit at any time after, 22 Hen. 6.26. B. for it was his own Latches to Å¿uffer it, for he might have brought his Quare Impedit upon the firÅ¿t diÅ¿turbance.

For years.Tenant for years Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit, although he doth not preÅ¿ent within the term, Nat. br. 34. B. 9 Edw. 3.338. pl. 6. 39 Hen. 6.39. viz. if the Church become void during the term, and no LapÅ¿e incurred, for it was a Chattel veÅ¿ted.

Tenant in common Å¿hall not have it without his Companion,In common. Nat. br. 34. Æ². 14 Eliz. Dyer 304. pl. 52. 33 Hen. 6.11. B. in reÅ¿pect of their common intereÅ¿t, and that the DiÅ¿turber may not be doubly vexed.

He that traverÅ¿eth an Office,TraverÅ¿e. and hath the Land in Farm, Å¿hall have the preÅ¿entment, if the Church be void during the time of his LeaÅ¿e, Å¿o it be found for him, although no mention be made of the AdvowÅ¿on, Nat. br. 34. P. for it goes with the Land.

Note,Note. that the King upon an Office found for him, Å¿hall not put the Patron out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, without admiÅ¿Å¿ion and inÅ¿titution of his Clerk, Coke 9. part. 96. A. Reynels caÅ¿e; for that is the only way to gain poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of an AdvowÅ¿on, and an Office may not be true, for it is traverÅ¿able.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom a Quare Impedit lies.
div.p: Patron Å¿ole.It lies againÅ¿t a Patron Å¿ole, 29 Hen. 6.57. 19 Hen. 6.67. pl. 14. & fol 73. pl. 1. & fol. 75. pl. 5.
But then the Incumbent Å¿hall not be removed, 29 Hen. 6.57. 7 Hen. 4.34. for if he be, it lies alÅ¿o againÅ¿t the DiÅ¿turber.
UnleÅ¿s there be no Incumbent at the time of the Writ brought, 29 Hen. 6.57. 19 Hen. 6.67. pl. 14. & fol. 73. pl. 1. & fol. 75. pl. 5. for then the Patron only muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily be the DiÅ¿turber.

Incumbent Å¿ole.If it be againÅ¿t an Incumbent Å¿ole it Å¿hall abate, 3 Hen. 4.2. Quare Impedit 113. 41 Edw 3.2. Br. Quare Imped. 24. vide 47 Edw. 3.10. for he comes in under another mans right, who muÅ¿t be named in the Writ.

But note, this is intended when the Inheritance, eÅ¿tate or intereÅ¿t of the Patron in the Patronage,Note. is to be deveÅ¿ted by the Judgment, for otherwiÅ¿e he ought not to be named, Coke 7. part. 26. B. Halls caÅ¿e, for it concerns him not to be made a party.
When there is no Patron, the Writ Å¿hall be againÅ¿t the Incumbent Å¿ole, 13 Hen. 8.12. 4 Hen. 8.3. for there can be no other DiÅ¿turber but he.

When the King preÅ¿ents, it lies againÅ¿t the Incumbent Å¿ole, becauÅ¿e the King Å¿hall not be Å¿ued, Coke 7. part. 26. B. Halls caÅ¿e, 92 Hen. 8. Dyer 48. pl. 16. 24 Edw. 3.77. pl. 103. Crooke 19 Hen. 7.53. pl. 9. But by Petition he may be Å¿ued too, and the Law intends he will do all his Subjects right without Å¿uit.

It lies for the Defendant againÅ¿t the Plaintiff,Plaintiff. if the Clerk of the Defendant be not inÅ¿tituted, Nat. br. 35. C. and he be diÅ¿turbed by the Plaintiff. It Å¿eems this is meant where there is a croÅ¿s Suit betwixt them.

But not of the Å¿ame preÅ¿entation, if the Plaintiff have brought his Writ, 19 Hen. 6.67. pl. 14. & fol. 73. pl. 1. fol. 75. pl. 5. 22 Edw. 3.4. pl. 10. for he that firÅ¿t commences his Action Å¿hall firÅ¿t determine his right.

The King grants a Free Chappel to B by Patent,Sheriff. if the Sheriff will not put him into poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, he Å¿hall have a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Sheriff, for this is in the nature of a Lay Å¿ee, and belongs not to the Ordinary, and the Writ Å¿hall be general, 14 Hen. 4.11. pl. 9. Haukeford, as in other Quare Impedits; but the Count muÅ¿t be Å¿pecial, as it Å¿eems.

div.head: Quare Impedit, of what diÅ¿turbances it lies.
div.p: If a DiÅ¿turber preÅ¿ents three times within the Å¿ix months;DiÅ¿turber. Quare Impedit lies for the former, Nat. br. 35. R. of the PreÅ¿entations; for there began the firÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of action.

The Ordinary refuÅ¿es to grant a Jure Patronatus to try the Title, or to admit the Clerk, a Quare Impedit lies, 33 Hen. 6.12.32. 34 Hen. 6.11. 35 Hen. 6.38. for this is a diÅ¿turbance to the PreÅ¿entation.
So if it be Litigious, and the Ordinary admit a Clerk without awarding a Jure Patronatus, 22 Hen. 6.25. Bre. 83. for this is to diÅ¿turb by forejudging of the right.
So if he do not admit him within convenient time, 22 Hen. 6.29. for delays are diÅ¿turbances, and accounted denials; for JuÅ¿tice ought to be Å¿peedily done.

The BiÅ¿hop refuÅ¿es to admit the Clerk, becauÅ¿e it was firÅ¿t found for another in a Jure Patronatus; this is a diÅ¿turbance, Nat. br. 35. G. for he is not to take notice of the Suits between the parties.
UnleÅ¿s the Admittas be delivered to him, 21 Hen. 6.44. for that is the Act of the Court, of which he is bound to take notice.

div.head: Quare Impedit, of what things it lies.
div.p: And if one had been diÅ¿turbed before the Statute, yet he Å¿hould have had the Writ, becauÅ¿e the Statute refers before as well as after, 6 Edw. 3.221. pl. 51. Q.
The Count, Lib. Intra. 646. C.
It lies of a Chappel, 22 Hen. 6.25. B. antea. Chappel.
And it lies by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. Lib. Intr. 52. A. Å¿ell. 2.
The Writ Å¿hall be PraeÅ¿entatum ad Capellam liberam, Nat. br. 32. H. 8.
But if the King brings a Quare Impedit of his free Chappel, it Å¿hall be praeÅ¿entare ad Praebendam in his Frank Chappel, Nat. br. 33. & 16 Edw. 3.3. nota differentiam.
It lies of a Deanary,Deanary. 17 Edw. 3.40.
It lies of Domus Sancti Martini, in BriÅ¿tol, Nat. br. 33 G. Domus S. Martini. HoÅ¿pital.
It lies of an HoÅ¿pital, Nat. br. 33. G. pro WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. the Count, Lib. Intra. 506. C. Sect. 1. becauÅ¿e they are all preÅ¿entative.

De Medietate Advocationis.It lies not de medietate Advocationis, neque de Advocatioue medietatis EccleÅ¿iae, Nat. br. 33. A. 33 Hen. 6.11. B. PriÅ¿ot, vide 4 Hen. 6.15. B. for it muÅ¿t be of an entire thing, or at leaÅ¿t Å¿o Å¿uppoÅ¿ed by the Writ, for the Law takes no notice of Å¿uch moieties.

But in Å¿uch caÅ¿es the Writ Å¿hall be general (Å¿cil. ad EccleÅ¿iam) and not (ad medietatem EccleÅ¿iae;) but the Count Å¿hall be Å¿pecial, and Å¿et forth Å¿pecial Title, Coke 5. part. 102. WinÅ¿ors caÅ¿e, 16 Edw. 6. Dyer 78. pl. 44.

But where there are two Å¿everal Patrons, and two Å¿everal Incumbents of the Å¿ame Church, within one and the Å¿ame Village, Å¿o that the AdvowÅ¿on and Church are Å¿evered in right and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, there one Patron may have a Quare Impedit de medietate EccleÅ¿iae, Coke 10. part. 135. B. Smiths caÅ¿e; for there their Titles are entire.
21 Hen. 6.4. pl. 8. in fine, One perÅ¿on Å¿ays that he was ParÅ¿on but of the Moiety of the Church, and good, 7 Edw. 3.246. pl. 24. Quare Impedit of the Moiety of the Church. Q.
It lies of a ParÅ¿onage,ParÅ¿onage. and the Writ Å¿hall be ad EccleÅ¿iam, becauÅ¿e EccleÅ¿ia is intended of a ParÅ¿onage, Nat. br. 32. H. viz. the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Church, Glebe, and Tithes.
It lies of a Prebendary,Prebend. per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5.
The Count, No. Lib. Intr. 507. B.
The Writ Å¿hall be ad Praebendam, Nat. br. 32. H. 40 Edw. 3.17. pl. 7. but it ought to Å¿hew the name of it, 40 Edw. 3.17. to make it more certain, for elÅ¿e the word is too general.
It lies of the Subdeaconry of York, Subdeaconry. Nat. br. 34. G. becauÅ¿e preÅ¿entative of right, as it Å¿eems.
The Writ Å¿hall be quod permittat eum praeÅ¿entare, and yet the King gives it by his Letters ters Patents, Nat. br. 34. G. but it Å¿eems Å¿uch Writs were but of puiÅ¿ne temps.
It lies of a Vicarage,Vicarage. per 2. WeÅ¿tm. cap. 5. viz. a Vicarage to be endowed.
The Writ Å¿hall be ad Vicariam, Nat. br. 32. H. which the Law well takes notice of.

div.head: The Count in a Quare Impedit.
div.p: He that brings a Quare Impedit in his count ought to alledge a PreÅ¿entment in himÅ¿elf, or in his AnceÅ¿tors, or in him by whom he claims, Nat. br. 33. H.
1. UnleÅ¿s a man erect a new Church, for then the Count Å¿hall be Å¿pecial, Nat. br. 33. H. 17 Edw. 3.12. and Å¿hall Å¿et it forth, to make it appear he cannot alledge a PreÅ¿entment.
2. If he recover in a Writ of right, then he may alledge the preÅ¿entation in him againÅ¿t whom he recovered, Nat. br. 33. J. Q.
Or he may have this Writ without alleadging any preÅ¿entation, for he may count upon the Record, Nat. br. 36. A. whereby he recovered, and that makes it appear the PreÅ¿entation belongs to him.
Or if he recover in a Quare Impedit, the Å¿ame Law, 42 Edw. 3.8. pl. 5.
3. He may alleadge Å¿eiÅ¿in in the Procurator, Nat. br. 33. J. 17 Edw. 3.60, & 75. which is, as it were his own Å¿eiÅ¿in.

He that alleadges PreÅ¿entation in himÅ¿elf, ought to Å¿hew that the PreÅ¿entee was inÅ¿tituted, although that it was againÅ¿t a Common perÅ¿on, for without InÅ¿titution he had no fruit of his preÅ¿entation, and Å¿o it is as nul. But againÅ¿t the King he ought to Å¿hew that he was Inducted, Com. 528. Bickleys caÅ¿e, Coke 6. part. 49. BoÅ¿welt caÅ¿e; for a man muÅ¿t make a full and compleat Title againÅ¿t the King.
And Å¿uch preÅ¿entment ought to be within memory, 17 Edw. 3.10. Quaere of the Law at this day.
PreÅ¿entation in his own name.DeviÅ¿ee for life alleadges the preÅ¿entation in himÅ¿elf, and good, Coke 5. part. 37. 8 Hen. 5.10. in reÅ¿pect of his Free-hold.
Of the preÅ¿entation of Tenant for life, vid. Coke 5. part. 97, 98.
For years, 7 Edw. 4.20. 22 Edw. 4.9. B. In Dower.
By the CourteÅ¿ie.
At Will, 5 Hen. 5.3. pl. 6.
TheÅ¿e are the preÅ¿entments of him that hath Fee. Q.

The King grants the AdvowÅ¿on to A, the Church being void, and preÅ¿ents, 13 Eliz. Dyer 330. pl. 36. by LapÅ¿e, 21 Eliz. Dyer 364. pl. 28. and good, for his grant hinders not, for he preÅ¿ents by LapÅ¿e upon another title.
But the iÅ¿Å¿ue in Tail ought to alleadge preÅ¿entment in the Donor, becauÅ¿e he derives his title from him, or he may alledge it in himÅ¿elf, Com. Manxels caÅ¿e, fol. 4. B.

If it be alleadged in the Donor or Donee, LeÅ¿Å¿or or LeÅ¿Å¿ee, it is not double, becauÅ¿e the
PreÅ¿entment of the LeÅ¿Å¿or or Donor is only traverÅ¿able,PreÅ¿entation in him, by which he claims. and not of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee or Donee, Coke 5. part. 99. A. Northumberlands caÅ¿e.
For the LeÅ¿Å¿ee ought regularly to alleadge it in the LeÅ¿Å¿or, Coke 5. part. 98. A.
Yet, if he alleadge PreÅ¿entation by himÅ¿elf it is good, 8 Hen. 25.4.
But in the Judgment of the Law this is the PreÅ¿entation of the LeÅ¿Å¿or, Coke 5. part. 89. and Å¿o taken notice of what ever he alleadge.
A PurchaÅ¿er may alleadge it in him whoÅ¿e EÅ¿tate he hath, becauÅ¿e he derives from him, 13 Hen. 8.12. pl. 2. 2 Edw. 3. pl. 29.1. 6 Edw. 3.204. pl. 7. Nat. br. 33. H.

He that brings a Quare Impedit ought to Å¿hew, Å¿pecially how the Church becomes void, 5 Edw. 4.72. B. for the Iucumbent may be removed out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion by Spoliation, DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, or be outed otherways, yet then the Church is full in the eye of the Law.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s in a Quare Impedit, 1. Before appearance; 2. After.
div.p: Vide Lib. Intra. 52. B. Sect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. At the Common Law it was but a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s infinite, 11 Hen. 6.3. Martin.

But per le Stat. Marlebridge, cap. 12. if he appears not at the Grand DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, a Writ Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue to the BiÅ¿hop, 24 Edw. 3.37. 5 Edw. 4.115. 7 Eliz. Dyer 241. pl. 48. 7 Eliz. Dyer 241. pl. 1. Nat. br. 38. N.
The Å¿ame Law in a Scire facias by the King, upon a Judgment in a Quare Impedit, 14 Edw. 3. Qu. Imped. 5.

So if the Sheriff returns a Nihil upon the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s, 12 Hen. 4.4. Hankeford, 21 Hen 6.56. pl. 13. 11 Hen. 6.3. pl. 8. becauÅ¿e the ProceÅ¿s is determined, vide 27 Hen. 6.5. pl. 32. for the Sheriff hath done as much as he can in the executing of it.
And this is for the miÅ¿chief of the LapÅ¿e, 24 Edw. 3.37. viz. in all the foregoing caÅ¿es wherein there is no Laches in the Patron, nor any delay cauÅ¿ed by him.

But if a Nihil be returned upon the Summons, Attachment, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, quaere 11 Hen. 6.3. if a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop 4. Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue; yet the better opinion there is, that a Writ Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue to the BiÅ¿hop. And this Å¿eems to be Å¿o upon the Å¿ame ground, viz. for the miÅ¿chief of a LapÅ¿e.

And if a Quare Impedit be againÅ¿t two, and one appears at the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s, the other makes default, a Writ Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue to the BiÅ¿hop pro querente againÅ¿t him that made default, N â¢ t. br. 39. B. 14 Hen. 7.19. but not againÅ¿t the other becauÅ¿e he appears according to Law.

Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop and B,
ãâã makes default at the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s, the BiÅ¿hop pleads that he claims nothing but as Ordinary, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop againÅ¿t B, after the Count made againÅ¿t the Defendants upon the BiÅ¿hops appearing at the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s, 10 Hen. 6.4. Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 3.

In a Quare Impedit the Defendant appears, and after appearance makes default, the Plantiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 2 Hen. 4.1. pl. 3. Nat. br. 38. S. becauÅ¿e it Å¿hall be intended he will not longer defend himÅ¿elf.

At the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s the Defendant pleads to iÅ¿Å¿ue, and after makes default, a Writ Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue to the BiÅ¿hop without more ado, for the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s was iÅ¿Å¿uable, 16 Edw. 3. Writ to the BiÅ¿hop 17.12 Edw. 2. Quare Impedit 168.
Upon a default at the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s the Plaintiff Å¿hall have Judgment, Lib. Intra. 507. A. Sect. 1, 2, 3. Judgment, as upon a Nihil dicit.

The Plaintiff is Non-Å¿uited, the Defendant Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop without making Title, as it Å¿eems; but the Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to make Title, 33 Hen. 6.1. pl. 2. for that puts all without queÅ¿tion for the future.

T brought an AÅ¿Å¿ize of Darrein PreÅ¿entment againÅ¿t P, and the AÅ¿Å¿ize was taken by his, viz. P's default, and when the AÅ¿Å¿ize was Å¿worn, T withdrawed himÅ¿elf; P Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, although he was not in Court, 9 Edw. 3. Darrein PreÅ¿entment 17. for Å¿ome Judgment muÅ¿t be, and it cannot be for T. And although P
â¢â¢ de default, yet the enqueÅ¿t might have found for him upon Å¿omething of their own knowledge.

div.head: Barr in a Quare Impedit, 1. By the Ordinary. 2. By others.
div.p: Plea by the Ordinary the Church Litigious.The Church was Litigious, and he Collated after the Å¿ix months, 34 Hen. 6.41. pl. 10. 5 Hen. 7.19. 34 Hen. 6.38. 2 Hen. 6.44. 18 Edw. 3.

It Å¿hall be accounted Litigious, where there are two PreÅ¿entations and two CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, and one
CommiÅ¿Å¿ion is found for one,What Å¿hall be accounted Litigious. and another for another, 22 H. 6.44. A. Newton & PaÅ¿ton; for no man here can judge whoÅ¿e the right is, for they are as it were in aequali jure.

But if the Title of one be found, and another preÅ¿ent, and requeÅ¿t is made to admit the Clerk, for which it was found, it is not Litigious, 22 Hen. 6.28. Br. of Quare Impedit 80. for there is a Title found for one, and none for the other.
If two Joyntenants, or Tenants in common preÅ¿ent Å¿everally, it is not Litigious, Doct. & Stud. 116. A. for their right is one and the Å¿ame.

If two preÅ¿ent Å¿everally, and neither the one nor the other pray a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion to enquire the right, the Church is Litigious, Lib. Intra 511, & 512. 35 Hen. 6.18. pl. 27.8. Edw. 3.289. pl. 49. becauÅ¿e the right of neither is put in iÅ¿Å¿ue.
Claiming nothing but as Ordinary, Judgment, Å¿i, &c. without Å¿pecial diÅ¿turbance; this is good, 5 Hen. 7.19. 22 Hen. 6.15. 33 Hen. 6. â¢â¢ .32. viz. a good plea in barr for the Ordinary.
But the Plaintiff upon this may pray Judgment, and have it with CeÅ¿Å¿at Executio, until, &c. Crook 17 Hen. 7.43. pl. 9. the right determined.
Pleas in diÅ¿ability of the perÅ¿on preÅ¿ented, are as followeth:RefuÅ¿ing the Clerk for default in the preÅ¿entee which is.

list.item: 1. An Alien, 7 Rich. 2. and this although he be made Denizen after, ibidem; viz. after he preÅ¿ented, for he was not idoneous at the time of the refuÅ¿al.

2. BaÅ¿tard, Coke 5. part. 58. A. 11 Hen. 4.8. A. 11 Hen. 7.12. 11 Hen. 4.37. but if he be admitted it is good. 29 Edw. 3.44. pl. 3. Q. whether, and by what Law it is a good plea, becauÅ¿e he is nullius filius.
3. Blind, Coke 11. part. 29. B. For he cannot Å¿ee to Å¿tudy, nor can watch over his Flock. Q. tamen. For blind men have received Orders.
4. Heretick. Coke 11. part. 29. B. For he is not fit to inÅ¿truct or guide his flock.
5. Homicide, 38 Edw. 3.2. For he is not fit to be a MiniÅ¿ter of the GoÅ¿pel of peace.
6. Infant, Coke. 5. part. 58. A. 6. Edw. 3.184. pl. 6. Herle. For he is not fit to guide himÅ¿elf or his own eÅ¿tate, much leÅ¿s others Å¿ouls.
7. Jew. Coke 11. part. 29. B. qua a Jew; but if a convert, it Å¿eems he may.
8. Illiterate, 12 Eliz. Dyer. 293. pl. 3. Coke 5. part. 58. A. Specotts caÅ¿e. 40 Edw. 3.25. pl. 31. For he is unfit to teach, and had more need to be taught.
9. Perjured, For he will make little conÅ¿cience of Religion.
11. MiÅ¿creant, Coke 5. part. 58. A. Specotts caÅ¿e, viz. that believes not rightly the Articles of the Faith: For how will he maintain and inÅ¿truct others in it?
12. Not able upon examination, 39 Edw. 3.1. pl. 5. viz. of the Ordinary in the principles of Religion, and other fit qualifications.
13. Premunire, 38 Edw. 3.3. pl. 9. In regard of the heinouÅ¿neÅ¿s of the offence and puniÅ¿hment.
14. HimÅ¿elf patron, 31 Hen. 6.621. For he ought not to preÅ¿ent himÅ¿elf.
15. Saracen, Coke 11. part 29. B. or Turk, or Infidel, not acknowledging God and ChriÅ¿t.
16. SchiÅ¿matick, Coke 5. part. 58. A. Specotts caÅ¿e. For he will make diÅ¿turbance in the Church.
17. SimoniÅ¿t. Lib. intra. 532. A. Q. By what Law.
18. Villain, 14 Hen. 7.28. B. for he is not Å¿ui juris.
19. Utlaw, Coke 5. part. 48. A. Specotts caÅ¿e, For he is fit for no Å¿ociety, and unfit to teach obedience to others, that hath none himÅ¿elf.

div.head: TheÅ¿e are good CauÅ¿es of refuÅ¿al, viz. which are above Å¿pecified.
div.p: Where one having a ParÅ¿onage in Wales, Note. and could not Å¿peak WelÅ¿h, and therefore excepted unto as inÅ¿ufficient, it was demurred to Trin. 27 Eliz. Albany verÅ¿us EpiÅ¿copum S. AÅ¿af. Q. Deley. as not a Å¿ufficient cauÅ¿e.

div.head: TheÅ¿e are not good cauÅ¿es of refuÅ¿al.
div.p: That he hath another Benefice with Cure, 14 Hen. 7.28. B. For he may be qualified to have two Benefices by the Stat.

Hunter of Taverns and a player at unlawful Games, Coke 5. part. 57. Specotts caÅ¿e. 9 Eliz. Dyer. 254. For this makes him not unfit to watch, though it make him Å¿candalous, for which he ought to be puniÅ¿hed.
CriminoÅ¿us, 34 Hen. 6.39. A. For that is a word of a very large extent, and uncertain.

div.head: TheÅ¿e are good cauÅ¿es of refuÅ¿al in the PreÅ¿enter.
div.p: Attainted, 15 Hen 5.17. B. Keble. viz. of Felony or TreaÅ¿on.

PreÅ¿enter which is.Excommunicated per 40 days 115 Hen. 7.7. B. Keble. and Å¿o Å¿tands excommunicated in contempt of the Church. This Law is now altered by the taking away the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical juriÅ¿diction in that point, and now is again revived.
Infant not of the Age of 14 years, Perkins. 4. A. For he Å¿hall not be judged of Å¿ufficient diÅ¿cretion to preÅ¿ent a fit perÅ¿on. Q. tamen.
Joynt Tenant or Tenant in common not agreeing, Nat. br. 34. V. concerning their preÅ¿enting; for that is litigious.
The Å¿ame Law is of one preÅ¿ent alone, 14 Eliz. Dyer. 340. pl. 54. except it be by conÅ¿ent.
A MaÅ¿ter of a Colledge preÅ¿ented by the Colledge, 14 Hen. 8.23. For that is like as when the Patron preÅ¿ents himÅ¿elf.
Utlawed, 15 Hen. 7.17. B. Keble. For he can have no Title.
A Corporation ought to preÅ¿ent in writing,PreÅ¿entation. 14 Hen. 8.2. and not by parol, for they cannot ill Å¿peak at once, as they may by writing.

A Body natural may preÅ¿ent by word, 14 Hen.
â¢ .22.

The King may preÅ¿ent by word, 19. Edw. 3. Quare impedit. 60. For he is but one perÅ¿on numerical,
though he hath a political capacity, and Å¿peaks in the plural number.

It is no Bar to Å¿ay that the other Writ was abeted,Abatement. if it were for form or falÅ¿e Latine, Coke
â¢ . part 27. B. Portmans caÅ¿e. For that is not the fault of the Plaintiff, but of the Clark.
But that it was abated, becauÅ¿e the 1 Plaintiff was made Knight, the Writ depending, this is ãâã good Bar, Coke 7. part. 27. B. Portmans caÅ¿e. For it was his own fault.

The Plaintiff counts of the preÅ¿entment to the AdvowÅ¿on in GroÅ¿s,Appendant. and a Grant of it to him; the Defendant pleads it was appendant, he cannot traverÅ¿e that it was not in groÅ¿s, becauÅ¿e by intendment they are Å¿everal AdvowÅ¿ons, Crooke. 19 Hen. 7.51. pl. 1. For one and the Å¿ame AdvowÅ¿ee cannot be in groÅ¿s, and alÅ¿o appendant.
An Arbitrement is a good Bar,Arbitrement. Lib. intra. 498. C. Å¿. 1.
A Confirmation or ratification by the King to the Incumbent is a good Bar againÅ¿t the Kingâª 7 Hen. 4.13.14 Hen. 4.25.837. Lib. intra. 531. Å¿ect. 22. by way of eÅ¿topple.Confirmation.
But this ought to be after Induction, 11 He â¢ . 4.9. For before he Å¿hall not be Å¿aid to be a perfect Incumbent, as to the King.
If the King be deceived, he may repeal the Confirmation, 31 Edw. 3. Quare impedit, 161 This by his prerogative; for the King ought ãâã be truly informed.

But then the repeal ought to be before Ind â¢
ction or InÅ¿tallation, 25 Edw. 3.47. for after ãâã is too late.
If the King recover and confirm the Incumbent, this is no Bar to the next avoidance, becauÅ¿e his Judgment cannot be executed, Nat. br. 34. F. 10. Edw. 3.389. pl. 32. 18 Edw. 3.57. pl. 87.

But if he LeaÅ¿e the AdvowÅ¿ons afterwards,
â¢ uare who Å¿hall have them?

Where one brought a Quare impedit, DiÅ¿continuance. and diÅ¿cootinued his Action, adjudged a good Bar, although that the Writ was purchaÅ¿ed afterwards within the 6 Months, Coke 7. part. 27. B. Portnans caÅ¿e. For it Å¿hall be intended he hath no right.
A Fine levied by the AnceÅ¿tor of the Plaintiff of the AdvowÅ¿on, is a good Bar,Fine. Lib. intra. 532. C. Å¿ect. 3.
Warranty and AÅ¿Å¿ets deÅ¿cended to the heir,Warranty is a good Bar againÅ¿t the IÅ¿Å¿ue in Tail, 43. Edw. 3.24. pl. 31.
No DiÅ¿turber.That he did not diÅ¿turb, is a good bar, Lib. â¢â¢ tra. 503. C. Å¿ect. 2. 22 Edw. 3.17. pl. 71. For a good IÅ¿Å¿ue may be taken upon it.
This may be pleaded to the grand DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 22 Edw. 3.17. pl. 71. as well as if he had appeared upon the firÅ¿t Å¿ummons.

But 21 Hen. 6.45. A. 2 Edw. 3.32. pl. 7. It is held that it is no Bar, becauÅ¿e no Title is made. 14. Edw. 3. Judgment, 158. and before Title made there needs no plea; yet Q. For he may, as it Å¿eems, admit a Title.

But if it be a good plea before IÅ¿Å¿ue, yet after IÅ¿Å¿ue joyned it is not, becauÅ¿e it is a delay, and Å¿o a diÅ¿turbance in it Å¿elf in the eye of the Law,
3 Edw. 3.50. pl. 6.4. Edw. 3.97. pl. 31.17. Edw. 3.71.

But 18. Edw. 3.149. pl. 15. & fol. 359. ãâã
Ã¨ contra, after title made, this is no plea, 5 Hen. 4.20. Br. Quare impedit, 62. Q.
AgainÅ¿t the King it is no Bar, becauÅ¿e the patty there ought to make a title, 7 Hen. 4.32. pl. 18.

Non-Å¿uit after appearance in another Quare impedit before for the Å¿ame advowÅ¿on,Non-Å¿uit. is a good Bar: although the laÅ¿t be purchaÅ¿ed within 6 Months, Coke. 7. part. 27. B. Portmans caÅ¿e. 21 Hen. 6.25.27. For that argues he had no right, and that his Suit was only vexatious.
And Å¿o if the former Writ were brought by the Plaintiff and another, and the Plantiff is nonÅ¿uit, 5 E. 157. pl. 10. For thereby he deÅ¿iÅ¿ts in his Claim.
No Å¿uch Church.No Å¿uch Church in the Å¿ame County, is no Bar, 8 Hen. 6.37. pl. 69. 9 Hen. 6.17. Q.
But 45 Edw. 3.36. pl. 2. Ã¨ contra. Q.
Pardon of the King for alienation is no Bar,Pardon. if the Church be void before the pardon, 27 Edw. 3.38. For then the pardon works not upon the precedent right.

Plentary a good Bar,Plentary. though the Patron his no notice of the Avoidance; for this is to Å¿top the Collation of the Ordinary, but not the PreÅ¿entation of the Patron, PaÅ¿ch. 39 Eliz. Com. B â¢â¢ . Seriven againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop of Lincolne.

Plenarty of a Frank Chappel is no Bar; for if he Å¿hall be put to his Quare impedit, then it Å¿hall be preÅ¿entative afterwards, 22 Hen. 6.25. B. Which is miÅ¿chievous to the Patron, in making
it Å¿ubject to the viÅ¿itation of the Ordinary.

The Church is Å¿aid to be full againÅ¿t a common perÅ¿on by InÅ¿titution, 22 Hen. 6.27. A. 14 Hen. 8 2. Brudenel. 12 Hen. 4.38. For by that the Clerk is approved, and Induction is but as it were giving of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.
And againÅ¿t the King by Induction, 22 Hen. 6.27. B. which makes him a compleat Incumbent to all intents and purpoÅ¿es.

He that pleads plenarty, ought to Å¿ay that it is full of his own preÅ¿entment, and not of anothers; for if the Defendant be diÅ¿turbed, he Å¿hall not be puniÅ¿hed, and if he hath title, he ought to Å¿hew it, 3 Hen. 6.20. Br. plenarty 6. 16 Edw. 4.11.8 Edw. 3. Statham.
He Å¿hall plead that he was in per 6 Months of his PreÅ¿entment before the purchaÅ¿e of the AdvowÅ¿on by the Plantiff.
But if it be of a preÅ¿entment of the predeceÅ¿Å¿or of the Plaintiff, yet it is good, 8 Edw. 3. preÅ¿entment 5.
The 6 Months Å¿hall be accounted according to the Kalendar, Coke 6. part. 61, 62. Catesbyes caÅ¿e; and not after 28 days to the Month; for that is the ancient account uÅ¿ed in Law.

div.head: Who Å¿hall plead Plenarty, and who not.
div.p: Incumbent pleads Plenarty of himÅ¿elf,Incumbent. ex praeÅ¿entatione B. viz. the Plantiff. Coke. 6 part 48.2 Hen. 6.14. pl. 22. No. Lib. intra. 265. A. abÅ¿que hoc that it was void; for the Incumbent is not able to plead it otherways, per 25 Edw. 3. cap. 7.
But 16 Edw. 4.11. pl. 6. Com. 501. A. Manwood Ã¨ contra. Ergo Q.
BecauÅ¿e he that pleads this, ought to Å¿ay, that the Incumbent is in of his own preÅ¿entation, 2 Rich. 2. Incumbent 4. Belknap. 46 Edw. 3.19. 18 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 48. and not of anothers.
But per 4 Edw. 4.13. The Incumbent pleads that the Plaintiff, or his predeceÅ¿Å¿or preÅ¿ented him. Q. For it Å¿eems to be uncertain.

ParÅ¿on imparÅ¿onee cannot plead plenarty, becauÅ¿e that he cannot Å¿ay, that he is in per Å¿ix Months of his own preÅ¿entment, 38 Hen. 6.20. B. 33 Hen. 6.12. pl. 27. Com. 501. A. Manwood. 39 Hen. 6.20.46. AÅ¿Å¿ize. pl. 4.
A Stranger, or he that claims nothing in the Patronage, cannot plead Plenarty, 7 Hen. 4.34. per Fitz James. For it lies not in his mouth to Å¿ay whether the Church be full or not.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom Plenarty is no Plea.
div.p: AgainÅ¿t the Lord that enters for Mortmain, it is no Plea; becauÅ¿e the Lord hath liberty by the Law to enter at any time within the year, 21 Edw. 3.27. pl. 25. 29 Edw. 3.10. pl. 31. Thorpe. 47 Edw. 3.11. pl. 8.
But after the year it is a good plea, 25 Edw. 3.34. 26 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit. 163. For then he is in the condition of another Petron.

Quaere if it be good againÅ¿t the Lord by â¢â¢â¢ cheat, â¢â¢
Hen. 8.14. Brudenel. It Å¿eems
it is, for he Å¿hall be in no better condition then, than the Patron that died without Heir.

It is no plea againÅ¿t the King, 35 Hen. 6.26. A. 1 Edw. 3.17. pl. 9. 8 Edw. 3.304. pl. 55. 43 Edw. 3.14. pl. 8. For it is not a Plea in chief to determine the right, but only delatory, and the King Å¿hall not be delayed.

But againÅ¿t the Queen, Mother or ConÅ¿ort, it Å¿eems to be good, 18 Edw. 3.13. pl. 9. 44 Edw. 3. Br. Plenarty 4. For Å¿he is but a Å¿ubject, and Å¿hall be in no better condition in the eye of the Law.

A good Bar to Å¿ay,PreÅ¿entation. that the Plaintiff preÅ¿ented his Clerk, and that he was inducted before the Writ purchaÅ¿ed, 12 Hen. 4.11. pl. 21. vide Crooke. 12 Hen. 7.20. pl. 6. For then he could have no cauÅ¿e of Action.
A Recovery in another Quare Impedit, Recovery. no Bar againÅ¿t the King, for he may make another Title, Nat. br. 35. P. than was made before, and a better it may be.
A Recovery by by the Plaintiff againÅ¿t another in a Quare Impedit for the Å¿ame AdvowÅ¿on, no Bar; for there might be two diÅ¿turbers.
Recovery by a Stranger in another Quare Impedit, no Bar, Crooke. 18 Hen. 7.49. pl. 4. For nothing concerns the preÅ¿ent Plaintiff.
That the Plaintiff is a RecuÅ¿ant Convict,RecuÅ¿ancy a good Bar; for the PreÅ¿entment is given to the UniverÅ¿ity, per 3 Jac. And therefore the Plaintiff can have no cauÅ¿e of Action.

ReleaÅ¿e of Actions PerÅ¿onals a good Bar,ReleaÅ¿e. 22 Hen. 6.25, vel 27. Littleton. fol. 116. A.
30 Hen. 6. Bar. 59. For this is a mixt Action, and Å¿o it is perÅ¿onal in part.
So of Actions real, Litteton 116. A. 9 Hen. 6.57. Martin: For being next, it is alÅ¿o real as well as perÅ¿onal.

If a PreÅ¿entment be alledged in the AnceÅ¿try of the Plaintiff, it is a good Bar to plead a ReleaÅ¿e and Quit claim of the AnceÅ¿try, pro fine 8 Edw. 2. Quare Impedit 166. For thereby the Plaintiffs cauÅ¿e of Action is extinct.

If there be more Plaintiffs in a Quare Impedit than one, the ReleaÅ¿e of one is no Bar, but for him only that releaÅ¿ed, Coke 5. part 97. B. Nor. thumberlands caÅ¿e. 30 Hen. 6. Bar. 59. ForteÅ¿cue. For their Titles may be diÅ¿tinct and Å¿everal.

div.head: Judgment in a Quare Impedit.
1. When he Å¿hall have Judgment. 2. Of what things he Å¿hall have Judgment.
div.p: Upon default after apppearance,Upon default. the Plaintiff Å¿hall have Judgment and Dammages, 2 Hen. 4.1. pl. 3. Nat. br. 38. S. For this is, as it were, the confeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Plaintiffs Title.
But upon default after a continuance, DiÅ¿treÅ¿s Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue out only, 6 Rich. 2. viz. before apparence make him to appear.

Upon Default at the grand DiÅ¿treÅ¿s the Plaintiff Å¿hall have Judgment, Lib. intra. 507. A. Å¿ect. 1, 2, 3. For that is the laÅ¿t proceÅ¿s to bring in the Defendant; and the Plaintiff can proceed no further upon mean proceÅ¿s.

In a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t two, and one makes default after appearance, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have Judgment againÅ¿t him that makes default, Nat. br. 39. B. But not againÅ¿t the other; for anothers default Å¿hall not prejudice him.

If in a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t three, one makes default after apparance, and it is found againÅ¿t the Plaintiff for the others that appeared, who make a title, and it Å¿eems they Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 31 Hen. 6.15. pl. 5. Q.

One Defendant makes Title by himÅ¿elf, and others make default, the Judgment Å¿hall be to have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop for him that makes Title; but this is not before the Plaintiff have counted, Nat. br. 38. J. 10 Hen. 6.4. pl. 13. For before that the cauÅ¿e of Action doth not appear.

Upon the Non-Å¿uit of the Plaintiff,Non-Å¿uit. the Defendant Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, but not before Title made, Nat. br. 38. K. 2 Hen. 5.6. pl. 28. 19 Edw. 4.9. pl. 10. 6 Edw. 3.23. ColluÅ¿ion 5. 14 Hen. 4.11. That it may appear he hath a colourable right at the leaÅ¿t.
UnleÅ¿s the Non-Å¿uit be after a Bar pleaded, 33 Hen. 6.1. pl. 2. & fol. 55. pl. 48. againÅ¿t the Defendants Title.

Three Å¿ue a Quare Impedit, and two are nonÅ¿uited, and one of the Plaintiffs was alÅ¿o one of the Defendants, therefore he cannot make Title, ideo quaere, if they Å¿hall not have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop without Title made, 11 Hen. 6.8. pl. 13. Q.

A. Å¿ued divers Writs of Quare Impedit againÅ¿t B, of the Å¿ame Church, and is non Å¿uited in all exceptone, the Defendant Å¿hall not have a Writ
to the BiÅ¿hop until that be determined, Nat. br. 38. R. For it may be the Plaintiff may clear his Title by that.

The Defendant makes Title to himÅ¿elf and another, the Plaintiff is non-Å¿uited, the Defendant Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop only, 13 Edw. 3. br. EpiÅ¿e. 25. For his Title is a Bar to the Plaintiff which is not oppoÅ¿ed.

The Sheriff returns a tardÃ¨, &c. the Plaintiff makes default, he Å¿hall be non-Å¿uited; Q. but the Defendant Å¿hall not have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, becauÅ¿e the Writ was not Å¿erved, 2 Hen. 5.3. pl. 14. Nat. br. 38. O. 2 Hen. 5.6. nor the other Non-Å¿uited, as it Å¿eems, becauÅ¿e the Writ was not duly executed.
If an Infant be non-Å¿uited, the Defendant Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 2 Mariae Dyer. 104. pl. 13. to avoid a lapÅ¿e, and that the Church may Å¿peedily be provided for.
A. brought a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t B, C and D, and is non-Å¿uited, B dies, C and D Å¿hall not have execution alone, 11 Edw. 3. br. EpiÅ¿copo 55. becauÅ¿e the Action was joyntly brought againÅ¿t all.

If one of the Co-parceners who bring a Quare Impedit, be non-Å¿uited, yet the other may Å¿ue, and the Defendant Å¿hall not have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop upon this Non-Å¿uit, 38 Edw. 3.35. br. EpiÅ¿c. 12. becauÅ¿e they have Å¿everal Inheritances, and the default of one Å¿hall not bind another.

The Plaintiff diÅ¿continued his Suit,Discontinuance. the Defendant Å¿hall have Judgment to have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, Coke 7. part. 27. B. For his diÅ¿continuance concludes he had no cauÅ¿e of Action.

A. brought a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t B, CompoÅ¿ition. and Å¿ued a Ne admittas, and then they compounded to preÅ¿ent by turn, there Å¿hall be a Å¿pecial Writ out of the Chancery to the BiÅ¿hop, to admit the Clerk that ought firÅ¿t to be admitted. For a Å¿pecial CauÅ¿e may have a Å¿pecial Writ, and varying from the uÅ¿ual form.

In a Quare Impedit the Defendant diÅ¿claims in the AdvowÅ¿on, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have Judgment,DiÅ¿claimer and a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 6 Edw. 3.7. Error 78. For by the DiÅ¿claimer he acknowledgeth he hath no Title.

Where a Writ abates for form or falÅ¿e Latine,Abatement. there Å¿hall not be Judgment for the Defendant to have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, Nat. br. 38. H. 14 Hen. 4.11. 13 Hen. 4.7. For the Title is not determined, but only the Plaintiff is delayed.
The Defendant makes default, the Incumbent abates the Writ by plea, the Defendant Å¿hall not have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, becauÅ¿e he made default, Nat. br. 38. H, and Å¿o is not rectus in Curia.
If the Plaintiff being a Prebend, be made a BiÅ¿hop in Dublin, this Å¿hall abate the Writ, per Wilby, 24 Edw. 3.26. pl. 21. Q. how it Å¿hall be taken notice of here.
If the Writ abates for MiÅ¿noÅ¿mer, or other non-Å¿ufficiency in it, the Defendant Å¿hall not have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, Nat. br. 38. M. 31 Hen. 6.15. For the right is not determined.

If a Quare Impedit is brought in Com. M. and the Count is of a Church in Com. O, the Writ Å¿hall abate, but the Defendant Å¿hall not
have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 21 Rich. 2.29. for the former reaÅ¿on.
It was found by verdict that the Metropolitan collated where the Ordinary ought to have done it,Verdict. when the year is paÅ¿Å¿ed, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, Nat. br. 38. P. Q.

In a Quare Impedit between A and B, if the Title appear for the King, Judgment Å¿hall be given for him, Nat. br. 38. E. notwithÅ¿tanding he is not party to the Suit, that is, by his Prerogative. All the Judges are the Kings CounÅ¿el, and ought to give Judgment for him, where his Right appears, although he Å¿ue not for it.

div.head: The Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, to whom it Å¿hall be directed.
div.p: If a man recover againÅ¿t another as well as the BiÅ¿hop, he ought to have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop of the DioceÅ¿s, Nat. br. 38. C. For a BiÅ¿hop is but a MiniÅ¿ter to admit the party.

If the Writ be againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, although he claim but as Ordinary, yet the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 8 Hen. 4.22. Lib. intra. 521. For he claims no right, nor doth any thing by executing the Writ in prejudice of himÅ¿elf.

If a man recover againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, he Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop or Metopolitan, Nat. br. 38. B. and Q. 18 Eliz. Dyer. 353. pl. 30. 38 Edw. 3.12. B. at the election of the party, as it Å¿eems.

If it be once to the Metropolitan, he Å¿hall never have it to an inferior BiÅ¿hop afterwards, ibidem,
for it is not uÅ¿ual in Law to deÅ¿cend from a higher authority to a lower.
Or to the Vicar general, if the BiÅ¿hop be out of the Realm, Nat. br. 38. Q. For the Vicar general â¢ an Officer under the ArchbiÅ¿hop.
Or to the Gardein of the Spiritualties of the â¢â¢ ch-biÅ¿hop, 7 Hen. 4.36. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, ãâã it Å¿eems.

If there be no BiÅ¿hop of the DioceÅ¿s, then to â¢â¢ e Metropolitan; if no Metropolitan, then to â¢â¢ e Gardein of the Spiritualties, but if before the accution the ArchbiÅ¿hop be made, quaere if the power of the Gardein be not determined, 18 Eliz. Dyer. 350. pl. 19. It Å¿eems it is.
If it be againÅ¿t the Arch-biÅ¿hop of York, the Writ Å¿hall be to the Metropolitan, 15 Eliz. Dyer. 328. pl. 7. viz. of all England, viz. the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury.

The King recovers a Prebendary or Sub-Dea
â¢â¢â¢ ry, or other Dignity againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, and â¢â¢â¢ es it by Letters Patents to A, yet A Å¿hall â¢ uve a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop to be admitted to the â¢ ings right. And if he die before induction, â¢â¢ d the, King grants this to B, he Å¿hall have a Writ out of the Chancery, and a Writ to the Bi
â¢ hop, Nat. br. 38. D. It Å¿eems the Writ Å¿hall be pecial.

The King recovers a Prebendary, and hath ãâã Writ to two BiÅ¿hops, becauÅ¿e the Prebendary â¢ as in one DioceÅ¿s, and the Church to which â¢â¢ e Prebendary belongs, is in another DioceÅ¿s, 14 Edw. 3.37. pl. 56. and Å¿o it concerns both â¢ he BiÅ¿hops.
If a man recover a Chappel donative, he Å¿hall have a Writ to the Sheriff, Nat. br. 48.8. For it is in the nature of a Lay Fee, and lies not wiÅ¿hin the juriÅ¿diction of the Ordinary.

div.head: ProceÅ¿s in a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop.
div.p: The ProceÅ¿s is alias, plures, Attachment, or a Writ de quare non admiÅ¿it, Nat. br. 47. C.

div.head: Of what things a man Å¿hall have Judgment.
div.p: 1. A Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and no dammages. Coke 6. part. 51. A. BoÅ¿wels CaÅ¿e. At the Common Law were no dammages in a Quare Impedit. But by the Statute dammages are given, as the Statute following mentions.

Statute WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 5. is, Si tempus Å¿emeÅ¿tre tranÅ¿ier it per impedimentum alicujus, ita quod EpiÅ¿copus ad EccleÅ¿iam conferat, & verus Patron ãâã ea vice praeÅ¿entationem amittat, adjudicentur da â¢â¢
pna ad valorem medietatis EccleÅ¿iae pro duob â¢â¢ annis, & Å¿i non tranÅ¿ierit Å¿ed diÅ¿rationetur praeÅ¿entatio infra tempus praedictum tunc adjudicentur da â¢â¢
pna ad valorem medietatis EccleÅ¿iae per unum a â¢
num.

The King is not within this Statute to have dammages, for at the Common Law the King was not in danger to loÅ¿e his preÅ¿entation per plenarty, Coke 6. part. 51. A. BoÅ¿wels caÅ¿e. 3 He â¢ . 6. Dammges 17. 34 Hen. 6.51. 14 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 54. 33 Edw. 3. Br. 916. vide 7 Edw. 6. Dyer. 236. pl. 28. And the Statute was made only for that intentâª

If it is found for the Plaintiff, and that the Church is full, the Plaintiff may have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, but then he Å¿hall recover no dammages, 24 Edw. 3.35. pl. 42, & 75. pl. 97. for he could not be damnified by reaÅ¿on of the ple
â¢â¢ rty.
It is found that the Ordinary preÅ¿ented before â¢ is time, the Plaintiff releaÅ¿es dammages, and had ãâã Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 11 Hen. 4.79. pl. 22. for the Ordinary had no right to preÅ¿ent.

The Ordinary claims nothing but as Ordinary, the Plaintiff had Judgment againÅ¿t him as Ordi
â¢â¢ ty, and the DiÅ¿turber and his Clerk dies, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have execution, but it Å¿eems no dammages, Crooke 17 Hen. 7.43. pl. 9. Quaere â¢â¢â¢ en, for it Å¿eems not reaÅ¿onable that he Å¿hould be without remedy.

The Defendant comes the firÅ¿t day, and confeÅ¿Å¿eth the Action, there Å¿hall be a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, but no dammages, 4 Edw. 2. Dammages 9. 5 Edw. 3.133. pl. 13. 5 Edw. 3.139. pl. 44. in regard of the Å¿malneÅ¿s of them, for de minimis ãâã curat Lex.

In a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Incumbent, the King revokes his preÅ¿entation, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have no dammages againÅ¿t the Incumbent, 44 Edw. 3.35. B. becauÅ¿e he came in upon the Kings preÅ¿entation, and is now ouÅ¿ted by him.

The Plaintiff Å¿hall not have dammages againÅ¿t the Incumbent, if he pleads not, or is not proved ãâã DiÅ¿turber, 45 Edw. 3. Dammages 39. but Å¿hall recover only the preÅ¿entation, 5 Edw. 3.13. but by his pleading he is a DiÅ¿turber, and dammages are recoverable for the diÅ¿turbance.

div.head: A Writ to the BiÅ¿hop,Single â¢â¢ mmages. and Å¿ingle dammages, 17 Edw. 3.5. pl. 12. 24 Edw. 3.37. pl. 54.26 Edw. 3.75. pl. 25.
div.p: A Å¿ues B and C, and it is found that B only had right, B Å¿hall have dammages againÅ¿t A and C, 45 Edw. 3.14. pl. 12. & br. EpiÅ¿copo, for they are both DiÅ¿turbers as to B.

In a Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Ordinary and B, the Ordinary confeÅ¿Å¿es the Action, and it is found againÅ¿t B, and that the Church is full of the preÅ¿entment of B, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and Å¿ingle dammages, or double dammages, and no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop at his election, 39 Edw. 3.15. but Å¿hall not have both, 5 Edw. 3.150. pl. 10. for this would be double Å¿atisfaction for one tort.

The Defendant confeÅ¿Å¿es the Action, the Plaintiff Å¿hews that the Å¿ix Months are paÅ¿t, and had a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop and dammages, 21 Edw. 3.55. pl. 8. 20 Edw. 3. ColluÅ¿ion 34. 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 76. pl. 35. by the Statute.

The Plaintiff and the Ordinary are at iÅ¿Å¿ue upon the ability of the Incumbent, the Ordinary admits him, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and Å¿ingle dammages; for the admittance proves him able, 40 Edw. 3.25. pl. 21. and conÅ¿equently the Ordinary a DiÅ¿turber, and to pay dammages.

A Writ to the BiÅ¿hop to admit the parties Clerk, and a Writ to the Sheriff to enquire of dammages, 19 Edw. 3. Quare Impedit 156. 24 Edw. 3.37. Lib. Intr. 507. C. Sect. 6, 7, 8. Å¿uÅ¿tained by the diÅ¿turbance.
It was found that the Metropolitan collated before his time, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, but then he Å¿hall have but Å¿ingle dammages, 11 Hen. 4.80. Nat. br. 38. P. vid. le Stat.

The BiÅ¿hop grants proximam praeÅ¿entationem to B, and dies, the Church voids, the SucceÅ¿Å¿or collates, B brings his Quare Impedit within Å¿ix Months, two years paÅ¿s, the Plaintiff had judgment, and upon his prayer had a Writ to remove the Incumbent, and Å¿ingle dammages, and a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop or Metropolitan at his election, 2 & 3 Mariae, Eliz. Dyer 194. pl. 33. to admit his Clerk.

Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Ordinary who Collates, and pleads to the Plaintiff that the Å¿ix months are paÅ¿Å¿ed, the Plaintiff recovers the preÅ¿entation and Å¿ingle dammages; for where the Ordinary claims as Ordinary where he cannot maintain the right, he cannot collate as Ordinary for the time paÅ¿t, 5 Edw. 3.150. pl. 19. Coke 5. part. 58. B. 30 Edw. 3.15. pl. 4.
The Å¿ame Law is upon a recovery againÅ¿t another man, if the Plaintiff will at his peril have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 77. pl. 35. 11 Hen. 4.79. pl. 22.

Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop of L. the Metropolitan, and againÅ¿t G his Clerk, they all three make default at the Grand diÅ¿treÅ¿s, and a Writ of enquiry of the points in the Writ, and dammages was awarded, and thereupon found that the Church was void two years, and that the Metropolitan collated G; and Judgment was that the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and
Å¿ingle dammages; but becauÅ¿e the Church void Å¿o long, and the Defendants in miÅ¿ericordia, 7 Eliz. Dyer 241. pl. 48.

div.head: A Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and double dammages.
div.p: Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Ordinary and B, the Å¿ix Months paÅ¿s, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have double dammages, although the Ordinary did not collate, becauÅ¿e he had jus conferendi, and alÅ¿o a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 43 Edw. 3.10. pl. 33.

The Plaintiff recovers double dammages, becauÅ¿e the Å¿ix Months were paÅ¿Å¿ed; and alÅ¿o a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and his Clerk inÅ¿tituted, becauÅ¿e the BiÅ¿hop did not collate; but this was not done by the party, 8 Edw. 3.280. pl. 9. Q.
A man Å¿hall recover double dammages, although he recover all before the Å¿ix Months paÅ¿s, 13 Edw. 4.3. Littleton. by the Stat. of W. 2.

div.head: Single dammages, and no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop.
div.p: Before the return of the Writ to enquire of dammages, the Å¿ix Months paÅ¿s, the BiÅ¿hop collates; yet but Å¿ingle dammages, 24 Edw. 3.35. pl. 13. 27 Edw. 3. Dammages 106.

But the reaÅ¿on it Å¿eems is, becauÅ¿e of the former Judgment, that he Å¿hall have a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop; and this being of Record Å¿hall Å¿top him from double dammages, for he is to have his Clerk thereby admitted.

22 Hen. 6.28. Dammages, but no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop. Quare Impedit againÅ¿t a ParÅ¿on imparÅ¿onee, and found for the Defendant, he Å¿hall
have dammages, but no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, Nat. br. 38. L. 26 Hen. 6. bre EpiÅ¿copo 6. for Å¿uch Writ would be to no purpoÅ¿e.

div.head: Double dammages, and no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop.
div.p: Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Ordinary and B, the Ordinary confeÅ¿Å¿eth the Action, and it is found againÅ¿t B, and that the Church is full of the preÅ¿entment of B, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have double dammages, but no Writ to the BiÅ¿hop; or Å¿hall have Å¿ingle dammages, and a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop at his election, 39 Edw. 3.15. but not both; for the double dammages are in recompence of his preÅ¿entation.

The Ordinary intitles himÅ¿elf by LapÅ¿e, the Patron and Incumbent confeÅ¿s the Action, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have double dammages againÅ¿t the Patron and Incumbent, 34 Hen. 6.41. 34 Hen. 6.39. becauÅ¿e the Church is full.

Quare Impedit againÅ¿t the Patron and Incumbent, they traverÅ¿e the Title, the Å¿ix Months paÅ¿s, the Plaintiff, if he recovers, Å¿hall have double dammages againÅ¿t both, 46 Edw. 3.15. pl. 5. Vid. the Stat.

div.head: Two Writs to the BiÅ¿hop.
div.p:
The Defendant in a Quare Impedit brought a Darrein preÅ¿entment againÅ¿t the Plaintiff, the Plaintiff is nonÅ¿uited in the Quare Impeditâª the Defendant recovers in the Darrein preÅ¿entment, the Defendant Å¿hall have Judgment to have two Writs to the BiÅ¿hop, but Å¿hall not have dammages
twice, Nat. br. 39. D. viz. upon the Plaintiffs nonÅ¿uit one, and upon his own recovery another, for that would be double amends.

div.head: In what Court, and what Judges have power to award a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop.
div.p: JuÅ¿tices of NiÅ¿i prius have power, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 30, & 40. 14 Edw. 3. cap. 16. 9 Eliz. Dyer 260. pl. 21. 6 Edw. 6.76. pl. 34.

The Lords, it Å¿eems, of Mannors, Judges in Wales, have not power, 36 Hen. 6. B. ForteÅ¿ â¢ ue, 35 Hen. 6.30. pl. 35. 3 Edw. 3.63. pl. 35. 8. Edw. 3.319. pl. 15. 24 Edw. 3.33. pl. 26. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 31. A. for the BiÅ¿hops are not tied to take notice of their Writs.
Lord in ancient DemeÅ¿n hath no power to award a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 7 Hen. 6.35. for this is an inferiour Court circumÅ¿cribed within its own JuriÅ¿diction.
The Five Ports cannot award a Writ to the BiÅ¿hop, 21 Hen. 7.88. pl. 7. Crooke; for theÅ¿e are particular FranchiÅ¿es within themÅ¿elves.

div.head: Ne Admittas.
What PerÅ¿in Å¿hall have it.
div.p: The Plaintiff in a Quare Impedit, or Darrein PreÅ¿entment, Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 35 F.
So the Defendant Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 37. H.

div.head: In what CaÅ¿es it lies.
div.p:
When a Quare Impedit or Darrein PreÅ¿entment is depending, and the Plaintiff or Defendant Å¿uppoÅ¿eth that the BiÅ¿hop will admit the Clerk of the other, then a Ne admittas lies, Nat. br. 37. F.
RegiÅ¿t. orig. 31. A. 21. Hen. 44. Newton, Vet. Nat. br. 24. B. to hinder the BiÅ¿hop from admitting any Clerk till the right be determined.

If one of the Writs be not depending, then it Its not, Nat. br. 37. H. viz. a Quare Impedit or Darrein PreÅ¿entment, for this Writ Å¿uppoÅ¿eth a Title in queÅ¿tion, which muÅ¿t be by one of thoÅ¿e Writs.

For if the right of AdvowÅ¿on is depending, it lies not, becauÅ¿e the PreÅ¿entation is not to be recovered in it, Nat. br â¢â¢
48. Q. and Å¿o the admittance of a Clerk is not in queÅ¿tion.
But note,Note. that this lies before any Certificate made, that a Quare Impedit or Darrein PreÅ¿entnent is depending, Nat. br. 37. H. for depending of the Writs reÅ¿ts not upon the Certificate.

Yet the party grieved by the Ne admittas Å¿hall have a Writ to the Chief JuÅ¿tice, to certifie if any Writ be depending; and if he certifie none, then a SuperÅ¿edeas Å¿hall be awarded, Nat. br. 37. H. to Å¿uperÅ¿ede the Ne admittas.

Note,Note. that this Writ does not hinder the Ordinary, but that he may preÅ¿ent by LapÅ¿e, unleÅ¿s he be party, Nat. br. 48. L. Vet. Nat. br. 24, & 25.
â¢ iz. party to the Suit, for elÅ¿e it concerns him not.

div.head: Within what time this ought to be brought.
div.p: Within Å¿ix Months, and not after by reaÅ¿on of LapÅ¿e.

Locum habet infra tempus Å¿emeÅ¿tre, & non p â¢ Å¿tea, quia DioceÅ¿anus illam conferat per LapÅ¿um temporis ad Å¿ex menÅ¿es, quia DioceÅ¿anus il â¢ ud Å¿pectaliter â¢ t indu â¢ tum, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 37. F.
Yet for the King it always keeps place, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 31. A. Nat. br. 37. F, & G. vide Br. for nullum tempus occurrit Regi, the King is not tied to circumÅ¿tances of time or place, &c.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: The Writ Å¿hall be alone, although the BiÅ¿hop be party, as where not; Tamen olim fuit, ne conferatis alicui EccleÅ¿iam de N. quae vacat, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 31. A, B. Nat. 38. A.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s.
div.p: Is Prohibition, Attachment, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, Nat. br. 24, & 25.

div.head: Quare non admiÅ¿it.
Out of what Court this iÅ¿Å¿ueth.
div.p: It iÅ¿Å¿ueth out of the Com. Bau. becauÅ¿e it iÅ¿Å¿ueth out of the Rolls of the Court, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 32. A. Vet. Nat. br. 25. B. 12 Edw. 3. Quare non admiÅ¿it 6.
For this is a Judicial Writ, Vet. Nat. br. 25. B. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 32. A. 12 Edw. 3. Quare non admiÅ¿it 6. & per Nat. br. 47. C. grounded upon a Record of Court.
This may iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the Chancery in the Vacation alÅ¿o; for in the Vacation it cannot iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the Common Pleas.

If the King recover in Com. Ban. in Quare Impedit, he may have this Writ in Ban. Regis, Nat.
br. 47. D. for this Writ is but to have the effect of his Suit, and he may Å¿eek for his right in any of his Courts.

div.head: What PerÅ¿on Å¿hall have it.
div.p: Every one that recovers, if the BiÅ¿hop will not admit, his Clerk Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 47. C. Vet. Nat. br. 25. B. or elÅ¿e his Suit would be but fruitleÅ¿s, if it were not compulÅ¿ory.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom it lies.
div.p: It Å¿hall be brought againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, although the Vicar general made the refuÅ¿al, Vet. Nat. br. 26. A. Nat. br. 47. J. 13 Edw. 36. Quare non admiÅ¿it 4. for the Law takes notice of him only as a more publick perÅ¿on concerned.
It was brought againÅ¿t the Gardein of the Spiritualties, upon refuÅ¿al of the BiÅ¿hop which is dead, Vet. Nat. br. 26. A. Nat. br. 47. J. and well, for he is now in the room of the BiÅ¿hop.
But it was denied againÅ¿t the ArchbiÅ¿hops Gardein of the Spiritualties, vivente ArchiepiÅ¿copo, at videtur.
And yet quaere per 17 Edw. 3.27. pl. 9. if the Metropolitan of Common right be not Gardein of the Spiritualties. It Å¿eems not Å¿ince Hen. 8. come.
It was maintained againÅ¿t the Official of the BiÅ¿hop, Nat. br. 47. N. who uÅ¿ed, as it Å¿eems, to admit Clerks preÅ¿ented.

div.head: In what CaÅ¿es this lies.
div.p: When a man recovers his preÅ¿entation, and the BiÅ¿hop will not admit his Clerk, the party Å¿hall have this Writ, Vet. Nat. br. 25. B. Nat. br. 47. C.

And this is although the BiÅ¿hop return cauÅ¿e, why he will not admit the Clerk. 9 Eliz. Dyer 260. pl. 21. Coke 6. part. 52. A. BoÅ¿wels caÅ¿e; for he muÅ¿t take notice of the Judgments given at the Law in Å¿uch caÅ¿es.

But if the Record be removed by a Writ of Error, it lies not till Judgment be affirmed, Nat. br. 47. E. for till then it doth not appear the Judgment was duly given, and this Writ doth Å¿uppoÅ¿e right Judgment given.

The BiÅ¿hop refuÅ¿es, and afterward admits him, yet the party it Å¿eems Å¿hall have this Writ, Nat. br. 47. L. Q. for it Å¿eems to little purpoÅ¿e, except it be to recover dammages for not admitting at firÅ¿t.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: 1. It ought to rehearÅ¿e the Recovery in the Quare Impedit, Nat. br. 47. C. becauÅ¿e that is the ground of the Writ.

2. It ought to be brought in the County where the refuÅ¿al was, becauÅ¿e he Å¿hall recover nothing but dammages, Vet. Nat. 25. B. Nat. 47. F. Coke 7. part. 3. A. Bulwers caÅ¿e, 38 Hen. 6 14 & 15.39 Edw. 3.2. pl. 5. 29 Hen. 8. Dyer 40. pl. 69. and the dammages can be beÅ¿t enquired and known there.

div.p:
The writ was againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, and counted, though the Vicar general refuÅ¿ed, and yet good, ãâã

Excommunication cannot be pleaded in the Plaintiff, becauÅ¿e the Writ Å¿uppoÅ¿eth a contemp â¢ in the Ordinary, in that the Plaintiff hath preÅ¿ented his Clerk in the Writ named after Judgment given for him, which Å¿uppoÅ¿eth him not Excommunicated; but a good plea, that the Incumbe â¢â¢ did not make requeÅ¿t after Judgment, 21 Hen. 7.71. pl. 14. Crooke; for without requeÅ¿t the Ordinary is not bound to take notice.

A good barr, that the Church was full before the Recovery of one not named in the Recovery, Nat. 47. K. and Å¿o the Ordinary had no cauÅ¿e to admit his Clerk.

The BiÅ¿hop returned that the AdvowÅ¿on is Å¿eiÅ¿ed into the hands of the King, by reaÅ¿on of WardÅ¿hip, and is Å¿o full of the Kings preÅ¿entment; this is good, 9 Eliz. Dyer. 260. pl. 21. tame â¢ Coke 6. part. 52. A. BoÅ¿wels caÅ¿e, Ã¨ contra. Q.

div.head: The Judgment.
div.p: The Judgment is but to have dammages, Nat. br. 47. G.

div.head: Quare Incumbravit.
In what Court it Å¿hall be brought.
div.p: It is a Writ Original, and therefore it ought to iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the Chancery, Nat. br. 48. G. as all Originals do; for the Chancery is Officina brevium.
But it Å¿hall be brought in Com. Ban. becauÅ¿e it a Common plea, Vet. Nat. br. 26. B. viz. made â¢â¢ rnable there.
And although the Record be removed out of ãâã Common pleas, Nat. br. 48. F. becauÅ¿e it is an â¢â¢â¢ ginal Writ, per Shard 17 Edw. 3.55. A.

But the King may bring this in Ban. Regis, al
