div.head: What perÅ¿on Å¿hall have it.
div.p: The Plaintiff or Defendant in a Quare Impedit, ãâã Darrein PreÅ¿entment, that recovers; for by the â¢ ecovery it appears they have Title.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom it lies.
div.p: It lies againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop, Vet. Nat. br. A.

div.head: In what CaÅ¿es this lies not.
div.p: It lies not in right of AdvowÅ¿on, Nat. br. 48. Q. ãâã that concerns not the preÅ¿entation.

It lies not unleÅ¿s a Ne Admittas be firÅ¿t directed ãâã the BiÅ¿hop, a Quare Impedit depending, Vet. â¢â¢ t. br. 26. B. Nat. br. 48. H. for by that he is to â¢ ake notice of the Suit, which otherwiÅ¿e he is not â¢â¢ und to.
Yet it was maintained, although no other Writ â¢ as firÅ¿t attained, Vet. Nat. br. 27. A. Q.
It lies not, unleÅ¿s the party hath recovered before by Judgment of the Court, Nat. br. 48. ãâã 17 Edw. 3. 50. pl. 21. and Å¿o cleared his Title.
The Incumbring by his Collation ought to b â¢ alledged to be within Å¿ix Months, Nat. br. 48. ãâã for after the Å¿ix Months there can be no incumbrance in reÅ¿pect of the LapÅ¿e.
And if he admit the Clerk of the other perÅ¿on after the Å¿ix Months, which was preÅ¿ente â¢ before the Action, the Writ lies, Nat. br. 48. L. Quaere.
The Writ is Original and iÅ¿Å¿ueth out of the Chancery only, Nat. br. 48. G. 17 Edw. 3.74. B. vide the Writ Nat. br. 48. O. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 32 A.

It ought to be brought in the County where the Church is, becauÅ¿e the Clerk of the BiÅ¿hop Å¿hall by this be removed, and the Clerk of the other admitted, Coke 7. part. 3. A. Bulwers caÅ¿e, Nat. br. 48. D. 38 Hen. 6.14. pl. 32 and the wrong is done in the County where the Church is, and that County may have beÅ¿t conuÅ¿ance of the cauÅ¿e.
It ought to make mention of the Recovery, Nat. br. 48. K. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 32. B. But 18 Edw. 3.17. by Wilby he ought not to mention it. Quaere.

The Writ needs not mention before wha â¢ JuÅ¿tices the Recovery was, and yet good; for the Recovery is the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and the Court is not material, quaere tamen, 18 Edw. 3.17. pl. 19. 17 Edw. 3.74. pl. 109. the Writ; 1. It needs not mention where the Court was, when the Recovery
â¢ ad, becauÅ¿e it is an Original Writ, and the Court is fixt. 2. Nor that the BiÅ¿hop Incumbred it within the Å¿ix Months, for it Å¿hall be intended Å¿o. 3. It is good, although it bore date within the Å¿ix Months, for it Å¿hall be maintained after the Recovery, and the party Å¿hall have it. 4. It lies in C â¢ n. Ba â¢ . although that the Record be removed, becauÅ¿e it is an Original Writ. vid. antea.

div.head: The Count.
div.p: The Count ought to mention the Recovery, Nat. br. 48. K. becauÅ¿e it is the ground of the Action.
It needs not to recite all the Record of the Recovery, although that it was recovered by Darrein PreÅ¿entment, but the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of it, 17 Edw. 3.55. pl. 34.
The Count mentions, that the BiÅ¿hop did Incumber (the Writ depending) the Church, yet good, 17 Edw. 3.74. pl. 109.
If one Writ be abated, the Plaintiff in another Writ may vary from the former Count, Nat. br. 48. M. for he now begins de novo, and is as if he had not counted before.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s.
div.p: It is Summons, Attachment, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, Vet. Nat. br. 26. B.

div.head: The Barr.
div.p: The Church was Litigious, and that he did Collate by LapÅ¿e, 34 Hen. 6.38. Quare Impedit, 89. a good barr. antea.
No Å¿uch Record a good barr, Vet. Nat. br. 26. B. antea.
Error brought, and the Record removed in Ban. Regis, no barr, Vet. Nat. br. 26. B. Q.
Did not Incumber after the prohibition of the Court to him delivered, is a good barr, Nat. br. 48. M. for before he was not bound to take notice of the Suit.

div.head: The Judgment.
div.p: It is to have his PreÅ¿entment and his Dammages, Nat. br. 48. H. 38. Hen. 6.14. Coke 7. part. 3. A. Bulwers caÅ¿e, 21 Edw. 3.3. pl. 7.
If the Plaintiff be NonÅ¿uited, yet it is not to him peremptory, Nat. br. 48. M. but he may commence a new Action; for he may be Nonfuit, and yet have a good Title.

div.head: Replevin.
In what Court it lies.
div.p: IN the County Court by plaint, per le Stat. dÃ© Marlebridge, cap. 21.
And this may be before the day of the Court, 9 Edw. 4.48. 21 Edw. 4.66. pl. 46. For the conveniency of the people.
But by the Common Law the Sheriff cannot make a Replevin without a Writ, 8 Eliz. Dyer. 256. pl. 67. viz. out of the Chancery.
In the 5 Ports, RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 79. A. Nat. br. 67. A. By Å¿pecial priviledge.
In a Court-Baron by plaint, but this ought to be entred Sedente Curia, 21 Edw. 4.66. pl. 46.

div.head: In Ban. Regis, or Com. Ban.
div.p: An ancient Demean is a good plea to out the Court of juriÅ¿diction, becauÅ¿e the reality may come in debate upon the Replevin, which ought to be tried there, Coke 5. part 105. Aldens caÅ¿e, tide 2 Edw. 3.32. pl. 10. 17 Edw. 3.52. pl. 28. & fol. 75. 40 Edw. 3.4. pl. 9. 29 Edw. 3.9. pl. 29. 4 Edw. 3.123. pl. 34.
It lies not in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, Coke 10. part. 74. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey. For that is a limited Court, and holds not plea of all Actions.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have a Replevin.
div.p: AdminiÅ¿trator.AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have a Replevin de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris, vid. the Count. Lib. Intra. 560. B. Å¿ect. 2. for the benefit of the InteÅ¿tates EÅ¿tate.

Husband and Wife.Husband and WiÅ¿e join in a Replevin for a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s taken upon the Land of the Wife, 2 Edw. 2. Replevin 42. DigeÅ¿t. brevium. 53. Å¿ect. 2. For they are both concerned, the Husband in right of his Wife, and the Wife in her own right.

But for goods of the Wife Å¿ole taken, which takes a Husband, the Husband alone Å¿hall bring the Action, Nat. br. 69. K. 33. Edw. 3. Repleg. 43. For by the Marriage the Goods and right to them are his.
If Goods be bayled to A, Baylee. he Å¿hall have a Replevin of them againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger, 21 Hen. 7.14. For he hath a property in them againÅ¿t all the world, but againÅ¿t the Bailor.

An Executor Å¿hall have it for Goods taken in the TeÅ¿tators time,Executor. 17 Edw. 3. Executors, 106. 24 Edw. 3. Avowry, 257. 21 Hen. 6.1. B. Markham. For the right and title to the Goods is come unto him by the ExecutorÅ¿hip.

Executors Å¿hall have it for the Goods in their hands that were the TeÅ¿tators. RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 81. B. 5 Edw. 3.133. pl. 14. 18 Edw. 2. Repleg. 24. 18 Edw. 3. Severance, 28. For now the intereÅ¿t is theirs in truÅ¿t.
And when he brings it of his own poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, he Å¿hall have it before the Probat of the TeÅ¿tament, Com. 281. A. in regard of the property which is in him thereby.
Joint-Tenant or Tenant in Common may join in a Replevin,Joint-Tenant, or Tenane in Common, 11 Hen. 6.31. in reÅ¿pect of their joint intereÅ¿t.
But if two others join, the Writ Å¿hall abate, 11 Hen. 6.31. 3 Hen. 4.16. 21 Edw. 4.23. For one Writ cannot try diÅ¿tinct intereÅ¿ts, but there muÅ¿t be Å¿everal Writs.

But in a Homine Repleg. Å¿trangers may join, Nat. 66. F. 8 Edw. 4.16. pl. 19. Propter favorem libertatis, and yet 8 Hen. 4.2. is, that they Å¿hall not join. Q. Ergo. It Å¿eems needleÅ¿s for two to join, becauÅ¿e the Writ may be as well proÅ¿ecuted by one.
ParÅ¿on Å¿hall have a Replevin of a Mortuary after SeiÅ¿ure,ParÅ¿on. but not before, Com. 281. A. Foxes caÅ¿e. 10 Hen. 4.1. For before he had no property in it, but a bare right.
For he had not property before SeiÅ¿ure, 16 Hen. 7.5. pl. 3. Brian. The SeiÅ¿ure gains a property in it.

1. He that hath not the property in a thing,Proprietor. Å¿hall not have a Replevin for it. 6 Hen. 4.2. pl. 17. 7 Hen. 4.18. 11 Hen. 4.17. pl. 39. 2 Hen. 6.14. pl. 10. 20 Hen. 6.18. A. 35 Hen. 6.22. A. 39 Hen. 6.35. pl. 47. 4 Edw. 2.1. pl. 2. 9 Edw. 3.340. pl. 19. Lib. intra. 568. C. Å¿ect. 5. For a Replevin Å¿uppoÅ¿eth a property in the thing reple
â¢ led by one.

2. He that hath Cattel by way of AgiÅ¿tment, Å¿hall have a Replevin, becauÅ¿e he hath a Å¿pecial
property againÅ¿t all Å¿trangers, as it is upon a Bailment, 3 Edw. 3.71. pl. 36.42. Edw. 3.18. pl. 32. 21 Edw. 4.54. pl. 24.
3. So he that hath them to manure his Land, 42 Edw. 3.18. 11 Hen. 4.29. 21 Hen. 7.14. 21 Edw. 4.54. pl. 24. 2 Edw. 3.34. pl. 19. For he hath a property in them to that purpoÅ¿e.
4. So if one have Goods bayled to him, 21 Hen. 7.14. viz. to keep, or to bail over as it Å¿eems. Q.

The Lord of a Villain Å¿hall have it for Cattel of a Villain taken,Lord. for the bringing of the Action is a Å¿ufficient claim of the Cattel, and there needs no Å¿eiÅ¿ure, 42 Edw. 3.18. 33 Edw. 1.3. Repleg. 43. 30 Edw. 3. Repleg. 36. 19 Edw. 3. Repleg. 32. 9 Hen. 6.26. Babington. Nat. br. 69. F.
But he Å¿hall not have dammages for the taking, but only for the Detainer, Nat. br. 69. F. For he could have no dammage, becauÅ¿e before the claim they were none of his.
SucceÅ¿Å¿or of an Abbey Å¿hall have it for taking any thing in the time of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. 9 Hen. 6.25. pl. 21. Martin. For now he is concerned in right of his houÅ¿e.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom a Replevin lies.
div.p: It lies not againÅ¿t him that hath Goods delivered to keep,Baylee. Lib. Intra. 569. B. Å¿ect. 1. For he comes lawfully to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of them.

It lies not againÅ¿t the King,King. nor where he is party, nor where the taking is in right of the King, 3 Hen. 7.1. Keble. This by his Prerogative.
It is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed the King will do no wrong.
It lies againÅ¿t a Lord that diÅ¿trains wrongfully,Lord. although the goods come again to the owner, Nat. br. 69. H. that the party injured may recover dammages.

It lies againÅ¿t the Sheriff, and the Writ Å¿hall be in the common form,Sheriff. and he Å¿hall be named by his proper name. RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 81. B. during his Office, but not as an Officer, but as a private perÅ¿on. Q. to whom the Writ Å¿hall be directed. It Å¿eems to the Coroner.

div.head: Of what things a Replevin lies.
div.p: It lies of Cattel, RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 81. Coke 1. part 141.Cattels. Mayowes caÅ¿e, the count. Lib. intra. 570. C. Å¿ect. 123.4. Coke 1. part. 54. A. Capels caÅ¿e. and the Replevin needs not mention the Colour or Value of them, but only the Kind and Nature; that the Sheriff may know of what to make retorne, in caÅ¿e the diÅ¿traier recovers.

But he ought to Å¿hew the place where they were taken; for the taking of them in another place Å¿hall abate the Writ, 2 Hen. 6.14. pl. 10. 35 Hen. 6.40. pl. 1. for the falÅ¿ity of it, and it Å¿hall not be accounted the Å¿ame taking.
It lies of Wood within the ForeÅ¿t, RegiÅ¿t. Wood Orig. 86. B. viz. Wood felled. Q. if he muÅ¿t Å¿hew what Wood it is.
Replevin lies of a Barge, 2 & 3 Mariae, Dyer. Barg â¢ . 117. pl. 73. If taken infra corpus Comitatus.
It lies of a MaÅ¿tiff-Dog,MaÅ¿tiff. 12 Hen. 8.3. For the Owner hath property in him, and he is a uÅ¿eful Creature.
Of a Leveret, 2 Edw. 2. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 20. Q. For it is but a thing of pleaÅ¿ure, if alive.
It lies not of Deeds of Land,Deeds. becauÅ¿e they are Real, 4, Hen. 10. pl. 4. And a Replevin is not a real Action meerly.
It lies of a Hive of Bees,Bees. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 81. A. For the Owner hath a property in them, and they are valuable.
It lies of a Ferret,Ferret. 2 Edw. 2. Avowry, 142. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
It lies of Grain in a Wagon loaded,Grain. Lib. intra. 560. B. Å¿ect. 2.562. D. Å¿ect. 3. Q. together with the Wagon, or without it.

It lies of a man,Man. if he be not committed by the command of the King or his JuÅ¿tices, or for the Death of a man, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 77. B. Nat. br. 66. E. that is, be kept priÅ¿oner without any Suit or proceÅ¿s in Law.

Or by JuÅ¿tice of the ForeÅ¿t outlawed, approver, taken for Felony with the manner, breaking priÅ¿on, known Thief, appealed by an approver, burner of a HouÅ¿e, or counterfeiting the Money or Seal of the King, or taken by an Excommunicato Capiendo, or for TreaÅ¿on, Convict of RediÅ¿Å¿ein, Nat. br. 66. E. For theÅ¿e are Capital Crimes.
But if a man be taken for TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in a ForeÅ¿t, he Å¿hall be replevied, if detained againÅ¿t pledges, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 80. A.

And the Writ Å¿hall be directed CuÅ¿todi ForeÅ¿tae, and if he be not delivered, then a Replevin Å¿hall
iÅ¿Å¿ue to the Sheriff, and an Attachment to attach the Gardein of the ForeÅ¿t, per Stat. 1 Edw. 3. up, 8. Statute 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 80. B. Nat. br. 67. A, B & C. Little uÅ¿e there is now of this Law.

And Å¿o for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in the Kings ChaÅ¿e, RegiÅ¿t. 80. B. becauÅ¿e the ChaÅ¿e remains at the common Law, Nat. br. 67. D. and is not ordered by Fo
â¢â¢ Å¿t-Law.
And Å¿o if a man reÅ¿cues one Indicted and Convicted for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in the ForeÅ¿t, RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 81. A. and the reÅ¿cuer detains the party.
Sheep and Lambs.If one takes Sheep which aÅ¿terwards have Lambs, it lies of all, Nat. Br. 69. D. 18 Edw. 3. 48. pl. 55. So of a Sow with Pig, a Mare with Fole, &c.
It lies of a Park Å¿eiÅ¿ed into the hands of the King,Park. RegiÅ¿t. 80. B. Nat. br. 67. E. Q.
Sow and Pigs.It lies of a Sow and Pigs which were not pigged at the time of the taking, 12 Edw. 45. pl. 10. 18 Edw. 3.48. Nat. br. 69. D. Q. Whether of a Bitch and her Whelps.
Cows and Calves.It lies of Cows and Calves not calved at the time of the taking, Nat. br. 69. D. 18 Edw. 3.48. pl. 55.
It lies of Yarn,Yarn. Mich. 39 & 40. Eliz. com. Ban. Burley verÅ¿us Read, and generally for any thing that may be diÅ¿trained.

div.head: The Writ.
div.p: If a live and dead thing be put in one Writ, the live Å¿hall be put firÅ¿t, RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 81. B. propter excellentiam rei. A living Dog is better than a dead Lion.
If it be of more live things, ye Å¿hall Å¿ay, Averia. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 81. B. Nat. br. 68. D. Com. 229. A. For that is a word of large extent, comprehending all four-footed beaÅ¿ts.

And if the Writ be Averia, and the Count be de Bonis & Catallis, it is not good, becauÅ¿e the Count is more large than the Writ, 2 Hen. 4.25. pl. 28. For Bona & Catalla comprehends all manner of Goods, as well dead as living things.
If it be of a live thing, it Å¿hall be named particularly, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 81. B. Nat. br. 68. D. Com. 229. A. 20 Hen. 6.42. pl. 21. viz. the kind of it.

If it be of more dead things, it Å¿hall be Å¿aid Catalla, and not Averia, 2 Hen. 4.25. pl. 28. Nat. br. 68. D. If it be of one dead, it Å¿hall be named, Nat. br. 68. D. RegiÅ¿t. 81. A. For the more certainty.

MiÅ¿noÅ¿mer of the Place.The Defendant Å¿hall not plead MiÅ¿noÅ¿mer of the place, but may Å¿ay that he took it in another place, 16 Hen. 7.5. pl. 4. fol. 7. pl. 9. and not in the place alledged by the Plaintiff, and this is a good traverÅ¿e.
DiÅ¿treÅ¿s in one County,County. and impounded in another County, Replevin lies in any of the Counties, Nat. Br. 69. I. For it is a continuing wrong from the taking to the impounding.
It is a good plea that the Defendant took the Cattel in another Village,Willage. 2 Hen. 6.14. pl. 10. For then it Å¿hall be preÅ¿umed not to be of the Å¿ame taking.

div.head: The ProceÅ¿s. 1. Of a man Replevied. 2. Of Chattels.
div.p: Repleg. alias pluries & Attachment againÅ¿t the Sheriff, Nat. br. 66. F. 167. B. to make a return.
If the Sheriff return him not repleviÅ¿able, a Capias in Withernam Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 79. A. 80. A & B. That is to take the perÅ¿on of the man that detained him, or hath elongated him.

If upon the Capias in Withernam, a Non eÅ¿t in
â¢ entus of the perÅ¿on be returned, then a Capias in Withernam Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue againÅ¿t his Goods, Nat br. 68. C. to make the Owner appear.
Repleg. alias and pluries, Nat. br. 68. E, F, G.
And an Attachment to the Coroners againÅ¿t the Sheriff, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 81. A. for not making his return.

Upon a return that the Bayliff of a FranchiÅ¿e makes not an AnÅ¿wer, or will not make deliverance, there Å¿hall be a Non omittas propter aliquam libertatem, but it Å¿eems that the Sheriff ought to do it without a Writ, Nat. br. 68. F. in favour of Liberty. Q. tamen.

div.head: If the Sheriff return
div.p: Fugavit, in another County.
That the Bayliff of the Liberty returns elongata.
Or that he cannot have the view.
Or that the Cattel elongata Å¿unt out of the County.
Or that the Bayliff of the Liberty returns that they are impounded within the Rectory of S.
In all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es Withernam Å¿hall be awarded, Nat. br. 68. G. 69. A. becauÅ¿e the Sheriff cannot execute the Writ of Replevin.
And upon this three Capias's and an Exigend. Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue, 5 Edw. 4.18. A. by Danby.
The Writ of Withernam ought to rehearÅ¿e the Return of the Sheriff. Nat. Br. 69. B. For upon that it is grounded.
Vid. The Writ RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 82. A. No. Lib. intra. 611. B. Å¿ect. 21.

If the Replevin be in the County-Court per plaint, and the Bayliff return elongata, the Sheriff ought to enquire by InqueÅ¿t whether it is Å¿o or not, and then Withernam Å¿hall be awarded by him, if it be true; and if he refuÅ¿e to grant the Withernam, the party Å¿hall have a Writ againÅ¿t him, and an Alias pluries, and an Attachment, Nat. br. 69. C. directed to the Coroner.

div.head: Second Deliverance.
div.p: At the Common Law a man may be non-Å¿uited in a Repleg. and have a new Replevin infinite, 34. Hen. 6.37. Danby. 10 Hen. 7.29. pl. 23. 19 Hen. 8.12. pl. 7. Q. For by this means the other party is delayed.
And if the Writ abate per Plea or ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, there Å¿hall be another Replevin, 34 Hen. 6.37. and not a Å¿econd Deliverance; for this abatement was not by wilful fault of the party.

But by WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap 2. if one be non-Å¿uited in Replevin, he Å¿hall have but a Second Deliverance
â¢ ut of the Rolls of the former Judgment, and â¢ ot a new Replevin, 19 Edw. 2. Repleg. 25. 4 Hen. 4.23. 30 Hen. 8. Dyer 41. pl. 4.21. Edw. 4. â¢
pl. 16.32 Edw. 3. Return of Cattel, 18.

But if Judgment be given againÅ¿t the Plaintiff ãâã a Repleg. upon a Demurrer or Verdict, no Se
â¢ ord Deliverance, 2 Hen. 4.23. pl. 9. But then be party is barr'd by judgment of the Court.
And Second Deliverance Å¿hall not be, but in the â¢â¢ me Court, Com. 206. B. where the Replevin â¢ as brought, and can beÅ¿t take notice of the CauÅ¿e.
Yet if he be non-Å¿uited in the County-Court, and it be removed in Ban. then it Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the Ban. 13 Edw. 3. Repleg. 37. For there the CauÅ¿e is now depending.

And if he be non-Å¿uited in the Second Deli
â¢ rance, he Å¿hall not have another Writ, 4 Hen. 6.8. Return of Cattel, 6. viz. of Second Delirerance; for this is final.
Second Deliverance is a Writ judicial, iÅ¿Å¿uing out of the former Record, per 2 WeÅ¿tm. cap. 2. depending.
Vide the Writ Lib. Intra. 572. B. Å¿ect. 2, 3, 4.
Vide the Count, Lib. intra. 572. B. 5.6. No. Lib. intra. 589. A. Å¿ect. 8.

And if a man be non-Å¿uited in a Repleg. after the Declaration, the Second Deliverance ought to agree with the Replevin in day, place and number of Cattel, &c. 3 Hen. 6.9. pl. 10. 21 Hen. 7.28. vid. 12 Hen. 7.4. 49 Edw. 3.29.
PerÅ¿ay. For it is to continue the Å¿ame Sait.
But 16 Edw. 3. Ayd 131. Thorpe. 17 Edw. 3. Repleg. 22. 26 Hen. 6. pl. 7. It may vary from the place. Q. tamen.
And per 26 Hen. 8. pl. 27. Fitz Herbert, it may vary from the number and day; Å¿o there be a certain deÅ¿cription of them, Q. tamen.
Repleg. of a Heifer, the Å¿econd deliverance was of a Cow, and good, 26 Hen. 8.6. pl. 27. For a Cow and a Heifer non variant Å¿pecie; for they differ only in age and appellation.

Upon a Non-Å¿uit in Repleg. return awarded, and upon Withernam awarded, and other Cattel taken, yet the Å¿econd deliverance Å¿hall be of the former Cattel; for Å¿o the Writ imports, 36 Hen. 1. Dyer 59. pl. 14. 2 Edw. 3.17. Avowry 171. 22 Hen. 7.92. pl. 7 Crooke, there Å¿hall not be a Å¿econd deliverance, becauÅ¿e the Plaintiff had eÅ¿trayed the former.

Husband had aid of a Wife in a Replevin, and makes default, the Wife cannot joyn in the Å¿econd deliverance, 18 Edw. 2. Repleg. 23. For Å¿he is not the principal actor in the Replevin, but the Husband.

div.head: DiÅ¿treÅ¿s.
In what caÅ¿e a man may diÅ¿train.
div.p: For Fine or Amerciament in a Court Leet.A man may diÅ¿train for a Fine or Amerciament in a Court-Leet, Coke 11. part. 45. A. Godfreys caÅ¿e; for a Fine and all Amerciaments in a Court-Leet DiÅ¿treÅ¿s is incident, 5 Edw. 3.139. pl. 43. 10 Edw. 3.303. pl. 10. by the Common Law.
For a Fine impoÅ¿ed in a Leet, Coke 8. part. 41. A. GrieÅ¿leyes caÅ¿e.
For breaking of a By-Law in the Leet of the Lord, he may diÅ¿train for the Amerciament, Coke. 6. part. 25. A.

DiÅ¿treÅ¿s is incident to an Amerciament in a Court-Leet, 9 Hen. 7.2. pl. 22. 8 Hen. 4.15. pl. 16. GaÅ¿ciogne. 12. Hen. 7.15. B. 4 Edw. 3.95. pl. 24. 29 Edw. 3.28. pl. 30. Doct. & Stud. 24. A. 5 Edw. 3.159. pl. 21.

Tax by Parliament.Collector of a Tax granted by Parliament, may diÅ¿train him that will not pay when the PariÅ¿hioners have aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed it, 22 Edw. 3.10. pl. 52. and juÅ¿tifie by the Act that granted it.
Amerciament in a Court Baron.A man Å¿hall be amerced for not doing of Å¿uit in a Court-Baron, 9 Hen. 7.22. Wood & Read, Coke 4. part 95. A. Slades caÅ¿e, 21 Hen. 6.39. pl. 8. and not diÅ¿trained.
And for Å¿uch Amerciament he Å¿hall diÅ¿train, 9 Hen. 7.22. per two JuÅ¿tices by Å¿pecial preÅ¿cription, No. Lib. intra. 570. C. Q.
For Amerciament in a Court-Baron a man may not diÅ¿train, 16 Hen. 7.14. pl. 9. 21 Hen. 6.39. pl. 8.
The Lord may preÅ¿cribe to diÅ¿train for an Amerciament in a Court-Baron, 15 Eliz. Dyer. 322. Coke 11. part. 45. A. and Å¿uch preÅ¿cription is good.
Yet Doct. & Stud. 74. Ã¨ contra. Q.
Crooke. If an Amerciament was at the Court-Leet, he may diÅ¿train, otherways not, Crooke, 20 Hen. 7.66 pl. 8. Q. What remedy is then for it? for it Å¿eems debt lies for it.
Amerciament in a Tourne. Special preÅ¿cription in the Sheriffs Tourne to Amerce, and for this there was a Å¿pecial preÅ¿cription for a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 33 Hen. 8.30. pl. 2.
Tax by the Inhabitants.A Tax was made by the Inhabitants of a PariÅ¿h, and a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s taken for it, and good, Doct. & Stud. 74. B. by preÅ¿cript.
Suit to a Mill.A man may diÅ¿train for Å¿uit to a Mill, 22 Hen. 6. 14. 9 Edw. 3.356. Nat. br. 122. M. For it is a profit, and valuable.
Rent Å¿ervice.A man may diÅ¿train for Rent Å¿ervice, and all manner of Å¿ervices, Doct. & Stud. 74. A. For it is a Duty iÅ¿Å¿uing out of the Land held.
A. gives Land to B, for him to Å¿erve in Å¿uch a place when he Å¿hall be requeÅ¿ted, he may diÅ¿train, 22 Hen. 6.33. A. Q. if he were never Å¿eiÅ¿ed of the Service.
Herriot. Difference between Å¿eiÅ¿ing and diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ing.For Herriot-Å¿ervice a man may diÅ¿train, 44 Edw. 3.13. pl. 24.27 AÅ¿Å¿ize. pl. 24. Com. 96. Mantels caÅ¿e. Doct. & Stud. 75. A.
But for Herriot-cuÅ¿tom he can but only Å¿eize, 2 Edw. 2. Herriot 7. 8 Hen. 7.10. Doct. & Stud. 75. A. And if he cannot Å¿eize, he hath no remedy.
And for Herriot-Å¿ervice a man may Å¿eize, 18 Edw. 3.22. pl. 4. 38 Edw. 3.7. pl. 27. 16 Ed. 3. Herriot 2. 6 Edw. 3.227. pl. 10. And DiÅ¿treÅ¿s for Herriot-Å¿ervice is more worthy than Heriot-cuÅ¿tom.

For a certain Leet.A man cannot diÅ¿train for a certain Leet without preÅ¿cription, becauÅ¿e it is againÅ¿t common
right, Coke 11. part 44. Godfreyes caÅ¿e. vide 6 Edw. 3.10. Å¿o that a preÅ¿cription binds common right.
And the Tything-man that preÅ¿cribes to have it of the ReÅ¿iants, ought to preÅ¿cribe to diÅ¿train, 6 Edw. 3.189. pl. 26. Coke 11. part. 44. B. elÅ¿e he cannot.

Ayd.A man may diÅ¿train for Ayd for marrying his Daughter, or making his Son Knight, Glanvil, Lib. 9. cap. 8. 5 Edw. 3.138. pl. 38. 39 Edw. 3.34. pl. 40. 40 Edw. 3.22. pl. 21. This by tenure is due to the Lord.

Suit to the Hundred.For Å¿uit to his Hundred Court by reaÅ¿on of tenure, there Å¿hall be a diÅ¿treÅ¿s of common right, Lib. intra. 608. B. 5 Edw. 3.152. pl. 32. 9 Edw. 3.356. pl. 39. to compel it to be done, or â¢ ecompence for not doing it.

The Lord may diÅ¿train for relief,Relief. and hath no other remedy, but his Executor Å¿hall have debt, and Å¿hall not diÅ¿train, Coke 4. part. 49. B. 7 Hen. 6.13. as for a duty veÅ¿ted in the Lord to whom it was a perÅ¿onal Å¿ervice.

A man cannot diÅ¿train for money due for AgiÅ¿tment, but Å¿hall have treÅ¿paÅ¿s,AgiÅ¿tment. if that they chaÅ¿e the Cattel out of the Land before the AgiÅ¿tment be paid, RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 92. A. 30 Edw. 3.11. pl. 6. Q. whether debt lies not for it againÅ¿t him that agiÅ¿ted his Cattel.
Inholder.An Inn-holder cannot diÅ¿train for his Victuals provided for his gueÅ¿ts, 3 Edw. 3. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 19. but may have an action of debt for the value of them.
He that takes Cattel as EÅ¿trays,EÅ¿tray. may diÅ¿train them until he be Å¿aisfied for the Meat, 44 Edw. 3.13. pl. 25. by the owner of them, if they be claimed within the year and the day.

Pledge. A. indebted to B for tabling, delivers Goods to him until he be Å¿atisfied; B. may diÅ¿train them until he be paid, 46 Edw. 3.30. pl. 39. that is, he may keep them; but this is upon the Å¿pecial agreement.
Toll.For Toll a man may diÅ¿train, 30 Edw. 3.15. B. 11 Hen. 6.39. 9 Hen. 6.45. 20 Hen. 7.1. Marrowe. viz. Toll of a Market or Fair, this Å¿eems not to be of common right.
But Trin. 28 Eliz. Ban. Regis. Rot. 963. the Village of Northampton diÅ¿trained for Toll, and alledged not a Å¿pecial Title, or preÅ¿cription to have Toll, and for this it was adjudged againÅ¿t them.

Dammage feaÅ¿ant.A Commoner may diÅ¿train the Cattel of a Å¿tranger, dammage feaÅ¿ant upon the common of common right, Coke. 9. part. 112. B. 7 Edw. 3.266. pl. 39. 24 Edw. 3.42. 46 Edw. 3.23. 15 Hen. 7.2. & 12. 13 Hen. 8.15. B. in reÅ¿pect of his intereÅ¿t in the Common.
ForfeituresThe Officers may diÅ¿train for the Forfeitures of Inn-keepers, and Å¿ell the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 1 Jac. cap. 9. by Statute. vid.
The Lord may diÅ¿train for the Forfeitures of Inmates, or for erection of Cottages, Stat. 31 Eliz. cap. 7. vid.
DiÅ¿treÅ¿s may be taken by Surveyors of High ways, 18 Eliz. cap. 10. from thoÅ¿e that make default in labouring. By the Stat.
Arrerages.Tenant in Dower cannot diÅ¿train for Arrerages of Rent due before the Recovery of her Dower, 40 Edw. 3.22. pl. 19. For the Tenants were not bound to pay her.

A LeaÅ¿e of Tithes rendring Rent,Rent. there Å¿hall be no diÅ¿treÅ¿s, becauÅ¿e the Tithes are the very thing leaÅ¿ed, 11 Hen. 4.40. and therefore cannot be diÅ¿trained no more than Land lett, and the rent iÅ¿Å¿ues not out of the Tithes.
Rent by preÅ¿cription.A perÅ¿on claims rent by preÅ¿cription, and diÅ¿trains for it, Lib. intra. 557. Charge 1. and good.
A. grants a Rent-charge to B in Tayl,Rentcharge. and grants, that if the Bayliff of the King diÅ¿trained, the party might diÅ¿train, 46 Edw. 3.18. and good by the contract.

Rent granted by Fine, and DiÅ¿treÅ¿s appointed to the JuÅ¿tices of the Com. Ban. or Barons of the Exchequer, they may diÅ¿train, 38 Edw. 3.33. So if the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s had been appointed to any others, they might diÅ¿train by vertue of the Fine.

div.head: Of what things a man may diÅ¿train.
div.p: Money cannot be diÅ¿trained,Money. unleÅ¿s it be in a Bag Å¿ealed, or a CheÅ¿t locked, 22 Edw. 4.50. B. pl. 17. 41 Edw. 3. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 14. For then it may be known and replevied, elÅ¿e it cannot.

Cattel in a Wagon.Cattel in a Wagon, viz. faÅ¿tned to it, may be diÅ¿trained, but out of a Wagon they cannot, 2 Hen. 4.15. pl. 17. 41 Edw. 3. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 14. 22 Edw. 4.50. 11 Hen. 7.14. pl. 8. 21 Hen. 7. 39. pl. 55. becauÅ¿e there can be no Return, neither doth a Replevin lie of them. Q. It Å¿eems becauÅ¿e Cattel of the Plough are not diÅ¿trainable, Å¿o they Å¿hall be adjudged if they be looÅ¿e; but when they are in the Wagon, it is known they are for other uÅ¿es. Q.
The Lord cannot Å¿eize the Cattel,Lord. and put them in a Wagon, and then diÅ¿train them, 18 Edw. 3.4. For by this means no Cattel of the Plough would be priviledged from diÅ¿training.

A HorÅ¿e at the Smiths Shop,HorÅ¿e. or a Garment in a Taylors Shop, or an HorÅ¿e in an HoÅ¿trey Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained; for this would hinder publick commerce and dealing: But if the Saddle be on the back of the HorÅ¿e when he is at the Shop, he may be deÅ¿trained, 22 Edw. 4.40. pl. 15. 15 Rich. 2. Avowry 19. becauÅ¿e it Å¿eems he is then as it were in the Owners cuÅ¿tody. Q. tamen.

A HorÅ¿e upon which I ride over my ground, the Lord cannot purÅ¿ue, and take him as a DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 6 Rich. 2. ReÅ¿cous 14. So if I have him bridled in my hand, as it Å¿eems; for that is to diÅ¿train the man as well as the HorÅ¿e.

A HorÅ¿e of any man through the whole Village Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained for the Fees of the Knights of the Parliament, 11 Hen. 4.2. For the Law looks upon the Village in general, and every one is liable for the whole, if he be able.
If a man be taxed to Fifteens, having Cattel levant in another Village, when they come within the PariÅ¿h they Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained, 18 Edw. 3. 11. pl. 39. For the PariÅ¿h is liable with the Tax.
If a HorÅ¿e of a Stranger eÅ¿capes into the Land of him that hath loÅ¿t IÅ¿Å¿ues, he Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained, as it Å¿eems, 5 Hen. 7.1. Q. For it Å¿eems hard.
If the beÅ¿t BeaÅ¿t be eÅ¿trayed, the Lord may diÅ¿train any Cattel in the Land, 27 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 24. viz. where the Lord is to have the beÅ¿t BeaÅ¿t; but it Å¿eems they muÅ¿t be levant and couchant.
A GoÅ¿hawk diÅ¿trained,GoÅ¿hawk. and the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s juÅ¿tified, 16 Edw. 4. pl. 9. viz. a reclaimed GoÅ¿hawk, for in that one may have a property, and it is valuable.
FiÅ¿hes in a Pond cannot be diÅ¿trained,FiÅ¿hes. Crookes Reports 188. becauÅ¿e they cannot be known what they are, nor can be replevied.
A Hive of Bees Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained, as it Å¿eems,Hive of Bees. for a Replevin lies of them, Nat. br. 68. D. Q. if it be in the day-time, how it can be.
Door or window.A Door or Window is not diÅ¿trainable, 11 Edw. 3. CeÅ¿Å¿avit. 21. 21 Hen. 7.26. 14 Hen. 8.25. Brudenel. For it is part of the Freehold.
A MilÅ¿tone that is Å¿evered for picking Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained, 14 Hen. 8.25.MilÅ¿tone. For it is part of the Mill.
An Anvil Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained,Anvil. 14 Hen. 8.25. For it is part of the Smiths Tools he gains his Livelihood by.
A Barge was diÅ¿trained by preÅ¿cription,Barge. 3 Mar Dyer. 117. pl. 73. and held good, for that may alter the Law.
The Lord diÅ¿trained Cattel for Å¿ervices before they were Levant and Couchant,Lord. 4 Edw. 3.37. IÅ¿Å¿ue joined, 8. 22 Hen. 6.37. 15 Hen. 7.17. Doct. & Stud. 15 A. and well, as it Å¿eems.

Sheep Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained,Sheep. if other diÅ¿treÅ¿s cannot be found at the day of the diÅ¿training,
29 Edw. 3.16. elÅ¿e not in reÅ¿pect of the hindrance of clothing.
Cattel of the Plough Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained,Plough. if there be other diÅ¿treÅ¿s Å¿ufficient, 14 Eliz. Dyer. 312. pl. 86. elÅ¿e they may; for otherwiÅ¿e the party may be without remedy.

Cattel in Dower.Cattel delivered by the Sheriff to the Tenant in Dower for Å¿eiÅ¿in of Rent Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained for Arrerages of the Rent, 40 Edw. 3.22. pl. 19. For Å¿he Å¿hall not take Å¿uch advantage.

Yarn brought upon a HorÅ¿e to a Neighbour to weigh,Yarn. this the Lord cannot diÅ¿train for Rent, becauÅ¿e it was brought for a Å¿pecial intent, Mich. 39 & 40 Eliz. com. Ban. Burleigh verÅ¿us Read. and it would hinder publick commerce and dealing.
If Cattel put into Black Acre,Cattel. and they Å¿tray into White Acre, through default of encloÅ¿ure, they Å¿hall not be diÅ¿trained, 22 Eliz. Dyer 365. pl. 33. For the Owner is in no fault.

Default of IncloÅ¿ure.A. ought to incloÅ¿e againÅ¿t B, and leaÅ¿es to C, for 21 years, which leaÅ¿es to D, for 10 years, rendring Rent, the Cattel of B, for default of encloÅ¿ure, eÅ¿cape into the Lands of A. and he purÅ¿ues them; C cannot diÅ¿train, for no default was in the owner of the Cattel, 15 Eliz. Dyer 317. pl. 9. vide 39 Edw. 3.3. pl. 12. and the Law doth not puniÅ¿h the innocent.

div.head: What PerÅ¿on Å¿hall diÅ¿train.
div.p: Dammage feaÅ¿ant.A Commoner Å¿hall diÅ¿train for dammage Å¿eÅ¿ant, and is not tied to Å¿hew per quod amiÅ¿it Communiam, No. Lib. intra. 573. D. Å¿ect. 4. 24 Edw. 3.42. pl. 23. Coke 9. part. 112. B. 46 Edw. 3.23. 15 Hen. 7.2. 7 Edw. 3.266. pl. 39.13. Hen. 8.15. For the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s there taken implies it.
Tenant at Å¿ufferance diÅ¿trains, dammages feaÅ¿ant. 4 Hen. 7.3. and good; for he hath title againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger.
He to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e before, 27 Hen. 8. could not diÅ¿train, becauÅ¿e he had nothing in the Land, 15 Hen. 7.2. pl. 4. but the Feoffee of the Land; but now it is otherwiÅ¿e.

Sheep bailed to a woman Å¿ole to dung her Land,Sheep. who takes a Husband, who commands the Owner to take them again, who refuÅ¿eth, the Husband may diÅ¿train them, dammage feaÅ¿ant, 43 Edw. 3.32. pl. 3. For now they are dammage feaÅ¿ant unto him in reÅ¿pect of his intereÅ¿t in the Land.
The Lord diÅ¿trains Cattel, becauÅ¿e the Tenant puts in more than he ought into the Common,Lord. 46 Edw. 3.12. pl. 13. and good, for he ought not to Å¿urcharge the Common.

A. Å¿old 50 Acres of Moor which lay common,Common. to B, yet every one of them ought to incloÅ¿e againÅ¿t the other, and if the Cattel of the one go into the Land of the other, they Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained, dammage feaÅ¿ant, 23 Eliz. Dyer 372. pl. 10. For by the Å¿ale the Lands are Å¿evered.

div.head: At what time a man may diÅ¿train.
div.p: Services and Amerciaments.For Rent-Å¿ervices he Å¿hall not diÅ¿train in the night, 11 Hen. 7.5. pl. 8. 12 Edw 3. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 17. 10 Edw. 3.21. Coke 9. part. 66. A. For the night is for reÅ¿t, and all things ought to be then in peace.
After the Term ended no diÅ¿treÅ¿s, 14 Hen. 4.31. For then the privity betwixt the LeÅ¿Å¿or and the LeÅ¿Å¿ee is gone. Q.
But 22 Hen. 7.96. pl. 5. by all, if a LeaÅ¿e for years be ended, and the LeÅ¿Å¿ee keeps in, the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall diÅ¿train for the arrerages. For that continues the privity as it Å¿eems. Q.

A LeaÅ¿e till Mich. for one year, rendring rent at Mich. he cannot diÅ¿train, becauÅ¿e the LeaÅ¿e is ended at the inÅ¿tant, Doct. & Stud. 74. A. That is, at the day, and the Law admits not of Fractions of time.

Husband and wife.Husband leaÅ¿es the Wifes Lands, rendring Rent, th Wife dies without IÅ¿Å¿ue, the Husband cannot diÅ¿train, becauÅ¿e the reverÅ¿ion goes to the Heir, 9 Hen. 6.45. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer 28. pl. 191. And the rent go with the ReverÅ¿ion.

A LeaÅ¿e for years,ReverÅ¿ion. & grants the reverÅ¿ion to B, yet if the Cattel of B comes upon the Land, A Å¿hall diÅ¿train during the Term, 10 Edw. 4.4. tamen quaere, becauÅ¿e he hath nothing in the Land.

Dammage feaÅ¿ant.For Dammage feaÅ¿ant in the night, one may diÅ¿train, and good enough, Coke 9. part. 66. A. Mackally's caÅ¿e. 11 Hen. 7.5. pl. 8. 12 Edw. 3. DiÅ¿treÅ¿s 17. 10 Edw. 3.21. For elÅ¿e it might be
miÅ¿chievous in reÅ¿pect of the dammages which might be done before the morning.
A. enters upon a condition broken, and takes the Cattel of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, dammage feaÅ¿ant, Quaere. 5 Eliz. Dyer 322. It Å¿eems he may; for he comes in upon a good Title.

A man may diÅ¿train dammage feaÅ¿ant, although the owner make freÅ¿h Å¿uit, in reÅ¿pect of his Å¿atisfaction for the dammage done, 7 H â¢ n. 7.1. pl. 11. 11 Hen. 7.4. pl. 11. 10 Hen. 7.21. Doct. & Stud. 15. Ã¨ contra.

div.head: In what place a man may diÅ¿train.

div.head: Who Å¿hall avow.
div.p: An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall avow for Rent due in the life of the InteÅ¿tate,AdminiÅ¿trator. per 32. Hen. 8. for he comes in the place of the InteÅ¿tate in reÅ¿pect of intereÅ¿t.

Husband and Wife.Husband and Wife in right of the wiÅ¿e, for Rent-Å¿ervices due for Land held of the wife, Lib. Intra. 555. D. Sect. 6. for the Husband hath the
preÅ¿ent intereÅ¿t, and by his death the wifes intereÅ¿t returns.
Or for Rent due to the wife afore Coverture, 4 Hen. 6.13. for by the Coverture the Rent belongs to the husband.

But one cannot make ConuÅ¿ance as Baily to the husband and wiÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e a Feme covert cannot make a Baily, 13 Hen. 4. Avowry 198. Q. how the Baily of Lands held by the husband in right of the wife Å¿hall avow? It Å¿eems as Baily to the husband only.

He to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e.He to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e before, 27 Hen. 8. cannot avow for dammage feÅ¿ant in his own name, becauÅ¿e he hath nothing in the Land at Common Law, but occupation at Å¿ufferance of the Feoffees, 15 Hen. 7.2. pl. 4. fol. 12. pl. 23. fol. 13. pl. 1. Crooke 17 Hen. 7.41. pl. 2. antea.

Gardein in Soccage.Gardein in Soccage may avow for dammage feaÅ¿ant in his own name, for he hath the Governance of the Land, Crooke 17 Hen. 7.46. B. Frowick, and Å¿o the wrong is, as it were, done to him, and he is to account for the profits of the Land.

SeiÅ¿in of Fealty is Å¿eiÅ¿in of all, becauÅ¿e he takes an Oath to do all, Coke 4. part. 8. A. Bevills caÅ¿e, 44 Edw. 3.11. 8 Hen. 6.16.
SeiÅ¿in of Annual Å¿ervice is Å¿eiÅ¿in of every CaÅ¿ual Å¿ervice, Coke 4. part. 8, 9. Bevills caÅ¿e, 20 Edw. 3. Avowry 121.76. B. Avowry 69. for the certain comprehends the incertain.
SeiÅ¿in of rent is Å¿eiÅ¿in of fealty, 29 Edw. 3.21. A. 3 Edw. 2. Avowry 188. for fealty is incident unto it.

SeiÅ¿in of one Annual Å¿ervice is not Å¿eiÅ¿in of another Annual Å¿ervice, becauÅ¿e it is the folly of the Lord that he did not obtain that which is annual, Coke 4. part. 9. A. Bevills caÅ¿e, 16 Eliz. Dyer 330. Q

ReÅ¿ervation the former year one RoÅ¿e, and afterwards 20 s. per annum, the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the one gives the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the other, Coke 4. part. 9. Bevills caÅ¿e; for they depend one upon another, and hang together like links of a Chain.
The Lord recovers dammage for Suit; this is a good Å¿eiÅ¿in of the Suit, Coke 4. part. A. Bevills caÅ¿e; for the dammage comes in room of the Å¿uit, and Å¿hew it was due.

Note that a Å¿eiÅ¿in in Law is Å¿ufficient Å¿eiÅ¿in within the Statute of 35 Hen. 8. cap. 2.1. becauÅ¿e the intent of the makers was to limit the time,
and not to exclude any Å¿eiÅ¿in that was at Common Law; 2. the words being (poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion or Å¿eiÅ¿in) in the disjunctive, make an actual Å¿eiÅ¿in, which referrs to the three former branches, and Å¿eiÅ¿in; this is either actual or in Law, which referrs to the fourth branch, Coke 4. part. 10. Bevils caÅ¿e.
MeaÅ¿nalty extinct by purchaÅ¿e of the Tenant, the old Å¿eiÅ¿in doth Å¿uffice for a Rent-Å¿eck,Ancient Å¿eiÅ¿in. Coke 4. part. 9. A. 2. Edw. 2. ExtinguiÅ¿h 6.

A Signory granted upon condition which is broken the ancient Å¿eiÅ¿in Å¿ufficeth, for the diÅ¿treÅ¿s is in lieu of the entry, Coke 4. part. 9. B. Bevills caÅ¿e; for he cannot diÅ¿train except he enter.

div.head: Barr to an Avowry.
div.p: Tender of amends for dammage feaÅ¿ant before diÅ¿treÅ¿s,Amends. or impounding is good; but not afterward, Coke 5. part. 76. A. 8. part. 147. A. Doct. & Stud. 112. B. Nat. br. 69. G. becauÅ¿e then the party is put to more loÅ¿s and trouble.

If there be tender of amends after diÅ¿treÅ¿s, and afore impounding, the detainer is wrongful and not the diÅ¿treÅ¿s, Coke 8. part. 147. A. Carpenters caÅ¿e. Q. for it Å¿eems the detainer is not wrongful, except he tender amends as well for his trouble and expences, as for the dammage done by the Cattel.
The tender of amends to the Baily is not good, Coke 5. part. 76 A. Pilkingtons caÅ¿e, 1 Hen. 4.15. pl. 17. for he hath not power to take it, for this belongs not to him as a Baily.

A claims Common appurtenant to Å¿uch a houÅ¿e pro omnibus averiis magnis, Common. and a verdict given
for him; and it was reÅ¿olved after verdict, that although he doth not Å¿ay (Å¿uis) it is good; ãâã . although he Å¿aid not Common appurtenant, PaÅ¿ch. 15. Jac. Ban. Regis, for both Å¿hall be Å¿o intended.

DiÅ¿claimer is a good bar,DiÅ¿claimer Coke 9. part. 34. Buck
â¢â¢ ls caÅ¿e, 15 Rich. 2. Avowry 214. viz. that the party who diÅ¿trained d â¢ d diÅ¿claim.

Grant by Tenant in tail.Avowry, becauÅ¿e A Å¿eiÅ¿ed in Å¿ee granted a tent to the Avowant, for which he diÅ¿trains, the other pleads that A was Å¿eiÅ¿ed in t â¢â¢ ; this is not good, if he traverÅ¿e not the Å¿eiÅ¿in in Å¿ee, 11 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 16. for he might be Å¿eiÅ¿ed alÅ¿o in Å¿ee in remainder.
Out of his Fee.Out of his Å¿ee is a good Barr, and every Stranger to the Avowry Å¿hall plead it, Coke 9. part. 20. A. 34. 15 Rich. 2. Avowry; for then the party cannot diÅ¿train there.
Note, Feodum dum homagium, & Å¿ervitium, Note. & non tenementum in dominico, Bracton lib. 2. fol. 46. B. Q. I Å¿uppoÅ¿e the meaning is, that there is Å¿ee, whereÅ¿oever homage or Å¿ervices are due.
If one avow, the other need not Å¿ay he took them in the high Street, but is put to his Action upon the Statute, 11 Rich 2. Avowry 87. which hinders the taking of Å¿uch diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es.

Injuria Å¿ua propria.In an Avowry for an Amerciament affered in Court Baron de injuria Å¿ua propria, is a good barr, for the CuÅ¿tome is traverÅ¿ed by that plea, Mich. 13 Jac. Com. Ban. Baker & Banks.

Ought to in loÅ¿e and did not.The Plaintiff Å¿ays, that the Defendant ought to have incloÅ¿ed, and did not do it Å¿ufficiently; ride the pleadings, 22 Eliz. Dyer 365. pl. 32. and that which is not Å¿ufficiently done is, as if it were not done at all.

Coparcener.ConuÅ¿ance for dammage feaÅ¿ant, the other Å¿aid that they are Coparceners; this is good, 10 & 11 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 15. for he is Å¿eized per my & per tout in all the Land, and therefore cannot be a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er.
Nothing in arrear.Nothing in arrear a good barr; but no Stranger Å¿hall plead it, Coke 9. part. 20. A. viz. upon a diÅ¿treÅ¿s for rent or Å¿ervices.

A releaÅ¿e of Actions perÅ¿onals and reals pleaded in barr of the Avowry for a corrody granted with a diÅ¿treÅ¿s,ReleaÅ¿e. a good barr, 27 Edw. 3.81. pl. 13. for the diÅ¿treÅ¿s is in the nature of an Action.

When the Lord varies from the truth of the quantity of his Å¿ervices by reaÅ¿on of Å¿eiÅ¿in,SeiÅ¿in. there the Defendant cannot traverÅ¿e the Å¿eiÅ¿in, Coke 9. part. 33. A. Com. 94. B. Mantels caÅ¿e, for the variance deÅ¿troys not the Å¿eiÅ¿in.

But if they differ of the quantity by reaÅ¿on of Å¿eiÅ¿in had, there the Å¿eiÅ¿in is traverÅ¿able, Coke 9. part. 33. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, Com. 94. B. Mantels caÅ¿e, 18 Edw. 2. Avowry 217. for the Å¿eiÅ¿in is the chief thing in queÅ¿tion.

Not Å¿eiÅ¿ed generally is a good barr, for by this he Å¿hall have no remedy of the Lord,Not Å¿eiÅ¿ed. Coke 9. part. 34. B. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 22 Hen. 6.3 A. 30 Hen. 6. Avowry 15. but he Å¿hall only retain the diÅ¿treÅ¿s. Q. for he Å¿hall have dammages.

But if the Lord avow and alledge Å¿eiÅ¿in by the hands of the Plaintiff or other perÅ¿on, the Plaintiff Å¿hall Å¿ay, never Å¿eiÅ¿ed by his hands, Coke 9. part. 35. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 22 Hen. 6.3. A. and this is a good barr, for here is a good iÅ¿Å¿ue tendered.

The Å¿eiÅ¿in is not traverÅ¿able, but for that only for which the Avowry is made, Coke 9 part. 35. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 26 Hen. 8.1. pl. 1. unleÅ¿s Å¿eiÅ¿in be alledged of a Å¿uperiour Å¿ervice, as if tenure be alledged per Homage, fealty, and rent, and the Avowry is for rent, and Å¿eiÅ¿in is alledged in all, the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the rent is only traverÅ¿able, Coke 9. part. 34. A. becauÅ¿e the Avowry is only for the rent.

But if it be of Homage, Fealty, Rent, and EÅ¿cuage, and the Avowry is for Homage, and he alledgeth Å¿eiÅ¿in in all, there the Å¿eiÅ¿in of EÅ¿cuage is traverÅ¿able, becauÅ¿e this is Å¿eiÅ¿in of all, Coke 9. part. 34. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 21 Edw. 3.52. 13 Edw. 3. Avowry 103.19 Edw. 2. Avowry 224.16 Edw. 4.11. pl. 11. for EÅ¿cuage includes all the reÅ¿t.

Tenure by Homage, Fealty, or EÅ¿cuage, or Suit of Court and other Å¿ervices, and Å¿eiÅ¿in is alledged of all, he may traverÅ¿e the Å¿eiÅ¿in of Homage and EÅ¿cuage, 2 Edw. 3.21. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e they include the reÅ¿t.

Not Å¿eiÅ¿ed within 40 years.Not Å¿eiÅ¿ed within 40 years is a good barr, 32 Hen. 8. cap. 2. Coke 9. part. 36. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 14 Eliz. Dyer 315. pl. 101. for it is not likely; if he had any right, there would have been no Å¿eiÅ¿in in Å¿o long time.

But he that pleads this, ought firÅ¿t to confeÅ¿s a tenure, to the intent that the Lord may have a Writ of CuÅ¿tomes and Services, 15 Rich. 2. Avowry 214. Coke 9. part. 34. B. Bucknals caÅ¿e. It Å¿eems the pleading Å¿o doth impliedly confeÅ¿s a tenure, or at leaÅ¿t doth not deny it.
But this is no plea in an Avowry for rent upon a grant or reÅ¿ervation by deed, becauÅ¿e the deed makes the Title, Coke 8. part. 65. A. FoÅ¿ters caÅ¿e, and not the Å¿eiÅ¿in.
Or upon a gift in Tail, becauÅ¿e the commencement of the EÅ¿tate is within the time of memory, Coke 8. part. 64. A. FoÅ¿ters caÅ¿e, 4. part. 11. A. Bevills caÅ¿e.

Or if it be for caÅ¿ual Å¿ervices, as homage, fealty, or to go to war, becauÅ¿e perchance it may not happen within 40 years, Coke 4. part. 10.11. Bevills caÅ¿e, and Å¿o there could be no Å¿eiÅ¿in of it.
So if the Lord releaÅ¿e to the Tenant Å¿o long as A hath heirs of his body, becauÅ¿e A may have heirs a long time after, Coke 4. part. 11. A. Bevilis caÅ¿e.

So if Land be conveyed to a Major and Commonality, which was held by homage and fealty, which conveys this over; this is no plea, becauÅ¿e the Major and Commonalty cannot do homage or fealty, Coke 4. part. 11. A. Bevills caÅ¿e; for that muÅ¿t be done by one Å¿ingle perÅ¿on, and not by a body politick conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of multitudes.

Note, 1. The IÅ¿Å¿ue in tail Å¿hall avoid Å¿eiÅ¿in by the hands of the Tenant in tail,SeiÅ¿in avoided in Avowry. Coke 9. part. 34. A. Bucknalls caÅ¿e, 34 Edw. 3. Avowry 131. for he comes in by the Donor.

But this is intended when the Tenant of the Lord makes a gift in Tail, the remainder in Fee; for the Tenant in tail Å¿hall himÅ¿elf avoid the encroachment and Å¿eiÅ¿in made between by the Donor, becauÅ¿e he ought to Å¿hew the commencement of the reÅ¿ervation, Coke 8. part. 65. A. FoÅ¿ters caÅ¿e, 10. part. 108. Lofields caÅ¿e.

2. SucceÅ¿Å¿or of a BiÅ¿hop Å¿hall avoid Å¿eiÅ¿in be
â¢â¢ en by the hands of the predeceÅ¿Å¿or, Coke 9. ãâã . 34. A. for the predeceÅ¿Å¿ors act Å¿hall not bind â¢ im.

3. Veray Tenant of the land, if he have deed â¢ od Å¿hew the contrary, Coke 9. part. 34. A. 10 Hen.

4. Encroachment of Å¿eiÅ¿in is not material, there is no tenure, Coke 9. part. 34. B. Bucknalls
â¢ Å¿e; for the tenure is the ground of the Å¿eiÅ¿in.

5. Such Å¿eiÅ¿in Å¿hall be avoided, becauÅ¿e it was ãâã coercion of diÅ¿treÅ¿s, Coke 9. part. 34. B. Buck

caÅ¿e, 12 Edw. 4.7. pl. 18. 8 Hen. 6.18. pl. 1. â¢â¢
Edw. 3.4. pl. 8. and not voluntarily rendred, ãâã is in the nature of a thing obtained by DureÅ¿s.

6. If rent be payable at one day in a year, and the Lord encroacheth Å¿eiÅ¿in upon two days of the year; this being involuntary, yet Å¿hall be avoided is an Avowry for this, that they agree in the â¢â¢â¢ ual Å¿um, Coke 9. part. 34. B. Bucknalls caÅ¿e,
â¢ ide 21 Edw. 4.64. pl. 36, & fol. 84. pl. 39. and the â¢â¢ me is only in queÅ¿tion, and the Lord is not leÅ¿Å¿ened in the rent.Tenure.
In an Avowry the Å¿eiÅ¿in is traverÅ¿able, and not the tenure, Crooke 13 Hen. 7.31. B. for without Å¿eiÅ¿in the Avowry is not iÅ¿Å¿uable.

1. When the Lord varies in avowing of the â¢ erity of the quantity of the Å¿ervices by colour of Å¿eiÅ¿in, the tenure Å¿hall be traverÅ¿ed, Coke 9. part. 33. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 10 Hen. 7.11. pl. 31. Com 94. Mantels caÅ¿e, Crooke 13 Hen. 7.31. B. â¢ iz. he may Å¿ay, that he holds not by Å¿o much â¢â¢ nt, or Å¿o many Å¿ervices.

But then the Tenant ought to confeÅ¿s the Tenure in part, for he needs not traverÅ¿e all the tenure, as to Å¿ay that he holds not of him; but he may diÅ¿claim or plead out of his fee, Coke 9. part. 35. A. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 10 Hen. 6.6, 7. pl. 20. 37 Hen. 6.25. pl. 13. 15 Rich. 2. Avowry 214. as to part.

But note 11 Hen. 4.10. pl. 22. the Tenant Å¿aid, that the Avowant did give the LordÅ¿hip to A in tail, the remainder to B in tail, and that A died without iÅ¿Å¿ue, B yet living; there he needs not Å¿uffer a DiÅ¿claimer, or plead out of his fee, but there fol. 7. pl. 40. he had judgment of the Avowry, and admitted good.

2. When they agree in the quantity of the Services, and vary in the quantity of the Land; there the Plaintiff may traverÅ¿e abÅ¿que hoc, that he held modo & forma, or Å¿ay that he held one Acre only, Coke 9. part. 35. B. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 20 Hen. 6.20, & 21.
And Å¿o one may avow Å¿everally where it is a joynt Tenure, or to the contrary, Coke 9. part. 35. B. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 9 Hen. 6.26. pl. 24. 2. Edw. 3.34. pl. 19.

But if he vary in the quantity of the Land and of the Services, he may not confeÅ¿s the Tenure according to the verity of the caÅ¿e, but may traverÅ¿e mode & forma, or Å¿ay he held one only, Coke 9. part. 35. A, & B. Bucknals caÅ¿e, 5 Hen 5.4.

3. When one diÅ¿trains for fealty, rent, and Å¿uit of Court, and alledges Å¿eiÅ¿in in all, and avows for rent, the Tenant may confeÅ¿s that he held by fealty and rent, and plead as to the rent nothing arrear, without that that he held by fealty, rent,
â¢ nd Å¿uit, modo & forma, as is alledged, and good; â¢â¢ d if upon IÅ¿Å¿ue joyned it be found, that he â¢ eld by fealty and rent, and not Å¿uit, although that â¢ he Avowry be for rent, yet inÅ¿omuch that the tenure alledged by the Avowant was traverÅ¿ed and found againÅ¿t him, Judgment Å¿hall be given againÅ¿t the Avowant, for in vain Å¿hall he make this traverÅ¿able, and yet that he Å¿hould have the return when it is found againÅ¿t him, Coke 9. part. 35, & 36. Bucknals caÅ¿e.
Tender of Homage ought to be to the perÅ¿on of the Lord,Tender. ubicunque fuerit infra regnum proper reverentiam, Bracton lib. 2. fol. 80. A. quaere. for this may be prejudicial to the Tenant.

div.head: Judgment.
div.p: If the Plaintiff counts upon a Detainer, and the Defendant appears and makes default, the other Å¿hall have Judgment for dammages and coÅ¿ts, and alÅ¿o for the value of the Cattel, Nat. br. 69. L. No. Lib. Intra. 610. C. Sect. 20. for by the default he confeÅ¿Å¿eth the tort.
Retorno habendo Null. 1. The Defendant Å¿aid that the place is ancient demeÅ¿n, &c. if the iÅ¿Å¿ue be found for him the Plaintiff Å¿hall not have a return, 21 Edw. 3.7. pl. 18.

2. If one juÅ¿tifies for Services and makes no Avowry, he Å¿hall not have a return, although it be found for him, 15 Edw. 4.29. 5 Edw. 4.6. 34 Hen. 6. Avowry 47. for there is difference betwixt Avowing and JuÅ¿tifying; Avowing Å¿uppoÅ¿eth tenure, but JuÅ¿tifying doth not.
If one make a ConuÅ¿ance as Bailiff, he Å¿hall have a return, No. Lib. Intra. 591. A. Å¿ect. 9. viz. for his MaÅ¿ter.
3. The Plaintiff in a Recaption dies, the Lord Å¿hall have return, if another Writ be purchaÅ¿ed, 11 Hen. 6.14. pl. 3. Q.

If the Plaintiff be NonÅ¿uited,Returno habendo. the other Å¿hall have a return, Lib. Intra. 570. D. Å¿ect. 1, 2. 11 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 14. 35 Hen. 6.47. pl. 12. 17 Hen. 8. br. Å¿econd Deliverance 15. 22 Hen. 7.92. pl. 7. Crooke; and this, although the other do make no Avowry, 16 Hen. 6. return of Cattel 1. 2 Hen. 5.6. for the NonÅ¿uit confeÅ¿Å¿eth the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s well taken, and Å¿o the Avowry is needleÅ¿s.
But otherways he may abate the Writ, by pleading 9 Hen. 6.4. pl. 10. 11 Hen. 6.5. B. Danby, 35 Hen. 6.40. pl. 1.

But if the Count abate, or if he count not of the place of the taking, yet he Å¿hall not have a return before an Avowry, 35 Hen. 6.40. pl. 1. becauÅ¿e that is but for want of good pleading, and he may have juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of complaint, notwithÅ¿tanding for ought that appears to the Court.
The Å¿econd Deliverance, he Å¿hall not have it without Avowry, per Newton, 16 Hen. 6. return of Cattel 1. for it is grounded upon a Title Å¿hewn.
The Defendant cannot claim a property in Repleg. to have a return, becauÅ¿e he ought to claim at the time of the Repleg. Å¿ued, 31 Hen. 6.12. pl. 1. and now it is too late.
The Plaint is removed, and it abates for default of the Sirname, there was a return awarded without an Avowry, 27 Hen. 6.3. pl. 35. for here is no right party complained of.

Repleg. againÅ¿t C and D, C pleads he took them not, D juÅ¿tifies in right of C, and found for him; yet he Å¿hall not have a return, 22 Hen. 6.52. pl. 27. becauÅ¿e he juÅ¿tifies in the right of another, who diÅ¿claims the diÅ¿treÅ¿s.

The Defendant pleads property in another, and found Å¿o; there he Å¿hall have a return without an Avowry, for the Plaintiff had deliverance without cauÅ¿e, 39 Hen. 6.35. pl. 47. PriÅ¿ott, becauÅ¿e the Cattel belonged to another.

One avows for rent at two days, one whereof is not come, the Plaintiff is NonÅ¿uited; there Å¿hall be a return in reÅ¿pect of the rent due for one day, becauÅ¿e he is not meerly an Actor, per 4. JuÅ¿tices againÅ¿t three.
But Newton Å¿aid, he ought to have Å¿everal Avowries. Q.

At the Common Law a return irrepleviÅ¿able was but when it was found againÅ¿t the Plaintiff,1. Return irrepleviÅ¿able, 1. At Common Law. 2. At the Statute Law. by an iÅ¿Å¿ue tried, 36 Hen. 6.8. pl. 24. Babbington, for then the matter was fully tried.
If the Defendant doth not anÅ¿wer to the Avowry, there the Cattel Å¿hall be irrepleviÅ¿able, Lib. Intra. 571. A. Å¿ect. 4. for he thereby confeÅ¿Å¿eth the diÅ¿treÅ¿s lawful.2.
Return irrepleviÅ¿able after WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 2. is but upon a NonÅ¿uit in Å¿econd Deliverance, 2 Hen. 4.23. pl. 9. Lib. Intra. 571. A. Å¿ect. 4, 5.

Upon a NonÅ¿uit in Repleg. it Å¿hall not be, 24 Edw. 3.33. pl. 22. if it be not after verdict,
14 Hen. 7.6. pl. 14. for he may have juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of complaint though he be NonÅ¿uit; but by the verdict it appears he had not.

If the Plaintiff be NonÅ¿uited in a Replevin, and after in a Å¿econd deliverance, there Å¿hall be a return irrepleviÅ¿able before Avowry; but quaere, if he Å¿hall have dammages before Avowry, 10 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 14. It Å¿eems he Å¿hall, for this double NonÅ¿uit admits the taking lawful.

If the Plaintiff be NonÅ¿uited when the Jury comes again and gives their verdict, yet there Å¿hall not be a return irrepleviÅ¿able, 34 Hen. 6.5. pl. 14. 14 Hen. 7.6. pl. 14. for it may be he hath better evidence, which he then failed of.
The Plaintiff in Repleg. makes default at the NiÅ¿i prius, they Å¿hall not be irrepleviÅ¿able, becauÅ¿e it is out of the Law, 3 Hen. 6.8. pl. 24.
The Plaintiff in a Repleg. is NonÅ¿uited, and a return awarded, the King demiÅ¿es, the pledges being warned come not; quaere, if the return Å¿hall be irrepleviÅ¿able, 1 Edw. 7. pl. 13.
Or upon a Return awarded in Å¿econd deliverance, 2 Hen. 4.23. pl. 9. Q.
Or upon a judgment againÅ¿t the Plaintiff upon a Demurrer, 2 Hen. 4.23. pl. 9. 14. Hen. 7.6. pl. 14.2, & 3 Mariae, Dyer 118. pl. 77. Q.
Upon a Demurrer upon a plea to the Writ, and judgment for the Defendant, they Å¿hall not be irrepleviÅ¿able, 34 Hen. 6.37. B. br. Repleg. 6. for that is not upon the merits of the cauÅ¿e.

Or upon iÅ¿Å¿ue tried, 2 Hen. 23. pl. 9. the Defendant in a Repleg. pleads to the Writ, and found by the Jury Å¿o, there Å¿hall be a return irrepleviÅ¿able, the contrary upon a Demurrer upon
a Writ or ConceÅ¿Å¿ion, 34 Hen. 6.37. B. br. Repleg. 6. for a verdict is of a higher account than a Demurrer or ConceÅ¿Å¿ion.

If the Plaintiff upon a Å¿econd Deliverance Å¿uffer the plea to be diÅ¿continued, there it Å¿hall be irrepleviÅ¿able, 17 Hen. br. Å¿econd Deliverance; for the Court will not be troubled with Suits to no purpoÅ¿e.

Dammages by Statutes.Note, that at this day dammages are given where the Plaintiff is NonÅ¿uited, or found againÅ¿t him. or otherwiÅ¿e barred in ConuÅ¿ance, Avowry, or JuÅ¿tification, for Rents, CuÅ¿tomes, or Services, per 7 Hen. 8. cap. 4. com. 82. B. Crokers caÅ¿e, 14 Mariae Dyer 141. pl. 46. 19 Hen. 8.11. pl. 7.
And for dammage feaÅ¿ant, per 21 Hen. 8. cap. 19.1, & 3 Mariae, Dyer 118. pl. 77. 4 Mariae, Dyer 141. pl. 46.

But if it be for an EÅ¿tray he Å¿hall not have dammages, becauÅ¿e the Statute extends not to it,
â¢ aÅ¿ch. 34 Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rot. 292. and being penal, it Å¿hall not be expounded by equity.
But at the Common Law the Avowant Å¿hall not recover dammages, 35 Hen. 6. pl. 12. for it was though enough for him to have return of the diÅ¿treÅ¿s.

If one have a return irrepleviÅ¿able upon a NonÅ¿uit in Å¿econd deliverance, it is doubted whether he Å¿hall have dammages before Avowry, 11 Eliz. Dyer 280. pl. 14. It Å¿eems he Å¿hall, becauÅ¿e there needs no Avowry. Quaere tamen, for it appears not to the Court, that he had cauÅ¿e to diÅ¿train.
