div.head: TreÅ¿paÅ¿s. In what Court TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies.
div.p: County Court.IN the County Court; but then it Å¿hall not Å¿ay vi & armis, Nat. br. 85. G. neither againÅ¿t the peace, becauÅ¿e the Sheriff cannot determine it, RegiÅ¿t. 92. A. for that Court is not to meddle with criminal matters.

Note, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 111. B. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s vi & armis, Note. Å¿hall not be Å¿ued in any Court but the Kings, or before his JuÅ¿tices, if otherways a SuperÅ¿edeas Å¿hall be awarded, Coke 8. part. 120. A. for he is the proper Judge of Å¿uch matters, as the chief conÅ¿ervator of the Peace.

In the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey,MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey. if the party be of the HouÅ¿hold, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies; but then it Å¿hall Å¿ay vi & armis, for battery or carrying away of goods, and no other cauÅ¿es, Coke 10. part. 72. A. which indeed are rather civil than criminal cauÅ¿es.
For it Å¿hall not be Quare clauÅ¿um fregit, Coke 10. part. 76. A. which is of a higher nature, and may concern title of Land.
It lies in Chancery for one priviledged there,Chancery. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 104. A. No. Lib. Intra. 678. B. Å¿ect. 20. in reÅ¿pect of his attendance required there.
And there Å¿hall be an Alias, &c. RegiÅ¿t. 104. A.
It lies in Com. Ban. or Ban. Regis, Nat. br. 86. G. for theÅ¿e are high Courts of Record.Com. Ban. Regis.

Ancient Demean.If TreÅ¿paÅ¿s be brought in the Court of the King, where the reality Å¿hall come in debate, Ancient Demean is a good plea, becauÅ¿e the Title ought to be tried there, Coke 5. part. 105. as in treÅ¿paÅ¿s for Trees, where the Defendant claims Franktenement in the land where the Trees grew, 6 Hen. 4.1. pl. 6. otherwiÅ¿e it is no plea, 46 Edw. 3.1. pl. 2. becauÅ¿e the Action is perÅ¿onal, which may be any where Å¿ued.
In TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for a Pigeon-houÅ¿e with Pigeons, it is no plea, 47 Edw. 3.22. pl. 54. viz. Ancient demeÅ¿n, becauÅ¿e the Action is chiefly in reÅ¿pect of the Pigeons.
So in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s upon the CaÅ¿e, 5 Rich. 2. cap. 7. becauÅ¿e dammages are only to be recovered, 21 Edw. 4.3. 2 Hen. 7.17. pl. 1. 47 Edw. 3.22. pl. 54. 46 Edw. 3.1.âª pl. 2. which are perÅ¿onal.
And note,Noteâª none may plead this, but the Tertenant of the Land in Ancient dem â¢â¢ n, 2 Hen. 7.17. pl. 1. and that in reÅ¿pect of his Å¿ervice to be done to the Lord there.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in the Five Ports, the Writ is, Dilecto & fideli Å¿uo W. ConÅ¿tabular. CaÅ¿tri Å¿ui de D. & CuÅ¿todi quinque Portuum Å¿uor. Å¿alutem. Mandamus vobis quod Audita quaerela A. de quadam tranÅ¿gr. eidem A. per B. qui eÅ¿t de libertate Portuum praedict. illat. ut dicitur, auditiÅ¿que hine & inde earum rationibus, eidem A. facias exhiberi celeris juÅ¿titiae complementum, prout de jure & Å¿ecundum legem, & conÅ¿uetudinem portuum praedict. fuerit faoiend. ne clamor ad nos inde perveniat iteratus, &c.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s.
div.p: Note, that he that taketh only the profit of the Å¿oil of anothers Land, Å¿hall not have a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s Quare clauÅ¿um fregit, 15 Hen. 7. 14 Hen. 8. becauÅ¿e he hath no intereÅ¿t in the Å¿oil.
He that hath certain Acres of land annuatim, Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, for he hath a term in thoÅ¿e Acres of land.

An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for goods of the InteÅ¿tates taken out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the AdminiÅ¿trator,AdminiÅ¿trator. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 94. A. 22 Edw. 4.120. pl. 32. the Count, Lib. Intra. 649. D. Sect. 1. for he hath a property in them ratione AdminiÅ¿trationis.

An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for goods taken out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the InteÅ¿tate, in reÅ¿pect of his intereÅ¿t in them, Nat.br. 92. A. 14 Hen. 7.13. Tremaile, the Count, Lib. Intra. 640. A. Sect. 1.

An Executor Å¿hall have it,Executor. per the Stat. of 4 Edw. 3. cap. 6. and the Statute of 31 Edw. 3. gives the Å¿ame remedy to an AdminiÅ¿trator; but this is by the equity of the Statute, 4 Edw. 3. cap. 7. Crooke 24 Hen. 7.101. B. pl. 2.

An AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿s before the AdminiÅ¿tration committed to him;AdminiÅ¿trator. but not againÅ¿t him that juÅ¿tifies under the Ordinary, for he was AdminiÅ¿trator pro tempore, 18 Hen. 6.22. pl. 7. 36 Hen. 6.8. A PriÅ¿ot, RegiÅ¿ter Original 102. B. that is, for goods taken before the AdminiÅ¿tration granted.

But if the AdminiÅ¿tration be committed by word to A, who Å¿ells goods to B, and dies, and the AdminiÅ¿tration is committed to C; quaere, if C Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the goods Å¿old: It Å¿eems not, for A had authority, as it Å¿eems, to Å¿ell.
An alien Friend Å¿hall have all Actions perÅ¿onals,Alien. 6 Hen. 8. Dyer pl. 8. Coke 7. part. 17. A. ratione commorantiae by the Law of Nations, which the Common Law maintains.

But an alien Enemy Å¿hall have no Action, 6 Hen. 8. Dyer 2. pl. 8. Coke 7. part. 17. A. 14 Hen. 8.4. for it is not reaÅ¿on, that he that wiÅ¿hes ill to the Nation where he lives, Å¿hould have the protection of their Laws.

Husband and wife.Husband and wife Executrix to B joyn in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for taking the Goods during coverture, 21 Edw. 4.5. per Littleton, and good, in reÅ¿pect of the Husbands intereÅ¿t in right of his wife, viz. in taking her goods.

In a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done to the wife Å¿ole, who takes a Husband, they Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in both their names, Nat. br. 87 H. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 95. A. for the dammages do concern the Husband, 21 Hen. 6.30. pl. 16. Lib. Intr. 6.50. C. Sect. 3. and the Count Å¿hall be bona & catalla of the wife, 7 Hen. 7.2. vide 14 Eliz. Dyer 305. pl. 59. the Count, Lib. Intra. 650. C. Sect. 3.

Husband and wife may joyn in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the beating of the wife, 46 Edw. 3.3. pl. 5. 22 AÅ¿Å¿ize 60, & 87. RegiÅ¿t. 105. B. Lib. Intra. 612, & 668. C. Sect. 4. for he is damnified by it, as well as his wife, viz. by loÅ¿ing his labour and Å¿ociety.
So for impriÅ¿onment of the Wife, Coke 5. part 59. A. FoÅ¿ters caÅ¿e, for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

But if they joyn for battery of both, this abates for the battery of the Husband, 9 Edw. 4.54. 3 Edw. 3. brev. 737. For the battery of the Husband is not the battery of the Wife; and Å¿o as to that, Å¿he hath no cauÅ¿e of Action.

And if they brought a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for beating and taking away of Goods during the coverture, thÃ© Writ Å¿hall Å¿ay de bonis of the Husband; for the Wife cannot have a property during the coverture, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. B.
And if the Husband and Wife are beaten, they Å¿hall have Å¿everal Actions, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. in the Note, quia tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿io perÅ¿onalis ought to be brought only by the perÅ¿on injured.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s quare domum Å¿uam fregit, & maremium iude aÅ¿portavit, &c. being the houÅ¿e of the Wife, is good by the Husband alone, becauÅ¿e he may pull it down and Å¿ell it, 43 Edw. 3.16. pl. 15 & fol. 26. pl. 6. Q. It Å¿eems Å¿o, becauÅ¿e he cannot be Å¿ued for it during the coverture.
So for entring and chaÅ¿ing and carrying away of the Deer in a Park, although the Wife had a joint EÅ¿tate with her Husband, yet it is a perÅ¿onal thing in the Husband, 43 Edw. 3.8. pl. 23.
So for Deeds concerning the Land of the Wife, 8 Hen. 5.9. pl. 13. For Deeds are Chattels, though they concern the Realty.
So in treÅ¿paÅ¿s upon the Statute of 5 Richard 2. cap. 7. becauÅ¿e he only Å¿hall have dammages, 38 Hen. 6.3. pl. 9.4. Edw. 4.13. if he recover.

So for taking away of his Wife and his Goods,
Nat. br. 89. O. 14 Hen. 6.2. pl. 11. 6 Edw. 3.208. pl. 2. 43 Edw. 3.23. pl. 15. 44 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 13. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 97. A. for this is given by WeÅ¿tm. 1. cap. 12. & WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 34. It Å¿eems this Statute was but in affirmance of the common Law.

Quando breve fertur ab aliquibus ad liberum tenementum annexis fiat in nomine amborum, Nota. Å¿ed Å¿i Å¿it de rebus libero tenemento non annexis in nomine viri tantum, Å¿ed Å¿i Å¿it de domo fracta Å¿it in nomine amborum, Å¿ed alii Clerici dicunt quod fiat in nomine viri tantum, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 108. B. This is when treÅ¿paÅ¿s is brought concerning HouÅ¿e and Lands of the Wife being covert.
Vide tamen in nomine amborum de clauÅ¿o fracto & bona, &c. Lib. intra. 640. B. Å¿ect. 4. & fol. 662. D. Å¿ect. 21 Rich. 2. brev. 933. Q.
Chaplain of a Chappel.The King collates, and the Sheriff puts him in who is collated, he Å¿hall have treÅ¿paÅ¿s, Nat. br. 37. D. if the TreÅ¿paÅ¿s be done after he be put in.

A Commoner Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for any thing in the Land,Commoner. viz. the Å¿oil of a Common, 4 Hen. 7.3. 15 Hen. 7.13. pl. 1. & fol. 12. pl. 23. For he hath only an intereÅ¿t in the Herbage, Q. tamen.

He that hath not Å¿oil. A lets Land to B, for to Å¿ow, and A to have the Moiety of the Corn, yet B cannot have treÅ¿paÅ¿s Quare clauÅ¿um fregit againÅ¿t him for waÅ¿ting of the Corn, for he hath intereÅ¿t in the whole Crop, Hill. 30 Eliz. H â¢ re verÅ¿us Oakley. And although this was not pleaded in abatement, yet the Å¿pecial matter being found, the Plaintiff Å¿hall not have judgment, becauÅ¿e it appears to
the Court they cannot be disjoined to have an action in Å¿uch form. For they are upon the matter joint-tenants of the Land.
He to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e.He to whoÅ¿e uÅ¿e, Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in his own name, but in the name of the Feoffees, Crooke 17 Hen. 7.41. pl. 2. For the EÅ¿tate in Law is in them.

A Copy-holder Å¿hall have treÅ¿paÅ¿s for the breaking his CloÅ¿e, and cutting his Trees,Copy-holder. 2 Hen. 8.4.12. Coke 4. part. 21. B. No. Lib. intra. 644. C. Å¿ect. 3. the pleadings. For he hath an intereÅ¿t in both to Å¿ome purpoÅ¿es.
He Å¿hall have it againÅ¿t the Lord, 20 Edw. 3. â¢ 0. Coke 4. part. 22. A. For the Lord in this â¢ eÅ¿pect is in no better condition than a Å¿tranger.

DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the mean profits,DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee. and all other things after his re-entry, Coke 11. part. 51. A. Liffords caÅ¿e. 3 Hen. 4.13. pl. 18. GaÅ¿coigne, 37 H. 6.7. pl. 13. but not before, becauÅ¿e then he had no intereÅ¿t in the Land, but a bare right.
But before his entry, he Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 32 Hen. 6.32. A. 38 Hen. 6.28. A. ForteÅ¿cue, viz. againÅ¿t one that entred before he was diÅ¿Å¿ciÅ¿ed. Q.

UnleÅ¿s in caÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, as Tenant for the Life of another is diÅ¿Å¿eized, and he for whoÅ¿e life he hath it, dies, or Tenant for years is outed, and the years expire, they Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s aÅ¿ore the entry, and recover the mean profits, 38 Hen. 6.28. B. Where there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity, the Law doth give way to uÅ¿ual things rather than there Å¿hould be a failure of JuÅ¿tice.
An Executor Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for Goods taken out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the TeÅ¿tator,Executor. Nat. Br. 87. E. RegiÅ¿t. 98. A. in reÅ¿pect of his intereÅ¿t by his ExecutorÅ¿hip.
And the Writ Å¿hall not Å¿ay ad grave damnum neque in retardationem executionis teÅ¿tamenti, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 98. A. the Count, Lib. intra. 640. A. Å¿ect. 2.
But this was given by the Stat. of 4 Edw. 3. cap. 6. 14 Hen. 7.13.
And at this day an Executor of an Executor Å¿hall have Å¿uch an Action, RegiÅ¿t. 98. A. the rule there; it Å¿eems upon the equity of the former Statute.
But he Å¿hould not have had it before, 25 Edw. 3. viz. at the Common Law. cap. 5. Com. 290. A. Chapmans caÅ¿e.
But an Executor Å¿hall not have Å¿uch Action De clauÅ¿o fracto, 11 Hen. 4.3. pl. 8. 4 Edw. 4.8. A. CateÅ¿by. viz. in vita TeÅ¿tatoris; for this is not within the Statute.
Neque de Arboribus Å¿ucciÅ¿is tempore TeÅ¿tatoris, 18 Edw. 4.16. A. Pigott. Nor this, and Å¿o both are left at the Common Law.
An Executor Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s before probate of the Will, unleÅ¿s it be for a thing taken out of his own poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Com. 281. Q. rationem differentiae.

One Executor Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for a thing taken out of his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, with his companion, 42 Edw. 3.26. pl. 12. 2 Rich. 2. Executor 75. For Executors are but as one perÅ¿on in Law, or he may bring it alone.

But the 19 Hen. 6.65. to the contrary. Q. Executor Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s de bonis TeÅ¿tatoris â¢ Å¿portatis in cuÅ¿todia Å¿ua exten. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 94. A. 2 Hen. 7.15. 6 Edw. 4.1. and good; for they are accounted the TeÅ¿tators, though to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of by the Executor in performance of the will.

A. takes AdminiÅ¿tration of the Goods of B, C proves a Will, by which he was made Executor, and brought TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t A for the Goods, it lies, although the AdminiÅ¿tration was not repealed; for the AdminiÅ¿tration was void from the beginning, Mich. 12. Jac. Ban. Regis. FiÅ¿her & Young. becauÅ¿e there was a Will made.

An Executor Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t the leÅ¿Å¿or which outs him, during the Term, RegiÅ¿t. rig. 102. B. if he have a LeaÅ¿e parol. Q. if by Deeds, whether he ought not to bring an Action of Recovery.

If the LeÅ¿Å¿or outs the Executor of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, the Writ Å¿hall be Summon. per bonos Å¿ummonit. &c. but if he outs him, and takes the Goods of the LeÅ¿Å¿or within the Land, the Writ Å¿hall be pone per vad. &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. B. in the Note, and this is in reÅ¿pect of the dammages he is to anÅ¿wer for taking the Goods.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lieth by a Goaler againÅ¿t one that takes ãâã priÅ¿oner from him;Goaler. for the Gaoler is liable for the perÅ¿on; but a good bar that he is not Goaler, becauÅ¿e it is the ground of the Action, 4 Edw. 4.6. pl. 7. & fol. 44. pl. ult.

Church-wardens Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the Goods of the Church taken in their time,Church-wardens or in the time of their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, Nat. br. 91. K.
8 Edw. 4.6. pl. 5. 12 Hen. 7.27. pl. 7. 11 Hen. 4.12. 8 Hen. 5.4. 37 Hen. 6.30. 10 Hen. 7.9. pl. 5. For they are intruÅ¿ted with them to the uÅ¿e of the PariÅ¿hioners.

But they Å¿hall count ad damnum parocbianorum, 8 Edw. 4.6. pl. 12 Hen. 7.27. pl. 7. For the Goods are the PariÅ¿hioners, and the Church-warden is intereÅ¿ted in their right, and is accountable unto them.
But a good plea that he is not Churchwarden, 4 Edw. 4.7. A. For that deÅ¿troys the Å¿uppoÅ¿al of the Writ.
But 19 Hen. 6.66. Å¿ays; that it is not good for Goods in the time of their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors. Q. yet the Law Å¿eems to be otherwiÅ¿e, elÅ¿e the pariÅ¿hioners might be damnified.
TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for making a Grant of Rent in Å¿ee taken to the uÅ¿e of the Parochians, Lib. intra. 7. D. Q.

Heir RaviÅ¿hment.Every AnceÅ¿tor male or female, Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for raviÅ¿hing of his or her Heir apparent againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger, but not againÅ¿t the Gardein in Chivalry, unleÅ¿s the Father only, Coke. 3. part. 38. B. Ratcliffs caÅ¿e, Nat. br. 143. R. 30. Edw. 6. pl. 7. & fol. 16. pl. 19. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 98. B. & 99. A. and the Mother; for the education of the Heir doth properly belong to the Father and Mother.

A man Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for his Son and Heir, Daughter and Heir taken away, Nat. br. 98. H. 29 AÅ¿Å¿ize 35. 21 Hen. 6.14. pl. 29.12 Hen. 4.16. pl. 9. 3 Edw. 4.12. B. Danby. For it is an injury to the Parents to loÅ¿e the comfort of the Child, eÅ¿pecially the eldeÅ¿t.
And this of what age Å¿oever his Son be, 32 Edw. 3. Gard. 32. though the dammage may be greater or leÅ¿s in regard of the Age.

A Grantee of Herbage of Land Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s,Grantee. quare clauÅ¿um fregit for the GraÅ¿s, but not for the other profits of the Land, as Fruit-trees, and the like, 11 Eliz. Dyer. 285 pl. 40. 3 Hen. 16. 13. A. 5. Hen. 7.10. B. For he hath nothing but the Herbage granted unto him.

The Heir Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for taking of a Deed concerning Land to him deÅ¿cended,Heir. and it is good, although he doth not Å¿ay, Å¿criptum Å¿uum, becauÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿ity it muÅ¿t belong to him, 1 Edw. 3.18, pl. 11. For it goes along with the inheritance.

But not againÅ¿t an Executor that taketh a Box with Deeds. 1. BecauÅ¿e the Box appertaineth to him. 2. He had not knowledge what was in the Box. 3. The Heir hath other remedy againÅ¿t him, Å¿cilicet a Detinue, 43 Edw. 3.24. pl. 3. becauÅ¿e the Box and Deeds come to him in a lawful way, though he cannot juÅ¿tifie the detaining.

But it lies againÅ¿t an Executor for taking away a Furnace fixed, or Fatts fixed to the Free-hold, or Pales faÅ¿tned, Windows, Doors, Evidences looÅ¿e, 21 Hen. 7.26. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e they all belong to the Free-hold as part of it.

It lies for an Heir againÅ¿t an Executor for taking FiÅ¿hes out of a Pond, Mich. 36 Eliz. Ban. Regis. Rot. 25. Parlett verÅ¿us Gray. Crooke 118 pl. 60. For they belong to the Å¿oil, viz. the Land covered with Water which makes the Pond.
So for Deer or Pigeons, vide AÅ¿Å¿ize 27. pl. 29. but not tame Deer or tame Pigeons; the out is as it were an Inheritance, the other a Chattel.

The LeÅ¿Å¿or excepts the Trees,LeÅ¿Å¿or. he Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s quare clauÅ¿um fregit, 14 Hen. 8.1. 28 Hen. 8. Dyer. 19. pl. 48. 46 Edw. 3.22. pl. 3. Coke 8. part. 63. A. Swaynes caÅ¿e. againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or, if he cut them down.
A LeÅ¿Å¿or at Will Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, although he determines his Will, until he enters, Crooke 3. Hen. 8.163. pl. 4. For before he hath no Title.

A enters upon Tenant at Will, and Å¿ubverts the Å¿oil, he Å¿hall have one Action, and the LeÅ¿Å¿or another, 19 Hen. 6.45. pl. 94. Å¿o of a Copyholder and Lord, 2 Hen. 4.12. Coke 4. part. 31. A. For as they are both damnified, Å¿o it is reaÅ¿on they Å¿hould both have recompence.

LeÅ¿Å¿ee cuts Trees to the intent to repair,LeÅ¿Å¿ee. the LeÅ¿Å¿or takes them, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 44 Edw. 3.44. for the dammage done him in cauÅ¿ing him to loÅ¿e his labour in cutting of them.

A Å¿tranger cuts Trees, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, and Å¿hall recover treble dammages, Doct. & Stud. 34. A. 23 Hen. 8. Br. waÅ¿t. 138. 44 Hen. 8.26. becauÅ¿e the LeÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall recover Å¿o much of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee in reÅ¿pect of the WaÅ¿te.
But if the LeÅ¿Å¿or dies, the LeÅ¿Å¿ee Å¿hall recover but Å¿ingle dammages, 44 Edw. 3.26. Crooke 3 Hen. 8.163. pl. 4. becauÅ¿e no more Å¿hall be recovered againÅ¿t him by the Heir.

1. If the Servant be beat,MaÅ¿ter. the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Nat. br. 91. I. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. A.
8 Hen. 6.28. 19 Hen. 6.35. pl. 73. although he be but a Å¿ervant at will, 21 Hen. 6.9. A. Newton. vide 11 Hen. 4.2.2. For the beating of the Servant is a dammage to the MaÅ¿ter, and the Servant may alÅ¿o have this Action.
2. For taking away his Apprentice, Nat. br. 91. I. 8 Hen. 6.28. 21 Hen. 6.31. pl. 18. whereby he loÅ¿eth his Å¿ervice.
3. The Lord of a Villain Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 22 Hen. 6.30.32. for taking away his Villain, or beating him, as it Å¿eems.

The Ordinary Å¿hall have it for a thing taken out of his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion,Ordinary. Nat. br. 91. M. 18 Hen. 6.23. 7 Hen. 4.18. pl. 22. 11 Hen. 7.12.17 Edw. 2. brev. 8 22. as Ordinary, for he hath a kind of property in it. But not for a thing which was not in his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Nat. br. 92. A. Coke 9. part 39. A. HenÅ¿lees caÅ¿e, 7 Hen. 4.18. pl. 22. For the Law takes no notice of his right without a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

A ParÅ¿on Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for Tithes taken after Å¿everance of the 9 parts,ParÅ¿on. 10 Hen. 4.2. pl. 2. GaÅ¿coign, 21 Hen. 7.27. pl. 5. before any Å¿eiÅ¿ure, becauÅ¿e it is certain by the Å¿everance what was his, and the Law caÅ¿ts the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion and property upon him, Com. 281. A. Foxes caÅ¿e.
But not of a Mortuary before Å¿eiÅ¿ure, Com. 281. A. 10. Hen. 4.1. but there is but a bare cuÅ¿tomary right.

A ParÅ¿on or Vicar Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the Walls or GlaÅ¿s of the Church, or GraÅ¿s or Trees in the Church-yard, &c. or Glebe-Land, 11 Hen. 4.12. pl. 25. 8 Hen. 6.9. pl. 20. 11 Hen. 6.4. B. Danby. Q. For the Church belongs
to the PariÅ¿hioners, and the Chancel to the ParÅ¿on, yet the free-hold of the Church is in the ParÅ¿on.

ParÅ¿on imparÅ¿onee Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t any that is admitted and inducted into the Å¿aid Church, if he intermeddle with the Glebe or Tythes, Com. 500. B. 38 Hen. 6.24. 39 Hen. 6.24. & 27. becauÅ¿e they belong unto him.

Protected perÅ¿on.He that hath a protection Royal, Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t him that takes his Goods, Nat. br. 92. B. though if not protected, he might take them; for during the protection, he is not to be moleÅ¿ted, and Å¿o hath wrong done him.
If one hath the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a thing,PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿or. he Å¿hall maintain an Action againÅ¿t him that hath no right, Com. 546. A. whether his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion be lawful or not.

But note,Note. that upon a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in Law only he Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 22 Hen. 6.49.5. but it muÅ¿t be an actual poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, for that is viÅ¿ible and notorious, and the other is not Å¿o, but may be diÅ¿putable.

But if A gives Goods to B, B Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s before poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, for he hath the property in Law in them, 2 Edw. 4.25. per 2 JuÅ¿tices, Coke 3. part. 26, 27. Butler & Baker. and property in Law is made then a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in Law.

In a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s brought it was found by office, that another was Tenant, and that it eÅ¿cheated to the King, this Å¿hall abate the Writ as to the things upon the Land, Com. 488. B. Nichols caÅ¿e, & 546. A. 19 Edw. 4.2. pl. 5. becauÅ¿e the Land was the Kings, and not the Plaintiffs.

He that enters upon the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the King, Å¿hall not gain poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, therefore he Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Com. 546. A. Paramors caÅ¿e. 2 Hen. 4.7. pl. 29. For nothing can paÅ¿s out of the Crown but by matter of Record.
Or upon a Farmer of the King, 2 Hen. 4.7. pl. 29. For he is in upon the Kings right, and the prejudice done unto him, is done unto the King immediately.
But againÅ¿t him that outs the Farmer, the King Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Com. 546. A. Paramors caÅ¿e. Q. whether the Farmer may not alÅ¿o have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s.
The King Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s,King. Nat. Br. 90. I. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 99. A.

And in this caÅ¿e the party cannot make fine, becauÅ¿e the dammages are to the King himÅ¿elf, to Hen. 4.3. pl. 7. and the fine Å¿hall be included in the dammages. Q. tamen. For it Å¿eems he Å¿hall make fine.

But for TreÅ¿paÅ¿s in the Rings Lands there uÅ¿es to be an information in the Exchequer, Nat. br. 90. I. This is not by way of EngliÅ¿h Bill, but on the Pleas Å¿ide. Q. if it may not be by an EngliÅ¿h Bill.

And in Å¿uch caÅ¿e the judgment is, that the party Å¿hall be removed and put out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, although that it be but a perÅ¿onal Suit, and the removal Å¿hall be by Writ formed in the caÅ¿e, ditected to the Sheriff. Com. 561. B. This Judgment is by way of Decree; ergo on the Pleas Å¿ide.
But the King may have a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s quare clanÅ¿um fregit, Nat. br. 90. I. if he will.
The Queen Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s without the King,Queen. Nat. Br. 101. for Lands belonging to her Revenue, and Å¿he is not in the nature of another Feme covert.

RevuÅ¿ancy Å¿hall be pleaded in diÅ¿ability to Å¿ue an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for as many Hereditaments as are not Å¿eiÅ¿ed into the Kings hands,RecuÅ¿ant. 3 Jac. cap. 5. For Å¿uch as are Å¿eiÅ¿ed concern not the RecuÅ¿ant.

A BiÅ¿hop Å¿hall not have an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s made in a vacancy of the BiÅ¿hoprick,BiÅ¿hop. 39 Edw. 3.12. pl. 18. 18 Edw. 2. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s 237. For that could not concern him, but the Guardian of the Spiritualties, as it Å¿eems.
Vide tamen RegiÅ¿t. 101. A Writ formed in Å¿uch caÅ¿e for the Å¿ucceeding BiÅ¿hop. Ergo. Q.

MaÅ¿ter of an HoÅ¿pital.A MaÅ¿ter of an HoÅ¿pital Å¿hall have an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for a thing done in the time of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or; for the dammage redounds to the HouÅ¿e, Nat. br. 89. G. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 196. B. the Writ there. And by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on why may not the BiÅ¿hop for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done in the Vacancy?
Tenant at will.Tenant at Will Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t a Stranger, 19 Hen. 6.45. pl. 94. 12 Edw. 4.8. pl. 20. 35 Hen. 6.5. pl. 7. For he hath a Title againÅ¿t him.
For entring his CloÅ¿e, and burning his Hay, 35 Hen. 6.5. pl. 7.

Copy-holder Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s,Copy-holder. Coke 4. part. 31. A. 2 Hen. 4.12. pl. 49. Coke. 4. part. 4.21. B, & 23. B. and this before his admiÅ¿Å¿ion, per deÅ¿cent; for his admiÅ¿Å¿ion is but a Ceremony, yet eÅ¿Å¿ential to his EÅ¿tate.

Tenant in common.Tenants in Common join in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s touching their Tenancies, Littleton, Å¿ect. 315. 18 Hen 6.5. 14 Hen. 6.9. pl. 38. 12 Hen. 6.4. pl. 11. 45 Edw. 3.13. 5 Hen. 4.1. 14 Hen. 4.31. 43 Edw. 3.24. pl. 3: 22 Hen. 6.12. in reÅ¿pect of their common and undivided intereÅ¿ts.
But if one dies, the other Å¿hall have an Action for all the TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 43 Edw. 3.24. pl. 3. For it Å¿urvives with the Land.
They ought to join in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 5 Rich. 2. cap. 7. 34 Hen. 6.32. pl. 16. 4 Edw. 4.18. 21 Hen. 7.22. becauÅ¿e it concerns them both in common and undividedly.
Note, For battery they Å¿hall not join, Reg. orig. 105. B. For that is a diÅ¿tinct TreÅ¿paÅ¿s; for the beating of one is not the beating of the other.

A had Male Swans, B Female, which having young ones, for the young ones they Å¿hall join, if they be taken away, becauÅ¿e they are Tenants in Common, Coke. 7. part. 17. A. 2 Rich. 3.15, 16. of the Swans and the young ones.
One Tenanant in common Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s de bonis aÅ¿portatis, againÅ¿t his companion that takes them, Lib. Intra. 653. B. Å¿ect. 3. becauÅ¿e he hath an intereÅ¿t in them.

Tenant for anothers life.Tenant for anothers Life is diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed, he for whoÅ¿e life he held dies, Tenant for anothers Life Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s without re-entry, becauÅ¿e the Act of God Å¿hall not prejudice him, 19 Hen. 6.28. B. AÅ¿cough. Coke 5. part. 41. Kniets caÅ¿e.
Tenant at Å¿ufferance.Tenant at Å¿ufferance Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Crook. 17 Hen. 7.47. A. for the feebleneÅ¿s and uncertainty of his EÅ¿tate.

If a man be outlawed or attainted in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s or Felony,Outlawed. and pardoned, he Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done to his perÅ¿on before the pardon, 29 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 63. No. Lib. intra. 248. A. 30 Edw. 3.4. pl. 18. For by the pardon he is made rectus in curia, and reÅ¿tored to the priviledge of the Law ab initio.
But for other TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, quaere 5 Edw. 3.170. viz. concerning his Goods or Lands in reÅ¿pect of the forfeiture.
But before a Scire facias be brought upon the pardon, he cannot without doubt, becauÅ¿e the pardon was conditional, 21 Edw. 3.55 pl. 7. Q.

div.head: AgainÅ¿t whom TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies.
div.p: AdminiÅ¿trator takes the Goods,AdminiÅ¿trator. B proves a Will, by which he was made Executor, and brought TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, and it lies, although the AdminiÅ¿tration were never repealed; for the AdminiÅ¿tration was void ab initio, and the AdminiÅ¿trator a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er, Mich. 12. Jac. Ban. Regis. FiÅ¿her & Young.

A makes a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s,Agreement. B agrees to it afterwards, and avows the doing of it; yet B is no TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er, 9 Edw 3.35. pl. 17, For the conÅ¿enting is a matter ex poÅ¿t facto, and cannot make him a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er ab initio.
TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t an Alien,Alien. DigeÅ¿t. br. 72. A. For an Alien is Å¿ubject to the Laws of the Land, as much as concerns the peace and quiet of it.

Attainted perÅ¿on.A perÅ¿on attainted Å¿hall be Å¿ued in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Mich. 38, & 39 Eliz. Com. Ban. BaniÅ¿ter & TruÅ¿Å¿el. No. Lib. intra. 248. A. For he Å¿hall not take advantage of his own wrong, to plead it in bar to the prejudice of another.

An Infant makes a Letter of Attorney to A, Attorney. to take Livery and SeiÅ¿in for him, A takes it, the Infant Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t A, becauÅ¿e it is for his advantage to take the Livery for him, 21 Hen. 6.31. B. AÅ¿cue.

Husband and wife.TreÅ¿paÅ¿s De muliere abducta cum bonis viri, &c. lies againÅ¿t Husband and Wife, becauÅ¿e the Wife may aÅ¿Å¿ent at the time to the RaviÅ¿hment, and alÅ¿o to the carrying away of the Goods, 43 Edw. 3. pl. 15.44. AÅ¿Å¿ize 13. and this AÅ¿Å¿ent makes her a joint TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er with her Husband.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t Husband and Wife, the Wife is taken by Capias, but not the Husband; Dodderidge and Haughton JuÅ¿tices Å¿aid, that if the Declaration be againÅ¿t the Wife alone, it is not good, and if there be no Declaration, the Wife Å¿hall be at large; but afterwards Dodderidge Å¿aid, a Declaration Å¿hall be put in againÅ¿t the Husband and Wife, and the Wife appearing, Å¿hall be committed to priÅ¿on; to which Crooke agreed: yet quaere what was done in it, Mich. 15 Jac. Ban. Regis. AÅ¿hwel againÅ¿t OpÅ¿hard and his Wife; if no Bail be put in for her: So hath it been Å¿ince held by Rolle Chief JuÅ¿tice.
If the Woman beat another, the Husband muÅ¿t be named in the Writ, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. B. Lib. intra. 612. A. Å¿ect. 11. for he muÅ¿t anÅ¿wer for his Wifes behaviour.
TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t him that commands another to do a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Commander. Doct. & Stud. 19. A. tamen quaere. For it Å¿eems otherwiÅ¿e.
Body politick.It lies againÅ¿t a MaÅ¿ter of an HoÅ¿pital and his Brethren, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. B. For they are one body in Law, and Å¿o it is but one TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done by them all.
Dean and Chapter.It lies againÅ¿t a Dean and Chapter, 32 Hen. 6.8. pl. 13. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.
Mayor & Commu. nalty.It lies againÅ¿t a Mayor and Communalty, Quare vi & armis, 38 Edw. 3.18. 8 Hen. 6.1. 9 Hen. 6.36. 20 Hen. 6.9. 15 Edw. 4.2. 4 Hen. 7.13. 32 Hen. 6.10. for the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e.

But no Capias lies againÅ¿t them, becauÅ¿e they cannot appear all in perÅ¿on; for this would make confuÅ¿ion, 45 Edw. 3.2 & 3. 22 AÅ¿Å¿ize 67. 21 Edw. 3.59. pl. 1. But they muÅ¿t appear by an Attorney for them all.
DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t his DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or before his entry,DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or. for the former entry upon his DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, 32 Hen. 6.32. 38 Hen. 6.28. A. ForteÅ¿cue.

But after his entry he Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or for all the mean profits taken during the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, Coke 11. part. 51. A. Liffords caÅ¿e, 3 Hen. 4.13. pl. 18. GaÅ¿coigne. 37 Hen. 6.7. pl. 12.

But Å¿hall not have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or of the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, for then the laÅ¿t DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or Å¿hould be twice charged, Coke 11. part. 51. once by the firÅ¿t DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, and a Å¿econd time by the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ee, which is unreaÅ¿onable.

Neither againÅ¿t the Feoffee or Feoffor of the former DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, 34 Hen. 6.30. pl. 14. 13 Hen. 7.15. Coke 11. part. 51. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on. Liffords caÅ¿e, 2 Edw. 4.18. pl. 12. per 2 JuÅ¿tices, Crooke 12 Hen. 7.1. pl. 2.
But againÅ¿t a Co-adjutor of a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or it lies, 21 Edw. 4.5, & 19. for he is as the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or himÅ¿elf.
It lies againÅ¿t an Infant,Infant. DigeÅ¿t. br. 72. Q. of what age. It Å¿eems at the age of DiÅ¿cretion.
It lies not againÅ¿t an Executor,Executor. quia actio perÅ¿onalis moritur cum perÅ¿ona, Doct. & Stud. 75. viz. for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done by the TeÅ¿tator, if perÅ¿onal.
Guardian Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t his Ward,Guardian. 5 Hen. 4.2. pl. 7. Q. for what TreÅ¿paÅ¿s; whether for a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s done to him as his Guardian?
It lies againÅ¿t an Ideot,Ideot. DigeÅ¿t. br. 72. A. Q. for it Å¿eems it lies not againÅ¿t one not compos mentis.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s and ImpriÅ¿onment lies not againÅ¿t any of the Judges at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, Judge. although he commit him without cauÅ¿e, 21 Hen. 6. pl. 9. in fine. For this would be to affront JuÅ¿tice, to call the Judges in queÅ¿tion for doing things as Judges. But they are queÅ¿tionable by the King.

But if Auditors commit not an Accomptant forthwith, but at another time,Auditors. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t them, 27 Hen. 6.8. pl. 7. For their power is limited to time and place; for they are Judges but hac vice.
It lies againÅ¿t a Miller that takes toll of them that are Toll-free,Miller. 41 Edw. 3.24. pl. 17. 44 Ed. 3.20. pl. 16. for it is dammage to them, and wrong in the Miller.
It lies againÅ¿t the Queen Å¿ole without joyning the King;Queen. for the King cannot be a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er to any.
TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies not againÅ¿t the Lord,Lord. per Marlebridge cap. 13. Q. for what TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es, and by whom. It Å¿eems for TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es done to his Villains moÅ¿t properly.
Non ideo puniatur dominus per redemptionem, Coke 4. part. 11. B. Bevills caÅ¿e.
But afore this Statute TreÅ¿paÅ¿s did lie againÅ¿t the Lord vi & armis, 48 Edw. 3.20. pl. 16 Thorp. for there the peace of the Commonwealth is concerned.

The reaÅ¿on that it lies not againÅ¿t the Lord is, inÅ¿omuch that he cannot come within his Tenants Land, being within his Fee, againÅ¿t the peace, although he had not cauÅ¿e to diÅ¿train; for it Å¿eems he may go any where within his own Fee, 47 Edw. 3.7. pl. 3. Finchden. Quaere tamen.
This Statute is intended as well to every LeÅ¿Å¿or as of the Lord, 9 Hen. 6.43. pl. 21. this is in caÅ¿es of Entries to diÅ¿train.

If the Lord diÅ¿train where nothing is in arrear, yet TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies not againÅ¿t him, Coke 4. part. 11. B. Bevils caÅ¿e, 9. part. 76. A. becauÅ¿e he may do this as Lord. Q. for it Å¿eems unreaÅ¿onable to vex his Tenants without cauÅ¿e; yet they are not without remedy, for they may replevy the diÅ¿treÅ¿s.

But if the Lord diÅ¿train where there is nothing arrear, and the MeÅ¿n will put his Cattel in the Pound for the Cattel of the Tenant, and the Lord will not permit him, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t the Lord, Coke 9. part. 22. B. CaÅ¿e of Avowry; becauÅ¿e here the Lord is offered a legal way to come to his right, if any thing be due to him.

And if the Lord incroach, and afterwards diÅ¿train for the Services, and for the Incroachment alÅ¿o, the Tenant may tender the very Services, and Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the other, Coke 4. part. 11. B. Bevils caÅ¿e, 10 Hen. 6.3. pl. 11. for though the Law favour him as Lord, yet it will not countenance his incroaching.

And if a Baily or Servant diÅ¿trains where nothing is arrear, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, becauÅ¿e it is not within the Statute, Coke 9. part. 76. A. Combs caÅ¿e, 9 Hen. 5.10. 11 Hen. 4.78. B. 9 Hen. 7.4. 48 Edw. 3.20. pl. 16. and they muÅ¿t take heed not to be too officious for their MaÅ¿ter.

AgainÅ¿t the Lord.When the Lord abuÅ¿es his Authorty given him by the Law, he Å¿hall be puniÅ¿hed by TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Coke 8. part. 146. the Å¿ix Carpenters caÅ¿e; for the Law will not countenance wrong, but puniÅ¿h it in any perÅ¿on.
If he labour or kill the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, 8 Edw. 4.15. 22 Edw. 4, 5. pl. 16. & fol. 47. pl. 22. Coke 8. part. 146. B. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies; for he muÅ¿t uÅ¿e it only as the Law allows.
If he tie the Cattel in the pound, 27 AÅ¿Å¿ize 64. which he ought not to do, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t him.

If he break the hedges or gates, or Å¿uch like, of the party where he diÅ¿trains, 20 Edw. 4.3. pl. 11. 48 Edw. 3.6. pl. 10. for though the Law allow him a way to come by his right, yet in doing it, it allows him not to do dammage to the other unneceÅ¿Å¿arily.
If he cut the Trees, or Å¿tay all night, 11 Hen. 4.75. upon the Land, for this the Law warrants him not to do.
The LeÅ¿Å¿ee cuts Trees to repair, the LeÅ¿Å¿or carries them away, and TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t him, 44 Edw. 3.44. for the LeÅ¿Å¿or might cut them, and therefore to take them away was a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s.
If the LeÅ¿Å¿or diÅ¿train dammage feaÅ¿ant, 5 Hen. 7.10. pl. 2. upon the Land left; for he hath no preÅ¿ent intereÅ¿t, and Å¿o there can be no Å¿uch dammages.
So if he out the Termor, 48 Edw. 3.6. pl. 11. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s and Ejectment lies.
Or the Executor of the Termor, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. B. may have this Action, for now the term is come unto him.

The LeÅ¿Å¿or excepts the Trees, and roots them up, it Å¿eems TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, Coke 11. part. 49. B. LiÅ¿Å¿ords caÅ¿e, in reÅ¿pect of the dammage done in the Soil by the rooting. Quaere tamen, for the whole Trees are reÅ¿erved.
The Lord Å¿ells the DiÅ¿treÅ¿s, and buys it again, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, 29 Hen. 8. Dyer 35. pl. 34. for he ought not to Å¿ell it, and the buying of it again cannot Å¿alve the matter.

It lies by a Copyholder againÅ¿t the Lord that cuts him, 21 Edw. 4.80. Coke 4. part. 22. A.
in reÅ¿pect of his intereÅ¿t in the Land by the CuÅ¿tome of the Mannor.

The ReaÅ¿on in all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es is, when one hath authority, licenÅ¿e, or entry by the Law given him, by the miÅ¿uÅ¿ing it, or the not doing it as he ought, he is a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er ab initio, Coke 8.146.
Deaf and dumb.It lies againÅ¿t one that is deaf and dumb, DigeÅ¿t. br. 72. A. for he may Å¿ee to do a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s. Q. if it lies againÅ¿t a blind man; it Å¿eems it doth.

Tenant at will.If Tenant at will make voluntary waÅ¿te, Coke 5. part. 13. B. Salops caÅ¿e, Littleton, 15. A. fo. per 3 Mariae Dyer 122. B. This is a determination of the Will of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, and TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies by the LeÅ¿Å¿or without entry, becauÅ¿e the term is determined.
For cutting Underwood TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, 2 Edw. 4.24. pl. 25. But quaere in what caÅ¿es.

Tenant by Å¿ufferance.It lies not againÅ¿t Tenant by Å¿ufferance, becauÅ¿e he comes lawfully to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 22 Edw. 4.13. pl. 3. viz. at the firÅ¿t, and he holds not by tort, becauÅ¿e by Å¿ufferance.

Tenant in Common.If there be two Tenants in common of a fold
â¢ ge by preÅ¿cription, one Å¿hall have a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t the other, for the breaking the fold, Nat. br. 91. A, H. Q.
For taking away the Meer-Å¿tones that bound Land,Meer-Å¿tone. 1 Hen. 5.1. pl. 1. for this is a great injury to the Owner of the Land, bounded by them.

Note,Sheriff. when the Court hath not JuriÅ¿diction of the cauÅ¿e commenced there, the Officer that makes the ArreÅ¿t Å¿hall be a TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿er; but where the Court hath JuriÅ¿diction, and proceeds
â¢â¢ ronice, there it is not puniÅ¿hable, Coke 10. part.
76. A. for the Officer is not to judge of the proceedings; but where there is no JuriÅ¿diction the Officers have no warrant at all for what they do, for they are accounted no Officers.

The Sheriff takes one not named in the Writ, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t the Sheriff, 11 Hen. 4.91. A. Hankeford, 13 Hen. 4.2. Hankeford & Thirning; for he hath no warrant for the ArreÅ¿t. It Å¿eems alÅ¿o a Writ of falÅ¿e ImpriÅ¿onment lies.
But if the Plaintiff Å¿hew another perÅ¿on to him, that was not to be ArreÅ¿ted, the Action lies againÅ¿t them both, for they are both Actors in the Å¿ame TreÅ¿paÅ¿s.

A procures the Sheriff to ArreÅ¿t B without a Writ, and after purchaÅ¿ed a Writ, and the Sheriff arreÅ¿ts him afterwards, being in his cuÅ¿tody, the Action lies, 7 Eliz. Dyer 244. pl. 61. for the purchaÅ¿ing the Writ, and ArreÅ¿ting of him afterwards, cannot purge the firÅ¿t wrong.
The Sheriff takes B upon a Capias, and returns not the Writ, B Å¿hall have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 20 Hen. 6.24. A. 21 Hen. 6.5. for if the Writ be not returned, it is as if there were no Writ.

OtherwiÅ¿e upon a Capias ad Å¿atisfaciend. for that is an Execution, and needs no return, Coke 4. part. 67. A. Capias to the Sheriff of MiddleÅ¿ex, and he takes him in London, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, 16 Edw. 4.6. for it is out of his County, and Å¿o done without warrant.
So if he makes a Repleg. of Cattel diÅ¿trained of an eÅ¿tranger, he may have TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t him, 14 Hen. 4 24. pl. 32. per Haukeford & Thirning, Doct. & Stud. 150. A. Q.
So if he come to make a Repleg. and breaks the hedges and gates, 20 Hen. 6.28. pl. 19. for he ought not to do Å¿uch violence.
So if he attach the HorÅ¿e of the MaÅ¿ter, in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Servant, for the debt of the Servant, Doct. & Stud. 138. B. for the property is in the MaÅ¿ter.
So if he breaks the houÅ¿e to ArreÅ¿t for Debt or TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, 13 Edw. 4.9. A. 18 Edw. 4.4. A. Coke 5. part. Semayns caÅ¿e; for this is againÅ¿t Law.
So if he makes a good return in Law, but a falÅ¿e in deed upon a Habeas corpus, Coke 9. part. 99. B. Bags caÅ¿e, 9 Hen. 6.44. for he ought to return the matter of fact truly.
If he takes Felons goods, where another hath them within his Hundred, Nat. br. 91. F. for this is without warrant.

Difference betwixt Å¿eiÅ¿ing & taking.One appears for receiving Felons, the Sheriff takes his Goods, and after he is acquitted, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies againÅ¿t the Sheriff; for he ought to have Å¿eized them only, and the other Å¿hall find Sureties, and if he can find none they Å¿hall be in the cuÅ¿tody of his Neighbours, 43 Edw. 3.24. pl. 1. which is in cuÅ¿tody of the Law; but where they are taken they are not Å¿o.

It lies againÅ¿t one outlawed,Outlaw. DigeÅ¿t. br. 72. A. Mich. 38 & 39 Eliz. Com. Ban. BaniÅ¿ter againÅ¿t TruÅ¿Å¿el, No. Lib. Intra. 248. A. for though an Out lawed perÅ¿on is not protected by the Law, yet he may be puniÅ¿hed by the Law for wronging another, elÅ¿e it might be miÅ¿chievous.

div.head: For what matters TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies, viz. for doing of wrong to the dammage of another; 1. touching Inheritance: 2. touching Chattels: 3. touching the Body.
div.p: The Plaintiff ought to Å¿hew the Town where the Inheritance corporate lies,Of Inheritance. concerning which the TreÅ¿paÅ¿s is brought; for otherwiÅ¿e there can be no venue to try the IÅ¿Å¿ue;Note. Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Luke verÅ¿us Sampter.
Of a CaÅ¿tle. Quare vi & armis caÅ¿trum ipÅ¿ius E apud D, fregit; &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 106. B.
Of a MeÅ¿Å¿uage. TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for the breaking of a houÅ¿e, Nat. br. 87. D. 88. A. RegiÅ¿t. Orig. 94. A. the Count, No. Lib. Intr. 653. G. Å¿ect. 7.
Of breaking a houÅ¿e, and the Count was of a Church by a perÅ¿on, and good, for the Church is a HouÅ¿e, viz. Domus Dei, 8 Hen. 6.9.
Of breaking a HouÅ¿e, and burning the Timber, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 94. B.
Of the burning of a HouÅ¿e, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 110. A. Nat br. 88. N. the Count, Lib. Intra. 607. C, & B. This is Felony by the Law, and puniÅ¿hable by death: Ergo quaere, whether TreÅ¿paÅ¿s lies.
For breaking the Door, and Windows of the houÅ¿e, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 99. A. Nat. br. 92. D.
For breaking the Head of a Mill,Mill. RegiÅ¿t. 96. A. Nat. br. 88. M. viz. of the Mill-pond.
For breaking a Pigeon-houÅ¿e,Pigeon-houÅ¿e. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 104. B. 10 Hen. 6.19. A. This is alÅ¿o Felony, if it be with intent to take the Pigeons.

For breaking my CloÅ¿e the Writ may be with a continuando, Nat. br. 91. L. the Count,Land. Lib. Intra. 647. D. Å¿ect. 1.642. A. Sect. 6. Lib. Intra. 619. A. Å¿ect. 1. viz. of a TreÅ¿paÅ¿s committed Å¿uch a day, and continued diverÅ¿is vicibus till Å¿uch a time afterwards.

For breaking a CloÅ¿e, the count was of a Church-yard; for that is a CloÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e incloÅ¿ed, 8 Hen. 6.9. pl. 20. and for digging in it, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 94. A. 2 Rich. 2. Barr 237. Nat. br. 87. B. 90. K. Q. who Å¿hall bring it, whether the PariÅ¿hioners or Churchwardens, or the ParÅ¿on or Vicar.
The Count, No. Lib. Intra. 661. D. Sect. 12. Lib. Intra. 622. B. Sect. 1.646. C.
For digging my Gravel, the Count, Lib. Intra. 646. C. Sect. 2.
For digging in my Land, Coke 9. part. 12. A. 7 Hen. 4.11.
For digging in my Mine, and carrying it away, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 104. B. 43 Edw. 3.35. pl. 53.
For digging in my Quarrey, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 105. A. and carrying the Stones away.
For hindring working in my Mine, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 104. A. in the digging of Lead, Coles, &c.
For breaking my Bridge, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 106. A. or a Bridge, which I am bound to maintain ratione tenurae, or otherwiÅ¿e.
Upon 8 Hen. 6. cap. 9. the Writ may be vi & armis, without Å¿hewing the entry of the Defendant congealable, 34 Hen. 6.26. pl. 14. becauÅ¿e the Action is grounded on the Statute.

It was brought upon a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in and Detainer with force, although that the Statute is within
