Carucam capt. ad cariand. upon WeÅ¿tm.
â¢ 1. cap. 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 98. A.
For taking away Writings in a Box,Writings. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 110. B. 106. B.
The Count, Lib. intra. 616. B. Å¿ect. 1.
For taking away Deeds, Minuments and Writings, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 111. A.
For breaking open a CheÅ¿t, and taking away Deeds, 36 Hen. 6.26. pl. 26.
For taking away a CheÅ¿t, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 110. B.
For taking away Hay,Hay. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 102. B.
For taking away Frumentum, Corn. the Writ was Bona & Catalla, and good, 46 Edw. 3.16. pl. 12. For Frumentum is Chattels.
Timber and Wood capt. & aÅ¿port. the Count,Timber. Lib. intra. 676. A. Å¿ect. 7.
Navem capt. & abduct. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 95.Ship. A. 102. B. Nat. br. 87. I. viz. intra corpus Comitatus, and not Å¿uper altum mare.
Navem capt. ad faciend. cariag, upon the Statute of WeÅ¿tm. 1. cap. 1. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 98. A. Nat. br. 90 C.
Scriptum obligatorium delivered in nature of an Acquittance,Obligation. 5 Hen. 4.2. 1 Hen. 7.14. 3 Edw. 3.72. pl. 1.
TeÅ¿tamentum abÅ¿tulit & aÅ¿portavit, Will. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 107. B.
Tunicam, Å¿c. a Coat Armor,Coat. 9 Edw. 4.14. pl. 8.
Five Tuns of Wine,Wine. the Writ was bona & catalla, and good; Wine taken and carried away, 39 Edw. 3.18. pl. 17. Lib. intra. 684. A. Å¿ect. 1.
The Count Lib. intra. 684. A. Å¿ect. 1.
VeÅ¿timenta, 11 Hen. 4.31. pl. 57. Q. whether he muÅ¿t not Å¿hew what.Cloaths.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Quare Å¿pinas Å¿uas creÅ¿cent. Thorns. cepit & aÅ¿portavit ad valen. &c. Good without Å¿hewing the number of Loads; for this is Å¿pecial, and the value reduces it to a certainty, Mich. 15. Jac. Ban. Regis, Jones & WilÅ¿on.
But if it be quaÅ¿dam garbas tritici, it is not good, for the uncertainty what is meant by Garbes, Shocks of Wheat. Trin. 7 Jac. Ban. Regis. For it Å¿eems a Garb may be more or leÅ¿s.

div.head: ERROR.

list.item: 1. Parliament, the Sheriff in RediÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿m. per Merton, cap. 3.
3. In him and whoÅ¿e EÅ¿tate he hath.
WeÅ¿tm. 1, 2, cap. 30. upon a Bill of exception.
5 Edw. 3. cap. 2. Error in MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, RedreÅ¿s in Ban. Regis.
9 Rich. 2. cap. 8. He in ReverÅ¿ion, his Heirs or SucceÅ¿Å¿ors Å¿hall have Error upon Judgment againÅ¿t Tenant for life, &c. and by equity he in Remainder.

34 Hen. 8. cap. 16. Error upon Judgment before the JuÅ¿tices in the grand SeÅ¿Å¿ions in Wales, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Ban. Regis in England, if it be in plea real or mixt: but for perÅ¿onal matters, it was to be redreÅ¿Å¿ed before the PreÅ¿ident and Council in Wales.

23 Eliz. cap. 3. FalÅ¿e Latine, raÅ¿ing, interlining, miÅ¿-entring of a Warrant of Attorney, or Proclamation, MiÅ¿-return, or not Return of the Sheriff, or fault of form in words Å¿hall not be Error in Fine or common Recovery.
27. Eliz. cap. 9. ordains, that this Statute of the 23 Eliz. cap. 3. extends to Fines and Recoveries in Wales.

27 Eliz. cap. 8. Judgment given in Ban. Regis, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed before the Judges of the Common Pleas, and Barons of the Exchequer, but then it ought to be in Debt, Detinue, Account, Covenant, Ejectione firmae, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s, Action upon the CaÅ¿e, and there Å¿hall be nothing aÅ¿Å¿igned in the JuriÅ¿diction of the Court, or in form in a Writ returned, Plaint, Bill, Declaration, Pleading, ProceÅ¿s, Verdict, or Proceedings.
31 Edw. 3. cap. 12. Error redreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Exchequer-Chamber before the Chancellor and the TreaÅ¿urer, calling to them the Barons of the Exchequer and JuÅ¿tices.
31 Eliz. cap. 1. The not coming of the Chancellor Å¿hall not make a DiÅ¿continuance of the Error in the Exchequer-Chamber.
And for Error therein Å¿ued upon a Judgment in Ban. Regis, three of the JuÅ¿tices or Barons may adjourn it, and it Å¿hall be no diÅ¿continuance.

div.head: Error.
In what Court Error Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed.
div.p: Upon Judgment in Court out of the Realm. Ireland.JUdgment given in Ban. Regis in Ireland, Error lies in Ban. Regis in England, 15 Edw. 3. Error 72, 37 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 7. 5 Edw. 2. Error 89. 36 AÅ¿Å¿ize, 5. Nat. br. 22. E. Coke 7. part 18. Calvins A. caÅ¿e.

But not upon a Judgment given in another Court in Ireland, 5 Edw. 2. Error 89. Nat. br. 22 E. but they Å¿hall be, as it Å¿eems, reverÅ¿ed in the Kings Bench there, if they be erroneous, and not trouble the Kings Bench here.

Erroneous Judgment in Wales Å¿hall not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Ban. Regis in England, Wales. Dodderidge, De Principalitate Walliae fol. 18. becauÅ¿e Wales was not parcel of the Crown of England, 27 Hen. 7.33. pl. 32. but a Principality of it Å¿elf belonging to the Crown.
But Crooke 11 Hen. 8.202. pl. 19. Ã¨ contra; for there it is Å¿aid it is parcel of England. Q.
But in Parliament this ought to be reverÅ¿ed, 19. Hen. 6.12. AÅ¿cue.
And alÅ¿o before JuÅ¿tices itincrant there, 19 Hen. 6.12. Newton, viz. in Wales.

But at this day Judgment given at the Grand SeÅ¿Å¿ions in Wales in a plea real or mixt, Å¿hall
be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis in England per Statute 34 Hen. 8. cap. 26.
But in plea perÅ¿onal it Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed before the PreÅ¿ident of the Council in Wales by Bill exhibited before him.
But Judgments given in the AÅ¿Å¿izes in Wales cannot be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Com. Ban. here, 8 Eliz. Dyer. 250.87.
IÅ¿le of Man. Erroneous Judgment given in the IÅ¿le of Man, may not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in England, becauÅ¿e it is not parcel of England, Crooke 11 Hen. 8.202. pl. 19.

Upon a Judgment given in ban. regis, Error lies in the Å¿ame Court per Common Law,2. Within the Realm in Court Å¿uperior, as Parliament, Ban. Regis. if it be upon Error in ProceÅ¿s, or default of Clerks, Nat. br. 21 I. 7 Hen. 6.28. pl. 22. 19 Hen. 6.2. pl. 2.15. Edw. 4.7. & 8. 3 Eliz. Dyer 196. pl. 39. 27 Hen. 8.15. B. Knightley.

But if it be Error in Law, which is the fault of the JuÅ¿tices, it Å¿hall not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed but by Parliament per Common Law, Nat. br. 21. I. 9 Edw. 4.3. 3 Eliz. Dyer 196. pl. 39. & 201. pl. 64. 23 Eliz. Dyer 374. pl. 19. 27 Hen. 8.25. B. Fitz-James. For they Å¿hall not reverÅ¿e their own Judgments.

But Error in proceÅ¿s or default of Clerks ought to be reverÅ¿ed in the Å¿ame Term, or otherwiÅ¿e it lies not in the Å¿ame Court, as it Å¿eems by the JuÅ¿tices, Trin. 7. Jac. ban. regis, ProwÅ¿e & Skeynner. Q.
But one caÅ¿e was Mich. 41 & 42 Eliz. Rot. 639. which is a rule that Error lies in another Term upon Error in ProceÅ¿s, when the party cannot have Error in the Exchequer Chamber.

But by the Stat. of 27 Eliz. cap. 8. if Judgment be given in ban. regis, upon a Suit commenced there, the Writ of Error lies in the Exchequer-Chamber, before the IuÅ¿tices of the Common Ban. and Barons of the Exchequer, or Å¿ix of them, Coke 3. part 7. B. 4. part 53 & 86. A. 5 part 18. B. 28. A. 43. A. 97. B.
But then it ought to be in Debt, Detinue, Account, Covenant, Ejectione firmae, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s upon the caÅ¿e, and no other Actions, for the Stat. Å¿hall not be largely expounded.

And alÅ¿o nothing Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿igned for Error in the juriÅ¿diction of the Court, or form of the Writ, Return, Plaint, Bill, Declaration, Pleadings, ProceÅ¿s, Verdict, or Proceedings; but only in matter in Law.
And alÅ¿o a Writ of Error lies upon this in Parliament, viz. upon a judgment given in the Kings Bench.

Iudgment given in Chancery, according to the Common Law, that is, on the Petty-bag Å¿ide, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Parliament, 37 Hen. 6.13. 11 Edw. 4.8. Choke. So it Å¿eems of a judgment in the Exchequer-Chamber.
Or in ban. regis, 14 Eliz. Dyer 315. pl. 100. and Å¿o it Å¿eems 37 Hen. 6.13. 8 Edw. 3.25. 17 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 24. com. 393. A. 39. AÅ¿Å¿ize 18.
And in caÅ¿e of Partition one Scire facias was brought in Chancery upon Error, and good, 42 AÅ¿Å¿ize 22.
If Letters Patents are enrolled in Chancery, there Å¿hall be a Scire facias to reverÅ¿e it there, 16 Edw. 3. bre. 651. 2 Rich. 3.1. A. if erroneous.
But another Subject upon this being grieved, Å¿hall have this redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Parliament, 16 Edw. 3. bre. 651. 37 Hen. 6.13.
But no Writ of Error lies altogether upon a Decree in Chancery, becauÅ¿e in their proceeding the Court is not a Court of Record, 37 Hen. 6.13. 27 Hen. 8.15. Rnightley. but meerly arbitrary.

A Judgment given in com. ban. if it be erroneous in ProceÅ¿s,Com. Ban. or in default of Clerks, it Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Å¿ame Court the Å¿ame Term, without a Writ, Nat. br. 21. I. 15 Edw. 4.7. & 8. 7 Hen. 6.28. pl. 22. 19 Hen. 6.2. pl. 2. viz. upon a motion at the Bar.
But for Error in Law in the Å¿ame Term, or other Error in another Term, this Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. re. only, Nat. br. 21. I. Coke 8. part. 5. A. 5 Mariae, bre. commiÅ¿Å¿ion 25.
It Å¿hall not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed at the Council-Table, 39 Edw. 3.14. pl. 28. For that is not a Court of Law, but of State.

Judgment given before the Barons of the Exchequer,Exchequer. Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Exchequer-Chamber before the Chancellor of England, TreaÅ¿urer, Barons, and JuÅ¿tices, 31 Edw. 3.12. A. 37 Hen. 6.15. 8 Hen. 7.13. pl. ult. com. 260. B. Coke 1. part. 11.34.3. part. 11. B. 8. part. 58. A. 65. B. 15 Edw. 4.18. 39 Hen. 6.52. 6 Hen. 7.15.
Inferior Court-The Statute of Merton, cap. 3. makes the Sheriff Judge of Record in rediÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, and Error lies upon a judgment given by him in ban. regis, Coke 6. part 12. a Gentlemans caÅ¿e.

Judgment given at the AÅ¿Å¿izes in the Countrey,AÅ¿Å¿izes. Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis, 33 Edw. 3. Verdict 48. 7 Eliz. Dyer 235. pl. 21. 23 Eliz. Dyer 375. pl. 19. 2 Rich. 3.1. pl. 1.10. AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 25.
Or in Com. Ban. Nat. br. 25. E.

But judgment given at the AÅ¿Å¿izes in Com. Monmouth, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed only in ban. reg. and not in the com. ban. becauÅ¿e the other IuÅ¿tices at the AÅ¿Å¿izes are by Letters Patents, 8 Eliz. Dyer 250. pl. 87. and if the AÅ¿Å¿izes be adjourned in com. ban. and judgment given there, it Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis, 8 Hen. 6.17.
And if judgment be given at the AÅ¿Å¿izes in a Quare Impedit, Error lies in ban regis, 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 76. pl. 34.
But judgment given at the AÅ¿Å¿izes, Å¿hall not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed at the Council-Table, 39 Edw. 3.14. pl. 28. vid. antea rationem quare non.
Oyer and Terminer.Upon CommiÅ¿Å¿ions of Oyer and Terminer by IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, the judgment given by them Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis, 29 Edw. 3.30 5 Mariae, brev. CommiÅ¿Å¿ions 25.

But Error lies not upon a thing done before the IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, 4 Hen. 6.24. Martin. For Å¿uch things are not accounted judgments, but may be rectified in Å¿ome caÅ¿es upon a motion made to that power.

But Error was brought upon an Utlawry, upon an Indictment taken before IuÅ¿tices of the Peace, 11 Hen. 4.53. For an Outlawry is a kind of a judgment given by the Coroner, though the Indictment pended before them.
ConuÅ¿ance granted to a City or Village corporate. JudgmentConuÅ¿ance of pleas granted to a City or Village corporate, their judgment Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Ban. Regis.
Or to a Body Natural, and not Corporate; for Å¿uch are judgments upon pleading.
For a judgment in CheÅ¿ter Error lies in Ban. Regis, Coke 2. part 89. B. 19 Hen. 6.12. 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 30.

But note,Note. in a Writ of Error upon a Judgment given in CheÅ¿ter, day Å¿hall be given for Å¿o long time that three Counties may be held there, before the return of the Writ in Ban. Regis, within the which time the JuÅ¿tices or Lieutenant of the Å¿ame County may redreÅ¿s the Error by the uÅ¿uage of the Å¿aid County, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 17. A. if they pleaÅ¿e.

But in a Writ of Error upon a Writ of Error depending there, they have no Å¿uch power; but the Record and the proceÅ¿s ought to be remanded at the firÅ¿t County or Court into Ban. Regis, RegiÅ¿t. orig, 17. A. Lib. intra. 290. A. Å¿ect. 1. CheÅ¿ter.
And by uÅ¿uage in the Å¿ame County of CheÅ¿ter, nine County-Courts Å¿hall be held one year, and eight another year, &c. RegiÅ¿t. orig. 17. A.
The uÅ¿uage is to have a Writ out of the Chancery retornable in Ban. Regis; for Writs of Error are excepted in the Charters granted to CheÅ¿ter.

And in this Error there, the JuÅ¿tices may award a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Defendant, returnable at the next County, and if the Judgment be affirmed, the party may have a Å¿pecial Writ of Error, reciting the former Writ, and
have the Records and ProceÅ¿s of both Judgments removed in Ban. Regis, there to be examined, and a Scire facias awarded againÅ¿t the Tertenant ad audiendum errores; for otherwiÅ¿e the party Å¿hall not be reÅ¿tored to that which he loÅ¿t, 15 Eliz. Dyer 321. pl. 20. 21 Hen. 7.34. pl. 32. Fineux, 34 Hen. 6.42. 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 36. Lib. intra. 290. B. Å¿ect. 1. CheÅ¿ter.
And by 18 Eliz. Dyer 345. pl. 6. if the judgment be reverÅ¿ed, the party Å¿hall be reÅ¿tored, and the Judges there forfeit to the King 100 l. although the Judgment was given by their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors.
But then it is not intended of Error in fact, but only of Error within the Record or ProceÅ¿s, No. Lib. intra. 231. A. Å¿ect. 2.
Upon a Claim allowed by the JuÅ¿tices of the ForeÅ¿t, Error lies upon it in Ban. Regis, ForeÅ¿t. 21 Edw. 3.48. pl. 70. For Å¿uch Allowance is a Judgment in its nature.

If eroneous Judgment be given in the Stannaries,Stannaries it Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed firÅ¿t before the Warden of the Stannaries, and after, before the Council of the Prince, and after, before the King himÅ¿elf, as Å¿upream Judge. It Å¿eems at the Council-Table, and not in the Kings Bench.

PaÅ¿ch. 7. Jac. Regis. per Flemming chief JuÅ¿tice, a Writ of Error or falÅ¿e judgment lies not upon judgment given in the Court of the Stannaries, as was reÅ¿olved by all the JuÅ¿tices: and it Å¿eems the reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e it is but an EngliÅ¿h Court, and not a Court of Record.

Judgment in the County Palatine of Durham Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed by a Writ of Error there, and upon Error in this Å¿econd judgment, Error lies in Ban. Regis., or in Com. Ban. Nat. br. 21. G. 14 Edw. 3. Error 6. 8 Eliz. Dyer 250. pl. 86.
Judgment in London, CuÅ¿tom. viz. before the Mayor, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in Com. Ban. or Ban. Regis, Nat. br. 20. E. 23. A. & B.
But a judgment before the Sheriffs of London, London. Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed before the Mayor and Aldermen in their HuÅ¿tings, Nat. br. 22. H. which is the higheÅ¿t Court.
And judgment before the Mayor and Sheriff, Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed by CommiÅ¿Å¿ion directed to certain perÅ¿ons at St. Martins the Great, Nat. br. 23. E. 18 Edw. 3.8.
But by 34 Hen. 6.42. pl. 14. the Mayor and Aldermen have forty days to adviÅ¿e of their judgment, and then the Recorder certifies it forthwith, if they do not reverÅ¿e it.

Note,Note. this manner of proceeding is given by the Stat. of 28 Edw. 3. cap. 10. Å¿cil. that the error Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed within the City; and if they do not redreÅ¿s it, then there Å¿hall be a commiÅ¿Å¿ion; and if error be found, they Å¿hall forfeit to the party his treble dammages, and to the King 1000 Marks, &c. but by the 1 Hen. 4. cap. 5. their Fine is at the diÅ¿cretion of the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners.

Judgment given in the Cinque-ports,Cinque-ports. Å¿hall not be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in com. ban. or ban. regis, but only by the Warden of the 5 Ports, at the Court at Shepewaye, & Å¿i falÅ¿um fuerit revocabitur, & Major & Jurati qui dederunt Judicium
fecerint fines & Major deponetur ab officio, 23 Eliz. Dyer 376. pl. 23.
The Writ to the Cinque-ports Å¿hall be directed CuÅ¿todi quinque portuum, vide 30 Hen. 6.6. Pole.
But 30 Hen. 6.6. the Barons of the five Ports are Judges there.

Upon a CuÅ¿tom in Village or Town to hold in all manner of Pleas,Village. and a judgment thereupon given, error lies in ban. regis, 21 Edw. 3.40. 37 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 5. Nat. br. 20. D. 2 Hen. 7.19. pl. 4. 18 Edw. 4.12. Mich. 10 Jac. ban. regis, GodÅ¿on verÅ¿us Duffeild.
Or in com. ban. Nat. br. 20. D. Common right. MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey.
Judgment in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey Å¿hall only be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis, per 5 Edw. 3. cap. 2. 10 Edw. 3. cap. 3. Lib. intra. 297. coram ipÅ¿o rege.
Judgment in Court of Pypowders Å¿hall be redreÅ¿Å¿ed in ban. regis, Pypowder or com. ban. Nat. br. 20. D.

div.head: Who Å¿hall have a Writ of Error.
div.p: He that confeÅ¿Å¿es the Action Å¿hall not have a Writ of error againÅ¿t his own confeÅ¿Å¿ion,Parties. Nat. br. 21. K. 34 Hen. 6.41. For he hath loÅ¿t all that advantage by his confeÅ¿Å¿ion.
ConuÅ¿or of a Statute Å¿hall have a Writ of error if execution be not well Å¿ued out againÅ¿t him,ConuÅ¿or. 18 Edw. 3.25. for to overthrow the execution.
And although he were outlawed (if he be pardoned) for then he is enabled again to Å¿ue. 29 AÅ¿Å¿ize 47. Nat. br. 22. B.

A Corporation Å¿hall have a Writ of Error jointly for a judgment given againÅ¿t them,Corporation. but no Å¿ingle perÅ¿on of them, 21 Edw. 4.58. TowneÅ¿end. For they are all but one body, and cannot Å¿ever, nor be Å¿evered in pleading, or in being impleaded.
He that diÅ¿claims Å¿hall not have it,DiÅ¿claim. Nat. br. 22. C. Coke. 8. part 6. B, & 62. A. viz. the thing Å¿ued for, whereupon judgment is given.
But if one plead Non-Tenure, and it be found againÅ¿t him,Non-Tenure. yet he Å¿hall have it, 6 Edw. 3.188. pl. 17. Nat. br. 22. C. For that is but a plea to the Action.

A brought a Praecipe againÅ¿t B, who infeoffs C, judgment is given for A, yet B Å¿hall have error, 21 Edw. 3.53. 12 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41.20. of AÅ¿Å¿ize, 2. 50 AÅ¿Å¿ize 3. Coke 1. part. 111. Albanies caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the judgment is againÅ¿t him, and not the Feoffee.

Judgment was given againÅ¿t the Defendant in debt, and after, becauÅ¿e he paid it not, nor rendred his Body, &c. judgment was given upon a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Bail, and they all join in a Writ of error, and therefore held not good, becauÅ¿e one of them is not party to the judgment given againÅ¿t the other, Mich. 9. Jac. Regis, WildgooÅ¿e againÅ¿t Duport; but they are diÅ¿tinct and Å¿everal judgments, given againÅ¿t them Å¿everally, and ought to have Å¿everal Writs of error.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t two, where one was within age, and appears by Attorney, and judgment Quod capiantur, they join in a Writ of error, becauÅ¿e
the judgment is entire, Hil. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, Orme & Bird; and good, though the judgment was well given againÅ¿t one of them.
Surviving joint-tenant Å¿hall have error of all the judgment given againÅ¿t both;Survivor. for he is only now concerned, 19 Edw. 3. Error 1.19. AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 8.
Two outlawed upon a Capias in RediÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in with force, one Å¿hall have error Å¿ole,Outlawed. 8 Hen. 4.3. For the Outlawry is as two Outlawries, viz. againÅ¿t each one of them particularly.

Judgment againÅ¿t two in conÅ¿piracy,ConÅ¿piracy. one dies, the other Å¿hall have a Writ of error, 24 Edw. 3.76. pl. 99. elÅ¿e it would be miÅ¿chievous to him, if the judgment be erroneous, if he may not reverÅ¿e it.

Mich. 30, & 31 Eliz. ban. regis, Pigot being an Infant, and another levies a fine,Infant. Pigot Å¿ole brought error, and good; for this is error in fact, therefore it Å¿hall be brought by him it moÅ¿t concerns, which here is the Infant.
If one makes a Retraxit, viz. upon the Roll,Retraxit. that he will not proceed, yet he Å¿hall have error, Coke. 8. part 62. A. Beechers caÅ¿e. For the Retraxit was but till the judgment.
The King Å¿hall have error,ReverÅ¿ion. 15 Edw. 3. Error 72. and that is but reaÅ¿onable.

He in reverÅ¿ion diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿es two joint-Tenants for Life, and Å¿uffers an erroneous recovery, the wife releaÅ¿es with warranty, and dies; this warranty is a bar to the Writ of error, becauÅ¿e by his own Act he had diÅ¿abled himÅ¿elf to take benefit of the forfeiture, Coke 3. part. 61. A. Lincoln-Colledg caÅ¿e. Q. De ceÅ¿t caÅ¿e.

A recovers a Moyety of a Mannor againÅ¿t B, which infeoffs C, B, Heir. and C makes partition; B dies, his Heir Å¿hall have a Writ of error, and by Newton if A had iÅ¿Å¿ue a Son and a Daughter by one Venter, and another Daughter by another Venter, and dies, the Son enters, and dies, the youngeÅ¿t Daughter is found Heir in a Nuper obiit, they make partition, the eldeÅ¿t Daughter Å¿hall have a Writ of Error, 19 Hen. 6.25. A. For the judgment binds her intereÅ¿t till it be reverÅ¿ed.
Prayer in Aid Å¿hall have a Writ of error, Nat. br. 21. C. Coke 3. part 3. B. 4 AÅ¿Å¿ize, Pray in Ayd. pl. 7. For the praying in Aid is but to Å¿atisfie his Title which he had before.
Patron after Aid,Patron. Prayer Å¿hall have error, 12 Hen 8.8. Pollard. For the Judgment concerns his Title, notwithÅ¿tanding the Aid-Prayer.
GarniÅ¿hee Å¿hall have a Writ of error, 21 Hen. 6.35. B. PaÅ¿ton. 7 Hen. 6.41. Coke 5. part. 99. B. Hoes caÅ¿e.GarniÅ¿hee For he is bound by the judgment.
GarniÅ¿hee in London upon an Attachment according to the CuÅ¿tom, Å¿hall have error, 22 Edw. 4.30, & 31. For the judgment is in part againÅ¿t him.
Tenant per Receipt Å¿hall have error, Coke 3. part. 3.4 AÅ¿Å¿ize 7. 20 Edw. 3. Error 2.Tenant. For by the Receipt he is made party to the Suit, and concerned in the judgment.
Vouchee Å¿hall have a Writ of error, 8 Hen. 4. 3. Nat. br. 21. C. 4. AÅ¿Å¿ize 7. 17 Edw. 3. ErrorVouchee. 90. Nat. br. 21. M. & 108. A. For by the Voucher he is called in, and made a party.
And the Tenant Å¿hall have another Writ of Error, 8 Hen. 4.3, 21 & Nat. br. 21. C. for they are Å¿everally concerned.
But if the Vouchee releaÅ¿e before Error brought, the Tenant Å¿hall not have it, 17 Edw. 2. Recovery in value 32. for by the releaÅ¿e he is barred, viz. a releaÅ¿e of Errors, or of his right.
Heir general Å¿hall have a Writ of Error, 20 Edw. 4.13. Lib. Intra. 269. A. Sect. 1. for he is prejudiced by the Judgment.
And if the AnceÅ¿tor be outlawed of Felony,Heir general. he, viz. the Heir Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 21. N. viz. to reverÅ¿e the Outlawry, and to gain his own intereÅ¿t.
But not for High TreaÅ¿on, per 28 Eliz. cap. 2. becauÅ¿e thereby the blood is corrupt and diÅ¿abled.
The Heir Å¿pecial Å¿hall have it for the Lands to which he is heir,Heir Å¿pecial. 3 Hen. 4.19. Nat. br. 21. K. 9 Hen. 6.47. 1 Mariae Dyer 90. pl. 5. but he muÅ¿t have a Å¿pecial Writ, as it Å¿eems.
Executor Å¿hall have Error upon judgment for debt or dammages,Executor: Nat. br. 21. M. given againÅ¿t the TeÅ¿tator, for the regaining of the TeÅ¿tators eÅ¿tate.

Although that he be Executor to the BiÅ¿hop, ParÅ¿on, or other Å¿ole Corporation, Nat. br. 22. A. Coke 4. part. 65. A. Fulwoods caÅ¿e, 8 Hen. 6.25. A. Martin. for that makes no difference in the caÅ¿e.

And this upon the Statute of 29 Eliz. cap. 8. Coke 6. part. fol. ult. Executor Å¿hall have error upon an Outlawry of the TeÅ¿tator, and reÅ¿titution of the goods loÅ¿t by the Outlawry, 11 Hen. 465. pl. 22. 5 Edw. 4.7.
Although that the Outlawry be for Felony, Coke 5. part. 111. A. vid. antea.

AdminiÅ¿trator Å¿hall have error in the Å¿ame manner as Executor Å¿hall have,AdminiÅ¿trator. Nat. br. 21. M. 6 Edw. 6. Dyer 76. pl. 31. for he hath the Å¿ame intereÅ¿t in the InteÅ¿tates perÅ¿onal eÅ¿tate.
A SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall have error for a thing which toucheth the SucceÅ¿Å¿ion,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. to a thing whereof he is Å¿o, Nat. br. 22. A. 16 Edw. 3. Error 69. 8 Hen. 6.25. A. Martin.

The King collates A to a Chappel,King. againÅ¿t whom an Action is brought, A reÅ¿igns to the King, the King collates B, Judgment is given pro querente, B Å¿hall have Error, 15 Edw. 3. Error 7. 15 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8. for now the intereÅ¿t concerns him.

But for Debt or Dammages recovered againÅ¿t a BiÅ¿hop,BiÅ¿hop. &c. or againÅ¿t any Secular Å¿ole Corporation, the SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall not have Error, Nat. br. 22. A. for the dammages concern the Executor and not the SucceÅ¿Å¿or, and Å¿o he hath no right to Å¿ue.

He in ReverÅ¿ion after the particular eÅ¿tate ended Å¿hall have Error at Common Law,ReverÅ¿ â¢ on. and not before, Coke 3 part. 4. A. 21 Hen. 6.29. Newton, 3 Hen. 4.6. 32 Edw. 3. Error 73. 4 Hen. 8. Dyer 6. pl. 5. com. 24. B. WeÅ¿ton, for before he is not concerned in the Judgment. Q.

And per 9 Rich 2. cap. 3. he Å¿hall have it during the EÅ¿tate for life, Coke 3. part. 4. 22 Edw. 4.31. A. VaviÅ¿or, 3 Hen. 4 6. 12 Hen. 8.9. A. Brudnell. And this Å¿eems reaÅ¿onable, for he may be prejudiced by the delay. Q.
And by equity he in the remainder Å¿hall have it, Nat. br. 108. A. 1 Mariae, Dyer 90. pl. 5.
But at Common Law the Donor in tall Å¿hall not have it altogether, com. 241. B. Q.

And yet he Å¿hall not have Error during the eÅ¿tate Tail, becauÅ¿e he is not within the Statute of 9 Rich. 2. cap. 3. Coke 3. part. 61. A. Lincoln Colledge caÅ¿e, & 10. part. 44. B. Portingtons caÅ¿e.
But after the EÅ¿tate tail ended he Å¿hall have it, becauÅ¿e the Law reÅ¿erves the reverÅ¿ion in the Donor, Coke 3. part. 3. B.

And although Tenant in tail Å¿uffered a Common Recovery, and releaÅ¿ed Errors, and yet â¢â¢ ings error and is barred, and dies without iÅ¿Å¿ue; â¢ et the Donor or he in Remainder Å¿hall have Er
â¢ or, 3 Eliz. Dyer 188. pl. 9. to reverÅ¿e the Recovery; â¢ or if that be erroneous, then the EÅ¿tate â¢ ail is not barred by it.

Note, regularly no Stranger Å¿hall have Error,EÅ¿tranger.
â¢ 2 Edw. 4.31. per Brian, viz. a Stranger to the Judgment; but this holds not always.

ConuÅ¿or aliens, Execution is Å¿ued erroneouÅ¿ly,ConuÅ¿or. the Alience Å¿hall have error, Nat. br. 22. B. 4 Hen. 8. Dyer 1. pl. 5. 17 AÅ¿Å¿ize, 24. 18 Edw. 3.25. pl. 17. Crooke, 6 Hen. 8.169. A. Pollard; for his title is concerned.

A claims wood in a ForeÅ¿t,Tenant. and this allowed before two JuÅ¿tices of the ForeÅ¿t, B, & C, which claim EÅ¿tovers, brought a writ of Error in Ban. Regis, 21 Edw. 3.48. pl. 70. and good to reverÅ¿e this allowance, which is in nature of a Judgment, and binds their right to the EÅ¿tovers.
The Tenant in a Praecipe enfeoffs B, Judgment given pro quer. B Å¿hall have Error for the miÅ¿chief, that may fall to him by the Judgment, 21 Edw. 3.53. 21 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41. 20 AÅ¿Å¿ize 2. 50 AÅ¿Å¿ize 3.

But quaere 50 AÅ¿Å¿ize 3. if the Tenant in the Praecipe aliens to B, which releaÅ¿es to the Feoffor for life, and judgment pro querente, if B Å¿hall have Error, per 9 Rich. 2. cap. 3. It Å¿eems he Å¿hall, for all his intereÅ¿t is not gone by the releaÅ¿e.

Where the King is party to the judgment,King. there Å¿hall be Error againÅ¿t him; but not before Petition made to the King, PaÅ¿ch. 12 Jac. Ban. Regis, Davies caÅ¿e, 23 Edw. 3.12. pl. 14. 18 Hen. 6.17. 22 Edw. 3.3. pl. 25. 24 Edw. 35. pl. 43. for it may be, that upon the Petition the King will let the judgment be reverÅ¿ed without Suit; and it is not fit to Å¿ue the King, where one may have right of him for asking it without Å¿uit.

div.head: The Writ of Error.
div.p: The Writ ought to make mention of him, which was Å¿ummoned and Å¿evered, 9 Hen. 6.38.13. becauÅ¿e he was once party to the Å¿uit.

An Action of Covenant is brought againÅ¿t A as AÅ¿Å¿ignee, and judgment given againÅ¿t him, he brought Error, the Writ needs not mention him as AÅ¿Å¿ignee, becauÅ¿e this Addition was not of Å¿ubÅ¿tance, 19 Eliz. Dyer 356. pl. 41. Q. for then he muÅ¿t be called LeÅ¿Å¿ee which properly he is not but by conÅ¿truction of Law.
The ProceÅ¿s in Error, 1. Æ²pon Judgment in Ireland. 2. Æ²pon a Bill Å¿ealed. 3. Judgment in another Court.

Error brought upon a Judgment given in Ban. Regis in Ireland, Ireland. there Å¿hall be a Scire facias in the Writ of Error againÅ¿t him that had the judgment; for by Sharde this is the uÅ¿age, and in no other manner, 34 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 7. and it is dangerous to alter the ancient practice of proceedings in Law.

In Error upon a Bill Å¿ealed,Bill Å¿ealed. there Å¿hall be a Scire facias againÅ¿t the JuÅ¿tices, which Å¿ealed it, ad cognoÅ¿cend. Sigilla, &c. per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 31. Lib. Intra. 293. C. Sect. 1. 11 Hen. 4.92. This is where Error is brought upon a Bill of exceptions.
But the JuÅ¿tices may deliver it in Court by their own hands, 11 Hen. 4.52.92. and then there Å¿hall be no Scire facias, for thereby they acknowledge their hands.

The ProceÅ¿s in a writ of Error againÅ¿t the Judges, to whom the Writ is directed, is Alias, ProceÅ¿s. Pluries, and Attachment, Nat. br. 22. G. if they do not certifie the Record which is before them.

Errors â¢ Å¿Å¿ignedWhen the Record is removed after Errors aÅ¿Å¿igned, the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Defendant ad audiend. Errores, Nat. br. 22 E. 10 Edw. 4.13. 3 Eliz. Dyer 195. pl. 38. & 201. pl. 63. 17 Edw. 3.5. This is to give him notice that the Record is removed, and of his proceeding thereupon.
And upon two Nihils a Non eÅ¿t inventus returned, the Court Å¿hall come to examination of the errors, 3 Eliz. 201. pl. 63. without the Defendants in the writ of Errors appearance.
But until Error aÅ¿Å¿igned the party Å¿hall not have a Scire facias, 24 Edw. 3.31. pl. 8. for it is to no purpoÅ¿e, for his appearance is to hear the cauÅ¿e.

And if he aÅ¿Å¿ign that for Error, which the Court takes clearly to be no error, he Å¿hall not have a Scire facias, 18 Hen. 6.17. for that would be to trouble the Court to no purpoÅ¿e; but if it be colourable it is otherwiÅ¿e.

But in Error brought againÅ¿t the King, there Å¿hall be no Scire facias, becauÅ¿e the King is intended to be always in Court, Nat. br. 21. H. either himÅ¿elf or his CounÅ¿el, for the Judges are of his CounÅ¿el.

The Writ needs not mention the names of the Tertenants,AgainÅ¿t whom a Sci. fac. in Error Å¿hall be Å¿ued. becauÅ¿e it is of common form uÅ¿ed otherwiÅ¿e, 8 Hen. 4.17. pl. 3. and the naming of them is not material.

If the Sheriff return that the Heir is not in his Bailywick,Other County. and the Tertenant Å¿hews that he is in another County, there Å¿hall go a Scire facias into that other County, 8 Hen. 4.18. pl. 3. Q. if he remove out of that into another, if another Scire facias Å¿hall iÅ¿Å¿ue, and Å¿o till he is found.

If a Recoverer make a Feoffment,Tertenant and die without Heir, it Å¿eems there that a Scire facias lies againÅ¿t the Tertenant only, and a Writ of Error, 8 Hen. 4.17. pl. 3. 9 Hen. 6.49. B. pl. 30. Q. whether not againÅ¿t the Lord by EÅ¿cheat alÅ¿o, becauÅ¿e he comes in by virtue of the Judgment.

Former Judgment.But the 9 Hen. 6.46. B. pl. 30. a Writ of Error lies againÅ¿t none but the party, or them that are
privy to the former Judgment. Q. if not againÅ¿t privities in Law as well as in fact.

Gardein in right.Gardein in right of the ward recovers in a Quare Impedit, and dies, the Defendant brought Error and a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Heir of the Recoverer, and againÅ¿t the Heir of him from whoÅ¿e right he took his title, and againÅ¿t the Incumbent, without naming the Executor; yet good, becauÅ¿e he recovers as Gardein in right; but the contrary as Gardein in deed, 8 Hen. 6.35. pl. 1. for there it Å¿eems the Executor is concerned, for the wardÅ¿hip is a Chattel.

FalÅ¿e Judgment.Error upon falÅ¿e Judgment in Oxford, viz. for Land, the party being dead that hath the Judgment, there Å¿hall go a Scire facias as well againÅ¿t the Heir of the Recoverer, as againÅ¿t the Tertenant, 8 Hen. 4.18. pl. 3.
A Scire facias needs not be Å¿ued againÅ¿t the Tertenant before the Judgment be reverÅ¿ed, 47 Edw. 3.7. for before that the Tertenants eÅ¿tate is not Å¿tirred.

But before that he enter, he Å¿hall have a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Tertenant, for otherwiÅ¿e he Å¿hall be a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, 4 Hen. 7.10. 47 Edw. 3.7. but by the Scire facias it appears that he enters not as a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or.

But if the Recoverer make a Feoffment to his own uÅ¿e, and then the Judgment be reverÅ¿ed,Feoffment there needs no Scire facias againÅ¿t the Feoff â¢ e; for this is aided per the Stat. of 1 Rich. 3. 26 Hen. 8.2.

Scire facias in Felony.Error upon an Outlawry in Felony, the Plaintiff ought to have a Scire facias to all the Lords, mediate or immediate, 7 Hen. 7.5.53. 4 Edw. 4.10. 11 Hen. 4. becauÅ¿e they are intitled by the Outlawry.
And alÅ¿o againÅ¿t the party, at whoÅ¿e Suit and the Tertenants, Lib. Intra. 308 B. Sect. 3.

And in a writ of Error,Delay. if the Plaintiff haÅ¿ten not his Suit, the Defendant Å¿hall have a Scire facias againÅ¿t the Plaintiff, to Å¿hew cauÅ¿e why he Å¿hould not have Execution, 24 Edw 3.24. 9 Hen. 6.13. or elÅ¿e he may proceed in Court to have the Judgment affirmed.
And in Å¿uch caÅ¿e upon two Nichils returned, the Defendant Å¿hall have execution, but after this the Plaintiff Å¿hall have a Scire facias, 9 Hen. 6.13. Q. for then it Å¿eems to be too late.

div.head: Diminution in Error, 1. by whom; 2. in what caÅ¿es, 3. at what time.
div.p: 1. The Plaintiff in Error may alledge Diminution, Nat. br. 25 A. that is, alledge that a whole Record is not removed.

The Defendant may do it alÅ¿o, 28 Hen. 6.11. 15 Eliz. Dyer 321. pl. 21. for if the Record be not wholly removed, the Court cannot judge of it, nor can the parties tell how to aÅ¿Å¿ign Errors; But this alledging of Diminution is now uÅ¿ed moÅ¿tly for delay.

Error in London. 2. Error upon a Judgment in London, the Recorder certifies the Record; yet he is held to do according to the cuÅ¿tome. Quaere, if Diminution Å¿hall be alledged, 34 Hen. 6.42. it Å¿eems it Å¿hould.
When all the Record is not removed Diminution may be alledged, Nat. br. 25. A. vide the Writ there.
Diminution may be alledged in

list.item: 1. The EÅ¿Å¿oin, Lib. Intra. 290. C. Sect. 1. 1 Hen. 7.2.
2. Continuance of the Jury, Lib. Intra. 290. D. Sect. 2.
3. Words in title in AÅ¿Å¿ize, Lib. intra. 290. D. Å¿ect. 3. or any thing material in the body of the Record.

div.p: Diminution Å¿hall not be alledged upon a Bill Å¿ealed, becauÅ¿e the bill is not of Record, 11 Hen. 4.52. Hull, & 65. but is given in to the Court by him that takes the exceptions.

3. After in nullo eÅ¿t erratum pleaded in another Term, the Plaintiff may not alledge Diminution,Diminution. 28 Hen. 6.11. for then he hath pleaded to the Record as it is, and acknowledged it to be rightly removed.
But the Defendant may, 28 Hen. 6.11. for he hath done nothing to conclude himÅ¿elf.
But per 7 Edw. 4.25. Error 45. the Defendant may not. Q.
But Coke 5. part. 37. B. BiÅ¿hops caÅ¿e, after in nullo eÅ¿t erratum pleaded, no Diminution Å¿hall be alledged by either party; for if it Å¿hould be Å¿uffered, it would cauÅ¿e great delay.

The Plaintiff to the Writ before that he aÅ¿Å¿igns Errors, or a Scire facias ad audiend. errores may alledge diminution, and by this means the Defendant may not afterwards alledge Diminution, 16 Eliz. Dyer 330. pl. 18. vide 13 Hen. 4 Error 92. becauÅ¿e it is done already, and it Å¿eems it may not be twice done.
But note,Note. that the Defendant after that he had rejoyned in the Writ, alledged Diminution, No. Lib. Intr. 232. B. Q.
The Plaintiff may not alledge Diminution for any Error in fact after a Scire facias awarded, 22 Edw. 4.45. but only for matter in Law; for the Scire facias admits the matter of fact to be right.

div.head: The AÅ¿Å¿ignment of Errors, 1. by whom; 2. at what time; 3. upon what Record; 4. of what things.
div.p: AÅ¿Å¿ignment of Errors is in place of a Declaration, 9 Edw. 4.32. for therein the Plaintiff declares, why the Defendant Å¿hould not have execution upon his Judgment.

AÅ¿Å¿ign Errors.If one brings a Writ of Error, and he and another aÅ¿Å¿ign Errors, this is good, as to him that brought the Writ of Error, and void as to the other, for that was but Å¿uperfluous; but if two brought error, and one aÅ¿Å¿ign errors, this is not good to either, becauÅ¿e the Writ was joynt, Mich. 9 Jac. in the Chequer Chamber, Shakely verÅ¿us Porter.

ConuÅ¿or of a Fine Å¿hall not aÅ¿Å¿ign error in the ConuÅ¿ance to reverÅ¿e his own Fine,ConuÅ¿or. which is his own act; neither the ConuÅ¿ee in the Grant and Render, which is his act; neither the Recoverer in the Recovery, Coke 5. part. 39. B. for they ought not to defeat, but to maintain their own acts.

Executor in Error by him upon a Judgment given againÅ¿t him,Executor. Å¿hall not aÅ¿Å¿ign for error, that the debt was but upon a Å¿imple Contract, Com. 182. A. 10 Hen. 6.24. for he might have pleaded it in barr of the Action.
Party Å¿hall not Å¿hew error in ProceÅ¿s,Party. unleÅ¿s he Å¿hews that it is for his advantage in his proÅ¿ecution, 7 Edw. 3.25. Coke 8. part. 59. A. Nat. br. 21. F.
But may afterwards Å¿hew that the Judgment is erroneous by reaÅ¿on of Å¿uch Error, Coke 8. part. 59. A. Beechers caÅ¿e, 14 Eliz. Dyer 315. pl. 99. and then is his proper time to do it.

ReverÅ¿ioner not being made a party Å¿hall not aÅ¿Å¿ign for Error,ReverÅ¿ioner. that the Sheriff made a warrant to the Baily to make a pannel where the party was guiÅ¿dable, 3 Hen. 4.6. for the trial concerns him not.
The SucceÅ¿Å¿or Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿ign for error,SucceÅ¿Å¿or. that his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or was but named Gardein, 15 Edw. 3. Error 7. where he ought to have been otherwiÅ¿e named.
Error Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿igned before a Scire facias Å¿hall be awarded, 24 Edw. 3.31. pl. 8.Scire fac. for that is the ground of the Scire facias.

For after a Scire facias awarded the Plaintiff cannot aÅ¿Å¿ign error in deed, 22 Edw. 4.45. for upon the return of the Scire facias the Defendant is to come in, and to hear the errors aÅ¿Å¿igned upon the Record.

Upon a Judgment given upon a Demurrer in Law, and a Writ to enquire of dammages awarded,Demurrer. and a Writ to enquire of dammages awarded, a Writ of Error was brought, and he aÅ¿Å¿igned errors, 17 Edw. 3.5. and good, as it Å¿eems. Quaere tamen.

If the Record and the Writ of Error do not agree, Error cannot be aÅ¿Å¿igned upon that Record,Record. Error cannot be aÅ¿Å¿igned upon that Record, 9 Hen. 6.4. 2 Eliz. Dyer 180. pl. 48. 28 Hen. 6.11. for it Å¿hall not be judged to be
the Å¿ame upon which the Writ of Error was brought.

New Writ of Error.If the Writ of Error be faulty in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, errors Å¿hall not be aÅ¿Å¿igned upon the Record, but Å¿hall have a new Writ, Quod coram vobis reÅ¿idet, 3 Hen. 6.3. & 26.5 Mariae Dyer 164. pl. 58. that is, upon the Record, which is removed, and remains where the new Writ is brought.
FalÅ¿e JudgmentBut if it be falÅ¿e Judgment, then there muÅ¿t be a new Writ to the Suitors, who were the Judges; for it is not of Record, 3 Hen. 6.26.

Error without a day.If Error be put without a day, there Å¿hall be a new Writ before that error be aÅ¿Å¿igned, 26 Hen. 6. Scire facias 33. Nat. b â¢ . 20. G. for the old Writ is null, and Å¿o the Judgment Å¿tands as if no writ had been brought.

Bill Å¿ealed.Upon a Bill Å¿ealed a man Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿ign error, per WeÅ¿tm. 2. cap. 31. 11 Hen. 4.52. 27 Hen. 8.15. 25. Coke 9. part. 13. B. Dowmans caÅ¿e, 9 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8. 14 Hen. 4.15. 4 Hen. 6.15 A. Martin, 33 Hen. 6.34. Littleton pl. 9. 7 Hen. 6.37. 10 Hen. 7.8.
And if the bill is refuÅ¿ed to be Å¿ealed, the party Å¿hall have a writ to compel them to Å¿eal it, RegiÅ¿t. orig. 182. A, & B.
But by Hill JuÅ¿tice it is intended of a thing pleaded in Court; for otherwiÅ¿e it Å¿hall not be Å¿ealed, for the Judges are not to take notice of it.
Challenge in an AÅ¿Å¿ize was put in a bill Å¿ealed,Challenge. and good, 9 AÅ¿Å¿ize 8. 21 Edw. 4.11. 20 Edw. 3.63. Lib. Intra. 346. C. 27 Hen. 8.24, 25.
Priviledge claimed, and not allowed,Priviledge there may be a bill Å¿ealed, 22 Edw. 4. Priviledge 1.
ConuÅ¿ance claimed,ConuÅ¿ance if the plea be challenged by one that is not party, there cannot be a bill Å¿ealed, 20 Edw. 3. ConuÅ¿ance 46. for it concerns him not.
A Patent to three to take an AÅ¿Å¿ize where two take it, there may be a bill Å¿ealed,Patent. and error upon it, 29 AÅ¿Å¿ize 42.
11 Hen. 92. AÅ¿Å¿ize,Bill Å¿ealed. the Tenant Å¿hews that the Sheriff was beyond Sea, and had a bill Å¿ealed of it.

list.item: 1. Although the bill did bear date after the Record removed; yet it is good.
2. Although the party did not bring it within the bill, but the JuÅ¿tices; yet good.
3. The party Å¿hall have a writ to the JuÅ¿tices, commanding them to Å¿eal it, where they do refuÅ¿e to do it.
4. A writ to the JuÅ¿tices ad cognoÅ¿cenda Å¿igilla. vid. antea.
5. Two JuÅ¿tices Å¿eal it, yet one of them may deliver it; for the Å¿ealing, not the delivery, is the principal matter.

6. The party brought a Scire facias ad cognoÅ¿cend. Å¿igilla, before the JuÅ¿tices come in Court; yet good, for after that they come the bill was of Record ab initio, and Å¿o the Scire facias may have a good relation.

div.p: Upon a tranÅ¿cript of the note of a Fine error Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿igned,TranÅ¿cript and if Error appears they Å¿hall Å¿end for the note it Å¿elf, and reverÅ¿e it, 21 Edw. 3.24. 16 Edw. 3. Record 35. 40 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 29.
For otherwiÅ¿e perchance the Fine may not be ingroÅ¿Å¿ed, which may prove miÅ¿chievous, 1 Mariae Dyer 89. pl. 4. Lib. Intra. 296. A. Å¿ect. 1. Fines, Nat. br. 20. B.
But note, 5 Mariae Dyer, Record 79. the Record Å¿hall be certified, and no other proclamation Å¿hall be made. This is intended of a Fine with Proclamations.
But 1 Mariae, Dyer 89. pl. 4. Ã¨ contra. Ergo quaere.
Upon a tranÅ¿cript in Parliament error is aÅ¿Å¿igned, for the Chief JuÅ¿tice brought up the Record, and reported it Ban. Regis, 8 Hen. 5. Error. 88. 23 Eliz. Dyer 375. pl. 19. 22 Edw. 3.3. pl. 25.
But in another Court it is otherwiÅ¿e, 40 AÅ¿Å¿ize 29. Nat. br. 20. F. Quaere rationem. It Å¿eems, becauÅ¿e all Courts agree not in one way of proceedings.
Upon an award by the JuÅ¿tices upon return,Priviledge upon a writ of Priviledge, no writ of Error lies, Coke 8. part. 127. B. caÅ¿e of the City of London; for this is no judgment upon Record.
Upon allowance of claim by the JuÅ¿tices of the ForeÅ¿t,Claim. 21 Edw. 3.48. pl. 70. error lies, vid. antea, for it is in nature of a Judgment.

Record removed.Upon a Judgment in an annuity, and after that a Judgment in a Scire facias upon the judgment; Error is brought upon the former judgment, the Record Å¿hall be removed, 11 Hen. 4.4. viz. the whole Record, as it Å¿eems.
Error upon a Fine with proclamations,Proclamations. the proclamations Å¿hall be certified, Com. 265. A. FiÅ¿hes caÅ¿eâª for they are part of the Record by virtue of the Statute.

A Writ of Error Å¿hall not be awarded until the final judgment be given,Award. Coke 11. part. 40. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e, 7 Rich. 2. Error 68. for the tenour of the Writ Å¿uppoÅ¿eth the judgment to be given.
UnleÅ¿s the Award be ad grave dampnum, Coke 11. part. 41. A. Metcalfs caÅ¿e; for then it Å¿eems a neceÅ¿Å¿ity to grant it before.

As in Debt againÅ¿t many by Å¿everal Praecipes, and judgment is given againÅ¿t one, he Å¿hall have error, and the pleadings Å¿hall be Å¿everal from the original, and if Error be in the original, tenore tantum Å¿hall be certified, Coke. 11. part. 41. A.

Judgment in an Account quod computet, Account. error lies not until the final judgment, Coke 11. part. 38. B. 21 Edw. 3.9. 1 Hen. 7.2. B. for the judgment is not perfect and entire before, nor the Record made up.

When an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿s is in part determined,TreÅ¿paÅ¿s. error lies not until it be determined all, 32 Hen. 6.5. pl. 5. 36 Hen. 6. Coke 11. part. 39. B. for before the whole Action is not determined, and Å¿o no compleat judgment.
So in a Formedon, 12 Eliz. Dyer 291. pl. 67. Coke 11. part. 39. B. Formedon.
So in TreÅ¿paÅ¿s againÅ¿t two,TreÅ¿paÅ¿s. 34 Hen. 6.41. pl. 9.
So in a Quare Impedit, 34 Hen. 6.41.Quare Impedit. Partition.
So in Partition, Mich. 40, & 41 Eliz. Com. Ban. CounteÅ¿s of Warwick againÅ¿t Henry Lord Barkley. All upon the Å¿ame ground.
If error be brought before the fourth day in Com. Ban. yet it is good,Day. becauÅ¿e of Record at the Commencement, 34 Hen. 6. Quaere, whether Å¿o in Banco Regis.
In an AÅ¿Å¿ize of Darrein PreÅ¿entment, a Writ was awarded to the BiÅ¿hop, and the AÅ¿Å¿ize is for dammages, error brought and allowed, 17 Edw. 3.5. pl. 12. for this was a judgment.

Error upon a judgment in a Scire facias upon a Fine,Record. and no Record removed, but the proceedings upon the former judgment, and yet good, 20 Edw. Error 2. viz. the Fine which is a Judgment in its nature, and the Scire facias is but to have Execution upon it; yet it Å¿eems better, if all were removed.

Praecipe quod reddat.Upon a Praecipe quod reddat judgment is given; and error brought; the original, nor the judicial Writ, nor the eÅ¿Å¿oyn Å¿hall be removed, 2 Edw. 3. Error 2. Thorpe 37. AÅ¿Å¿ize 5. but only the Record of the judgment; for there the error is only Å¿uppoÅ¿ed.
UnleÅ¿s Error be aÅ¿Å¿igned in the Original, 24 Edw. 3.24. and then it muÅ¿t be removed, viz. the tenour of it.
And then the tranÅ¿cript of the Record only Å¿hall be removed,TranÅ¿cript 34 AÅ¿Å¿ize 7. 36 Hen 6.13. for the Record is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed not to be erroneous.
Error upon an execution upon a Statute-Merchant,Statute-Merchant. and error in proceÅ¿s aÅ¿Å¿igned, the original Å¿hall be removed, 18 Edw. 3.24. for the original is part of the proceÅ¿s.
Ancient Demean.And if it be of Ancient demeÅ¿n Lands, the Original Å¿hall be removed, 34 AÅ¿Å¿ize 7. out of that Court.
But Error upon a judgment in Ireland, the Original Å¿hall not be removed, 74 AÅ¿Å¿ize 7. 37 AÅ¿Å¿ize 15. Finchden. Quaere rationem; it Å¿eems, becauÅ¿e it is a Record of another Kingdom.

Fine and Recovery.Error lies not upon a Fine or Common recovery for falÅ¿e Latin, raÅ¿ure, interlining, miÅ¿-entry of the warrant of Attorney, Proclamation miÅ¿-returned, or not return of the Sheriff, or default of form in words, 23 Eliz. cap. 3. This Statute was made in favour of Fines, and to Å¿upport them, becauÅ¿e they are the common AÅ¿Å¿urances of the land.
And by 27 Eliz. cap. 9. this extends to Fines in Wales, and Recoveries there.
But if the fine be paÅ¿Å¿ed before the Kings Silver be entred, it is Error, No. Lib. Intra. 231. A. Å¿ect. 2. viz. for the not entring of it; which is paid pro licentia concordandi.
If a Writ of Covenant be returned before the TeÅ¿te, this Å¿hall be amended, Coke 5. part. 45. B. Gages caÅ¿e; for it is the miÅ¿priÅ¿ion of the Clerk.
The Caption before the TeÅ¿te of the Dedimus, is no error, No. Lib. Intra. 255. C. Sect. 11. for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

PaÅ¿ch. 1. Jacobi Regis, Rot. 426. the CounteÅ¿s of Bedford againÅ¿t FoÅ¿ter, 1. Error aÅ¿Å¿igned was, becauÅ¿e the Writ of Covenant was of eight MeÅ¿Å¿uages and two Tofts, and the Fine certified is of eight MeÅ¿Å¿uages and two MeÅ¿Å¿uages, but non allocatur, becauÅ¿e the Record hath relation to the Writ of Covenant. 2. Error aÅ¿Å¿igned, becauÅ¿e the IndorÅ¿ement was Executio iÅ¿tius brevis patet in quadam panella &c. where it Å¿hould be in quadam Å¿chedula, Å¿ed non allocatur, becauÅ¿e in Å¿ubÅ¿tance it is the Å¿ame thing, expreÅ¿Å¿ed by divers names.

Mich. 30 Eliz. Ban. Regis, AuÅ¿tein & Steede verÅ¿us Conaway & Webbe, a Fine was levied of
two Tenements, and void, becauÅ¿e a Praecipe lies not of it; this caÅ¿e is entred, Hill. 30 Eliz. Rot. 165. for a Tenement is a thing incertain, of which a Fine cannot be levied.

Infancy good Error in a Fine,Infancy. Nat. br. 21. D. 3 Hen. 6.16. B. 2 Rich. 3.1. 17 Edw. 3.53. pl. 33. 27 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 53. if it be brought during his Minority, that he may be inÅ¿pected by the Court, and his Age proved.
But if he come to full age it is not; for then he is not in the Å¿ame condition as he was when he levied the Fine, 17 Edw. 3.53. pl. 33. Greene, 17 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 17. no â¢ can it be Å¿o well tried.

And although the other ject a protection, yet if the Infant be inÅ¿pected when he comes to full age, he Å¿hall have the benefit of his nonage, 22 Edw. 3.6. pl. 24. 21 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 10. for the Infant could not proceed to reverÅ¿e the Fine during his Infancy, by reaÅ¿on of the protection.

Feme Covert.Feme Covert, as Feme Å¿ole, levies a Fine, this Å¿hall bind all but the Husband, Coke 7. part. 8. Bedfords caÅ¿e, 17 Edw. 3.52; & 78. 7 Hen. 4.23. becauÅ¿e as to him Å¿he was covert, and could not act without him, though not in reÅ¿pect of others.

But if the Husband enters and dies,Husband. the Fine is void without more Å¿uit to all parties concerned, Coke 7. part. 8. Bedfords caÅ¿e, 7 Hen. 4.2.23. for that Å¿hews his diÅ¿agreement to his Wives act.

But if living the former Husband, and Å¿he take a Å¿econd Husband, and they levy a Fine; this is utterly void, becauÅ¿e the Å¿econd Marriage is void, 7 Hen. 4.24. B. GaÅ¿coign, 9 Hen. 6.34. B.
pl. 3. This was before the Statute of Jac. againÅ¿t having two wives or two husbands.

Note,Note: when a thing is amendable before the Writ of Error brought, it is amendable as well after, and this by a Superiour Court, as well as an Inferiour Court, Coke 8. part. 162. A. Blackamores caÅ¿e; for the Writ of Error doth not hinder Å¿uch amendments.
Note,Note. that thoÅ¿e things that are not amendable and yet vicious, are Errors at this day, for there is no other way to redreÅ¿s them.

When Judgment is given, but not upon a verdict of 12. upon IÅ¿Å¿ue joyned, there are 7 Errors not amendable, Coke 8. part. 162. A. Blackamores caÅ¿e; as upon a Judgment by default, by Nihil dicit, non Å¿um informatus, or upon a Demurrer, &c. Vid. Å¿ome alterations by a late Statute temps Caroli Secundi, concerning Errors.
Want of the Original Writ,1. Original. No. Lib. Intra. 246. D.
MiÅ¿priÅ¿ion of the form of the Original,2. Form. falÅ¿e Latin in it, or variance from the RegiÅ¿ter.
Material variance between the Original and the Count or Declaration,3. Count. as C.W. in the Writ, and W. W. in the Count, Coke 5. part. 37. BiÅ¿hops caÅ¿e.
JeoÅ¿ail,4. Pleading. fault of Colour, inÅ¿ufficient pleading, or Å¿ome default of the perÅ¿on, or of his CounÅ¿el.
Error, or miÅ¿priÅ¿ion of the Judges in another Term, MiÅ¿ericordia pro Capiatur, & Ã¨ contra, Coke 8. part. 59. A. 41 Eliz. Dyer 315. pl. 99.
Want of warrant of Attorney.6. Warrant.

Error in pleas of the Crown and Appeals,7. Appeal. or in proceedings upon them, they are not amendable, for they are excepted out of the Statute of Amendments; and alÅ¿o Error in the exigent to make one to be outlawed, Coke 8. part. 162. A. Blackamores caÅ¿e, Br. 10. This is in favour of life and liberty, and property.

What things are amendable after verdict. 1. Material variance.When Judgment is given upon a verdict of 12. men, upon iÅ¿Å¿ue joyned, there are 10. MiÅ¿priÅ¿ions not to be remedied or amended, Coke 8. part. 163. Blackamores caÅ¿e.
Material variance between the Original and the Count, Coke 5. part. 37. BiÅ¿hops caÅ¿e.
The Original is Barbara, and the Count is Barbaria; this is erroneous, Mich. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, HarriÅ¿on & Fettiplace, for they are two Å¿everal names, and Å¿o may be two Å¿everal perÅ¿ons.

WaÅ¿te brought in Burrum Appleby, and Flackbridge, and the Count is of waÅ¿te made in Burrum Appleby & Flackbridge Park in Langton, and it is variance, becauÅ¿e there is more in the Count than in the Writ, Hill. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. CounteÅ¿s of Cumberlands caÅ¿e, and Å¿o it may not be for one and the Å¿ame matter.
When the Original and the Count differs in the Å¿ubÅ¿tance, Coke 5 part. 45.

Husband and wife brought debt, or an Action for rent due to them, where it was due to the wife before Coverture; this is aided by the Statute, and good after verdict, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Peore verÅ¿us Boule.
Hill. 36. Eliz. Ban. Regis, Rot. 610. Griffin verÅ¿us Elliot.

Ejectione firmae wants (vi & armis) this is but a fault in form; and Å¿hall not Å¿tay Judgment after Verdict; and then it was alÅ¿o Å¿aid, that theÅ¿e words are not material, for it may be without them, 7 Hen. 6.4. 17 Edw. 3.1. Q.
3. MiÅ¿priÅ¿ion of the ViÅ¿ne.When the Venue is miÅ¿taken.

The IÅ¿Å¿ue was, that within the Mannor of Wargrave, and it was of the Mannor of Wafield, demiÅ¿able by Copy of Court Roll, &c. the Venue was of the Mannor of Wargrave, and good, becauÅ¿e the iÅ¿Å¿ue was upon the CuÅ¿tome within the Mannor of Wargrave, Coke 11. part. 18. A. Nevils caÅ¿e; but if one Mannor was in one County, and another in another, then it is otherways, Mich. 11 Jac. Ban. Regis, in the Å¿ame caÅ¿e; for then that Jury could not try the iÅ¿Å¿ue.
1. Trin. 11 Jac. Ban. Regis, Morton verÅ¿us Orde, reÅ¿olved in a Writ of Error 1.
Infancy during Nonage Å¿hall be tried by the JuÅ¿tices by inÅ¿pection and other proof in Court, Coke 9. part. 30. 17 Edw. 2. Account 122. 46 Edw. 3.8. 48 Edw. 3.11. 14 Hen. 4. after Nonage by a Jury.
2. If it be doubtful to the JuÅ¿tices, the Infant and the WitneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hall be examined in Court, 25 Edw. 3.42. 50 Edw. 3.5.

3. If he be of full age in Actions reals, it, viz. the IÅ¿Å¿ue, Å¿hall be tried where the Land lies, 21 Edw. 3.28. 38 Edw. 3.17. 44 AÅ¿Å¿ize 10. 46 Edw. 3.7. 13 Hen. 4.3. 19 Hen. 6.51. for the Land is the principal matter.

4. If it be an Action perÅ¿onal as Ejectione firmae, it Å¿hall be tried where the Action is brought, 21 Edw. 3.7. 3 Hen. 6.40. 34 Hen. 6.50.
and Å¿o it was adjudged, becauÅ¿e it is tranÅ¿itory, and not fixt to a place.
4. Sheriffs Retorn.When the Retorn is by the Sheriff, where it ought to be by the Coroners, or Ã¨ converÅ¿o; for Å¿uch is no retorn, becauÅ¿e made by a wrong Officer.
When the Sheriff puts not his name to the Retorn of the Jury,5. Jury. as he ought to do; for elÅ¿e it cannot be known to be his Retorn.

6. Venire facias.When there is no Retorn indorÅ¿ed upon the Venire facias, Å¿o if the name of the Sheriff be not put to the Writ of Inquiry of Dammages, Mich. 9. Jac. in the Chequer Chamber, Shackly verÅ¿us Porter, for theÅ¿e are things of Å¿ubÅ¿tance.
When one gives the Verdict that was not returned in the Venire facias, 7. Verdict. though he be Å¿worn.
When it appears to the Court by all the Record,8. Action. that the Plaintiff had no cauÅ¿e of Action; for the Court is to judge of the Record.
In Appeal,9. Crown. or Pleas of the Crown, or in any proceedings upon them. Antea.
Statutes penal.Or to the Writ, Bill, or Action, Informations, upon popular or penal Statutes.

10. Law. Judgment.Error in Law by miÅ¿priÅ¿ion of the Judges in the judgment entred in another term, Coke 5. part. 57. B. Specots caÅ¿e; but in the Å¿ame term it may, becauÅ¿e all that term the judgment is in the breaÅ¿t of the Judges.

Action upon the CaÅ¿e in Cur. Wallingford, the judgment was, quod defend. capiatur; this is Error, being but an Action upon the caÅ¿e, Trin. 9 Jac. Ban. Regis, Northcot verÅ¿us Heywood, for the Judge ought to be defendens in miÅ¿ericordia; for
it is capiatur only where the Action is vi & armis, in reÅ¿pect of the fine to the King.

ConceÅ¿Å¿um eÅ¿t pro ConÅ¿ideratum eÅ¿t. ConceÅ¿Å¿um eÅ¿t, where it Å¿hould be ConÅ¿ideratum eÅ¿t; this is Error, although there are 21. PreÅ¿idents in my Lord Cokes Reports to the contrary, for by Man Secondary the Books are falÅ¿e printed, Mich. 8. Jac. Ban. Regis, Rot. 641. and by Williams, if it be videbitur Curiae; this is erroneous, for the Court is not to vary from their forms in Å¿uch high matters as Judgment are.
If it be Capiatur againÅ¿t the Defendant in an Ejectione firmae, Mich. 8 Jac. Ban. Regis, Rot. 232. Dolby verÅ¿us Holbrook, it is error, for it Å¿hould be ideo in miÅ¿ericordia.

JuriÅ¿dictioÌ of Court.It is ordained per 27 Eliz. cap. 8. that if Error be brought in the Chequer upon a judgment in Ban. Regis, they Å¿hall not aÅ¿Å¿ign it in the JuriÅ¿diction of the Court, or in form of the Writ, Return, Plaint, Bill, Declaration, Pleading, ProceÅ¿s, Verdict, or Proceedings; but only inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon the matter in Law.
And alÅ¿o there is a ProviÅ¿o, that it Å¿hall be in Debt, Detinue, Account, Covenant, Ejectione firmae, TraverÅ¿e, Action upon the CaÅ¿e; and not in other Actions of a higher nature.

In proceÅ¿sThe party cannot Å¿hew Error in ProceÅ¿s in delay of the Defendant, unleÅ¿s he Å¿hew that it is for his diÅ¿advantage, and that he is injured thereby, 7 Edw. 3.25. Coke 8. part. 59. A. Beechers caÅ¿e.
Nothing that is done contrary to the Office of a Judge Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿igned for Error,Judge. Nat. br. 21. B. 7 Hen. 7.4. for their Authority Å¿hall not be queÅ¿tioned this way.

Granting of Aid where it Å¿hould not be, is not Error, Å¿o of Receipt, 7 Edw. 4.12. 21 Edw. 4.65 B. 5 Hen. 7.8. 8 Hen. 7.9, 11. 14 Hen. 6.5. pl. 25. but if it be denied where it ought to be granted, it is Error; for none is prejudiced by the former, but by the latter the Defendant is prejudiced.
So of GarniÅ¿hment, 14 Edw. 4.1. pl. 3.
So of making of an Attorney, Nat. br. 22. D. 21 Edw. 4.77.
But denial of Aid or Receipt,ViÅ¿ne. where it ought to be, is Error, Edw. 4.65. B. 5 Hen. 7.8. 8 Hen. 7.9. vid. antea.
When the ViÅ¿ne is miÅ¿taken,ViÅ¿ne. it is error, for there is no right trial.

In Replevin.Replevin, the Defendant preÅ¿cribes to have all the PaÅ¿ture of Å¿uch a place in W. except Common for the Inhabitants of D. and the PreÅ¿cription being traverÅ¿ed, the Jury was of the ViÅ¿ne of W. only; and this was ruled good in Error brought, becauÅ¿e the words of exception to the Inhabitants of D. was void, therefore this was not put in iÅ¿Å¿ue, Trin. 11 Jac. Ban. Regis, Wicker verÅ¿us Stockeman, and Å¿o nothing in Dale was put in iÅ¿Å¿ue.

In waÅ¿teIn WaÅ¿te brought, the IÅ¿Å¿ue was for certain Oaks cut for repairing of the CaÅ¿tle of Burrum, the ViÅ¿ne was of the Village of Burrum, where it Å¿hould have been of the CaÅ¿tle of Burrum, this is Er â¢ or, Hill. 12 Jac. Com. Ban. the CounteÅ¿s of Cumberlands caÅ¿e, for a CaÅ¿tle and a Village are two different places.

Trover & ConverÅ¿ion.Trover and ConverÅ¿ion brought in Coventry, upon not guilty pleaded, the ViÅ¿ne was De Vicineto Civitatis Coventriae, and this Å¿hewed in arreÅ¿t of judgment, Å¿ed non allocatur, and error upon in brought, and it Å¿eems that by Williams and Yelverton JuÅ¿tices, that it is error; for it Å¿hould be of Coventry; for Vicinetum is of the Neighborhood of Coventry, and excludes the City, and the Sheriff of the Country ought to make it out, 7 Hen. 6.36. B. 4 Edw. 4.39. 7 Hen. 4.12.80. InqueÅ¿t 36. Quare tamen; for the Court did adviÅ¿e about bringing of a new Action, and did not determine the QueÅ¿tion, PaÅ¿ch. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, Procter verÅ¿us Clifton.

TreÅ¿paÅ¿s for lopping of Wood in HurÅ¿lay, TreÅ¿paÅ¿s. the Defendant pleads that the place is parcel of the Mannor of Mamden in the PariÅ¿h of HurÅ¿lay, and the CuÅ¿tom is, that the Copy-holder may cut, &c. and found for the Plaintiff, and the ViÅ¿ne was of HurÅ¿lay, and it was moved that it was not good, for the PariÅ¿h is not certain, becauÅ¿e it may comprehend more Villages; but it was good per Curiam, becauÅ¿e HurÅ¿lay Å¿hall be taken to be a Village and PariÅ¿h, and Å¿hall not be intended, that there are more Villages in one PariÅ¿h, except it be Å¿hewed, 5 Edw. 3.20. Mich. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, Brocke verÅ¿us Spencer.

Condition to pay money. Hill. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, Savil & CavendiÅ¿h, Condition to pay money in the Church porch of the PariÅ¿h of H. and pleads performance, the ViÅ¿ne was of H. and yet good, for as it Å¿eems the Village and PariÅ¿h Å¿hall be intended all one, and the PariÅ¿h Å¿hall not be intended to comprehend more Villages.

Debt upon an Obligation to perform Covenants,Obligation. and declares of the breaking of the Condition, becauÅ¿e a Å¿tranger recovered the Land at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter upon a good title, where the Land lies in Com. Berks, the Defendant Å¿aid that it was by Covin, without this, that it was upon a good Title, the Plaintiff Å¿aid that it was upon a good Title the ViÅ¿ne Å¿hall be of the County of Berks, where the IÅ¿Å¿ue is joined upon the good Title, and where the Land lies, but contrary if the iÅ¿Å¿ue be joined upon the Covin; for that is alledged at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, but it was Å¿aid, if it were a perÅ¿onal Action, it Å¿hall be where the Recovery is alledged, Mich. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis, HanÅ¿aker verÅ¿us Kirby.

Ejectione firmae of Land in S & T the Defendant pleads a Feoffment of the Land by Deed at S. the Plaintiff Å¿aid non feoffavit, Ejectment &c. the ViÅ¿ne was of S. and T. and good; for the alledging of the Feoffment at S, is idle; for it cannot be but upon the Land which is alledged to be in S. and T. Mich. 9. Jac. Ban. Regis. and Å¿o the Venue is rightly laid there.

Debt for 20 l. the Defendant pleads that at another time the Plaintiff Å¿ued him in London, Debt. in Å¿uch a PariÅ¿h for the Å¿ame debt, and Å¿hews the Record certain, &c. and that he had execution in another PariÅ¿h, &c. the Plaintiff Å¿aid that it was in debt for another 20 l. for the which execution was awarded abÅ¿q, hoc that the plaint and the execution was for the Å¿ame 20 l. yet the ViÅ¿ne Å¿hall be in both PariÅ¿hes, becauÅ¿e the iÅ¿Å¿ue is as well of the execution as of the plaint, 5 Edw. 4.110.

A vouches B, who vouches C, and after iÅ¿Å¿ue tried, the former Vouchee, viz. B. dies, this Å¿hall
not be pleaded in arreÅ¿t of judgment againÅ¿t A, but it is error, if judgment be given, 21 Hen. 7.80. pl. 1. Crooke, but if A die, it Å¿hall abate the Writ in facto, ibidem. becauÅ¿e he is Defendant, and Å¿o no judgment can be given.
In detinue againÅ¿t A, he prays garniÅ¿hment againÅ¿t B, which comes and pleads, and they are at iÅ¿Å¿ue, A dies, the Writ abates, ibidem.

div.head: Bar in Error.
div.p: No bar to Å¿ay that the former Writ depending,Feofment the Plaintiff did infeoff another; for he remains Tenant notwithÅ¿tanding the Feoffment, 21 Edw. 3.53. 20 AÅ¿Å¿ize 2. 12 AÅ¿Å¿ize 41. Coke. 1. part 111. Albanyes caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the Feoffment was made pendente lite.
In nullo eÅ¿t erratum. In nullo eÅ¿t erratum, a good Bar, 28 Hen. 6.10. 9 Edw. 4.32. 15 Eliz. Dyer 321. pl. 21. For it deÅ¿troys the very Å¿uppoÅ¿al of the Writ.

But note upon Error in Deed this is no plea. 7 Edw. 4.16. 9 Edw. 4.32. 3 Edw. 6. Dyer 65.2 Mariae, Dyer. 104. pl. 10. Lib. intra. 288. D. Å¿ect. 1.289. D. Å¿ect. 1. No. Lib. intra. 233. B. becauÅ¿e that doth not appear upon the Record.

ReleaÅ¿e of Errors is a good Bar,ReleaÅ¿e. 20 Edw. 3. Error 2. Littleton 116 B. Coke 8. part 152. Althams caÅ¿e. 6 Hen. 4.8. pl. 36. 5 Edw. 4.96. B. For the releaÅ¿e of Errors makes the judgment good, were it never Å¿o vicious.

But a releaÅ¿e of Actions reals and perÅ¿onals it is no Bar in error of an Outlawry, Coke S. part. 152. Littleton, 116. B. For the Outlawry concerns the Commonwealth, which intereÅ¿t cannot be releaÅ¿ed by a private perÅ¿on.
If the Defendant be outlawed in RediÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, a releaÅ¿e of all demands is no Bar, becauÅ¿e the Original and the Judgment are the proceÅ¿s upon the Outlawry. 11 Hen. 4.6.
The ReleaÅ¿e of the Vouchee Å¿hall bar the Tenant, 17 Edw. 2. Error 90. for the Tenant recovers in value againÅ¿t him.

ReleaÅ¿e of Errors by Tenant in Tail, is no bar to the iÅ¿Å¿ue, although it be tried againÅ¿t the Tenant in Tail, 3 Eliz. Dyer 188. pl. 9. For the iÅ¿Å¿ue in Tail is not bound by the judgment; for the iÅ¿Å¿ues derives paramount the tenant in Tail, viz. performam doni.

But if he in reverÅ¿ion in Tail diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿es Tenant in Dower, and Å¿uffers an erroneous Recovery, and Tenant in Dower releaÅ¿es with warranty, and dies, this is a good Bar, Coke 3. part 60, 61. Lincolne Colledge caÅ¿e; becauÅ¿e the recovery cut off the entail.

A ReleaÅ¿e of one bars another, when two are to recover a perÅ¿onal thing in reÅ¿pect of their joint-intereÅ¿t; but when they are to diÅ¿chage themÅ¿elves, it is otherwiÅ¿e, Coke 6. part 25. Ruddocks caÅ¿e. As where an Action is brought againÅ¿t two jointly to one thing, it Å¿eems if one confeÅ¿s the Action, this Å¿hall not bind the other.

If an Action be brought againÅ¿t two jointy, and a judgment is thereupon had againÅ¿t them, and one of them releaÅ¿eth errors, this Å¿hall not hinder the other to bring a Writ of Error, becauÅ¿e he is to be charged by the judgment.

The King brought Error,SciÅ¿une. it is no plea, that his MiniÅ¿ters have Å¿eized the Land, unleÅ¿s the King agree to it, 39 AÅ¿Å¿ize pl. 18. For the King Å¿hall
not be bound by the Act of his Officers without his conÅ¿ent. Yet Q. if it be done by an Officer of Record.

div.head: The Judgment in Error. 1. For the Plaintiff. 2. For the Defendant. 3. For both.
div.p: In Error two things are to be done. 1. To reverÅ¿e the judgment. 2. That the party be reÅ¿tored to all that he loÅ¿t by reaÅ¿on of the judgment, 9 Hen. 6.47. B. Martin. Coke 5. part 39. B. Tayes caÅ¿e. Q. Whether he Å¿hall be Å¿atisfied for all his dammages? It Å¿eems he Å¿hall.
The judgment was that the Plaintiff Å¿hould not be reÅ¿tored to the Land,AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e. with the mean profits, 11 Hen. 4: 93. pl. 49. Q. For a Å¿everal Action lies for the mean profits.
And 8 Hen. 6.2. A. Rolfe, that he Å¿hall recover the Land and the IÅ¿Å¿ues of the Land, that is, the profits.

Information upon IntruÅ¿ion.The judgment was, Quod judicium reverÅ¿etur & adunlletur, & quod Defendens de intraÅ¿ione, intruÅ¿ione, tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ione & contemptu, convincatur, & Ã poÅ¿seÅ¿Å¿ione amoveatur & capiatur, &c. quodque recordum mittatur in Scaccarium pro executione habenda, &c. Coke 1. part 40. A. Altonwoods caÅ¿e. The Action and judgment were in the Exchequer.
In a Quare Impedit, that former judgment Å¿hould be void,Quare impedit. and the Plaintiff reÅ¿tored to all that he loÅ¿t, 18 & 19 Eliz. Dyer 353. pl. 30.

Gardein recovers in a Quare Impedit in right of the Ward, the Defendant at full age of the Ward brought error, and a Scire facias againÅ¿t
the Ward, the Ward entitles himÅ¿elf by his ancient right, and found for him. 1. The judgment Å¿hall be reverÅ¿ed againÅ¿t the Gardein, and yet the Defendant Å¿hall not be reÅ¿tored, becauÅ¿e he is barred by the plea of the Ward, 9 Hen. 6.47.: B. Newton.

The judgment was, that the judgment Å¿hall be reverÅ¿ed,RediÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in and that the Plaintiff be reÅ¿tored to the Land, and to the iÅ¿Å¿ues taken in the mean time, 9 Hen. 4.6. pl. 19. that is, to the mean profits of the Land taken pendente lite.

The judgment was upon an Utlawry in felony,Utlawry. that the Utlawry Å¿hould be reverÅ¿ed, and he reÅ¿tored at the common Law to all that he had loÅ¿t by this cauÅ¿e, 11 Hen. 4.53. pl. 32. 7 Hen. 4.40. B.
And that he Å¿hould be reÅ¿tored at the Common Law to that he had loÅ¿t, 3 Eliz. Dyer 196. pl. 39. viz. by reaÅ¿on of the Owtlawry.

Error by Executors of the TeÅ¿tators being utlawed was, that the Utlawry be reverÅ¿ed, and that they Å¿hall be reÅ¿tored to the goods of their TeÅ¿tator, Å¿eized by reaÅ¿on of it, 11 Hen. 4.65. pl. 22.

It Å¿hall be Quod judicium redditum Å¿taret in omni robore per Coke Chief JuÅ¿tice, PaÅ¿c. 12. Jac. Ban. Regis, Sir John Heydons caÅ¿e; and yet 21 Edw. 4.44. A. was quod judicium redditum remanebit Å¿tabile in perpetuum, nor the form is let judgment be affirmed.

Et ulterius conceÅ¿sum eÅ¿t, quod praedictus A, recuperet verÅ¿us praefat. This is the Judgment for d â¢ mn â¢ ges. B. 10. l. eidem A. per Curiam Domini Regis hic adjudicat. juxta formam Statuti inde nuper edit. &c. promiÅ¿is & coÅ¿tagiis & dampnis
Å¿uis quae Å¿uÅ¿tinuit occaÅ¿ione dilatationis executionis praedict. praetextu proÅ¿ecutionis dicti brevis Domini Regis de errore, &c. Lib. intra. 244. B. Å¿ect. 8. & 292. B,

By the Statute of 3 Hen 7. cap. 10. if error be Å¿ued before execution, and afterwards be diÅ¿continued by default of the party that brings it, or he be nonÅ¿uited, or judgment affirmed, the other Å¿hall recover his coÅ¿ts and dammages by the diÅ¿cretion of the Judges.

An Infant and another levie a Fine, this may be reverÅ¿ed to the Infant by a Writ of Error, but it Å¿hall be good againÅ¿t the other, Coke 1. part 76. B. Bredons caÅ¿e. No. Lib. intra. 255. C. Å¿ect. 11. For the Fine Å¿hall Å¿tand good as far as by Law it may.

But if the Husband and Wife levy a Fine of the Land of the Wife, and they reverÅ¿e it for Error, they Å¿hall be reÅ¿tored forthwith, becauÅ¿e the HuÅ¿band is joyned with his Wife but for conformity, Coke 2. part 77. B. Cromwels caÅ¿e. For the EÅ¿tate paÅ¿Å¿eth only from the Wife.
Though Execution be reverÅ¿ed, the judgment is yet good, Coke 5. part 32. Pettifers caÅ¿e; and a new Execution may be taken out.
A Fine reverÅ¿ed for fault in the Proclamations only, remains a good Fine at the common Law; for the other is but a DiÅ¿continuance, 4 Eliz. Dyer, pl. 54. and is nothing to vitiate the Fine.
Lib. intra. 307. C. Å¿ect. 1.
